The boy knew too well for his (boy) peace of mind upon whose lair he (boy) had lighted. Uglier persons than gipsies were known to cross Egdon at times, and a reddleman was one of them.

``How I wish `twas only a gipsy!'' (he)
he (Egdon) murmured.

The man was by this time coming back from the horses. In his (Egdon) fear of being seen the boy rendered detection certain by nervous motion. The heather and peat stratum overhung the brow of the pit in mats, hiding the actual verge. The boy had stepped beyond the solid ground; the heather now gave way, and down he (boy) rolled over the scarp of grey sand to the very foot of the man.

The red man opened the lantern and turned it upon the figure of the prostrate boy.

``Who be ye?'' (he)
he (boy) said.

``Johnny Nunsuch, master!'' (unknown)

``What were you doing up there?'' (unknown)

``I don't know.'' (unknown)

``Watching me, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``Yes, master.'' (unknown)

``What did you watch me for?'' (unknown)

``Because I was coming home from Miss Vye's bonfire.'' (unknown)

``Beest hurt?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``Why, yes, you be--your hand is bleeding. Come under my tilt and let me tie it up.'' (unknown)

``Please let me look for my sixpence.'' (unknown)

``How did you come by that?'' (unknown)

``Miss Vye gied it to me for keeping up her (it) bonfire.'' (the man)

The sixpence was found, and the man went to the van, the boy behind, almost holding his (boy) breath.

The man took a piece of rag from a satchel containing sewing materials, tore off a strip, which, like everything else, was tinged red, and proceeded to bind up the wound.

``My eyes have got foggy-like--please may I sit down, master?'' (the boy)
said the boy.

``To be sure, poor chap. `Tis enough to make you feel fainty. Sit on that bundle.'' (The man)

The man finished tying up the gash, and the boy said,

``I think I'll go home now, master.'' (the boy)

``You are rather afraid of me. Do you know what I be?'' (The child)

The child surveyed his (boy) vermilion figure up and down with much misgiving and finally said,

``Yes.'' (The child)

``Well, what?'' (unknown)

``The reddleman!'' (he)
he (boy) faltered.

``Yes, that's what I be. Though there's more than one. You little children think there's only one cuckoo, one fox, one giant, one devil, and one reddleman, when there's lots of us all.'' (unknown)

``Is there? You won't carry me off in your bags, will ye, master? `Tis said that the reddleman will sometimes.'' (unknown)

``Nonsense. All that reddlemen do is sell reddle. You see all these bags at the back of my cart? They are not full of little boys--only full of red stuff.'' (unknown)

``Was you born a reddleman?'' (unknown)

``No, I took to it. I should be as white as you if I were to give up the trade--that is, I should be white in time--perhaps six months; not at first, because `tis grow'd into my skin and won't wash out. Now, you'll never be afraid of a reddleman again, will ye?'' (unknown)

``No, never. Willy Orchard said he (Willy) seed a red ghost here t'other day--perhaps that was you?'' (unknown)

``I was here t'other day.'' (unknown)

``Were you making that dusty light I saw by now?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, I was beating out some bags. And have you had a good bonfire up there? I saw the light. Why did Miss Vye want a bonfire so bad that she (Willy) should give you sixpence to keep it up?'' (unknown)

``I don't know. I was tired, but she (Willy) made me bide and keep up the fire just the same, while she (Willy) kept going up across Rainbarrow way.'' (unknown)

``And how long did that last?'' (unknown)

``Until a hopfrog jumped into the pond.'' (The reddleman)

The reddleman suddenly ceased to talk idly.

``A hopfrog?'' (he)
he (boy) inquired.
``Hopfrogs don't jump into ponds this time of year.'' (unknown)

``They do, for I heard one.'' (unknown)

``Certain-sure?'' (unknown)

``Yes. She (Willy) told me afore that I should hear’n; and so I did. They say she (Willy)'s clever and deep, and perhaps she (Willy) charmed `en to come.'' (unknown)

``And what then?'' (unknown)

``Then I came down here, and I was afeard, and I went back; but I didn't like to speak to her (Willy), because of the gentleman, and I came on here again.'' (unknown)

``A gentleman--ah! What did she (Willy) say to him (gentleman), my man?'' (unknown)

``Told him (gentleman) she (Willy) supposed he (gentleman) had not married the other woman because he (gentleman) liked his (gentleman) old sweetheart best; and things like that.'' (unknown)

``What did the gentleman say to her (sweetheart), my sonny?'' (unknown)

``He (gentleman) only said he (gentleman) did like her (sweetheart) best, and how he (gentleman) was coming to see her (sweetheart) again under Rainbarrow o' nights.'' (unknown)

``Ha!'' (the reddleman hand)
cried the reddleman, slapping his (boy) hand against the side of his (boy) van so that the whole fabric shook under the blow.
``That's the secret o't!'' (The boy)

The little boy jumped clean from the stool.

``My man, don't you be afraid,'' (the dealer)
said the dealer in red, suddenly becoming gentle.
``I forgot you were here. That's only a curious way reddlemen have of going mad for a moment; but they don't hurt anybody. And what did the lady say then?'' (unknown)

``I can't mind. Please, Master Reddleman, may I go home-along now?'' (unknown)

``Ay, to be sure you may. I'll go a bit of ways with you.'' (He)

He (dealer) conducted the boy out of the gravel pit and into the path leading to his (dealer) mother's cottage. When the little figure had vanished in the darkness the reddleman returned, resumed his (dealer) seat by the fire, and proceeded to darn again.

9--Love Leads a Shrewd Man into Strategy

Reddlemen of the old school are now but seldom seen. Since the introduction of railways Wessex farmers have managed to do without these Mephistophelian visitants, and the bright pigment so largely used by shepherds in preparing sheep for the fair is obtained by other routes. Even those who yet survive are losing the poetry of existence which characterized them when the pursuit of the trade meant periodical journeys to the pit whence the material was dug, a regular camping out from month to month, except in the depth of winter, a peregrination among farms which could be counted by the hundred, and in spite of this Arab existence the preservation of that respectability which is insured by the never-failing production of a well-lined purse.

Reddle spreads its lively hues over everything it lights on, and stamps unmistakably, as with the mark of Cain, any person who has handled it half an hour.

A child's first sight of a reddleman was an epoch in his (Cain) life. That blood-coloured figure was a sublimation of all the horrid dreams which had afflicted the juvenile spirit since imagination began.

``The reddleman is coming for you!'' (Wessex)
had been the formulated threat of Wessex mothers for many generations. He (Cain) was successfully supplanted for a while, at the beginning of the present century, by Buonaparte; but as process of time rendered the latter personage stale and ineffective the older phrase resumed its early prominence. And now the reddleman has in his (Cain) turn followed Buonaparte to the land of worn-out bogeys, and his (Cain) place is filled by modern inventions.

The reddleman lived like a gipsy; but gipsies he (Cain) scorned. He (Cain) was about as thriving as travelling basket and mat makers; but he (Cain) had nothing to do with them. He (Cain) was more decently born and brought up than the cattledrovers who passed and repassed him (Cain) in his (Cain) wanderings; but they merely nodded to him (Cain). His (Cain) stock was more valuable than that of pedlars; but they did not think so, and passed his (Cain) cart with eyes straight ahead. He (Cain) was such an unnatural colour to look at that the men of roundabouts and waxwork shows seemed gentlemen beside him (Cain); but he (Cain) considered them low company, and remained aloof. Among all these squatters and folks of the road the reddleman continually found himself; yet he (Cain) was not of them. His (Cain) occupation tended to isolate him (Cain), and isolated he (Cain) was mostly seen to be.

It was sometimes suggested that reddlemen were criminals for whose misdeeds other men wrongfully suffered--that in escaping the law they had not escaped their own consciences, and had taken to the trade as a lifelong penance. Else why should they have chosen it? In the present case such a question would have been particularly apposite. The reddleman who had entered Egdon that afternoon was an instance of the pleasing being wasted to form the ground-work of the singular, when an ugly foundation would have done just as well for that purpose. The one point that was forbidding about this reddleman was his (Egdon) colour. Freed from that he (Freed) would have been as agreeable a specimen of rustic manhood as one would often see. A keen observer might have been inclined to think--which was, indeed, partly the truth--that he (Freed) had relinquished his (Freed) proper station in life for want of interest in it. Moreover, after looking at him (Freed) one would have hazarded the guess that good nature, and an acuteness as extreme as it could be without verging on craft, formed the framework of his (Freed) character.

While he (Freed) darned the stocking his (Freed) face became rigid with thought. Softer expressions followed this, and then again recurred the tender sadness which had sat upon him (Freed) during his (Freed) drive along the highway that afternoon. Presently his (Freed) needle stopped. He (Freed) laid down the stocking, arose from his (Freed) seat, and took a leathern pouch from a hook in the corner of the van. This contained among other articles a brown-paper packet, which, to judge from the hinge-like character of its worn folds, seemed to have been carefully opened and closed a good many times. He (character) sat down on a three-legged milking stool that formed the only seat in the van, and, examining his (character) packet by the light of a candle, took thence an old letter and spread it open. The writing had originally been traced on white paper, but the letter had now assumed a pale red tinge from the accident of its situation; and the black strokes of writing thereon looked like the twigs of a winter hedge against a vermilion sunset. The letter bore a date some two years previous to that time, and was signed

``Thomasin Yeobright.'' (unknown)
It ran as follows:--

DEAR DIGGORY VENN,--The question you put when you overtook me coming home from Pond-close gave me such a surprise that I am afraid I did not make you exactly understand what I meant. Of course, if my aunt had not met me I could have explained all then at once, but as it was there was no chance. I have been quite uneasy since, as you know I do not wish to pain you, yet I fear I shall be doing so now in contradicting what I seemed to say then. I cannot, Diggory, marry you, or think of letting you call me your sweetheart. I could not, indeed, Diggory. I hope you will not much mind my saying this, and feel in a great pain. It makes me very sad when I think it may, for I like you very much, and I always put you next to my cousin Clym in my mind. There are so many reasons why we cannot be married that I can hardly name them all in a letter. I did not in the least expect that you were going to speak on such a thing when you followed me, because I had never thought of you in the sense of a lover at all. You must not becall me for laughing when you spoke; you mistook when you thought I laughed at you as a foolish man. I laughed because the idea was so odd, and not at you at all. The great reason with my own personal self for not letting you court me is, that I do not feel the things a woman ought to feel who consents to walk with you with the meaning of being your wife. It is not as you think, that I have another in my mind, for I do not encourage anybody, and never have in my life. Another reason is my aunt. She (aunt) would not, I know, agree to it, even if I wished to have you. She (aunt) likes you very well, but she (aunt) will want me to look a little higher than a small dairy-farmer, and marry a professional man. I hope you will not set your heart against me for writing plainly, but I felt you might try to see me again, and it is better that we should not meet. I shall always think of you as a good man, and be anxious for your well-doing. I send this by Jane Orchard's little maid,--And remain Diggory, your faithful friend,

THOMASIN YEOBRIGHT.

To MR. VENN, Dairy-farmer.

Since the arrival of that letter, on a certain autumn morning long ago, the reddleman and Thomasin had not met till today. During the interval he (Diggory) had shifted his (Diggory) position even further from hers than it had originally been, by adopting the reddle trade; though he (Diggory) was really in very good circumstances still. Indeed, seeing that his (Diggory) expenditure was only one-fourth of his (Diggory) income, he (Diggory) might have been called a prosperous man.

Rejected suitors take to roaming as naturally as unhived bees; and the business to which he (Diggory) had cynically devoted himself was in many ways congenial to Venn. But his (Diggory) wanderings, by mere stress of old emotions, had frequently taken an Egdon direction, though he (Egdon) never intruded upon her (Diggory) who attracted him (Egdon) thither. To be in Thomasin's heath, and near her (Diggory), yet unseen, was the one ewe-lamb of pleasure left to him (Egdon).

Then came the incident of that day, and the reddleman, still loving her (Diggory) well, was excited by this accidental service to her (Diggory) at a critical juncture to vow an active devotion to her (Diggory) cause, instead of, as hitherto, sighing and holding aloof. After what had happened it was impossible that he (Egdon) should not doubt the honesty of Wildeve's intentions. But her (Diggory) hope was apparently centred upon him (Egdon); and dismissing his (Egdon) regrets Venn determined to aid her (Diggory) to be happy in her (Diggory) own chosen way. That this way was, of all others, the most distressing to himself, was awkward enough; but the reddleman's love was generous.

His (Egdon) first active step in watching over Thomasin's interests was taken about seven o’clock the next evening and was dictated by the news which he (Egdon) had learnt from the sad boy. That Eustacia was somehow the cause of Wildeve's carelessness in relation to the marriage had at once been Venn's conclusion on hearing of the secret meeting between them. It did not occur to his (Venn) mind that Eustacia's love signal to Wildeve was the tender effect upon the deserted beauty of the intelligence which her (Eustacia) grandfather had brought home. His (grandfather) instinct was to regard her (Eustacia) as a conspirator against rather than as an antecedent obstacle to Thomasin's happiness.

During the day he (grandfather) had been exceedingly anxious to learn the condition of Thomasin, but he (grandfather) did not venture to intrude upon a threshold to which he (grandfather) was a stranger, particularly at such an unpleasant moment as this. He (grandfather) had occupied his (grandfather) time in moving with his (grandfather) ponies and load to a new point in the heath, eastward to his (grandfather) previous station; and here he (grandfather) selected a nook with a careful eye to shelter from wind and rain, which seemed to mean that his (grandfather) stay there was to be a comparatively extended one. After this he (grandfather) returned on foot some part of the way that he (grandfather) had come; and, it being now dark, he (grandfather) diverged to the left till he (grandfather) stood behind a holly bush on the edge of a pit not twenty yards from Rainbarrow.

He (grandfather) watched for a meeting there, but he (grandfather) watched in vain. Nobody except himself came near the spot that night.

But the loss of his (grandfather) labour produced little effect upon the reddleman. He (grandfather) had stood in the shoes of Tantalus, and seemed to look upon a certain mass of disappointment as the natural preface to all realizations, without which preface they would give cause for alarm.

The same hour the next evening found him (grandfather) again at the same place; but Eustacia and Wildeve, the expected trysters, did not appear.

He (Wildeve) pursued precisely the same course yet four nights longer, and without success. But on the next, being the day-week of their previous meeting, he (Wildeve) saw a female shape floating along the ridge and the outline of a young man ascending from the valley. They met in the little ditch encircling the tumulus--the original excavation from which it had been thrown up by the ancient British people.

The reddleman, stung with suspicion of wrong to Thomasin, was aroused to strategy in a moment. He (man) instantly left the bush and crept forward on his (man) hands and knees. When he (man) had got as close as he (man) might safely venture without discovery he (man) found that, owing to a cross-wind, the conversation of the trysting pair could not be overheard.

Near him (man), as in divers places about the heath, were areas strewn with large turves, which lay edgeways and upside down awaiting removal by Timothy Fairway, previous to the winter weather. He (Fairway) took two of these as he (Fairway) lay, and dragged them over him (Fairway) till one covered his (Fairway) head and shoulders, the other his (Fairway) back and legs. The reddleman would now have been quite invisible, even by daylight; the turves, standing upon him (Fairway) with the heather upwards, looked precisely as if they were growing. He (Fairway) crept along again, and the turves upon his (Fairway) back crept with him (Fairway). Had he (Fairway) approached without any covering the chances are that he (Fairway) would not have been perceived in the dusk; approaching thus, it was as though he (Fairway) burrowed underground. In this manner he (Fairway) came quite close to where the two were standing.

``Wish to consult me on the matter?'' (unknown)
reached his (Fairway) ears in the rich, impetuous accents of Eustacia Vye.
``Consult me? It is an indignity to me to talk so--I won't bear it any longer!'' (She)
She (Fairway) began weeping.
``I have loved you, and have shown you that I loved you, much to my regret; and yet you can come and say in that frigid way that you wish to consult with me whether it would not be better to marry Thomasin. Better--of course it would be. Marry her (me)--she (me) is nearer to your own position in life than I am!'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes; that's very well,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve peremptorily.
``But we must look at things as they are. Whatever blame may attach to me for having brought it about, Thomasin's position is at present much worse than yours. I simply tell you that I am in a strait.'' (unknown)

``But you shall not tell me! You must see that it is only harassing me. Damon, you have not acted well; you have sunk in my opinion. You have not valued my courtesy--the courtesy of a lady in loving you--who used to think of far more ambitious things. But it was Thomasin's fault.

``She (lady) won you away from me, and she (lady) deserves to suffer for it. Where is she (lady) staying now? Not that I care, nor where I am myself. Ah, if I were dead and gone how glad she (lady) would be! Where is she (lady), I ask?'' (unknown)

``Thomasin is now staying at her (lady) aunt's shut up in a bedroom, and keeping out of everybody's sight,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said indifferently.

``I don't think you care much about her (lady) even now,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia with sudden joyousness,
``for if you did you wouldn't talk so coolly about her (lady). Do you talk so coolly to her (lady) about me? Ah, I expect you do! Why did you originally go away from me? I don't think I can ever forgive you, except on one condition, that whenever you desert me, you come back again, sorry that you served me so.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

``I never wish to desert you.'' (unknown)

``I do not thank you for that. I should hate it to be all smooth. Indeed, I think I like you to desert me a little once now and then. Love is the dismallest thing where the lover is quite honest. O, it is a shame to say so; but it is true!'' (She)
She (Eustacia) indulged in a little laugh.
``My low spirits begin at the very idea. Don't you offer me tame love, or away you go!'' (unknown)

``I wish Tamsie were not such a confoundedly good little woman,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve,
``so that I could be faithful to you without injuring a worthy person. It is I who am the sinner after all; I am not worth the little finger of either of you.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

``But you must not sacrifice yourself to her (woman) from any sense of justice,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
replied Eustacia quickly.
``If you do not love her (woman) it is the most merciful thing in the long run to leave her (woman) as she (woman) is. That's always the best way. There, now I have been unwomanly, I suppose. When you have left me I am always angry with myself for things that I have said to you.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve walked a pace or two among the heather without replying. The pause was filled up by the intonation of a pollard thorn a little way to windward, the breezes filtering through its unyielding twigs as through a strainer. It was as if the night sang dirges with clenched teeth.

She (Eustacia) continued, half sorrowfully,

``Since meeting you last, it has occurred to me once or twice that perhaps it was not for love of me you did not marry her (woman). Tell me, Damon--I'll try to bear it. Had I nothing whatever to do with the matter?'' (She)

``Do you press me to tell?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I must know. I see I have been too ready to believe in my own power.'' (unknown)

``Well, the immediate reason was that the license would not do for the place, and before I could get another she (woman) ran away. Up to that point you had nothing to do with it. Since then her (woman) aunt has spoken to me in a tone which I don't at all like.'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes! I am nothing in it--I am nothing in it. You only trifle with me. Heaven, what can I, Eustacia Vye, be made of to think so much of you!'' (unknown)

``Nonsense; do not be so passionate... Eustacia, how we roved among these bushes last year, when the hot days had got cool, and the shades of the hills kept us almost invisible in the hollows!'' (She)

She (Eustacia) remained in moody silence till she (Eustacia) said,

``Yes; and how I used to laugh at you for daring to look up to me! But you have well made me suffer for that since.'' (she)

``Yes, you served me cruelly enough until I thought I had found someone fairer than you. A blessed find for me, Eustacia.'' (unknown)

``Do you still think you found somebody fairer?'' (unknown)

``Sometimes I do, sometimes I don't. The scales are balanced so nicely that a feather would turn them.'' (unknown)

``But don't you really care whether I meet you or whether I don't?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said slowly.

``I care a little, but not enough to break my rest,'' (the man)
replied the young man languidly.
``No, all that's past. I find there are two flowers where I thought there was only one. Perhaps there are three, or four, or any number as good as the first... Mine is a curious fate. Who would have thought that all this could happen to me?'' (She)

She (Eustacia) interrupted with a suppressed fire of which either love or anger seemed an equally possible issue,

``Do you love me now?'' (She)

``Who can say?'' (unknown)

``Tell me; I will know it!'' (unknown)

``I do, and I do not,'' (he)
said he (man) mischievously.
``That is, I have my times and my seasons. One moment you are too tall, another moment you are too do-nothing, another too melancholy, another too dark, another I don't know what, except--that you are not the whole world to me that you used to be, my dear. But you are a pleasant lady to know and nice to meet, and I dare say as sweet as ever--almost.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia was silent, and she (Eustacia) turned from him (man), till she (Eustacia) said, in a voice of suspended mightiness,

``I am for a walk, and this is my way.'' (she)

``Well, I can do worse than follow you.'' (unknown)

``You know you can't do otherwise, for all your moods and changes!'' (she)
she (Eustacia) answered defiantly.
``Say what you will; try as you may; keep away from me all that you can--you will never forget me. You will love me all your life long. You would jump to marry me!'' (unknown)

``So I would!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.
``Such strange thoughts as I've had from time to time, Eustacia; and they come to me this moment. You hate the heath as much as ever; that I know.'' (unknown)

``I do,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) murmured deeply. ```Tis my cross, my shame, and will be my death!''

``I abhor it too,'' (he)
said he (Wildeve).
``How mournfully the wind blows round us now!'' (She)

She (Eustacia) did not answer. Its tone was indeed solemn and pervasive. Compound utterances addressed themselves to their senses, and it was possible to view by ear the features of the neighbourhood. Acoustic pictures were returned from the darkened scenery; they could hear where the tracts of heather began and ended; where the furze was growing stalky and tall; where it had been recently cut; in what direction the fir-clump lay, and how near was the pit in which the hollies grew; for these differing features had their voices no less than their shapes and colours.

``God, how lonely it is!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
resumed Wildeve.
``What are picturesque ravines and mists to us who see nothing else? Why should we stay here? Will you go with me to America? I have kindred in Wisconsin.'' (unknown)

``That wants consideration.'' (unknown)

``It seems impossible to do well here, unless one were a wild bird or a landscape-painter. Well?'' (unknown)

``Give me time,'' (she)
she (they) softly said, taking his (Wildeve) hand.
``America is so far away. Are you going to walk with me a little way?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

As Eustacia uttered the latter words she (Eustacia) retired from the base of the barrow, and Wildeve followed her (Eustacia), so that the reddleman could hear no more.

He (Wildeve) lifted the turves and arose. Their black figures sank and disappeared from against the sky. They were as two horns which the sluggish heath had put forth from its crown, like a mollusc, and had now again drawn in.

The reddleman's walk across the vale, and over into the next where his (Wildeve) cart lay, was not sprightly for a slim young fellow of twenty-four. His (Wildeve) spirit was perturbed to aching. The breezes that blew around his (Wildeve) mouth in that walk carried off upon them the accents of a commination.

He (Wildeve) entered the van, where there was a fire in a stove. Without lighting his (Wildeve) candle he (Wildeve) sat down at once on the three-legged stool, and pondered on what he (Wildeve) had seen and heard touching that still-loved one of his (Wildeve). He (Wildeve) uttered a sound which was neither sigh nor sob, but was even more indicative than either of a troubled mind.

``My Tamsie,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) whispered heavily.
``What can be done? Yes, I will see that Eustacia Vye.'' (the reddleman)

10--A Desperate Attempt at Persuasion

The next morning, at the time when the height of the sun appeared very insignificant from any part of the heath as compared with the altitude of Rainbarrow, and when all the little hills in the lower levels were like an archipelago in a fog-formed Aegean, the reddleman came from the brambled nook which he (Wildeve) had adopted as his (Wildeve) quarters and ascended the slopes of Mistover Knap.

Though these shaggy hills were apparently so solitary, several keen round eyes were always ready on such a wintry morning as this to converge upon a passer-by. Feathered species sojourned here in hiding which would have created wonder if found elsewhere. A bustard haunted the spot, and not many years before this five and twenty might have been seen in Egdon at one time. Marsh-harriers looked up from the valley by Wildeve's. A cream-coloured courser had used to visit this hill, a bird so rare that not more than a dozen have ever been seen in England; but a barbarian rested neither night nor day till he (Wildeve) had shot the African truant, and after that event cream-coloured coursers thought fit to enter Egdon no more.

A traveller who should walk and observe any of these visitants as Venn observed them now could feel himself to be in direct communication with regions unknown to man. Here in front of him (man) was a wild mallard--just arrived from the home of the north wind. The creature brought within him (man) an amplitude of Northern knowledge. Glacial catastrophes, snowstorm episodes, glittering auroral effects, Polaris in the zenith, Franklin underfoot--the category of his (Franklin) commonplaces was wonderful. But the bird, like many other philosophers, seemed as he (Franklin) looked at the reddleman to think that a present moment of comfortable reality was worth a decade of memories.

Venn passed on through these towards the house of the isolated beauty who lived up among them and despised them. The day was Sunday; but as going to church, except to be married or buried, was exceptional at Egdon, this made little difference. He (Venn) had determined upon the bold stroke of asking for an interview with Miss Vye--to attack her (Venn) position as Thomasin's rival either by art or by storm, showing therein, somewhat too conspicuously, the want of gallantry characteristic of a certain astute sort of men, from clowns to kings. The great Frederick making war on the beautiful Archduchess, Napoleon refusing terms to the beautiful Queen of Prussia, were not more dead to difference of sex than the reddleman was, in his (Napoleon) peculiar way, in planning the displacement of Eustacia.

To call at the captain's cottage was always more or less an undertaking for the inferior inhabitants. Though occasionally chatty, his (Napoleon) moods were erratic, and nobody could be certain how he (Napoleon) would behave at any particular moment. Eustacia was reserved, and lived very much to herself. Except the daughter of one of the cotters, who was their servant, and a lad who worked in the garden and stable, scarcely anyone but themselves ever entered the house. They were the only genteel people of the district except the Yeobrights, and though far from rich, they did not feel that necessity for preserving a friendly face towards every man, bird, and beast which influenced their poorer neighbours.

When the reddleman entered the garden the old man was looking through his (man) glass at the stain of blue sea in the distant landscape, the little anchors on his (man) buttons twinkling in the sun. He (man) recognized Venn as his (man) companion on the highway, but made no remark on that circumstance, merely saying,

``Ah, reddleman--you here? Have a glass of grog?'' (companion)

Venn declined, on the plea of it being too early, and stated that his (Venn) business was with Miss Vye. The captain surveyed him (captain) from cap to waistcoat and from waistcoat to leggings for a few moments, and finally asked him (captain) to go indoors.

Miss Vye was not to be seen by anybody just then; and the reddleman waited in the window-bench of the kitchen, his (captain) hands hanging across his (captain) divergent knees, and his (captain) cap hanging from his (captain) hands.

``I suppose the young lady is not up yet?'' (he)
he (captain) presently said to the servant.

``Not quite yet. Folks never call upon ladies at this time of day.'' (unknown)

``Then I'll step outside,'' (unknown)
said Venn.
``If she (lady) is willing to see me, will she (lady) please send out word, and I'll come in.'' (The reddleman)

The reddleman left the house and loitered on the hill adjoining. A considerable time elapsed, and no request for his (captain) presence was brought. He (captain) was beginning to think that his (captain) scheme had failed, when he (captain) beheld the form of Eustacia herself coming leisurely towards him (captain). A sense of novelty in giving audience to that singular figure had been sufficient to draw her (Eustacia) forth.

She (Eustacia) seemed to feel, after a bare look at Diggory Venn, that the man had come on a strange errand, and that he (man) was not so mean as she (Eustacia) had thought him (man); for her (Eustacia) close approach did not cause him (man) to writhe uneasily, or shift his (man) feet, or show any of those little signs which escape an ingenuous rustic at the advent of the uncommon in womankind. On his (man) inquiring if he (man) might have a conversation with her (Eustacia) she (Eustacia) replied,

``Yes, walk beside me,'' (she)
and continued to move on.

Before they had gone far it occurred to the perspicacious reddleman that he (man) would have acted more wisely by appearing less unimpressionable, and he (man) resolved to correct the error as soon as he (man) could find opportunity.

``I have made so bold, miss, as to step across and tell you some strange news which has come to my ears about that man.'' (unknown)

``Ah! what man?'' (He)

He (man) jerked his (man) elbow to the southeast--the direction of the Quiet Woman.

Eustacia turned quickly to him (man).

``Do you mean Mr. Wildeve?'' (unknown)

``Yes, there is trouble in a household on account of him (Wildeve), and I have come to let you know of it, because I believe you might have power to drive it away.'' (unknown)

``I? What is the trouble?'' (unknown)

``It is quite a secret. It is that he (Wildeve) may refuse to marry Thomasin Yeobright after all.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia, though set inwardly pulsing by his (man) words, was equal to her (Eustacia) part in such a drama as this. She (Eustacia) replied coldly,

``I do not wish to listen to this, and you must not expect me to interfere.'' (She)

``But, miss, you will hear one word?'' (unknown)

``I cannot. I am not interested in the marriage, and even if I were I could not compel Mr. Wildeve to do my bidding.'' (unknown)

``As the only lady on the heath I think you might,'' (unknown)
said Venn with subtle indirectness.
``This is how the case stands. Mr. Wildeve would marry Thomasin at once, and make all matters smooth, if so be there were not another woman in the case. This other woman is some person he (Wildeve) has picked up with, and meets on the heath occasionally, I believe. He (Wildeve) will never marry her (woman), and yet through her (woman) he (Wildeve) may never marry the woman who loves him (Wildeve) dearly. Now, if you, miss, who have so much sway over us menfolk, were to insist that he (Wildeve) should treat your young neighbour Tamsin with honourable kindness and give up the other woman, he (Wildeve) would perhaps do it, and save her (woman) a good deal of misery.'' (unknown)

``Ah, my life!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia, with a laugh which unclosed her (Eustacia) lips so that the sun shone into her (Eustacia) mouth as into a tulip, and lent it a similar scarlet fire.
``You think too much of my influence over menfolk indeed, reddleman. If I had such a power as you imagine I would go straight and use it for the good of anybody who has been kind to me--which Thomasin Yeobright has not particularly, to my knowledge.'' (unknown)

``Can it be that you really don't know of it--how much she (woman) had always thought of you?'' (unknown)

``I have never heard a word of it. Although we live only two miles apart I have never been inside her (woman) aunt's house in my life.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

The superciliousness that lurked in her (Eustacia) manner told Venn that thus far he (Venn) had utterly failed. He (Venn) inwardly sighed and felt it necessary to unmask his (Venn) second argument.

``Well, leaving that out of the question, `tis in your power, I assure you, Miss Vye, to do a great deal of good to another woman.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) shook her (Eustacia) head.

``Your comeliness is law with Mr. Wildeve. It is law with all men who see `ee. They say, `This well-favoured lady coming--what's her (lady) name? How handsome!' Handsomer than Thomasin Yeobright,'' (the reddleman)
the reddleman persisted, saying to himself,
``God forgive a rascal for lying!'' (the reddleman)
And she (Eustacia) was handsomer, but the reddleman was far from thinking so. There was a certain obscurity in Eustacia's beauty, and Venn's eye was not trained. In her (Eustacia) winter dress, as now, she (Eustacia) was like the tiger-beetle, which, when observed in dull situations, seems to be of the quietest neutral colour, but under a full illumination blazes with dazzling splendour.

Eustacia could not help replying, though conscious that she (Eustacia) endangered her (Eustacia) dignity thereby.

``Many women are lovelier than Thomasin,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said,
``so not much attaches to that.'' (she)

The reddleman suffered the wound and went on:

``He (God) is a man who notices the looks of women, and you could twist him (God) to your will like withywind, if you only had the mind.'' (The reddleman)

``Surely what she (lady) cannot do who has been so much with him (God) I cannot do living up here away from him (God).'' (The reddleman)

The reddleman wheeled and looked her (Eustacia) in the face.

``Miss Vye!'' (he)
he (Venn) said.

``Why do you say that--as if you doubted me?'' (She)
She (Eustacia) spoke faintly, and her (Eustacia) breathing was quick.
``The idea of your speaking in that tone to me!'' (she)
she (Eustacia) added, with a forced smile of hauteur.
``What could have been in your mind to lead you to speak like that?'' (unknown)

``Miss Vye, why should you make believe that you don't know this man?--I know why, certainly. He (man) is beneath you, and you are ashamed.'' (unknown)

``You are mistaken. What do you mean?'' (The reddleman)

The reddleman had decided to play the card of truth.

``I was at the meeting by Rainbarrow last night and heard every word,'' (he)
he (Venn) said.
``The woman that stands between Wildeve and Thomasin is yourself.'' (Candaules wife)

It was a disconcerting lift of the curtain, and the mortification of Candaules' wife glowed in her (wife). The moment had arrived when her (wife) lip would tremble in spite of herself, and when the gasp could no longer be kept down.

``I am unwell,'' (she)
she (wife) said hurriedly.
``No--it is not that--I am not in a humour to hear you further. Leave me, please.'' (unknown)

``I must speak, Miss Vye, in spite of paining you. What I would put before you is this. However it may come about--whether she (woman) is to blame, or you--her (woman) case is without doubt worse than yours. Your giving up Mr. Wildeve will be a real advantage to you, for how could you marry him (Wildeve)? Now she (woman) cannot get off so easily--everybody will blame her (woman) if she (woman) loses him (Wildeve). Then I ask you--not because her (woman) right is best, but because her (woman) situation is worst--to give him (Wildeve) up to her (woman).'' (unknown)

``No--I won't, I won't!'' (she)
she (wife) said impetuously, quite forgetful of her (wife) previous manner towards the reddleman as an underling.
``Nobody has ever been served so! It was going on well--I will not be beaten down--by an inferior woman like her (woman). It is very well for you to come and plead for her (woman), but is she (woman) not herself the cause of all her (woman) own trouble? Am I not to show favour to any person I may choose without asking permission of a parcel of cottagers? She (woman) has come between me and my inclination, and now that she (woman) finds herself rightly punished she (woman) gets you to plead for her (woman)!'' (unknown)

``Indeed,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn earnestly,
``she (woman) knows nothing whatever about it. It is only I who ask you to give him (woman) up. It will be better for her (woman) and you both. People will say bad things if they find out that a lady secretly meets a man who has ill-used another woman.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

``I have NOT injured her (woman)--he (man) was mine before he (man) was hers! He (man) came back--because--because he (man) liked me best!'' (she)
she (wife) said wildly.
``But I lose all self-respect in talking to you. What am I giving way to!'' (unknown)

``I can keep secrets,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn gently.
``You need not fear. I am the only man who knows of your meetings with him (man). There is but one thing more to speak of, and then I will be gone. I heard you say to him (man) that you hated living here--that Egdon Heath was a jail to you.'' (unknown)

``I did say so. There is a sort of beauty in the scenery, I know; but it is a jail to me. The man you mention does not save me from that feeling, though he (man) lives here. I should have cared nothing for him (man) had there been a better person near.'' (The reddleman)

The reddleman looked hopeful; after these words from her (wife) his (Venn) third attempt seemed promising.

``As we have now opened our minds a bit, miss,'' (he)
he (Venn) said,
``I'll tell you what I have got to propose. Since I have taken to the reddle trade I travel a good deal, as you know.'' (he)

She (wife) inclined her (wife) head, and swept round so that her (wife) eyes rested in the misty vale beneath them.

``And in my travels I go near Budmouth. Now Budmouth is a wonderful place--wonderful--a great salt sheening sea bending into the land like a bow--thousands of gentlepeople walking up and down--bands of music playing--officers by sea and officers by land walking among the rest--out of every ten folks you meet nine of `em in love.'' (unknown)

``I know it,'' (she)
she (wife) said disdainfully.
``I know Budmouth better than you. I was born there. My father came to be a military musician there from abroad. Ah, my soul, Budmouth! I wish I was there now.'' (The reddleman)

The reddleman was surprised to see how a slow fire could blaze on occasion.

``If you were, miss,'' (he)
he (Venn) replied,
``in a week's time you would think no more of Wildeve than of one of those he (father)'th-croppers that we see yond. Now, I could get you there.'' (he)

``How?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia, with intense curiosity in her (Eustacia) heavy eyes.

``My uncle has been for five and twenty years the trusty man of a rich widow-lady who has a beautiful house facing the sea. This lady has become old and lame, and she (lady) wants a young company-keeper to read and sing to her (lady), but can't get one to her (lady) mind to save her (lady) life, though she (lady)'ve advertised in the papers, and tried half a dozen. She (lady) would jump to get you, and Uncle would make it all easy.'' (unknown)

``I should have to work, perhaps?'' (unknown)

``No, not real work--you'd have a little to do, such as reading and that. You would not be wanted till New Year's Day.'' (unknown)

``I knew it meant work,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, drooping to languor again.

``I confess there would be a trifle to do in the way of amusing her (lady); but though idle people might call it work, working people would call it play. Think of the company and the life you'd lead, miss; the gaiety you'd see, and the gentleman you'd marry. My uncle is to inquire for a trustworthy young lady from the country, as she (lady) don't like town girls.'' (unknown)

``It is to wear myself out to please her (lady)! and I won't go. O, if I could live in a gay town as a lady should, and go my own ways, and do my own doings, I'd give the wrinkled half of my life! Yes, reddleman, that would I.'' (companion)

``Help me to get Thomasin happy, miss, and the chance shall be yours,'' (companion)
urged her (Eustacia) companion.

``Chance--`tis no chance,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said proudly.
``What can a poor man like you offer me, indeed?--I am going indoors. I have nothing more to say. Don't your horses want feeding, or your reddlebags want mending, or don't you want to find buyers for your goods, that you stay idling here like this?'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn spoke not another word. With his (Venn) hands behind him (Venn) he (Venn) turned away, that she (Eustacia) might not see the hopeless disappointment in his (Venn) face. The mental clearness and power he (Venn) had found in this lonely girl had indeed filled his (Venn) manner with misgiving even from the first few minutes of close quarters with her (girl). Her (girl) youth and situation had led him (Venn) to expect a simplicity quite at the beck of his (Venn) method. But a system of inducement which might have carried weaker country lasses along with it had merely repelled Eustacia. As a rule, the word Budmouth meant fascination on Egdon. That Royal port and watering place, if truly mirrored in the minds of the heathfolk, must have combined, in a charming and indescribable manner a Carthaginian bustle of building with Tarentine luxuriousness and Baian health and beauty. Eustacia felt little less extravagantly about the place; but she (Eustacia) would not sink her (Eustacia) independence to get there.

When Diggory Venn had gone quite away, Eustacia walked to the bank and looked down the wild and picturesque vale towards the sun, which was also in the direction of Wildeve's. The mist had now so far collapsed that the tips of the trees and bushes around his (Venn) house could just be discerned, as if boring upwards through a vast white cobweb which cloaked them from the day. There was no doubt that her (Eustacia) mind was inclined thitherward; indefinitely, fancifully--twining and untwining about him (Venn) as the single object within her (Eustacia) horizon on which dreams might crystallize. The man who had begun by being merely her (Eustacia) amusement, and would never have been more than her (Eustacia) hobby but for his (man) skill in deserting her (Eustacia) at the right moments, was now again her (Eustacia) desire. Cessation in his (man) love-making had revivified her (Eustacia) love. Such feeling as Eustacia had idly given to Wildeve was dammed into a flood by Thomasin. She (Eustacia) had used to tease Wildeve, but that was before another had favoured him (Wildeve). Often a drop of irony into an indifferent situation renders the whole piquant.

``I will never give him (man) up--never!'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said impetuously.

The reddleman's hint that rumour might show her (Eustacia) to disadvantage had no permanent terror for Eustacia. She (Eustacia) was as unconcerned at that contingency as a goddess at a lack of linen. This did not originate in inherent shamelessness, but in her (Eustacia) living too far from the world to feel the impact of public opinion. Zenobia in the desert could hardly have cared what was said about her (Zenobia) at Rome. As far as social ethics were concerned Eustacia approached the savage state, though in emotion she (Eustacia) was all the while an epicure. She (Eustacia) had advanced to the secret recesses of sensuousness, yet had hardly crossed the threshold of conventionality.

11--The Dishonesty of an Honest Woman

The reddleman had left Eustacia's presence with desponding views on Thomasin's future happiness; but he (Zenobia) was awakened to the fact that one other channel remained untried by seeing, as he (Zenobia) followed the way to his (Zenobia) van, the form of Mrs. Yeobright slowly walking towards the Quiet Woman. He (Zenobia) went across to her (Woman); and could almost perceive in her (Woman) anxious face that this journey of hers to Wildeve was undertaken with the same object as his (Wildeve) own to Eustacia.

She (Eustacia) did not conceal the fact.

``Then,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman,
``you may as well leave it alone, Mrs. Yeobright.'' (the reddleman)

``I half think so myself,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.
``But nothing else remains to be done besides pressing the question upon him (man).'' (unknown)

``I should like to say a word first,'' (unknown)
said Venn firmly.
``Mr. Wildeve is not the only man who has asked Thomasin to marry him (Wildeve); and why should not another have a chance? Mrs. Yeobright, I should be glad to marry your niece and would have done it any time these last two years. There, now it is out, and I have never told anybody before but herself.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright was not demonstrative, but her (Yeobright) eyes involuntarily glanced towards his (Wildeve) singular though shapely figure.

``Looks are not everything,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman, noticing the glance.
``There's many a calling that don't bring in so much as mine, if it comes to money; and perhaps I am not so much worse off than Wildeve. There is nobody so poor as these professional fellows who have failed; and if you shouldn't like my redness--well, I am not red by birth, you know; I only took to this business for a freak; and I might turn my hand to something else in good time.'' (unknown)

``I am much obliged to you for your interest in my niece; but I fear there would be objections. More than that, she (niece) is devoted to this man.'' (unknown)

``True; or I shouldn't have done what I have this morning.'' (unknown)

``Otherwise there would be no pain in the case, and you would not see me going to his (man) house now. What was Thomasin's answer when you told her (niece) of your feelings?'' (unknown)

``She (niece) wrote that you would object to me; and other things.'' (unknown)

``She (niece) was in a measure right. You must not take this unkindly--I merely state it as a truth. You have been good to her (niece), and we do not forget it. But as she (niece) was unwilling on her (niece) own account to be your wife, that settles the point without my wishes being concerned.'' (unknown)

``Yes. But there is a difference between then and now, ma’am. She (niece) is distressed now, and I have thought that if you were to talk to her (niece) about me, and think favourably of me yourself, there might be a chance of winning her (niece) round, and getting her (niece) quite independent of this Wildeve's backward and forward play, and his (it) not knowing whether he (it)'ll have her (niece) or no.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright shook her (Yeobright) head.

``Thomasin thinks, and I think with her (niece), that she (niece) ought to be Wildeve's wife, if she (niece) means to appear before the world without a slur upon her (niece) name. If they marry soon, everybody will believe that an accident did really prevent the wedding. If not, it may cast a shade upon her (niece) character--at any rate make her (niece) ridiculous. In short, if it is anyhow possible they must marry now.'' (unknown)

``I thought that till half an hour ago. But, after all, why should her (niece) going off with him (character) to Anglebury for a few hours do her (niece) any harm? Anybody who knows how pure she (niece) is will feel any such thought to be quite unjust. I have been trying this morning to help on this marriage with Wildeve--yes, I, ma’am--in the belief that I ought to do it, because she (niece) was so wrapped up in him (Wildeve). But I much question if I was right, after all. However, nothing came of it. And now I offer myself.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright appeared disinclined to enter further into the question.

``I fear I must go on,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) said.
``I do not see that anything else can be done.'' (she)

And she (Yeobright) went on. But though this conversation did not divert Thomasin's aunt from her (Yeobright) purposed interview with Wildeve, it made a considerable difference in her (Yeobright) mode of conducting that interview. She (Yeobright) thanked God for the weapon which the reddleman had put into her (Yeobright) hands.

Wildeve was at home when she (Yeobright) reached the inn. He (Wildeve) showed her (Yeobright) silently into the parlour, and closed the door. Mrs. Yeobright began--

``I have thought it my duty to call today. A new proposal has been made to me, which has rather astonished me. It will affect Thomasin greatly; and I have decided that it should at least be mentioned to you.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

``Yes? What is it?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said civilly.

``It is, of course, in reference to her (it) future. You may not be aware that another man has shown himself anxious to marry Thomasin. Now, though I have not encouraged him (man) yet, I cannot conscientiously refuse him (man) a chance any longer. I don't wish to be short with you; but I must be fair to him (man) and to her (it).'' (unknown)

``Who is the man?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve with surprise.

``One who has been in love with her (it) longer than she (it) has with you. He (man) proposed to her (it) two years ago. At that time she (it) refused him (man).'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (unknown)

``He (man) has seen her (it) lately, and has asked me for permission to pay his (man) addresses to her (it). She (it) may not refuse him (man) twice.'' (unknown)

``What is his (man) name?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright declined to say.

``He (man) is a man Thomasin likes,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) added,
``and one whose constancy she (it) respects at least. It seems to me that what she (it) refused then she (it) would be glad to get now. She (it) is much annoyed at her (it) awkward position.'' (she)

``She (it) never once told me of this old lover.'' (unknown)

``The gentlest women are not such fools as to show EVERY card.'' (unknown)

``Well, if she (it) wants him (lover) I suppose she (it) must have him (lover).'' (unknown)

``It is easy enough to say that; but you don't see the difficulty. He (lover) wants her (it) much more than she (it) wants him (lover); and before I can encourage anything of the sort I must have a clear understanding from you that you will not interfere to injure an arrangement which I promote in the belief that it is for the best. Suppose, when they are engaged, and everything is smoothly arranged for their marriage, that you should step between them and renew your suit? You might not win her (it) back, but you might cause much unhappiness.'' (unknown)

``Of course I should do no such thing,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve
``But they are not engaged yet. How do you know that Thomasin would accept him (it)?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

``That's a question I have carefully put to myself; and upon the whole the probabilities are in favour of her (it) accepting him (it) in time. I flatter myself that I have some influence over her (it). She (it) is pliable, and I can be strong in my recommendations of him (it).'' (unknown)

``And in your disparagement of me at the same time.'' (unknown)

``Well, you may depend upon my not praising you,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) said drily.
``And if this seems like manoeuvring, you must remember that her (it) position is peculiar, and that she (it) has been hardly used. I shall also be helped in making the match by her (it) own desire to escape from the humiliation of her (it) present state; and a woman's pride in these cases will lead her (it) a very great way. A little managing may be required to bring her (it) round; but I am equal to that, provided that you agree to the one thing indispensable; that is, to make a distinct declaration that she (it) is to think no more of you as a possible husband. That will pique her (it) into accepting him (husband).'' (unknown)

``I can hardly say that just now, Mrs. Yeobright. It is so sudden.'' (unknown)

``And so my whole plan is interfered with! It is very inconvenient that you refuse to help my family even to the small extent of saying distinctly you will have nothing to do with us.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve reflected uncomfortably.

``I confess I was not prepared for this,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.
``Of course I'll give her (Yeobright) up if you wish, if it is necessary. But I thought I might be her (Yeobright) husband.'' (unknown)

``We have heard that before.'' (unknown)

``Now, Mrs. Yeobright, don't let us disagree. Give me a fair time. I don't want to stand in the way of any better chance she (Yeobright) may have; only I wish you had let me know earlier. I will write to you or call in a day or two. Will that suffice?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) replied,
``provided you promise not to communicate with Thomasin without my knowledge.'' (she)

``I promise that,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said. And the interview then terminated, Mrs. Yeobright returning homeward as she (Yeobright) had come.

By far the greatest effect of her (Yeobright) simple strategy on that day was, as often happens, in a quarter quite outside her (Yeobright) view when arranging it. In the first place, her (Yeobright) visit sent Wildeve the same evening after dark to Eustacia's house at Mistover.

At this hour the lonely dwelling was closely blinded and shuttered from the chill and darkness without. Wildeve's clandestine plan with her (Eustacia) was to take a little gravel in his (Wildeve) hand and hold it to the crevice at the top of the window shutter, which was on the outside, so that it should fall with a gentle rustle, resembling that of a mouse, between shutter and glass. This precaution in attracting her (Eustacia) attention was to avoid arousing the suspicions of her (Eustacia) grandfather.

The soft words,

``I hear; wait for me,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
in Eustacia's voice from within told him (grandfather) that she (Eustacia) was alone.

He (grandfather) waited in his (grandfather) customary manner by walking round the enclosure and idling by the pool, for Wildeve was never asked into the house by his (Wildeve) proud though condescending mistress. She (mistress) showed no sign of coming out in a hurry. The time wore on, and he (Wildeve) began to grow impatient. In the course of twenty minutes she (mistress) appeared from round the corner, and advanced as if merely taking an airing.

``You would not have kept me so long had you known what I come about,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said with bitterness.
``Still, you are worth waiting for.'' (unknown)

``What has happened?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.
``I did not know you were in trouble. I too am gloomy enough.'' (unknown)

``I am not in trouble,'' (he)
said he (Wildeve).
``It is merely that affairs have come to a head, and I must take a clear course.'' (unknown)

``What course is that?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) asked with attentive interest.

``And can you forget so soon what I proposed to you the other night? Why, take you from this place, and carry you away with me abroad.'' (unknown)

``I have not forgotten. But why have you come so unexpectedly to repeat the question, when you only promised to come next Saturday? I thought I was to have plenty of time to consider.'' (unknown)

``Yes, but the situation is different now.'' (unknown)

``Explain to me.'' (unknown)

``I don't want to explain, for I may pain you.'' (unknown)

``But I must know the reason of this hurry.'' (unknown)

``It is simply my ardour, dear Eustacia. Everything is smooth now.'' (unknown)

``Then why are you so ruffled?'' (unknown)

``I am not aware of it. All is as it should be. Mrs. Yeobright--but she (Yeobright) is nothing to us.'' (unknown)

``Ah, I knew she (Yeobright) had something to do with it! Come, I don't like reserve.'' (unknown)

``No--she (Yeobright) has nothing. She (Yeobright) only says she (Yeobright) wishes me to give up Thomasin because another man is anxious to marry her (Yeobright). The woman, now she (woman) no longer needs me, actually shows off!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
Wildeve's vexation has escaped him (Wildeve) in spite of himself.

Eustacia was silent a long while.

``You are in the awkward position of an official who is no longer wanted,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said in a changed tone.

``It seems so. But I have not yet seen Thomasin.'' (unknown)

``And that irritates you. Don't deny it, Damon. You are actually nettled by this slight from an unexpected quarter.'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (unknown)

``And you come to get me because you cannot get her (woman). This is certainly a new position altogether. I am to be a stop-gap.'' (unknown)

``Please remember that I proposed the same thing the other day.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia again remained in a sort of stupefied silence. What curious feeling was this coming over her (Eustacia)? Was it really possible that her (Eustacia) interest in Wildeve had been so entirely the result of antagonism that the glory and the dream departed from the man with the first sound that he (man) was no longer coveted by her (Eustacia) rival? She (Eustacia) was, then, secure of him (man) at last. Thomasin no longer required him (man). What a humiliating victory! He (man) loved her (Eustacia) best, she (Eustacia) thought; and yet--dared she (Eustacia) to murmur such treacherous criticism ever so softly?--what was the man worth whom a woman inferior to herself did not value? The sentiment which lurks more or less in all animate nature--that of not desiring the undesired of others--was lively as a passion in the supersubtle, epicurean heart of Eustacia. Her (woman) social superiority over him (man), which hitherto had scarcely ever impressed her (woman), became unpleasantly insistent, and for the first time she (woman) felt that she (woman) had stooped in loving him (man).

``Well, darling, you agree?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

``If it could be London, or even Budmouth, instead of America,'' (she)
she (woman) murmured languidly.
``Well, I will think. It is too great a thing for me to decide offhand. I wish I hated the heath less--or loved you more.'' (unknown)

``You can be painfully frank. You loved me a month ago warmly enough to go anywhere with me.'' (unknown)

``And you loved Thomasin.'' (unknown)

``Yes, perhaps that was where the reason lay,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) returned, with almost a sneer.
``I don't hate her (you) now.'' (unknown)

``Exactly. The only thing is that you can no longer get her (you).'' (unknown)

``Come--no taunts, Eustacia, or we shall quarrel. If you don't agree to go with me, and agree shortly, I shall go by myself.'' (unknown)

``Or try Thomasin again. Damon, how strange it seems that you could have married her (Eustacia) or me indifferently, and only have come to me because I am--cheapest! Yes, yes--it is true. There was a time when I should have exclaimed against a man of that sort, and been quite wild; but it is all past now.'' (unknown)

``Will you go, dearest? Come secretly with me to Bristol, marry me, and turn our backs upon this dog-hole of England for ever? Say Yes.'' (unknown)

``I want to get away from here at almost any cost,'' (she)
she (woman) said with weariness,
``but I don't like to go with you. Give me more time to decide.'' (she)

``I have already,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.
``Well, I give you one more week.'' (unknown)

``A little longer, so that I may tell you decisively. I have to consider so many things. Fancy Thomasin being anxious to get rid of you! I cannot forget it.'' (unknown)

``Never mind that. Say Monday week. I will be here precisely at this time.'' (unknown)

``Let it be at Rainbarrow,'' (she)
said she (woman).
``This is too near home; my grandfather may be walking out.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, dear. On Monday week at this time I will be at the Barrow. Till then good-bye.'' (unknown)

``Good-bye. No, no, you must not touch me now. Shaking hands is enough till I have made up my mind.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia watched his (Wildeve) shadowy form till it had disappeared. She (Eustacia) placed her (Eustacia) hand to her (Eustacia) forehead and breathed heavily; and then her (Eustacia) rich, romantic lips parted under that homely impulse--a yawn. She (Eustacia) was immediately angry at having betrayed even to herself the possible evanescence of her (Eustacia) passion for him (Wildeve). She (Eustacia) could not admit at once that she (Eustacia) might have overestimated Wildeve, for to perceive his (Wildeve) mediocrity now was to admit her (Eustacia) own great folly heretofore. And the discovery that she (Eustacia) was the owner of a disposition so purely that of the dog in the manger had something in it which at first made her (Eustacia) ashamed.

The fruit of Mrs. Yeobright's diplomacy was indeed remarkable, though not as yet of the kind she (Eustacia) had anticipated. It had appreciably influenced Wildeve, but it was influencing Eustacia far more. Her (Eustacia) lover was no longer to her (Eustacia) an exciting man whom many women strove for, and herself could only retain by striving with them. He (man) was a superfluity.

She (Eustacia) went indoors in that peculiar state of misery which is not exactly grief, and which especially attends the dawnings of reason in the latter days of an ill-judged, transient love. To be conscious that the end of the dream is approaching, and yet has not absolutely come, is one of the most wearisome as well as the most curious stages along the course between the beginning of a passion and its end.

Her (Eustacia) grandfather had returned, and was busily engaged in pouring some gallons of newly arrived rum into the square bottles of his (grandfather) square cellaret. Whenever these home supplies were exhausted he (grandfather) would go to the Quiet Woman, and, standing with his (grandfather) back to the fire, grog in hand, tell remarkable stories of how he (grandfather) had lived seven years under the waterline of his (grandfather) ship, and other naval wonders, to the natives, who hoped too earnestly for a treat of ale from the teller to exhibit any doubts of his (teller) truth.

He (teller) had been there this evening.

``I suppose you have heard the Egdon news, Eustacia?'' (he)
he (teller) said, without looking up from the bottles.
``The men have been talking about it at the Woman as if it were of national importance.'' (unknown)

``I have heard none,'' (she)
she (Woman) said.

``Young Clym Yeobright, as they call him (Young), is coming home next week to spend Christmas with his (Young) mother. He (Young) is a fine fellow by this time, it seems. I suppose you remember him (Young)?'' (unknown)

``I never saw him (Young) in my life.'' (unknown)

``Ah, true; he (Young) left before you came here. I well remember him (Young) as a promising boy.'' (unknown)

``Where has he (Young) been living all these years?'' (unknown)

``In that rookery of pomp and vanity, Paris, I believe.'' (the Comer)

BOOK TWO -- THE ARRIVAL

1--Tidings of the Comer

On the fine days at this time of the year, and earlier, certain ephemeral operations were apt to disturb, in their trifling way, the majestic calm of Egdon Heath. They were activities which, beside those of a town, a village, or even a farm, would have appeared as the ferment of stagnation merely, a creeping of the flesh of somnolence. But here, away from comparisons, shut in by the stable hills, among which mere walking had the novelty of pageantry, and where any man could imagine himself to be Adam without the least difficulty, they attracted the attention of every bird within eyeshot, every reptile not yet asleep, and set the surrounding rabbits curiously watching from hillocks at a safe distance.

The performance was that of bringing together and building into a stack the furze faggots which Humphrey had been cutting for the captain's use during the foregoing fine days. The stack was at the end of the dwelling, and the men engaged in building it were Humphrey and Sam, the old man looking on.

It was a fine and quiet afternoon, about three o’clock; but the winter solstice having stealthily come on, the lowness of the sun caused the hour to seem later than it actually was, there being little here to remind an inhabitant that he (inhabitant) must unlearn his (inhabitant) summer experience of the sky as a dial. In the course of many days and weeks sunrise had advanced its quarters from northeast to southeast, sunset had receded from northwest to southwest; but Egdon had hardly heeded the change.

Eustacia was indoors in the dining-room, which was really more like a kitchen, having a stone floor and a gaping chimney-corner. The air was still, and while she (Eustacia) lingered a moment here alone sounds of voices in conversation came to her (Eustacia) ears directly down the chimney. She (Eustacia) entered the recess, and, listening, looked up the old irregular shaft, with its cavernous hollows, where the smoke blundered about on its way to the square bit of sky at the top, from which the daylight struck down with a pallid glare upon the tatters of soot draping the flue as seaweed drapes a rocky fissure.

She (Eustacia) remembered: the furze-stack was not far from the chimney, and the voices were those of the workers.

Her (Eustacia) grandfather joined in the conversation.

``That lad ought never to have left home. His (lad) father's occupation would have suited him (lad) best, and the boy should have followed on. I don't believe in these new moves in families. My father was a sailor, so was I, and so should my son have been if I had had one.'' (unknown)

``The place he (son)'s been living at is Paris,'' (Humphrey)
said Humphrey, ``and they tell me `tis where the king's head was cut off years ago. My poor mother used to tell me about that business. `Hummy,' she (mother) used to say, `I was a young maid then, and as I was at home ironing Mother's caps one afternoon the parson came in and said,
``They've cut the king's head off, Jane; and what `twill be next God knows.''''' (the captain)

``A good many of us knew as well as He (God) before long,'' (the captain)
said the captain, chuckling.
``I lived seven years under water on account of it in my boyhood--in that damned surgery of the Triumph, seeing men brought down to the cockpit with their legs and arms blown to Jericho... And so the young man has settled in Paris. Manager to a diamond merchant, or some such thing, is he (Manager) not?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir, that's it. `Tis a blazing great business that he (Manager) belongs to, so I've heard his (Manager) mother say--like a king's palace, as far as diments go.'' (unknown)

``I can well mind when he (Manager) left home,'' (Sam)
said Sam.

```Tis a good thing for the feller,'' said Humphrey.

``A sight of times better to be selling diments than nobbling about here.'' (unknown)

``It must cost a good few shillings to deal at such a place.'' (unknown)

``A good few indeed, my man,'' (the captain)
replied the captain.
``Yes, you may make away with a deal of money and be neither drunkard nor glutton.'' (unknown)

``They say, too, that Clym Yeobright is become a real perusing man, with the strangest notions about things. There, that's because he (man) went to school early, such as the school was.'' (unknown)

``Strange notions, has he (man)?'' (the man)
said the old man.
``Ah, there's too much of that sending to school in these days! It only does harm. Every gatepost and barn's door you come to is sure to have some bad word or other chalked upon it by the young rascals--a woman can hardly pass for shame sometimes. If they'd never been taught how to write they wouldn't have been able to scribble such villainy. Their fathers couldn't do it, and the country was all the better for it.'' (unknown)

``Now, I should think, Cap’n, that Miss Eustacia had about as much in her (Eustacia) head that comes from books as anybody about here?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps if Miss Eustacia, too, had less romantic nonsense in her (Eustacia) head it would be better for her (Eustacia),'' (the captain)
said the captain shortly; after which he (captain) walked away.

``I say, Sam,'' (Humphrey)
observed Humphrey when the old man was gone,
``she (Eustacia) and Clym Yeobright would make a very pretty pigeon-pair--hey? If they wouldn't I'll be dazed! Both of one mind about niceties for certain, and learned in print, and always thinking about high doctrine--there couldn't be a better couple if they were made o' purpose. Clym's family is as good as hers. His (Sam) father was a farmer, that's true; but his (Sam) mother was a sort of lady, as we know. Nothing would please me better than to see them two man and wife.'' (the man)

``They'd look very natty, arm-in-crook together, and their best clothes on, whether or no, if he (man)'s at all the well-favoured fellow he (man) used to be.'' (unknown)

``They would, Humphrey. Well, I should like to see the chap terrible much after so many years. If I knew for certain when he (chap) was coming I'd stroll out three or four miles to meet him (chap) and help carry anything for’n; though I suppose he (chap)'s altered from the boy he (chap) was. They say he (chap) can talk French as fast as a maid can eat blackberries; and if so, depend upon it we who have stayed at home shall seem no more than scroff in his (chap) eyes.'' (unknown)

``Coming across the water to Budmouth by steamer, isn't he (chap)?'' (unknown)

``Yes; but how he (chap)'s coming from Budmouth I don't know.'' (unknown)

``That's a bad trouble about his (chap) cousin Thomasin. I wonder such a nice-notioned fellow as Clym likes to come home into it. What a nunnywatch we were in, to be sure, when we heard they weren't married at all, after singing to `em as man and wife that night! Be dazed if I should like a relation of mine to have been made such a fool of by a man. It makes the family look small.'' (unknown)

``Yes. Poor maid, her (maid) heart has ached enough about it. Her (maid) health is suffering from it, I hear, for she (maid) will bide entirely indoors. We never see her (maid) out now, scampering over the furze with a face as red as a rose, as she (maid) used to do.'' (unknown)

``I've heard she (maid) wouldn't have Wildeve now if he (Wildeve) asked her (maid).'' (unknown)

``You have? `Tis news to me.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

While the furze-gatherers had desultorily conversed thus Eustacia's face gradually bent to the hearth in a profound reverie, her (Eustacia) toe unconsciously tapping the dry turf which lay burning at her (Eustacia) feet.

The subject of their discourse had been keenly interesting to her (Eustacia). A young and clever man was coming into that lonely heath from, of all contrasting places in the world, Paris. It was like a man coming from heaven. More singular still, the heathmen had instinctively coupled her (Eustacia) and this man together in their minds as a pair born for each other.

That five minutes of overhearing furnished Eustacia with visions enough to fill the whole blank afternoon. Such sudden alternations from mental vacuity do sometimes occur thus quietly. She (Eustacia) could never have believed in the morning that her (Eustacia) colourless inner world would before night become as animated as water under a microscope, and that without the arrival of a single visitor. The words of Sam and Humphrey on the harmony between the unknown and herself had on her (Eustacia) mind the effect of the invading Bard's prelude in the Castle of Indolence, at which myriads of imprisoned shapes arose where had previously appeared the stillness of a void.

Involved in these imaginings she (Eustacia) knew nothing of time. When she (Eustacia) became conscious of externals it was dusk. The furze-rick was finished; the men had gone home. Eustacia went upstairs, thinking that she (Eustacia) would take a walk at this her (Eustacia) usual time; and she (Eustacia) determined that her (Eustacia) walk should be in the direction of Blooms-End, the birthplace of young Yeobright and the present home of his (Bard) mother. She (mother) had no reason for walking elsewhere, and why should she (mother) not go that way? The scene of the daydream is sufficient for a pilgrimage at nineteen. To look at the palings before the Yeobrights' house had the dignity of a necessary performance. Strange that such a piece of idling should have seemed an important errand.

She (mother) put on her (mother) bonnet, and, leaving the house, descended the hill on the side towards Blooms-End, where she (mother) walked slowly along the valley for a distance of a mile and a half. This brought her (mother) to a spot in which the green bottom of the dale began to widen, the furze bushes to recede yet further from the path on each side, till they were diminished to an isolated one here and there by the increasing fertility of the soil. Beyond the irregular carpet of grass was a row of white palings, which marked the verge of the heath in this latitude. They showed upon the dusky scene that they bordered as distinctly as white lace on velvet. Behind the white palings was a little garden; behind the garden an old, irregular, thatched house, facing the heath, and commanding a full view of the valley. This was the obscure, removed spot to which was about to return a man whose latter life had been passed in the French capital--the centre and vortex of the fashionable world.

2--The People at Blooms-End Make Ready

All that afternoon the expected arrival of the subject of Eustacia's ruminations created a bustle of preparation at Blooms-End. Thomasin had been persuaded by her (Eustacia) aunt, and by an instinctive impulse of loyalty towards her (Eustacia) cousin Clym, to bestir herself on his (cousin) account with an alacrity unusual in her (Eustacia) during these most sorrowful days of her (Eustacia) life. At the time that Eustacia was listening to the rick-makers' conversation on Clym's return, Thomasin was climbing into a loft over her (Eustacia) aunt's fuelhouse, where the store-apples were kept, to search out the best and largest of them for the coming holiday-time.

The loft was lighted by a semicircular hole, through which the pigeons crept to their lodgings in the same high quarters of the premises; and from this hole the sun shone in a bright yellow patch upon the figure of the maiden as she (Eustacia) knelt and plunged her (Eustacia) naked arms into the soft brown fern, which, from its abundance, was used on Egdon in packing away stores of all kinds. The pigeons were flying about her (Eustacia) head with the greatest unconcern, and the face of her (Eustacia) aunt was just visible above the floor of the loft, lit by a few stray motes of light, as she (Eustacia) stood halfway up the ladder, looking at a spot into which she (Eustacia) was not climber enough to venture.

``Now a few russets, Tamsin. He (Wildeve) used to like them almost as well as ribstones.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin turned and rolled aside the fern from another nook, where more mellow fruit greeted her (Eustacia) with its ripe smell. Before picking them out she (Eustacia) stopped a moment.

``Dear Clym, I wonder how your face looks now?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, gazing abstractedly at the pigeon-hole, which admitted the sunlight so directly upon her (Eustacia) brown hair and transparent tissues that it almost seemed to shine through her (Eustacia).

``If he (Wildeve) could have been dear to you in another way,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright from the ladder,
``this might have been a happy meeting.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

``Is there any use in saying what can do no good, Aunt?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (aunt)
said her (Yeobright) aunt, with some warmth.
