She (Eustacia) threw off her (Eustacia) trappings in the outhouse, rolled them up, and went indoors to her (Eustacia) chamber.

7--A Coalition between Beauty and Oddness

The old captain's prevailing indifference to his (captain) granddaughter's movements left her (granddaughter) free as a bird to follow her (granddaughter) own courses; but it so happened that he (captain) did take upon himself the next morning to ask her (granddaughter) why she (granddaughter) had walked out so late.

``Only in search of events, Grandfather,'' (she)
she (granddaughter) said, looking out of the window with that drowsy latency of manner which discovered so much force behind it whenever the trigger was pressed.

``Search of events--one would think you were one of the bucks I knew at one-and-twenty.'' (unknown)

``It is lonely here.'' (unknown)

``So much the better. If I were living in a town my whole time would be taken up in looking after you. I fully expected you would have been home when I returned from the Woman.'' (unknown)

``I won't conceal what I did. I wanted an adventure, and I went with the mummers. I played the part of the Turkish Knight.'' (unknown)

``No, never? Ha, ha! Good gad! I didn't expect it of you, Eustacia.'' (unknown)

``It was my first performance, and it certainly will be my last. Now I have told you--and remember it is a secret.'' (unknown)

``Of course. But, Eustacia, you never did--ha! ha! Dammy, how `twould have pleased me forty years ago! But remember, no more of it, my girl. You may walk on the heath night or day, as you choose, so that you don't bother me; but no figuring in breeches again.'' (unknown)

``You need have no fear for me, Grandpapa.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Here the conversation ceased, Eustacia's moral training never exceeding in severity a dialogue of this sort, which, if it ever became profitable to good works, would be a result not dear at the price. But her (Eustacia) thoughts soon strayed far from her (Eustacia) own personality; and, full of a passionate and indescribable solicitude for one to whom she (Eustacia) was not even a name, she (Eustacia) went forth into the amplitude of tanned wild around her (Eustacia), restless as Ahasuerus the Jew. She (Eustacia) was about half a mile from her (Eustacia) residence when she (Eustacia) beheld a sinister redness arising from a ravine a little way in advance--dull and lurid like a flame in sunlight and she (Eustacia) guessed it to signify Diggory Venn.

When the farmers who had wished to buy in a new stock of reddle during the last month had inquired where Venn was to be found, people replied,

``On Egdon Heath.'' (people)
Day after day the answer was the same. Now, since Egdon was populated with heath-croppers and furze-cutters rather than with sheep and shepherds, and the downs where most of the latter were to be found lay some to the north, some to the west of Egdon, his (Egdon) reason for camping about there like Israel in Zin was not apparent. The position was central and occasionally desirable. But the sale of reddle was not Diggory's primary object in remaining on the heath, particularly at so late a period of the year, when most travellers of his (Diggory) class had gone into winter quarters.

Eustacia looked at the lonely man. Wildeve had told her (Eustacia) at their last meeting that Venn had been thrust forward by Mrs. Yeobright as one ready and anxious to take his (Venn) place as Thomasin's betrothed. His (Venn) figure was perfect, his (Venn) face young and well outlined, his (Venn) eye bright, his (Venn) intelligence keen, and his (Venn) position one which he (Venn) could readily better if he (Venn) chose. But in spite of possibilities it was not likely that Thomasin would accept this Ishmaelitish creature while she (Yeobright) had a cousin like Yeobright at her (Yeobright) elbow, and Wildeve at the same time not absolutely indifferent. Eustacia was not long in guessing that poor Mrs. Yeobright, in her (Yeobright) anxiety for her (Yeobright) niece's future, had mentioned this lover to stimulate the zeal of the other. Eustacia was on the side of the Yeobrights now, and entered into the spirit of the aunt's desire.

``Good morning, miss,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman, taking off his (lover) cap of hareskin, and apparently bearing her (Eustacia) no ill-will from recollection of their last meeting.

``Good morning, reddleman,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, hardly troubling to lift her (Eustacia) heavily shaded eyes to his (lover).
``I did not know you were so near. Is your van here too?'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn moved his (Venn) elbow towards a hollow in which a dense brake of purple-stemmed brambles had grown to such vast dimensions as almost to form a dell. Brambles, though churlish when handled, are kindly shelter in early winter, being the latest of the deciduous bushes to lose their leaves.

The roof and chimney of Venn's caravan showed behind the tracery and tangles of the brake.

``You remain near this part?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) asked with more interest.

``Yes, I have business here.'' (unknown)

``Not altogether the selling of reddle?'' (unknown)

``It has nothing to do with that.'' (unknown)

``It has to do with Miss Yeobright?'' (he)

Her (Eustacia) face seemed to ask for an armed peace, and he (Venn) therefore said frankly,

``Yes, miss; it is on account of her (Yeobright).'' (he)

``On account of your approaching marriage with her (Yeobright)?'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn flushed through his (Venn) stain.

``Don't make sport of me, Miss Vye,'' (he)
he (Venn) said.

``It isn't true?'' (unknown)

``Certainly not.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) was thus convinced that the reddleman was a mere pis aller in Mrs. Yeobright's mind; one, moreover, who had not even been informed of his (Venn) promotion to that lowly standing.

``It was a mere notion of mine,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) said quietly; and was about to pass by without further speech, when, looking round to the right, she (Yeobright) saw a painfully well-known figure serpentining upwards by one of the little paths which led to the top where she (Yeobright) stood. Owing to the necessary windings of his (Venn) course his (Venn) back was at present towards them. She (Yeobright) glanced quickly round; to escape that man there was only one way. Turning to Venn, she (Yeobright) said,
``Would you allow me to rest a few minutes in your van? The banks are damp for sitting on.'' (she)

``Certainly, miss; I'll make a place for you.'' (She)

She (Yeobright) followed him (Venn) behind the dell of brambles to his (Venn) wheeled dwelling into which Venn mounted, placing the three-legged stool just within the door.

``That is the best I can do for you,'' (he)
he (Venn) said, stepping down and retiring to the path, where he (Venn) resumed the smoking of his (Venn) pipe as he (Venn) walked up and down.

Eustacia bounded into the vehicle and sat on the stool, ensconced from view on the side towards the trackway. Soon she (Eustacia) heard the brushing of other feet than the reddleman's, a not very friendly

``Good day'' (the reddleman a)
uttered by two men in passing each other, and then the dwindling of the foot-fall of one of them in a direction onwards. Eustacia stretched her (Eustacia) neck forward till she (Eustacia) caught a glimpse of a receding back and shoulders; and she (Eustacia) felt a wretched twinge of misery, she (Eustacia) knew not why. It was the sickening feeling which, if the changed heart has any generosity at all in its composition, accompanies the sudden sight of a once-loved one who is beloved no more.

When Eustacia descended to proceed on her (Eustacia) way the reddleman came near.

``That was Mr. Wildeve who passed, miss,'' (he)
he (Eustacia) said slowly, and expressed by his (Eustacia) face that he (Eustacia) expected her (Eustacia) to feel vexed at having been sitting unseen.

``Yes, I saw him (Wildeve) coming up the hill,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
replied Eustacia.
``Why should you tell me that?'' (the reddleman)
It was a bold question, considering the reddleman's knowledge of her (Eustacia) past love; but her (Eustacia) undemonstrative manner had power to repress the opinions of those she (Eustacia) treated as remote from her (Eustacia).

``I am glad to hear that you can ask it,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman bluntly.
``And, now I think of it, it agrees with what I saw last night.'' (unknown)

``Ah--what was that?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
Eustacia wished to leave him (Eustacia), but wished to know.

``Mr. Wildeve stayed at Rainbarrow a long time waiting for a lady who didn't come.'' (unknown)

``You waited too, it seems?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I always do. I was glad to see him (Wildeve) disappointed. He (Wildeve) will be there again tonight.'' (unknown)

``To be again disappointed. The truth is, reddleman, that that lady, so far from wishing to stand in the way of Thomasin's marriage with Mr. Wildeve, would be very glad to promote it.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn felt much astonishment at this avowal, though he (Venn) did not show it clearly; that exhibition may greet remarks which are one remove from expectation, but it is usually withheld in complicated cases of two removes and upwards.

``Indeed, miss,'' (he)
he (Venn) replied.

``How do you know that Mr. Wildeve will come to Rainbarrow again tonight?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) asked.

``I heard him (Wildeve) say to himself that he (Wildeve) would. He (Wildeve)'s in a regular temper.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia looked for a moment what she (Eustacia) felt, and she (Eustacia) murmured, lifting her (Eustacia) deep dark eyes anxiously to his (Venn),

``I wish I knew what to do. I don't want to be uncivil to him (Wildeve); but I don't wish to see him (Wildeve) again; and I have some few little things to return to him (Wildeve).'' (she)

``If you choose to send `em by me, miss, and a note to tell him (Wildeve) that you wish to say no more to him (Wildeve), I'll take it for you quite privately. That would be the most straightforward way of letting him (Wildeve) know your mind.'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.
``Come towards my house, and I will bring it out to you.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) went on, and as the path was an infinitely small parting in the shaggy locks of the heath, the reddleman followed exactly in her (Eustacia) trail. She (Eustacia) saw from a distance that the captain was on the bank sweeping the horizon with his (captain) telescope; and bidding Venn to wait where he (Venn) stood she (Eustacia) entered the house alone.

In ten minutes she (Eustacia) returned with a parcel and a note, and said, in placing them in his (Venn) hand,

``Why are you so ready to take these for me?'' (she)

``Can you ask that?'' (unknown)

``I suppose you think to serve Thomasin in some way by it. Are you as anxious as ever to help on her (Wildeve) marriage?'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn was a little moved.

``I would sooner have married her (Wildeve) myself,'' (he)
he (Venn) said in a low voice.
``But what I feel is that if she (Wildeve) cannot be happy without him (Wildeve) I will do my duty in helping her (Wildeve) to get him (Wildeve), as a man ought.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia looked curiously at the singular man who spoke thus. What a strange sort of love, to be entirely free from that quality of selfishness which is frequently the chief constituent of the passion, and sometimes its only one! The reddleman's disinterestedness was so well deserving of respect that it overshot respect by being barely comprehended; and she (Eustacia) almost thought it absurd.

``Then we are both of one mind at last,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.

``Yes,'' (unknown)
replied Venn gloomily.
``But if you would tell me, miss, why you take such an interest in her (Wildeve), I should be easier. It is so sudden and strange.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia appeared at a loss.

``I cannot tell you that, reddleman,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said coldly.

Venn said no more. He (Venn) pocketed the letter, and, bowing to Eustacia, went away.

Rainbarrow had again become blended with night when Wildeve ascended the long acclivity at its base. On his (Wildeve) reaching the top a shape grew up from the earth immediately behind him (Wildeve). It was that of Eustacia's emissary. He (Wildeve) slapped Wildeve on the shoulder. The feverish young inn-keeper and ex-engineer started like Satan at the touch of Ithuriel's spear.

``The meeting is always at eight o’clock, at this place,'' (unknown)
said Venn,
``and here we are--we three.'' (unknown)

``We three?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve, looking quickly round.

``Yes; you, and I, and she (Wildeve). This is she (Wildeve).'' (He)
He (Wildeve) held up the letter and parcel.

Wildeve took them wonderingly.

``I don't quite see what this means,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.
``How do you come here? There must be some mistake.'' (unknown)

``It will be cleared from your mind when you have read the letter. Lanterns for one.'' (The reddleman)
The reddleman struck a light, kindled an inch of tallow-candle which he (Wildeve) had brought, and sheltered it with his (Wildeve) cap.

``Who are you?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve, discerning by the candle-light an obscure rubicundity of person in his (Wildeve) companion.
``You are the reddleman I saw on the hill this morning--why, you are the man who--'' (unknown)

``Please read the letter.'' (unknown)

``If you had come from the other one I shouldn't have been surprised,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
murmured Wildeve as he (Wildeve) opened the letter and read. His (Wildeve) face grew serious.

TO MR. WILDEVE.

After some thought I have decided once and for all that we must hold no further communication. The more I consider the matter the more I am convinced that there must be an end to our acquaintance. Had you been uniformly faithful to me throughout these two years you might now have some ground for accusing me of heartlessness; but if you calmly consider what I bore during the period of your desertion, and how I passively put up with your courtship of another without once interfering, you will, I think, own that I have a right to consult my own feelings when you come back to me again. That these are not what they were towards you may, perhaps, be a fault in me, but it is one which you can scarcely reproach me for when you remember how you left me for Thomasin.

The little articles you gave me in the early part of our friendship are returned by the bearer of this letter. They should rightly have been sent back when I first heard of your engagement to her (you).

EUSTACIA.

By the time that Wildeve reached her (EUSTACIA) name the blankness with which he (Wildeve) had read the first half of the letter intensified to mortification.

``I am made a great fool of, one way and another,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said pettishly.
``Do you know what is in this letter?'' (The reddleman)

The reddleman hummed a tune.

``Can't you answer me?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
asked Wildeve warmly.

``Ru-um-tum-tum,'' (the reddleman)
sang the reddleman.

Wildeve stood looking on the ground beside Venn's feet, till he (Wildeve) allowed his (Wildeve) eyes to travel upwards over Diggory's form, as illuminated by the candle, to his (Wildeve) head and face.

``Ha-ha! Well, I suppose I deserve it, considering how I have played with them both,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said at last, as much to himself as to Venn.
``But of all the odd things that ever I knew, the oddest is that you should so run counter to your own interests as to bring this to me.'' (unknown)

``My interests?'' (unknown)

``Certainly. `Twas your interest not to do anything which would send me courting Thomasin again, now she (My) has accepted you--or something like it. Mrs. Yeobright says you are to marry her (Yeobright). `Tisn't true, then?'' (unknown)

``Good Lord! I heard of this before, but didn't believe it. When did she (Yeobright) say so?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve began humming as the reddleman had done.

``I don't believe it now,'' (unknown)
cried Venn.

``Ru-um-tum-tum,'' (unknown)
sang Wildeve.

``O Lord--how we can imitate!'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn contemptuously.
``I'll have this out. I'll go straight to her (Yeobright).'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Diggory withdrew with an emphatic step, Wildeve's eye passing over his (Wildeve) form in withering derision, as if he (Wildeve) were no more than a heath-cropper. When the reddleman's figure could no longer be seen, Wildeve himself descended and plunged into the rayless hollow of the vale.

To lose the two women--he (Wildeve) who had been the well-beloved of both--was too ironical an issue to be endured. He (Wildeve) could only decently save himself by Thomasin; and once he (Wildeve) became her (himself) husband, Eustacia's repentance, he (Wildeve) thought, would set in for a long and bitter term. It was no wonder that Wildeve, ignorant of the new man at the back of the scene, should have supposed Eustacia to be playing a part. To believe that the letter was not the result of some momentary pique, to infer that she (Eustacia) really gave him (Wildeve) up to Thomasin, would have required previous knowledge of her (Eustacia) transfiguration by that man's influence. Who was to know that she (Eustacia) had grown generous in the greediness of a new passion, that in coveting one cousin she (Eustacia) was dealing liberally with another, that in her (Eustacia) eagerness to appropriate she (Eustacia) gave way?

Full of this resolve to marry in haste, and wring the heart of the proud girl, Wildeve went his (Wildeve) way.

Meanwhile Diggory Venn had returned to his (Venn) van, where he (Venn) stood looking thoughtfully into the stove. A new vista was opened up to him (Venn). But, however promising Mrs. Yeobright's views of him (Venn) might be as a candidate for her (Yeobright) niece's hand, one condition was indispensable to the favour of Thomasin herself, and that was a renunciation of his (Venn) present wild mode of life. In this he (Venn) saw little difficulty.

He (Venn) could not afford to wait till the next day before seeing Thomasin and detailing his (Venn) plan. He (Venn) speedily plunged himself into toilet operations, pulled a suit of cloth clothes from a box, and in about twenty minutes stood before the van-lantern as a reddleman in nothing but his (Venn) face, the vermilion shades of which were not to be removed in a day. Closing the door and fastening it with a padlock, Venn set off towards Blooms-End.

He (Venn) had reached the white palings and laid his (Venn) hand upon the gate when the door of the house opened, and quickly closed again. A female form had glided in. At the same time a man, who had seemingly been standing with the woman in the porch, came forward from the house till he (man) was face to face with Venn. It was Wildeve again.

``Man alive, you've been quick at it,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Diggory sarcastically.

``And you slow, as you will find,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.
``And,'' (unknown)
lowering his (Wildeve) voice,
``you may as well go back again now. I've claimed her (Yeobright), and got her (Yeobright). Good night, reddleman!'' (unknown)
Thereupon Wildeve walked away.

Venn's heart sank within him (Venn), though it had not risen unduly high. He (Venn) stood leaning over the palings in an indecisive mood for nearly a quarter of an hour. Then he (Venn) went up the garden path, knocked, and asked for Mrs. Yeobright.

Instead of requesting him (Venn) to enter she (Yeobright) came to the porch. A discourse was carried on between them in low measured tones for the space of ten minutes or more. At the end of the time Mrs. Yeobright went in, and Venn sadly retraced his (Venn) steps into the heath. When he (Venn) had again regained his (Venn) van he (Venn) lit the lantern, and with an apathetic face at once began to pull off his (Venn) best clothes, till in the course of a few minutes he (Venn) reappeared as the confirmed and irretrievable reddleman that he (Venn) had seemed before.

8--Firmness Is Discovered in a Gentle Heart

On that evening the interior of Blooms-End, though cosy and comfortable, had been rather silent. Clym Yeobright was not at home. Since the Christmas party he (Venn) had gone on a few days' visit to a friend about ten miles off.

The shadowy form seen by Venn to part from Wildeve in the porch, and quickly withdraw into the house, was Thomasin's. On entering she (Thomasin) threw down a cloak which had been carelessly wrapped round her (Thomasin), and came forward to the light, where Mrs. Yeobright sat at her (Yeobright) work-table, drawn up within the settle, so that part of it projected into the chimney-corner.

``I don't like your going out after dark alone, Tamsin,'' (aunt)
said her (Yeobright) aunt quietly, without looking up from her (Yeobright) work.

``I have only been just outside the door.'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
inquired Mrs. Yeobright, struck by a change in the tone of Thomasin's voice, and observing her (Yeobright). Thomasin's cheek was flushed to a pitch far beyond that which it had reached before her (Yeobright) troubles, and her (Yeobright) eyes glittered.

``It was HE (Man) who knocked,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) said.

``I thought as much.'' (unknown)

``He (Man) wishes the marriage to be at once.'' (unknown)

``Indeed! What--is he (Man) anxious?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
Mrs. Yeobright directed a searching look upon her (Yeobright) niece.
``Why did not Mr. Wildeve come in?'' (unknown)

``He (Wildeve) did not wish to. You are not friends with him (Wildeve), he (Wildeve) says. He (Wildeve) would like the wedding to be the day after tomorrow, quite privately; at the church of his (Wildeve) parish--not at ours.'' (unknown)

``Oh! And what did you say?'' (unknown)

``I agreed to it,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
Thomasin answered firmly.
``I am a practical woman now. I don't believe in hearts at all. I would marry him (Wildeve) under any circumstances since--since Clym's letter.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

A letter was lying on Mrs. Yeobright's work-basket, and at Thomasin's words her (Yeobright) aunt reopened it, and silently read for the tenth time that day:--

What is the meaning of this silly story that people are circulating about Thomasin and Mr. Wildeve? I should call such a scandal humiliating if there was the least chance of its being true. How could such a gross falsehood have arisen? It is said that one should go abroad to hear news of home, and I appear to have done it. Of course I contradict the tale everywhere; but it is very vexing, and I wonder how it could have originated. It is too ridiculous that such a girl as Thomasin could so mortify us as to get jilted on the wedding day. What has she (girl) done?

``Yes,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
Mrs. Yeobright said sadly, putting down the letter.
``If you think you can marry him (Wildeve), do so. And since Mr. Wildeve wishes it to be unceremonious, let it be that too. I can do nothing. It is all in your own hands now. My power over your welfare came to an end when you left this house to go with him (Wildeve) to Anglebury.'' (She)
She (Yeobright) continued, half in bitterness,
``I may almost ask, why do you consult me in the matter at all? If you had gone and married him (Wildeve) without saying a word to me, I could hardly have been angry--simply because, poor girl, you can't do a better thing.'' (She)

``Don't say that and dishearten me.'' (unknown)

``You are right--I will not.'' (unknown)

``I do not plead for him (Wildeve), Aunt. Human nature is weak, and I am not a blind woman to insist that he (Wildeve) is perfect. I did think so, but I don't now. But I know my course, and you know that I know it. I hope for the best.'' (unknown)

``And so do I, and we will both continue to,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright, rising and kissing her (Yeobright).
``Then the wedding, if it comes off, will be on the morning of the very day Clym comes home?'' (unknown)

``Yes. I decided that it ought to be over before he (Wildeve) came. After that you can look him (Wildeve) in the face, and so can I. Our concealments will matter nothing.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright moved her (Yeobright) head in thoughtful assent, and presently said,

``Do you wish me to give you away? I am willing to undertake that, you know, if you wish, as I was last time. After once forbidding the banns I think I can do no less.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

``I don't think I will ask you to come,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin reluctantly, but with decision.
``It would be unpleasant, I am almost sure. Better let there be only strangers present, and none of my relations at all. I would rather have it so. I do not wish to do anything which may touch your credit, and I feel that I should be uncomfortable if you were there, after what has passed. I am only your niece, and there is no necessity why you should concern yourself more about me.'' (unknown)

``Well, he (I) has beaten us,'' (aunt)
her (Yeobright) aunt said.
``It really seems as if he (I) had been playing with you in this way in revenge for my humbling him (I) as I did by standing up against him (I) at first.'' (unknown)

``O no, Aunt,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
murmured Thomasin.

They said no more on the subject then. Diggory Venn's knock came soon after; and Mrs. Yeobright, on returning from her (Yeobright) interview with him (Venn) in the porch, carelessly observed,

``Another lover has come to ask for you.'' (him)

``No?'' (unknown)

``Yes, that queer young man Venn.'' (unknown)

``Asks to pay his (man) addresses to me?'' (unknown)

``Yes; and I told him (man) he (man) was too late.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin looked silently into the candle-flame.

``Poor Diggory!'' (she)
she (Yeobright) said, and then aroused herself to other things.

The next day was passed in mere mechanical deeds of preparation, both the women being anxious to immerse themselves in these to escape the emotional aspect of the situation. Some wearing apparel and other articles were collected anew for Thomasin, and remarks on domestic details were frequently made, so as to obscure any inner misgivings about her (Yeobright) future as Wildeve's wife.

The appointed morning came. The arrangement with Wildeve was that he (Wildeve) should meet her (Yeobright) at the church to guard against any unpleasant curiosity which might have affected them had they been seen walking off together in the usual country way.

Aunt and niece stood together in the bedroom where the bride was dressing. The sun, where it could catch it, made a mirror of Thomasin's hair, which she (bride) always wore braided. It was braided according to a calendar system--the more important the day the more numerous the strands in the braid. On ordinary working-days she (bride) braided it in threes; on ordinary Sundays in fours; at Maypolings, gipsyings, and the like, she (bride) braided it in fives. Years ago she (bride) had said that when she (bride) married she (bride) would braid it in sevens. She (bride) had braided it in sevens today.

``I have been thinking that I will wear my blue silk after all,'' (she)
she (bride) said.
``It is my wedding day, even though there may be something sad about the time. I mean,'' (she)
she (bride) added, anxious to correct any wrong impression,
``not sad in itself, but in its having had great disappointment and trouble before it.'' (she)

Mrs. Yeobright breathed in a way which might have been called a sigh.

``I almost wish Clym had been at home,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) said.
``Of course you chose the time because of his (Diggory) absence.'' (unknown)

``Partly. I have felt that I acted unfairly to him (Diggory) in not telling him (Diggory) all; but, as it was done not to grieve him (Diggory), I thought I would carry out the plan to its end, and tell the whole story when the sky was clear.'' (unknown)

``You are a practical little woman,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright, smiling.
``I wish you and he (Diggory)--no, I don't wish anything. There, it is nine o’clock,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) interrupted, hearing a whizz and a dinging downstairs.

``I told Damon I would leave at nine,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin, hastening out of the room.

Her (Yeobright) aunt followed. When Thomasin was going up the little walk from the door to the wicket-gate, Mrs. Yeobright looked reluctantly at her (Yeobright), and said,

``It is a shame to let you go alone.'' (her)

``It is necessary,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin.

``At any rate,'' (aunt)
added her (Yeobright) aunt with forced cheerfulness,
``I shall call upon you this afternoon, and bring the cake with me. If Clym has returned by that time he (Damon) will perhaps come too. I wish to show Mr. Wildeve that I bear him (Wildeve) no ill-will. Let the past be forgotten. Well, God bless you! There, I don't believe in old superstitions, but I'll do it.'' (aunt)
She (Yeobright) threw a slipper at the retreating figure of the girl, who turned, smiled, and went on again.

A few steps further, and she (Yeobright) looked back.

``Did you call me, Aunt?'' (she)
she (Yeobright) tremulously inquired.
``Good-bye!'' (she)

Moved by an uncontrollable feeling as she (Yeobright) looked upon Mrs. Yeobright's worn, wet face, she (Yeobright) ran back, when her (Yeobright) aunt came forward, and they met again.

``O--Tamsie,'' (unknown)
said the elder, weeping,
``I don't like to let you go.'' (unknown)

``I--I am--'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
Thomasin began, giving way likewise. But, quelling her (Yeobright) grief, she (Yeobright) said
``Good-bye!'' (she)
again and went on.

Then Mrs. Yeobright saw a little figure wending its way between the scratching furze-bushes, and diminishing far up the valley--a pale-blue spot in a vast field of neutral brown, solitary and undefended except by the power of her (Yeobright) own hope.

But the worst feature in the case was one which did not appear in the landscape; it was the man.

The hour chosen for the ceremony by Thomasin and Wildeve had been so timed as to enable her (Yeobright) to escape the awkwardness of meeting her (Yeobright) cousin Clym, who was returning the same morning. To own to the partial truth of what he (cousin) had heard would be distressing as long as the humiliating position resulting from the event was unimproved. It was only after a second and successful journey to the altar that she (Yeobright) could lift up her (Yeobright) head and prove the failure of the first attempt a pure accident.

She (Yeobright) had not been gone from Blooms-End more than half an hour when Yeobright came by the meads from the other direction and entered the house.

``I had an early breakfast,'' (he)
he (cousin) said to his (cousin) mother after greeting her (mother).
``Now I could eat a little more.'' (he)

They sat down to the repeated meal, and he (cousin) went on in a low, anxious voice, apparently imagining that Thomasin had not yet come downstairs,

``What's this I have heard about Thomasin and Mr. Wildeve?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

``It is true in many points,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright quietly;
``but it is all right now, I hope.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
She (Yeobright) looked at the clock.

``True?'' (unknown)

``Thomasin is gone to him (Wildeve) today.'' (unknown)

Clym pushed away his (cousin) breakfast.

``Then there is a scandal of some sort, and that's what's the matter with Thomasin. Was it this that made her (it) ill?'' (unknown)

``Yes. Not a scandal--a misfortune. I will tell you all about it, Clym. You must not be angry, but you must listen, and you'll find that what we have done has been done for the best.'' (She)

She (Yeobright) then told him (cousin) the circumstances. All that he (cousin) had known of the affair before he (cousin) returned from Paris was that there had existed an attachment between Thomasin and Wildeve, which his (Wildeve) mother had at first discountenanced, but had since, owing to the arguments of Thomasin, looked upon in a little more favourable light. When she (mother), therefore, proceeded to explain all he (Wildeve) was greatly surprised and troubled.

``And she (it) determined that the wedding should be over before you came back,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright,
``that there might be no chance of her (it) meeting you, and having a very painful time of it. That's why she (it) has gone to him (I); they have arranged to be married this morning.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

``But I can't understand it,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright, rising. ```Tis so unlike her (Yeobright). I can see why you did not write to me after her (Yeobright) unfortunate return home. But why didn't you let me know when the wedding was going to be--the first time?''

``Well, I felt vexed with her (it) just then. She (it) seemed to me to be obstinate; and when I found that you were nothing in her (it) mind I vowed that she (it) should be nothing in yours. I felt that she (it) was only my niece after all; I told her (it) she (it) might marry, but that I should take no interest in it, and should not bother you about it either.'' (unknown)

``It wouldn't have been bothering me. Mother, you did wrong.'' (unknown)

``I thought it might disturb you in your business, and that you might throw up your situation, or injure your prospects in some way because of it, so I said nothing. Of course, if they had married at that time in a proper manner, I should have told you at once.'' (unknown)

``Tamsin actually being married while we are sitting here!'' (unknown)

``Yes. Unless some accident happens again, as it did the first time. It may, considering he (you)'s the same man.'' (unknown)

``Yes, and I believe it will. Was it right to let her (It) go? Suppose Wildeve is really a bad fellow?'' (unknown)

``Then he (fellow) won't come, and she (It)'ll come home again.'' (unknown)

``You should have looked more into it.'' (unknown)

``It is useless to say that,'' (mother)
his (Wildeve) mother answered with an impatient look of sorrow.
``You don't know how bad it has been here with us all these weeks, Clym. You don't know what a mortification anything of that sort is to a woman. You don't know the sleepless nights we've had in this house, and the almost bitter words that have passed between us since that Fifth of November. I hope never to pass seven such weeks again. Tamsin has not gone outside the door, and I have been ashamed to look anybody in the face; and now you blame me for letting her (woman) do the only thing that can be done to set that trouble straight.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said slowly.
``Upon the whole I don't blame you. But just consider how sudden it seems to me. Here was I, knowing nothing; and then I am told all at once that Tamsie is gone to be married. Well, I suppose there was nothing better to do. Do you know, Mother,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) continued after a moment or two, looking suddenly interested in his (Wildeve) own past history,
``I once thought of Tamsin as a sweetheart? Yes, I did. How odd boys are! And when I came home and saw her (Mother) this time she (Mother) seemed so much more affectionate than usual, that I was quite reminded of those days, particularly on the night of the party, when she (Mother) was unwell. We had the party just the same--was not that rather cruel to her (Mother)?'' (he)

``It made no difference. I had arranged to give one, and it was not worth while to make more gloom than necessary. To begin by shutting ourselves up and telling you of Tamsin's misfortunes would have been a poor sort of welcome.'' (unknown)

Clym remained thinking.

``I almost wish you had not had that party,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said;
``and for other reasons. But I will tell you in a day or two. We must think of Tamsin now.'' (he)

They lapsed into silence.

``I'll tell you what,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright again, in a tone which showed some slumbering feeling still.
``I don't think it kind to Tamsin to let her (Tamsin) be married like this, and neither of us there to keep up her (Tamsin) spirits or care a bit about her (Tamsin). She (Tamsin) hasn't disgraced herself, or done anything to deserve that. It is bad enough that the wedding should be so hurried and unceremonious, without our keeping away from it in addition. Upon my soul, `tis almost a shame. I'll go.'' (unknown)

``It is over by this time,'' (mother)
said his (Wildeve) mother with a sigh;
``unless they were late, or he (Tamsin)--'' (mother)

``Then I shall be soon enough to see them come out. I don't quite like your keeping me in ignorance, Mother, after all. Really, I half hope he (Tamsin) has failed to meet her (Mother)!'' (mother)

``And ruined her (Mother) character?'' (unknown)

``Nonsense--that wouldn't ruin Thomasin.'' (He)

He (Wildeve) took up his (Wildeve) hat and hastily left the house. Mrs. Yeobright looked rather unhappy, and sat still, deep in thought. But she (Yeobright) was not long left alone. A few minutes later Clym came back again, and in his (Wildeve) company came Diggory Venn.

``I find there isn't time for me to get there,'' (unknown)
said Clym.

``Is she (Mother) married?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
Mrs. Yeobright inquired, turning to the reddleman a face in which a strange strife of wishes, for and against, was apparent.

Venn bowed.

``She (Mother) is, ma’am.'' (unknown)

``How strange it sounds,'' (unknown)
murmured Clym.

``And he (Tamsin) didn't disappoint her (Mother) this time?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright.

``He (Tamsin) did not. And there is now no slight on her (Mother) name. I was hastening ath'art to tell you at once, as I saw you were not there.'' (unknown)

``How came you to be there? How did you know it?'' (she)
she (Yeobright) asked.

``I have been in that neighbourhood for some time, and I saw them go in,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman.
``Wildeve came up to the door, punctual as the clock. I didn't expect it of him (Tamsin).'' (He)
He (Venn) did not add, as he (Venn) might have added, that how he (Venn) came to be in that neighbourhood was not by accident; that, since Wildeve's resumption of his (Wildeve) right to Thomasin, Venn, with the thoroughness which was part of his (Wildeve) character, had determined to see the end of the episode.

``Who was there?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright.

``Nobody hardly. I stood right out of the way, and she (Mother) did not see me.'' (The reddleman)
The reddleman spoke huskily, and looked into the garden.

``Who gave her (Mother) away?'' (unknown)

``Miss Vye.'' (unknown)

``How very remarkable! Miss Vye! It is to be considered an honour, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``Who's Miss Vye?'' (unknown)
said Clym.

``Captain Vye's granddaughter, of Mistover Knap.'' (unknown)

``A proud girl from Budmouth,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright.
``One not much to my liking. People say she (girl)'s a witch, but of course that's absurd.'' (The reddleman)

The reddleman kept to himself his (Wildeve) acquaintance with that fair personage, and also that Eustacia was there because he (Wildeve) went to fetch her (Eustacia), in accordance with a promise he (Wildeve) had given as soon as he (Wildeve) learnt that the marriage was to take place. He (Wildeve) merely said, in continuation of the story--

``I was sitting on the churchyard wall when they came up, one from one way, the other from the other; and Miss Vye was walking thereabouts, looking at the headstones. As soon as they had gone in I went to the door, feeling I should like to see it, as I knew her (girl) so well. I pulled off my boots because they were so noisy, and went up into the gallery. I saw then that the parson and clerk were already there.'' (He)

``How came Miss Vye to have anything to do with it, if she (clerk) was only on a walk that way?'' (unknown)

``Because there was nobody else. She (clerk) had gone into the church just before me, not into the gallery. The parson looked round before beginning, and as she (clerk) was the only one near he (parson) beckoned to her (clerk), and she (clerk) went up to the rails. After that, when it came to signing the book, she (clerk) pushed up her (clerk) veil and signed; and Tamsin seemed to thank her (clerk) for her (clerk) kindness.'' (The reddleman)
The reddleman told the tale thoughtfully for there lingered upon his (Wildeve) vision the changing colour of Wildeve, when Eustacia lifted the thick veil which had concealed her (Eustacia) from recognition and looked calmly into his (Wildeve) face.
``And then,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Diggory sadly,
``I came away, for her (clerk) history as Tamsin Yeobright was over.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

``I offered to go,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright regretfully.
``But she (clerk) said it was not necessary.'' (unknown)

``Well, it is no matter,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman.
``The thing is done at last as it was meant to be at first, and God send her (clerk) happiness. Now I'll wish you good morning.'' (He)

He (Diggory) placed his (Diggory) cap on his (Diggory) head and went out.

From that instant of leaving Mrs. Yeobright's door, the reddleman was seen no more in or about Egdon Heath for a space of many months. He (Heath) vanished entirely. The nook among the brambles where his (Heath) van had been standing was as vacant as ever the next morning, and scarcely a sign remained to show that he (Heath) had been there, excepting a few straws, and a little redness on the turf, which was washed away by the next storm of rain.

The report that Diggory had brought of the wedding, correct as far as it went, was deficient in one significant particular, which had escaped him (Diggory) through his (Diggory) being at some distance back in the church. When Thomasin was tremblingly engaged in signing her (Heath) name Wildeve had flung towards Eustacia a glance that said plainly,

``I have punished you now.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
She (Heath) had replied in a low tone--and he (Wildeve) little thought how truly--
``You mistake; it gives me sincerest pleasure to see her (clerk) your wife today.'' (he)

BOOK THREE -- THE FASCINATION

1--

``My Mind to Me a Kingdom Is'' (Clym Yeobright)

In Clym Yeobright's face could be dimly seen the typical countenance of the future. Should there be a classic period to art hereafter, its Pheidias may produce such faces. The view of life as a thing to be put up with, replacing that zest for existence which was so intense in early civilizations, must ultimately enter so thoroughly into the constitution of the advanced races that its facial expression will become accepted as a new artistic departure. People already feel that a man who lives without disturbing a curve of feature, or setting a mark of mental concern anywhere upon himself, is too far removed from modern perceptiveness to be a modern type. Physically beautiful men--the glory of the race when it was young--are almost an anachronism now; and we may wonder whether, at some time or other, physically beautiful women may not be an anachronism likewise.

The truth seems to be that a long line of disillusive centuries has permanently displaced the Hellenic idea of life, or whatever it may be called. What the Greeks only suspected we know well; what their Aeschylus imagined our nursery children feel. That old-fashioned revelling in the general situation grows less and less possible as we uncover the defects of natural laws, and see the quandary that man is in by their operation.

The lineaments which will get embodied in ideals based upon this new recognition will probably be akin to those of Yeobright. The observer's eye was arrested, not by his (man) face as a picture, but by his (man) face as a page; not by what it was, but by what it recorded. His (man) features were attractive in the light of symbols, as sounds intrinsically common become attractive in language, and as shapes intrinsically simple become interesting in writing.

He (man) had been a lad of whom something was expected. Beyond this all had been chaos. That he (man) would be successful in an original way, or that he (man) would go to the dogs in an original way, seemed equally probable. The only absolute certainty about him (man) was that he (man) would not stand still in the circumstances amid which he (man) was born.

Hence, when his (man) name was casually mentioned by neighbouring yeomen, the listener said,

``Ah, Clym Yeobright--what is he (God) doing now?'' (the listener)
When the instinctive question about a person is, What is he (listener) doing? it is felt that he (listener) will be found to be, like most of us, doing nothing in particular. There is an indefinite sense that he (listener) must be invading some region of singularity, good or bad. The devout hope is that he (listener) is doing well. The secret faith is that he (listener) is making a mess of it. Half a dozen comfortable market-men, who were habitual callers at the Quiet Woman as they passed by in their carts, were partial to the topic. In fact, though they were not Egdon men, they could hardly avoid it while they sucked their long clay tubes and regarded the heath through the window. Clym had been so inwoven with the heath in his (Egdon) boyhood that hardly anybody could look upon it without thinking of him (Egdon). So the subject recurred: if he (Egdon) were making a fortune and a name, so much the better for him (Egdon); if he (Egdon) were making a tragical figure in the world, so much the better for a narrative.

The fact was that Yeobright's fame had spread to an awkward extent before he (Egdon) left home.

``It is bad when your fame outruns your means,'' (Jesuit)
said the Spanish Jesuit Gracian. At the age of six he (Egdon) had asked a Scripture riddle:
``Who was the first man known to wear breeches?'' (he)
and applause had resounded from the very verge of the heath. At seven he (Egdon) painted the Battle of Waterloo with tiger-lily pollen and black-currant juice, in the absence of water-colours. By the time he (Egdon) reached twelve he (Egdon) had in this manner been heard of as artist and scholar for at least two miles round. An individual whose fame spreads three or four thousand yards in the time taken by the fame of others similarly situated to travel six or eight hundred, must of necessity have something in him (Egdon). Possibly Clym's fame, like Homer's, owed something to the accidents of his (Homer) situation; nevertheless famous he (Homer) was.

He (Homer) grew up and was helped out in life. That waggery of fate which started Clive as a writing clerk, Gay as a linen-draper, Keats as a surgeon, and a thousand others in a thousand other odd ways, banished the wild and ascetic heath lad to a trade whose sole concern was with the especial symbols of self-indulgence and vainglory.

The details of this choice of a business for him (lad) it is not necessary to give. At the death of his (lad) father a neighbouring gentleman had kindly undertaken to give the boy a start, and this assumed the form of sending him (lad) to Budmouth. Yeobright did not wish to go there, but it was the only feasible opening. Thence he (lad) went to London; and thence, shortly after, to Paris, where he (lad) had remained till now.

Something being expected of him (lad), he (lad) had not been at home many days before a great curiosity as to why he (lad) stayed on so long began to arise in the heath. The natural term of a holiday had passed, yet he (lad) still remained. On the Sunday morning following the week of Thomasin's marriage a discussion on this subject was in progress at a hair-cutting before Fairway's house. Here the local barbering was always done at this hour on this day, to be followed by the great Sunday wash of the inhabitants at noon, which in its turn was followed by the great Sunday dressing an hour later. On Egdon Heath Sunday proper did not begin till dinner-time, and even then it was a somewhat battered specimen of the day.

These Sunday-morning hair-cuttings were performed by Fairway; the victim sitting on a chopping-block in front of the house, without a coat, and the neighbours gossiping around, idly observing the locks of hair as they rose upon the wind after the snip, and flew away out of sight to the four quarters of the heavens. Summer and winter the scene was the same, unless the wind were more than usually blusterous, when the stool was shifted a few feet round the corner. To complain of cold in sitting out of doors, hatless and coatless, while Fairway told true stories between the cuts of the scissors, would have been to pronounce yourself no man at once. To flinch, exclaim, or move a muscle of the face at the small stabs under the ear received from those instruments, or at scarifications of the neck by the comb, would have been thought a gross breach of good manners, considering that Fairway did it all for nothing. A bleeding about the poll on Sunday afternoons was amply accounted for by the explanation.

``I have had my hair cut, you know.'' (Yeobright)

The conversation on Yeobright had been started by a distant view of the young man rambling leisurely across the heath before them.

``A man who is doing well elsewhere wouldn't bide here two or three weeks for nothing,'' (unknown)
said Fairway.
``He (man)'s got some project in `s head--depend upon that.'' (unknown)

``Well, `a can't keep a diment shop here,'' (Sam)
said Sam.

``I don't see why he (man) should have had them two heavy boxes home if he (man) had not been going to bide; and what there is for him (man) to do here the Lord in heaven knows.'' (Yeobright)

Before many more surmises could be indulged in Yeobright had come near; and seeing the hair-cutting group he (Sam) turned aside to join them. Marching up, and looking critically at their faces for a moment, he (Sam) said, without introduction,

``Now, folks, let me guess what you have been talking about.'' (he)

``Ay, sure, if you will,'' (Sam)
said Sam.

``About me.'' (unknown)

``Now, it is a thing I shouldn't have dreamed of doing, otherwise,'' (unknown)
said Fairway in a tone of integrity;
``but since you have named it, Master Yeobright, I'll own that we was talking about `ee. We were wondering what could keep you home here mollyhorning about when you have made such a world-wide name for yourself in the nick-nack trade--now, that's the truth o't.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

``I'll tell you,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright with unexpected earnestness.
``I am not sorry to have the opportunity. I've come home because, all things considered, I can be a trifle less useless here than anywhere else. But I have only lately found this out. When I first got away from home I thought this place was not worth troubling about. I thought our life here was contemptible. To oil your boots instead of blacking them, to dust your coat with a switch instead of a brush--was there ever anything more ridiculous? I said.'' (unknown)

``So `tis; so `tis!'' (unknown)

``No, no--you are wrong; it isn't.'' (unknown)

``Beg your pardon, we thought that was your meaning?'' (unknown)

``Well, as my views changed my course became very depressing. I found that I was trying to be like people who had hardly anything in common with myself. I was endeavouring to put off one sort of life for another sort of life, which was not better than the life I had known before. It was simply different.'' (unknown)

``True; a sight different,'' (unknown)
said Fairway.

``Yes, Paris must be a taking place,'' (Humphrey)
said Humphrey.
``Grand shop-winders, trumpets, and drums; and here be we out of doors in all winds and weathers--'' (unknown)

``But you mistake me,'' (unknown)
pleaded Clym.
``All this was very depressing. But not so depressing as something I next perceived--that my business was the idlest, vainest, most effeminate business that ever a man could be put to. That decided me--I would give it up and try to follow some rational occupation among the people I knew best, and to whom I could be of most use. I have come home; and this is how I mean to carry out my plan. I shall keep a school as near to Egdon as possible, so as to be able to walk over here and have a night-school in my mother's house. But I must study a little at first, to get properly qualified. Now, neighbours, I must go.'' (unknown)

And Clym resumed his (Humphrey) walk across the heath.

``He (Egdon)'ll never carry it out in the world,'' (unknown)
said Fairway.
``In a few weeks he (Egdon)'ll learn to see things otherwise.'' (the man)

```Tis good-hearted of the young man,'' said another.

``But, for my part, I think he (Egdon) had better mind his (Egdon) business.'' (Disappointment Yeobright)

2--The New Course Causes Disappointment

Yeobright loved his (man) kind. He (man) had a conviction that the want of most men was knowledge of a sort which brings wisdom rather than affluence. He (man) wished to raise the class at the expense of individuals rather than individuals at the expense of the class. What was more, he (man) was ready at once to be the first unit sacrificed.

In passing from the bucolic to the intellectual life the intermediate stages are usually two at least, frequently many more; and one of those stages is almost sure to be worldly advanced. We can hardly imagine bucolic placidity quickening to intellectual aims without imagining social aims as the transitional phase. Yeobright's local peculiarity was that in striving at high thinking he (man) still cleaved to plain living--nay, wild and meagre living in many respects, and brotherliness with clowns.

He (man) was a John the Baptist who took ennoblement rather than repentance for his (man) text. Mentally he (man) was in a provincial future, that is, he (man) was in many points abreast with the central town thinkers of his (man) date. Much of this development he (man) may have owed to his (man) studious life in Paris, where he (man) had become acquainted with ethical systems popular at the time.

In consequence of this relatively advanced position, Yeobright might have been called unfortunate. The rural world was not ripe for him (man). A man should be only partially before his (man) time--to be completely to the vanward in aspirations is fatal to fame. Had Philip's warlike son been intellectually so far ahead as to have attempted civilization without bloodshed, he (son) would have been twice the godlike hero that he (hero) seemed, but nobody would have heard of an Alexander.

In the interests of renown the forwardness should lie chiefly in the capacity to handle things. Successful propagandists have succeeded because the doctrine they bring into form is that which their listeners have for some time felt without being able to shape. A man who advocates aesthetic effort and deprecates social effort is only likely to be understood by a class to which social effort has become a stale matter. To argue upon the possibility of culture before luxury to the bucolic world may be to argue truly, but it is an attempt to disturb a sequence to which humanity has been long accustomed. Yeobright preaching to the Egdon eremites that they might rise to a serene comprehensiveness without going through the process of enriching themselves was not unlike arguing to ancient Chaldeans that in ascending from earth to the pure empyrean it was not necessary to pass first into the intervening heaven of ether.

Was Yeobright's mind well-proportioned? No. A well proportioned mind is one which shows no particular bias; one of which we may safely say that it will never cause its owner to be confined as a madman, tortured as a heretic, or crucified as a blasphemer. Also, on the other hand, that it will never cause him (owner) to be applauded as a prophet, revered as a priest, or exalted as a king. Its usual blessings are happiness and mediocrity. It produces the poetry of Rogers, the paintings of West, the statecraft of North, the spiritual guidance of Tomline; enabling its possessors to find their way to wealth, to wind up well, to step with dignity off the stage, to die comfortably in their beds, and to get the decent monument which, in many cases, they deserve. It never would have allowed Yeobright to do such a ridiculous thing as throw up his (Rogers) business to benefit his (Rogers) fellow-creatures.

He (Rogers) walked along towards home without attending to paths. If anyone knew the heath well it was Clym. He (Rogers) was permeated with its scenes, with its substance, and with its odours. He (Rogers) might be said to be its product. His (Rogers) eyes had first opened thereon; with its appearance all the first images of his (Rogers) memory were mingled, his (Rogers) estimate of life had been coloured by it: his (Rogers) toys had been the flint knives and arrow-heads which he (Rogers) found there, wondering why stones should

``grow'' (he)
to such odd shapes; his (Rogers) flowers, the purple bells and yellow furze: his (Rogers) animal kingdom, the snakes and croppers; his (Rogers) society, its human haunters. Take all the varying hates felt by Eustacia Vye towards the heath, and translate them into loves, and you have the heart of Clym. He (Rogers) gazed upon the wide prospect as he (Rogers) walked, and was glad.

To many persons this Egdon was a place which had slipped out of its century generations ago, to intrude as an uncouth object into this. It was an obsolete thing, and few cared to study it. How could this be otherwise in the days of square fields, plashed hedges, and meadows watered on a plan so rectangular that on a fine day they looked like silver gridirons? The farmer, in his (farmer) ride, who could smile at artificial grasses, look with solicitude at the coming corn, and sigh with sadness at the fly-eaten turnips, bestowed upon the distant upland of heath nothing better than a frown. But as for Yeobright, when he (farmer) looked from the heights on his (farmer) way he (farmer) could not help indulging in a barbarous satisfaction at observing that, in some of the attempts at reclamation from the waste, tillage, after holding on for a year or two, had receded again in despair, the ferns and furze-tufts stubbornly reasserting themselves.

He (farmer) descended into the valley, and soon reached his (farmer) home at Blooms-End. His (farmer) mother was snipping dead leaves from the window-plants. She (mother) looked up at him (farmer) as if she (mother) did not understand the meaning of his (farmer) long stay with her (mother); her (mother) face had worn that look for several days. He (farmer) could perceive that the curiosity which had been shown by the hair-cutting group amounted in his (farmer) mother to concern. But she (mother) had asked no question with her (mother) lips, even when the arrival of his (farmer) trunk suggested that he (farmer) was not going to leave her (mother) soon. Her (mother) silence besought an explanation of him (farmer) more loudly than words.

``I am not going back to Paris again, Mother,'' (he)
he (farmer) said.
``At least, in my old capacity. I have given up the business.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright turned in pained surprise.

``I thought something was amiss, because of the boxes. I wonder you did not tell me sooner.'' (unknown)

``I ought to have done it. But I have been in doubt whether you would be pleased with my plan. I was not quite clear on a few points myself. I am going to take an entirely new course.'' (unknown)

``I am astonished, Clym. How can you want to do better than you've been doing?'' (unknown)

``Very easily. But I shall not do better in the way you mean; I suppose it will be called doing worse. But I hate that business of mine, and I want to do some worthy thing before I die. As a schoolmaster I think to do it--a school-master to the poor and ignorant, to teach them what nobody else will.'' (unknown)

``After all the trouble that has been taken to give you a start, and when there is nothing to do but to keep straight on towards affluence, you say you will be a poor man's schoolmaster. Your fancies will be your ruin, Clym.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright spoke calmly, but the force of feeling behind the words was but too apparent to one who knew her (Yeobright) as well as her (Yeobright) son did. He (son) did not answer. There was in his (son) face that hopelessness of being understood which comes when the objector is constitutionally beyond the reach of a logic that, even under favouring conditions, is almost too coarse a vehicle for the subtlety of the argument.

No more was said on the subject till the end of dinner. His (objector) mother then began, as if there had been no interval since the morning.

``It disturbs me, Clym, to find that you have come home with such thoughts as those. I hadn't the least idea that you meant to go backward in the world by your own free choice. Of course, I have always supposed you were going to push straight on, as other men do--all who deserve the name--when they have been put in a good way of doing well.'' (unknown)

``I cannot help it,'' (unknown)
said Clym, in a troubled tone.
``Mother, I hate the flashy business. Talk about men who deserve the name, can any man deserving the name waste his (man) time in that effeminate way, when he (man) sees half the world going to ruin for want of somebody to buckle to and teach them how to breast the misery they are born to? I get up every morning and see the whole creation groaning and travailing in pain, as St. Paul says, and yet there am I, trafficking in glittering splendours with wealthy women and titled libertines, and pandering to the meanest vanities--I, who have health and strength enough for anything. I have been troubled in my mind about it all the year, and the end is that I cannot do it any more.'' (unknown)

``Why can't you do it as well as others?'' (unknown)

``I don't know, except that there are many things other people care for which I don't; and that's partly why I think I ought to do this. For one thing, my body does not require much of me. I cannot enjoy delicacies; good things are wasted upon me. Well, I ought to turn that defect to advantage, and by being able to do without what other people require I can spend what such things cost upon anybody else.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Now, Yeobright, having inherited some of these very instincts from the woman before him (objector), could not fail to awaken a reciprocity in her (woman) through her (woman) feelings, if not by arguments, disguise it as she (woman) might for his (objector) good. She (woman) spoke with less assurance.

``And yet you might have been a wealthy man if you had only persevered. Manager to that large diamond establishment--what better can a man wish for? What a post of trust and respect! I suppose you will be like your father; like him (father), you are getting weary of doing well.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (son)
said her (woman) son,
``I am not weary of that, though I am weary of what you mean by it. Mother, what is doing well?'' (son)

Mrs. Yeobright was far too thoughtful a woman to be content with ready definitions, and, like the

``What is wisdom?'' (a woman)
of Plato's Socrates, and the
``What is truth?'' (Plato Socrates)
of Pontius Pilate, Yeobright's burning question received no answer.

The silence was broken by the clash of the garden gate, a tap at the door, and its opening. Christian Cantle appeared in the room in his (Cantle) Sunday clothes.

It was the custom on Egdon to begin the preface to a story before absolutely entering the house, so as to be well in for the body of the narrative by the time visitor and visited stood face to face. Christian had been saying to them while the door was leaving its latch,

``To think that I, who go from home but once in a while, and hardly then, should have been there this morning!'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)

```Tis news you have brought us, then, Christian?'' said Mrs. Yeobright.

``Ay, sure, about a witch, and ye must overlook my time o' day; for, says I, `I must go and tell `em, though they won't have half done dinner.' I assure ye it made me shake like a driven leaf. Do ye think any harm will come o't?'' (unknown)

``Well--what?'' (unknown)

``This morning at church we was all standing up, and the pa'son said, `Let us pray.' `Well,' thinks I, `one may as well kneel as stand'; so down I went; and, more than that, all the rest were as willing to oblige the man as I. We hadn't been hard at it for more than a minute when a most terrible screech sounded through church, as if somebody had just gied up their heart's blood. All the folk jumped up and then we found that Susan Nunsuch had pricked Miss Vye with a long stocking-needle, as she (Nunsuch) had threatened to do as soon as ever she (Nunsuch) could get the young lady to church, where she (Nunsuch) don't come very often. She (Nunsuch)'ve waited for this chance for weeks, so as to draw her (Nunsuch) blood and put an end to the bewitching of Susan's children that has been carried on so long. Sue followed her (Susan) into church, sat next to her (Susan), and as soon as she (Susan) could find a chance in went the stocking-needle into my lady's arm.'' (unknown)

``Good heaven, how horrid!'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright.

``Sue pricked her (Susan) that deep that the maid fainted away; and as I was afeard there might be some tumult among us, I got behind the bass viol and didn't see no more. But they carried her (Susan) out into the air, `tis said; but when they looked round for Sue she (Sue) was gone. What a scream that girl gied, poor thing! There were the pa'son in his (my) surplice holding up his (my) hand and saying, `Sit down, my good people, sit down!' But the deuce a bit would they sit down. O, and what d’ye think I found out, Mrs. Yeobright? The pa'son wears a suit of clothes under his (my) surplice!--I could see his (my) black sleeves when he (my) held up his (my) arm.'' (unknown)

```Tis a cruel thing,'' said Yeobright.

``Yes,'' (mother)
said his (Christian) mother.

``The nation ought to look into it,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian.
``Here's Humphrey coming, I think.'' (Humphrey)

In came Humphrey.

``Well, have ye heard the news? But I see you have. `Tis a very strange thing that whenever one of Egdon folk goes to church some rum job or other is sure to be doing. The last time one of us was there was when neighbour Fairway went in the fall; and that was the day you forbad the banns, Mrs. Yeobright.'' (unknown)

``Has this cruelly treated girl been able to walk home?'' (unknown)
said Clym.

``They say she (girl) got better, and went home very well. And now I've told it I must be moving homeward myself.'' (unknown)

``And I,'' (Humphrey)
said Humphrey.
``Truly now we shall see if there's anything in what folks say about her (girl).'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

When they were gone into the heath again Yeobright said quietly to his (Humphrey) mother,

``Do you think I have turned teacher too soon?'' (mother)

``It is right that there should be schoolmasters, and missionaries, and all such men,'' (she)
she (mother) replied.
``But it is right, too, that I should try to lift you out of this life into something richer, and that you should not come back again, and be as if I had not tried at all.'' (Sam)

Later in the day Sam, the turf-cutter, entered.

``I've come a-borrowing, Mrs. Yeobright. I suppose you have heard what's been happening to the beauty on the hill?'' (unknown)

``Yes, Sam: half a dozen have been telling us.'' (unknown)

``Beauty?'' (unknown)
said Clym.

``Yes, tolerably well-favoured,'' (Sam)
Sam replied.
``Lord! all the country owns that `tis one of the strangest things in the world that such a woman should have come to live up there.'' (unknown)

``Dark or fair?'' (unknown)

``Now, though I've seen her (woman) twenty times, that's a thing I cannot call to mind.'' (unknown)

``Darker than Tamsin,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
murmured Mrs. Yeobright.

``A woman who seems to care for nothing at all, as you may say.'' (unknown)

``She (woman) is melancholy, then?'' (unknown)
inquired Clym.

``She (woman) mopes about by herself, and don't mix in with the people.'' (unknown)

``Is she (woman) a young lady inclined for adventures?'' (unknown)

``Not to my knowledge.'' (unknown)

``Doesn't join in with the lads in their games, to get some sort of excitement in this lonely place?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``Mumming, for instance?'' (unknown)

``No. Her (woman) notions be different. I should rather say her (woman) thoughts were far away from here, with lords and ladies she (woman)'ll never know, and mansions she (woman)'ll never see again.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Observing that Clym appeared singularly interested Mrs. Yeobright said rather uneasily to Sam,

``You see more in her (woman) than most of us do. Miss Vye is to my mind too idle to be charming. I have never heard that she (woman) is of any use to herself or to other people. Good girls don't get treated as witches even on Egdon.'' (Sam)

``Nonsense--that proves nothing either way,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.

``Well, of course I don't understand such niceties,'' (Sam)
said Sam, withdrawing from a possibly unpleasant argument;
``and what she (woman) is we must wait for time to tell us. The business that I have really called about is this, to borrow the longest and strongest rope you have. The captain's bucket has dropped into the well, and they are in want of water; and as all the chaps are at home today we think we can get it out for him (captain). We have three cart-ropes already, but they won't reach to the bottom.'' (Sam)

Mrs. Yeobright told him (Sam) that he (Sam) might have whatever ropes he (Sam) could find in the outhouse, and Sam went out to search. When he (Sam) passed by the door Clym joined him (Sam), and accompanied him (Sam) to the gate.

``Is this young witch-lady going to stay long at Mistover?'' (he)
he (Sam) asked.

``I should say so.'' (unknown)

``What a cruel shame to ill-use her (captain), She (captain) must have suffered greatly--more in mind than in body.'' (a girl)

```Twas a graceless trick--such a handsome girl, too. You ought to see her (girl), Mr. Yeobright, being a young man come from far, and with a little more to show for your years than most of us.''

``Do you think she (captain) would like to teach children?'' (unknown)
said Clym.

Sam shook his (Sam) head.

``Quite a different sort of body from that, I reckon.'' (unknown)

``O, it was merely something which occurred to me. It would of course be necessary to see her (captain) and talk it over--not an easy thing, by the way, for my family and hers are not very friendly.'' (unknown)

``I'll tell you how you mid see her (captain), Mr. Yeobright,'' (Sam)
said Sam.
``We are going to grapple for the bucket at six o’clock tonight at her (captain) house, and you could lend a hand. There's five or six coming, but the well is deep, and another might be useful, if you don't mind appearing in that shape. She (captain)'s sure to be walking round.'' (unknown)

``I'll think of it,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright; and they parted.

He (Sam) thought of it a good deal; but nothing more was said about Eustacia inside the house at that time. Whether this romantic martyr to superstition and the melancholy mummer he (martyr) had conversed with under the full moon were one and the same person remained as yet a problem.

3--The First Act in a Timeworn Drama

The afternoon was fine, and Yeobright walked on the heath for an hour with his (martyr) mother. When they reached the lofty ridge which divided the valley of Blooms-End from the adjoining valley they stood still and looked round. The Quiet Woman Inn was visible on the low margin of the heath in one direction, and afar on the other hand rose Mistover Knap.

``You mean to call on Thomasin?'' (he)
he (martyr) inquired.

``Yes. But you need not come this time,'' (mother)
said his (martyr) mother.

``In that case I'll branch off here, Mother. I am going to Mistover.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright turned to him (martyr) inquiringly.

``I am going to help them get the bucket out of the captain's well,'' (he)
he (martyr) continued.
``As it is so very deep I may be useful. And I should like to see this Miss Vye--not so much for her (Mother) good looks as for another reason.'' (unknown)

``Must you go?'' (mother)
his (martyr) mother asked.

``I thought to.'' (unknown)

And they parted.

``There is no help for it,'' (Clym mother)
murmured Clym's mother gloomily as he (martyr) withdrew.
``They are sure to see each other. I wish Sam would carry his (Sam) news to other houses than mine.'' (unknown)

Clym's retreating figure got smaller and smaller as it rose and fell over the hillocks on his (martyr) way.

``He (Sam) is tender-hearted,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright to herself while she (Yeobright) watched him (martyr);
``otherwise it would matter little. How he (Sam)'s going on!'' (him)

He (martyr) was, indeed, walking with a will over the furze, as straight as a line, as if his (martyr) life depended upon it. His (martyr) mother drew a long breath, and, abandoning the visit to Thomasin, turned back. The evening films began to make nebulous pictures of the valleys, but the high lands still were raked by the declining rays of the winter sun, which glanced on Clym as he (martyr) walked forward, eyed by every rabbit and field-fare around, a long shadow advancing in front of him (martyr).

On drawing near to the furze-covered bank and ditch which fortified the captain's dwelling he (captain) could hear voices within, signifying that operations had been already begun. At the side-entrance gate he (captain) stopped and looked over.

Half a dozen able-bodied men were standing in a line from the well-mouth, holding a rope which passed over the well-roller into the depths below. Fairway, with a piece of smaller rope round his (captain) body, made fast to one of the standards, to guard against accidents, was leaning over the opening, his (captain) right hand clasping the vertical rope that descended into the well.

``Now, silence, folks,'' (unknown)
said Fairway.

The talking ceased, and Fairway gave a circular motion to the rope, as if he (captain) were stirring batter. At the end of a minute a dull splashing reverberated from the bottom of the well; the helical twist he (captain) had imparted to the rope had reached the grapnel below.

``Haul!'' (unknown)
said Fairway; and the men who held the rope began to gather it over the wheel.

``I think we've got sommat,'' (unknown)
said one of the haulers-in.

``Then pull steady,'' (unknown)
said Fairway.

They gathered up more and more, till a regular dripping into the well could be heard below. It grew smarter with the increasing height of the bucket, and presently a hundred and fifty feet of rope had been pulled in.

Fairway then lit a lantern, tied it to another cord, and began lowering it into the well beside the first: Clym came forward and looked down. Strange humid leaves, which knew nothing of the seasons of the year, and quaint-natured mosses were revealed on the wellside as the lantern descended; till its rays fell upon a confused mass of rope and bucket dangling in the dank, dark air.

``We've only got en by the edge of the hoop--steady, for God's sake!'' (unknown)
said Fairway.

They pulled with the greatest gentleness, till the wet bucket appeared about two yards below them, like a dead friend come to earth again. Three or four hands were stretched out, then jerk went the rope, whizz went the wheel, the two foremost haulers fell backward, the beating of a falling body was heard, receding down the sides of the well, and a thunderous uproar arose at the bottom. The bucket was gone again.

``Damn the bucket!'' (unknown)
said Fairway.

``Lower again,'' (Sam)
said Sam.

``I'm as stiff as a ram's horn stooping so long,'' (unknown)
said Fairway, standing up and stretching himself till his (Sam) joints creaked.

``Rest a few minutes, Timothy,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.
``I'll take your place.'' (unknown)

The grapnel was again lowered. Its smart impact upon the distant water reached their ears like a kiss, whereupon Yeobright knelt down, and leaning over the well began dragging the grapnel round and round as Fairway had done.

``Tie a rope round him (Timothy)--it is dangerous!'' (unknown)
cried a soft and anxious voice somewhere above them.

Everybody turned. The speaker was a woman, gazing down upon the group from an upper window, whose panes blazed in the ruddy glare from the west. Her (woman) lips were parted and she (woman) appeared for the moment to forget where she (woman) was.

The rope was accordingly tied round his (speaker) waist, and the work proceeded. At the next haul the weight was not heavy, and it was discovered that they had only secured a coil of the rope detached from the bucket. The tangled mass was thrown into the background. Humphrey took Yeobright's place, and the grapnel was lowered again.

Yeobright retired to the heap of recovered rope in a meditative mood. Of the identity between the lady's voice and that of the melancholy mummer he (Humphrey) had not a moment's doubt.

``How thoughtful of her (folks)!'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said to himself.

Eustacia, who had reddened when she (Eustacia) perceived the effect of her (Eustacia) exclamation upon the group below, was no longer to be seen at the window, though Yeobright scanned it wistfully. While he (Humphrey) stood there the men at the well succeeded in getting up the bucket without a mishap. One of them went to inquire for the captain, to learn what orders he (captain) wished to give for mending the well-tackle. The captain proved to be away from home, and Eustacia appeared at the door and came out. She (Eustacia) had lapsed into an easy and dignified calm, far removed from the intensity of life in her (Eustacia) words of solicitude for Clym's safety.

``Will it be possible to draw water here tonight?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) inquired.

``No, miss; the bottom of the bucket is clean knocked out. And as we can do no more now we'll leave off, and come again tomorrow morning.'' (unknown)

``No water,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) murmured, turning away.

``I can send you up some from Blooms-End,'' (the men)
said Clym, coming forward and raising his (captain) hat as the men retired.

Yeobright and Eustacia looked at each other for one instant, as if each had in mind those few moments during which a certain moonlight scene was common to both. With the glance the calm fixity of her (Eustacia) features sublimed itself to an expression of refinement and warmth; it was like garish noon rising to the dignity of sunset in a couple of seconds.

``Thank you; it will hardly be necessary,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) replied.

``But if you have no water?'' (unknown)

``Well, it is what I call no water,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, blushing, and lifting her (Eustacia) long-lashed eyelids as if to lift them were a work requiring consideration.
``But my grandfather calls it water enough. I'll show you what I mean.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) moved away a few yards, and Clym followed.
