When she (Eustacia) reached the corner of the enclosure, where the steps were formed for mounting the boundary bank, she (Eustacia) sprang up with a lightness which seemed strange after her (Eustacia) listless movement towards the well. It incidentally showed that her (Eustacia) apparent languor did not arise from lack of force.

Clym ascended behind her (Eustacia), and noticed a circular burnt patch at the top of the bank.

``Ashes?'' (he)
he (It) said.

``Yes,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.
``We had a little bonfire here last Fifth of November, and those are the marks of it.'' (she)

On that spot had stood the fire she (Eustacia) had kindled to attract Wildeve.

``That's the only kind of water we have,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) continued, tossing a stone into the pool, which lay on the outside of the bank like the white of an eye without its pupil. The stone fell with a flounce, but no Wildeve appeared on the other side, as on a previous occasion there.
``My grandfather says he (grandfather) lived for more than twenty years at sea on water twice as bad as that,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) went on,
``and considers it quite good enough for us here on an emergency.'' (she)

``Well, as a matter of fact there are no impurities in the water of these pools at this time of the year. It has only just rained into them.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) shook her (Eustacia) head.

``I am managing to exist in a wilderness, but I cannot drink from a pond,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.

Clym looked towards the well, which was now deserted, the men having gone home.

``It is a long way to send for spring-water,'' (he)
he (pupil) said, after a silence.
``But since you don't like this in the pond, I'll try to get you some myself.'' (He)
He (pupil) went back to the well.
``Yes, I think I could do it by tying on this pail.'' (unknown)

``But, since I would not trouble the men to get it, I cannot in conscience let you.'' (unknown)

``I don't mind the trouble at all.'' (He)

He (pupil) made fast the pail to the long coil of rope, put it over the wheel, and allowed it to descend by letting the rope slip through his (pupil) hands. Before it had gone far, however, he (pupil) checked it.

``I must make fast the end first, or we may lose the whole,'' (he)
he (pupil) said to Eustacia, who had drawn near.
``Could you hold this a moment, while I do it--or shall I call your servant?'' (unknown)

``I can hold it,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia; and he (pupil) placed the rope in her (Eustacia) hands, going then to search for the end.

``I suppose I may let it slip down?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) inquired.

``I would advise you not to let it go far,'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``It will get much heavier, you will find.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

However, Eustacia had begun to pay out. While he (pupil) was tying she (Eustacia) cried,

``I cannot stop it!'' (she)

Clym ran to her (Eustacia) side, and found he (pupil) could only check the rope by twisting the loose part round the upright post, when it stopped with a jerk.

``Has it hurt you?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) replied.

``Very much?'' (unknown)

``No; I think not.'' (She)
She (Eustacia) opened her (Eustacia) hands. One of them was bleeding; the rope had dragged off the skin. Eustacia wrapped it in her (Eustacia) handkerchief.

``You should have let go,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.
``Why didn't you?'' (unknown)

``You said I was to hold on... This is the second time I have been wounded today.'' (unknown)

``Ah, yes; I have heard of it. I blush for my native Egdon. Was it a serious injury you received in church, Miss Vye?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

There was such an abundance of sympathy in Clym's tone that Eustacia slowly drew up her (Eustacia) sleeve and disclosed her (Eustacia) round white arm. A bright red spot appeared on its smooth surface, like a ruby on Parian marble.

``There it is,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, putting her (Eustacia) finger against the spot.

``It was dastardly of the woman,'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``Will not Captain Vye get her (woman) punished?'' (unknown)

``He (Captain) is gone from home on that very business. I did not know that I had such a magic reputation.'' (unknown)

``And you fainted?'' (he)
said Clym, looking at the scarlet little puncture as if he (jerk) would like to kiss it and make it well.

``Yes, it frightened me. I had not been to church for a long time. And now I shall not go again for ever so long--perhaps never. I cannot face their eyes after this. Don't you think it dreadfully humiliating? I wished I was dead for hours after, but I don't mind now.'' (unknown)

``I have come to clean away these cobwebs,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.
``Would you like to help me--by high-class teaching? We might benefit them much.'' (unknown)

``I don't quite feel anxious to. I have not much love for my fellow-creatures. Sometimes I quite hate them.'' (unknown)

``Still I think that if you were to hear my scheme you might take an interest in it. There is no use in hating people--if you hate anything, you should hate what produced them.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean Nature? I hate her (you) already. But I shall be glad to hear your scheme at any time.'' (unknown)

The situation had now worked itself out, and the next natural thing was for them to part. Clym knew this well enough, and Eustacia made a move of conclusion; yet he (jerk) looked at her (Eustacia) as if he (jerk) had one word more to say. Perhaps if he (jerk) had not lived in Paris it would never have been uttered.

``We have met before,'' (he)
he (jerk) said, regarding her (Eustacia) with rather more interest than was necessary.

``I do not own it,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia, with a repressed, still look.

``But I may think what I like.'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``You are lonely here.'' (unknown)

``I cannot endure the heath, except in its purple season. The heath is a cruel taskmaster to me.'' (unknown)

``Can you say so?'' (he)
he (jerk) asked.
``To my mind it is most exhilarating, and strengthening, and soothing. I would rather live on these hills than anywhere else in the world.'' (unknown)

``It is well enough for artists; but I never would learn to draw.'' (unknown)

``And there is a very curious druidical stone just out there.'' (He)
He (jerk) threw a pebble in the direction signified.
``Do you often go to see it?'' (unknown)

``I was not even aware there existed any such curious druidical stone. I am aware that there are boulevards in Paris.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright looked thoughtfully on the ground.

``That means much,'' (he)
he (jerk) said.

``It does indeed,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.

``I remember when I had the same longing for town bustle. Five years of a great city would be a perfect cure for that.'' (unknown)

``Heaven send me such a cure! Now, Mr. Yeobright, I will go indoors and plaster my wounded hand.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

They separated, and Eustacia vanished in the increasing shade. She (Eustacia) seemed full of many things. Her (Eustacia) past was a blank, her (Eustacia) life had begun. The effect upon Clym of this meeting he (jerk) did not fully discover till some time after. During his (jerk) walk home his (jerk) most intelligible sensation was that his (jerk) scheme had somehow become glorified. A beautiful woman had been intertwined with it.

On reaching the house he (jerk) went up to the room which was to be made his (jerk) study, and occupied himself during the evening in unpacking his (jerk) books from the boxes and arranging them on shelves. From another box he (jerk) drew a lamp and a can of oil. He (jerk) trimmed the lamp, arranged his (jerk) table, and said,

``Now, I am ready to begin.'' (He)

He (jerk) rose early the next morning, read two hours before breakfast by the light of his (jerk) lamp--read all the morning, all the afternoon. Just when the sun was going down his (jerk) eyes felt weary, and he (jerk) leant back in his (jerk) chair.

His (jerk) room overlooked the front of the premises and the valley of the heath beyond. The lowest beams of the winter sun threw the shadow of the house over the palings, across the grass margin of the heath, and far up the vale, where the chimney outlines and those of the surrounding tree-tops stretched forth in long dark prongs. Having been seated at work all day, he (jerk) decided to take a turn upon the hills before it got dark; and, going out forthwith, he (jerk) struck across the heath towards Mistover.

It was an hour and a half later when he (jerk) again appeared at the garden gate. The shutters of the house were closed, and Christian Cantle, who had been wheeling manure about the garden all day, had gone home. On entering he (Cantle) found that his (Cantle) mother, after waiting a long time for him (Cantle), had finished her (mother) meal.

``Where have you been, Clym?'' (she)
she (mother) immediately said.
``Why didn't you tell me that you were going away at this time?'' (unknown)

``I have been on the heath.'' (unknown)

``You'll meet Eustacia Vye if you go up there.'' (unknown)

Clym paused a minute.

``Yes, I met her (Yeobright) this evening,'' (he)
he (Cantle) said, as though it were spoken under the sheer necessity of preserving honesty.

``I wondered if you had.'' (unknown)

``It was no appointment.'' (unknown)

``No; such meetings never are.'' (unknown)

``But you are not angry, Mother?'' (unknown)

``I can hardly say that I am not. Angry? No. But when I consider the usual nature of the drag which causes men of promise to disappoint the world I feel uneasy.'' (unknown)

``You deserve credit for the feeling, Mother. But I can assure you that you need not be disturbed by it on my account.'' (unknown)

``When I think of you and your new crotchets,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright, with some emphasis,
``I naturally don't feel so comfortable as I did a twelvemonth ago. It is incredible to me that a man accustomed to the attractive women of Paris and elsewhere should be so easily worked upon by a girl in a heath. You could just as well have walked another way.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

``I had been studying all day.'' (unknown)

``Well, yes,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) added more hopefully,
``I have been thinking that you might get on as a schoolmaster, and rise that way, since you really are determined to hate the course you were pursuing.'' (she)

Yeobright was unwilling to disturb this idea, though his (Cantle) scheme was far enough removed from one wherein the education of youth should be made a mere channel of social ascent. He (Cantle) had no desires of that sort. He (Cantle) had reached the stage in a young man's life when the grimness of the general human situation first becomes clear; and the realization of this causes ambition to halt awhile. In France it is not uncustomary to commit suicide at this stage; in England we do much better, or much worse, as the case may be.

The love between the young man and his (man) mother was strangely invisible now. Of love it may be said, the less earthly the less demonstrative. In its absolutely indestructible form it reaches a profundity in which all exhibition of itself is painful. It was so with these. Had conversations between them been overheard, people would have said,

``How cold they are to each other!'' (people)

His (man) theory and his (man) wishes about devoting his (man) future to teaching had made an impression on Mrs. Yeobright. Indeed, how could it be otherwise when he (man) was a part of her (Yeobright)--when their discourses were as if carried on between the right and the left hands of the same body? He (man) had despaired of reaching her (Yeobright) by argument; and it was almost as a discovery to him (man) that he (man) could reach her (Yeobright) by a magnetism which was as superior to words as words are to yells.

Strangely enough he (man) began to feel now that it would not be so hard to persuade her (Yeobright) who was his (man) best friend that comparative poverty was essentially the higher course for him (man), as to reconcile to his (man) feelings the act of persuading her (Yeobright). From every provident point of view his (man) mother was so undoubtedly right, that he (man) was not without a sickness of heart in finding he (man) could shake her (mother).

She (mother) had a singular insight into life, considering that she (mother) had never mixed with it. There are instances of persons who, without clear ideas of the things they criticize have yet had clear ideas of the relations of those things. Blacklock, a poet blind from his (poet) birth, could describe visual objects with accuracy; Professor Sanderson, who was also blind, gave excellent lectures on colour, and taught others the theory of ideas which they had and he (Sanderson) had not. In the social sphere these gifted ones are mostly women; they can watch a world which they never saw, and estimate forces of which they have only heard. We call it intuition.

What was the great world to Mrs. Yeobright? A multitude whose tendencies could be perceived, though not its essences. Communities were seen by her (Yeobright) as from a distance; she (Yeobright) saw them as we see the throngs which cover the canvases of Sallaert, Van Alsloot, and others of that school--vast masses of beings, jostling, zigzagging, and processioning in definite directions, but whose features are indistinguishable by the very comprehensiveness of the view.

One could see that, as far as it had gone, her (Yeobright) life was very complete on its reflective side. The philosophy of her (Yeobright) nature, and its limitation by circumstances, was almost written in her (Yeobright) movements. They had a majestic foundation, though they were far from being majestic; and they had a ground-work of assurance, but they were not assured. As her (Yeobright) once elastic walk had become deadened by time, so had her (Yeobright) natural pride of life been hindered in its blooming by her (Yeobright) necessities.

The next slight touch in the shaping of Clym's destiny occurred a few days after. A barrow was opened on the heath, and Yeobright attended the operation, remaining away from his (Yeobright) study during several hours. In the afternoon Christian returned from a journey in the same direction, and Mrs. Yeobright questioned him (Yeobright).

``They have dug a hole, and they have found things like flowerpots upside down, Mis'ess Yeobright; and inside these be real charnel bones. They have carried `em off to men's houses; but I shouldn't like to sleep where they will bide. Dead folks have been known to come and claim their own. Mr. Yeobright had got one pot of the bones, and was going to bring `em home--real skellington bones--but `twas ordered otherwise. You'll be relieved to hear that he (Yeobright) gave away his (Yeobright) pot and all, on second thoughts; and a blessed thing for ye, Mis'ess Yeobright, considering the wind o' nights.'' (unknown)

``Gave it away?'' (unknown)

``Yes. To Miss Vye. She (You) has a cannibal taste for such churchyard furniture seemingly.'' (unknown)

``Miss Vye was there too?'' (unknown)

``Ay, `a b'lieve she (You) was.'' (mother)

When Clym came home, which was shortly after, his (Yeobright) mother said, in a curious tone,

``The urn you had meant for me you gave away.'' (mother)

Yeobright made no reply; the current of her (mother) feeling was too pronounced to admit it.

The early weeks of the year passed on. Yeobright certainly studied at home, but he (Yeobright) also walked much abroad, and the direction of his (Yeobright) walk was always towards some point of a line between Mistover and Rainbarrow.

The month of March arrived, and the heath showed its first signs of awakening from winter trance. The awakening was almost feline in its stealthiness. The pool outside the bank by Eustacia's dwelling, which seemed as dead and desolate as ever to an observer who moved and made noises in his (Yeobright) observation, would gradually disclose a state of great animation when silently watched awhile. A timid animal world had come to life for the season. Little tadpoles and efts began to bubble up through the water, and to race along beneath it; toads made noises like very young ducks, and advanced to the margin in twos and threes; overhead, bumblebees flew hither and thither in the thickening light, their drone coming and going like the sound of a gong.

On an evening such as this Yeobright descended into the Blooms-End valley from beside that very pool, where he (Yeobright) had been standing with another person quite silently and quite long enough to hear all this puny stir of resurrection in nature; yet he (Yeobright) had not heard it. His (Yeobright) walk was rapid as he (Yeobright) came down, and he (Yeobright) went with a springy trend. Before entering upon his (Yeobright) mother's premises he (Yeobright) stopped and breathed. The light which shone forth on him (Yeobright) from the window revealed that his (Yeobright) face was flushed and his (Yeobright) eye bright. What it did not show was something which lingered upon his (Yeobright) lips like a seal set there. The abiding presence of this impress was so real that he (Yeobright) hardly dared to enter the house, for it seemed as if his (Yeobright) mother might say,

``What red spot is that glowing upon your mouth so vividly?'' (mother)

But he (Yeobright) entered soon after. The tea was ready, and he (Yeobright) sat down opposite his (Yeobright) mother. She (mother) did not speak many words; and as for him (Yeobright), something had been just done and some words had been just said on the hill which prevented him (Yeobright) from beginning a desultory chat. His (Yeobright) mother's taciturnity was not without ominousness, but he (Yeobright) appeared not to care. He (Yeobright) knew why she (mother) said so little, but he (Yeobright) could not remove the cause of her (mother) bearing towards him (Yeobright). These half-silent sittings were far from uncommon with them now. At last Yeobright made a beginning of what was intended to strike at the whole root of the matter.

``Five days have we sat like this at meals with scarcely a word. What's the use of it, Mother?'' (unknown)

``None,'' (she)
said she (mother), in a heart-swollen tone.
``But there is only too good a reason.'' (unknown)

``Not when you know all. I have been wanting to speak about this, and I am glad the subject is begun. The reason, of course, is Eustacia Vye. Well, I confess I have seen her (Mother) lately, and have seen her (Mother) a good many times.'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes; and I know what that amounts to. It troubles me, Clym. You are wasting your life here; and it is solely on account of her (Mother). If it had not been for that woman you would never have entertained this teaching scheme at all.'' (mother)

Clym looked hard at his (Yeobright) mother.

``You know that is not it,'' (he)
he (Yeobright) said.

``Well, I know you had decided to attempt it before you saw her (Mother); but that would have ended in intentions. It was very well to talk of, but ridiculous to put in practice. I fully expected that in the course of a month or two you would have seen the folly of such self-sacrifice, and would have been by this time back again to Paris in some business or other. I can understand objections to the diamond trade--I really was thinking that it might be inadequate to the life of a man like you even though it might have made you a millionaire. But now I see how mistaken you are about this girl I doubt if you could be correct about other things.'' (unknown)

``How am I mistaken in her (girl)?'' (unknown)

``She (girl) is lazy and dissatisfied. But that is not all of it. Supposing her (girl) to be as good a woman as any you can find, which she (girl) certainly is not, why do you wish to connect yourself with anybody at present?'' (unknown)

``Well, there are practical reasons,'' (unknown)
Clym began, and then almost broke off under an overpowering sense of the weight of argument which could be brought against his (Yeobright) statement.
``If I take a school an educated woman would be invaluable as a help to me.'' (unknown)

``What! you really mean to marry her (woman)?'' (unknown)

``It would be premature to state that plainly. But consider what obvious advantages there would be in doing it. She (woman)--'' (unknown)

``Don't suppose she (woman) has any money. She (woman) hasn't a farthing.'' (unknown)

``She (woman) is excellently educated, and would make a good matron in a boarding-school. I candidly own that I have modified my views a little, in deference to you; and it should satisfy you. I no longer adhere to my intention of giving with my own mouth rudimentary education to the lowest class. I can do better. I can establish a good private school for farmers' sons, and without stopping the school I can manage to pass examinations. By this means, and by the assistance of a wife like her (wife)--'' (unknown)

``Oh, Clym!'' (unknown)

``I shall ultimately, I hope, be at the head of one of the best schools in the county.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright had enunciated the word

``her (wife)'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
with a fervour which, in conversation with a mother, was absurdly indiscreet. Hardly a maternal heart within the four seas could in such circumstances, have helped being irritated at that ill-timed betrayal of feeling for a new woman.

``You are blinded, Clym,'' (she)
she (woman) said warmly.
``It was a bad day for you when you first set eyes on her (wife). And your scheme is merely a castle in the air built on purpose to justify this folly which has seized you, and to salve your conscience on the irrational situation you are in.'' (unknown)

``Mother, that's not true,'' (he)
he (Yeobright) firmly answered.

``Can you maintain that I sit and tell untruths, when all I wish to do is to save you from sorrow? For shame, Clym! But it is all through that woman--a hussy!'' (unknown)

Clym reddened like fire and rose. He (Yeobright) placed his (Yeobright) hand upon his (Yeobright) mother's shoulder and said, in a tone which hung strangely between entreaty and command,

``I won't hear it. I may be led to answer you in a way which we shall both regret.'' (mother)

His (Yeobright) mother parted her (mother) lips to begin some other vehement truth, but on looking at him (Yeobright) she (mother) saw that in his (Yeobright) face which led her (mother) to leave the words unsaid. Yeobright walked once or twice across the room, and then suddenly went out of the house. It was eleven o’clock when he (Yeobright) came in, though he (Yeobright) had not been further than the precincts of the garden. His (Yeobright) mother was gone to bed. A light was left burning on the table, and supper was spread. Without stopping for any food he (Yeobright) secured the doors and went upstairs.

4--An Hour of Bliss and Many Hours of Sadness

The next day was gloomy enough at Blooms-End. Yeobright remained in his (Bliss) study, sitting over the open books; but the work of those hours was miserably scant. Determined that there should be nothing in his (Bliss) conduct towards his (Bliss) mother resembling sullenness, he (Bliss) had occasionally spoken to her (mother) on passing matters, and would take no notice of the brevity of her (mother) replies. With the same resolve to keep up a show of conversation he (Bliss) said, about seven o’clock in the evening,

``There's an eclipse of the moon tonight. I am going out to see it.'' (he)
And, putting on his (Bliss) overcoat, he (Bliss) left her (mother).

The low moon was not as yet visible from the front of the house, and Yeobright climbed out of the valley until he (Bliss) stood in the full flood of her (mother) light. But even now he (Bliss) walked on, and his (Bliss) steps were in the direction of Rainbarrow.

In half an hour he (Bliss) stood at the top. The sky was clear from verge to verge, and the moon flung her (mother) rays over the whole heath, but without sensibly lighting it, except where paths and water-courses had laid bare the white flints and glistening quartz sand, which made streaks upon the general shade. After standing awhile he (Bliss) stooped and felt the heather. It was dry, and he (Bliss) flung himself down upon the barrow, his (Bliss) face towards the moon, which depicted a small image of herself in each of his (Bliss) eyes.

He (Bliss) had often come up here without stating his (Bliss) purpose to his (Bliss) mother; but this was the first time that he (Bliss) had been ostensibly frank as to his (Bliss) purpose while really concealing it. It was a moral situation which, three months earlier, he (Bliss) could hardly have credited of himself. In returning to labour in this sequestered spot he (Bliss) had anticipated an escape from the chafing of social necessities; yet behold they were here also. More than ever he (Bliss) longed to be in some world where personal ambition was not the only recognized form of progress--such, perhaps, as might have been the case at some time or other in the silvery globe then shining upon him (Bliss). His (Bliss) eye travelled over the length and breadth of that distant country--over the Bay of Rainbows, the sombre Sea of Crises, the Ocean of Storms, the Lake of Dreams, the vast Walled Plains, and the wondrous Ring Mountains--till he (Bliss) almost felt himself to be voyaging bodily through its wild scenes, standing on its hollow hills, traversing its deserts, descending its vales and old sea bottoms, or mounting to the edges of its craters.

While he (Bliss) watched the far-removed landscape a tawny stain grew into being on the lower verge--the eclipse had begun. This marked a preconcerted moment--for the remote celestial phenomenon had been pressed into sublunary service as a lover's signal. Yeobright's mind flew back to earth at the sight; he (lover) arose, shook himself and listened. Minute after minute passed by, perhaps ten minutes passed, and the shadow on the moon perceptibly widened. He (lover) heard a rustling on his (lover) left hand, a cloaked figure with an upturned face appeared at the base of the Barrow, and Clym descended. In a moment the figure was in his (lover) arms, and his (lover) lips upon hers.

``My Eustacia!'' (unknown)

``Clym, dearest!'' (unknown)

Such a situation had less than three months brought forth.

They remained long without a single utterance, for no language could reach the level of their condition--words were as the rusty implements of a by-gone barbarous epoch, and only to be occasionally tolerated.

``I began to wonder why you did not come,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright, when she (Yeobright) had withdrawn a little from his (lover) embrace.

``You said ten minutes after the first mark of shade on the edge of the moon, and that's what it is now.'' (unknown)

``Well, let us only think that here we are.'' (unknown)

Then, holding each other's hand, they were again silent, and the shadow on the moon's disc grew a little larger.

``Has it seemed long since you last saw me?'' (she)
she (Yeobright) asked.

``It has seemed sad.'' (unknown)

``And not long? That's because you occupy yourself, and so blind yourself to my absence. To me, who can do nothing, it has been like living under stagnant water.'' (unknown)

``I would rather bear tediousness, dear, than have time made short by such means as have shortened mine.'' (unknown)

``In what way is that? You have been thinking you wished you did not love me.'' (unknown)

``How can a man wish that, and yet love on? No, Eustacia.'' (unknown)

``Men can, women cannot.'' (unknown)

``Well, whatever I may have thought, one thing is certain--I do love you--past all compass and description. I love you to oppressiveness--I, who have never before felt more than a pleasant passing fancy for any woman I have ever seen. Let me look right into your moonlit face and dwell on every line and curve in it! Only a few hairbreadths make the difference between this face and faces I have seen many times before I knew you; yet what a difference--the difference between everything and nothing at all. One touch on that mouth again! there, and there, and there. Your eyes seem heavy, Eustacia.'' (unknown)

``No, it is my general way of looking. I think it arises from my feeling sometimes an agonizing pity for myself that I ever was born.'' (unknown)

``You don't feel it now?'' (unknown)

``No. Yet I know that we shall not love like this always. Nothing can ensure the continuance of love. It will evaporate like a spirit, and so I feel full of fears.'' (unknown)

``You need not.'' (unknown)

``Ah, you don't know. You have seen more than I, and have been into cities and among people that I have only heard of, and have lived more years than I; but yet I am older at this than you. I loved another man once, and now I love you.'' (unknown)

``In God's mercy don't talk so, Eustacia!'' (unknown)

``But I do not think I shall be the one who wearies first. It will, I fear, end in this way: your mother will find out that you meet me, and she (mother) will influence you against me!'' (unknown)

``That can never be. She (mother) knows of these meetings already.'' (unknown)

``And she (mother) speaks against me?'' (unknown)

``I will not say.'' (unknown)

``There, go away! Obey her (mother). I shall ruin you. It is foolish of you to meet me like this. Kiss me, and go away forever. Forever--do you hear?--forever!'' (unknown)

``Not I.'' (unknown)

``It is your only chance. Many a man's love has been a curse to him (man).'' (unknown)

``You are desperate, full of fancies, and wilful; and you misunderstand. I have an additional reason for seeing you tonight besides love of you. For though, unlike you, I feel our affection may be eternal. I feel with you in this, that our present mode of existence cannot last.'' (unknown)

``Oh! `tis your mother. Yes, that's it! I knew it.'' (unknown)

``Never mind what it is. Believe this, I cannot let myself lose you. I must have you always with me. This very evening I do not like to let you go. There is only one cure for this anxiety, dearest--you must be my wife.'' (She)

She (Yeobright) started--then endeavoured to say calmly,

``Cynics say that cures the anxiety by curing the love.'' (She)

``But you must answer me. Shall I claim you some day--I don't mean at once?'' (unknown)

``I must think,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
Eustacia murmured.
``At present speak of Paris to me. Is there any place like it on earth?'' (unknown)

``It is very beautiful. But will you be mine?'' (unknown)

``I will be nobody else's in the world--does that satisfy you?'' (unknown)

``Yes, for the present.'' (unknown)

``Now tell me of the Tuileries, and the Louvre,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) continued evasively.

``I hate talking of Paris! Well, I remember one sunny room in the Louvre which would make a fitting place for you to live in--the Galerie d’Apollon. Its windows are mainly east; and in the early morning, when the sun is bright, the whole apartment is in a perfect blaze of splendour. The rays bristle and dart from the encrustations of gilding to the magnificent inlaid coffers, from the coffers to the gold and silver plate, from the plate to the jewels and precious stones, from these to the enamels, till there is a perfect network of light which quite dazzles the eye. But now, about our marriage--'' (unknown)

``And Versailles--the King's Gallery is some such gorgeous room, is it not?'' (unknown)

``Yes. But what's the use of talking of gorgeous rooms? By the way, the Little Trianon would suit us beautifully to live in, and you might walk in the gardens in the moonlight and think you were in some English shrubbery; It is laid out in English fashion.'' (unknown)

``I should hate to think that!'' (unknown)

``Then you could keep to the lawn in front of the Grand Palace. All about there you would doubtless feel in a world of historical romance.'' (He)

He (lover) went on, since it was all new to her (Eustacia), and described Fontainebleau, St. Cloud, the Bois, and many other familiar haunts of the Parisians; till she (Eustacia) said--

``When used you to go to these places?'' (she)

``On Sundays.'' (unknown)

``Ah, yes. I dislike English Sundays. How I should chime in with their manners over there! Dear Clym, you'll go back again?'' (unknown)

Clym shook his (lover) head, and looked at the eclipse.

``If you'll go back again I'll--be something,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said tenderly, putting her (Eustacia) head near his (lover) breast.
``If you'll agree I'll give my promise, without making you wait a minute longer.'' (unknown)

``How extraordinary that you and my mother should be of one mind about this!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.
``I have vowed not to go back, Eustacia. It is not the place I dislike; it is the occupation.'' (unknown)

``But you can go in some other capacity.'' (unknown)

``No. Besides, it would interfere with my scheme. Don't press that, Eustacia. Will you marry me?'' (unknown)

``I cannot tell.'' (unknown)

``Now--never mind Paris; it is no better than other spots. Promise, sweet!'' (unknown)

``You will never adhere to your education plan, I am quite sure; and then it will be all right for me; and so I promise to be yours for ever and ever.'' (her)

Clym brought her (Eustacia) face towards his (lover) by a gentle pressure of the hand, and kissed her (Eustacia).

``Ah! but you don't know what you have got in me,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.
``Sometimes I think there is not that in Eustacia Vye which will make a good homespun wife. Well, let it go--see how our time is slipping, slipping, slipping!'' (She)
She (Eustacia) pointed towards the half-eclipsed moon.

``You are too mournful.'' (unknown)

``No. Only I dread to think of anything beyond the present. What is, we know. We are together now, and it is unknown how long we shall be so; the unknown always fills my mind with terrible possibilities, even when I may reasonably expect it to be cheerful... Clym, the eclipsed moonlight shines upon your face with a strange foreign colour, and shows its shape as if it were cut out in gold. That means that you should be doing better things than this.'' (unknown)

``You are ambitious, Eustacia--no, not exactly ambitious, luxurious. I ought to be of the same vein, to make you happy, I suppose. And yet, far from that, I could live and die in a hermitage here, with proper work to do.'' (a lover)

There was that in his (lover) tone which implied distrust of his (lover) position as a solicitous lover, a doubt if he (lover) were acting fairly towards one whose tastes touched his (lover) own only at rare and infrequent points. She (Eustacia) saw his (lover) meaning, and whispered, in a low, full accent of eager assurance

``Don't mistake me, Clym--though I should like Paris, I love you for yourself alone. To be your wife and live in Paris would be heaven to me; but I would rather live with you in a hermitage here than not be yours at all. It is gain to me either way, and very great gain. There's my too candid confession.'' (She)

``Spoken like a woman. And now I must soon leave you. I'll walk with you towards your house.'' (unknown)

``But must you go home yet?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) asked.
``Yes, the sand has nearly slipped away, I see, and the eclipse is creeping on more and more. Don't go yet! Stop till the hour has run itself out; then I will not press you any more. You will go home and sleep well; I keep sighing in my sleep! Do you ever dream of me?'' (unknown)

``I cannot recollect a clear dream of you.'' (unknown)

``I see your face in every scene of my dreams, and hear your voice in every sound. I wish I did not. It is too much what I feel. They say such love never lasts. But it must! And yet once, I remember, I saw an officer of the Hussars ride down the street at Budmouth, and though he (officer) was a total stranger and never spoke to me, I loved him (officer) till I thought I should really die of love--but I didn't die, and at last I left off caring for him (officer). How terrible it would be if a time should come when I could not love you, my Clym!'' (unknown)

``Please don't say such reckless things. When we see such a time at hand we will say, `I have outlived my faith and purpose,' and die. There, the hour has expired--now let us walk on.'' (unknown)

Hand in hand they went along the path towards Mistover. When they were near the house he (lover) said,

``It is too late for me to see your grandfather tonight. Do you think he (grandfather) will object to it?'' (he)

``I will speak to him (grandfather). I am so accustomed to be my own mistress that it did not occur to me that we should have to ask him (grandfather).'' (unknown)

Then they lingeringly separated, and Clym descended towards Blooms-End.

And as he (lover) walked further and further from the charmed atmosphere of his (lover) Olympian girl his (lover) face grew sad with a new sort of sadness. A perception of the dilemma in which his (lover) love had placed him (lover) came back in full force. In spite of Eustacia's apparent willingness to wait through the period of an unpromising engagement, till he (lover) should be established in his (lover) new pursuit, he (lover) could not but perceive at moments that she (Eustacia) loved him (lover) rather as a visitant from a gay world to which she (Eustacia) rightly belonged than as a man with a purpose opposed to that recent past of his (man) which so interested her (Eustacia). It meant that, though she (Eustacia) made no conditions as to his (man) return to the French capital, this was what she (Eustacia) secretly longed for in the event of marriage; and it robbed him (man) of many an otherwise pleasant hour. Along with that came the widening breach between himself and his (man) mother. Whenever any little occurrence had brought into more prominence than usual the disappointment that he (man) was causing her (mother) it had sent him (man) on lone and moody walks; or he (man) was kept awake a great part of the night by the turmoil of spirit which such a recognition created. If Mrs. Yeobright could only have been led to see what a sound and worthy purpose this purpose of his (man) was and how little it was being affected by his (man) devotions to Eustacia, how differently would she (Eustacia) regard him (man)!

Thus as his (man) sight grew accustomed to the first blinding halo kindled about him (man) by love and beauty, Yeobright began to perceive what a strait he (man) was in. Sometimes he (man) wished that he (man) had never known Eustacia, immediately to retract the wish as brutal. Three antagonistic growths had to be kept alive: his (man) mother's trust in him (man), his (man) plan for becoming a teacher, and Eustacia's happiness. His (man) fervid nature could not afford to relinquish one of these, though two of the three were as many as he (man) could hope to preserve. Though his (man) love was as chaste as that of Petrarch for his (man) Laura, it had made fetters of what previously was only a difficulty. A position which was not too simple when he (man) stood whole-hearted had become indescribably complicated by the addition of Eustacia. Just when his (man) mother was beginning to tolerate one scheme he (man) had introduced another still bitterer than the first, and the combination was more than she (mother) could bear.

5--Sharp Words Are Spoken, and a Crisis Ensues

When Yeobright was not with Eustacia he (man) was sitting slavishly over his (man) books; when he (man) was not reading he (man) was meeting her (Eustacia). These meetings were carried on with the greatest secrecy.

One afternoon his (man) mother came home from a morning visit to Thomasin. He (man) could see from a disturbance in the lines of her (mother) face that something had happened.

``I have been told an incomprehensible thing,'' (she)
she (mother) said mournfully.
``The captain has let out at the Woman that you and Eustacia Vye are engaged to be married.'' (unknown)

``We are,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.
``But it may not be yet for a very long time.'' (unknown)

``I should hardly think it WOULD be yet for a very long time! You will take her (Woman) to Paris, I suppose?'' (She)
She (mother) spoke with weary hopelessness.

``I am not going back to Paris.'' (unknown)

``What will you do with a wife, then?'' (unknown)

``Keep a school in Budmouth, as I have told you.'' (unknown)

``That's incredible! The place is overrun with schoolmasters. You have no special qualifications. What possible chance is there for such as you?'' (unknown)

``There is no chance of getting rich. But with my system of education, which is as new as it is true, I shall do a great deal of good to my fellow-creatures.'' (unknown)

``Dreams, dreams! If there had been any system left to be invented they would have found it out at the universities long before this time.'' (unknown)

``Never, Mother. They cannot find it out, because their teachers don't come in contact with the class which demands such a system--that is, those who have had no preliminary training. My plan is one for instilling high knowledge into empty minds without first cramming them with what has to be uncrammed again before true study begins.'' (unknown)

``I might have believed you if you had kept yourself free from entanglements; but this woman--if she (woman) had been a good girl it would have been bad enough; but being--'' (unknown)

``She (woman) is a good girl.'' (unknown)

``So you think. A Corfu bandmaster's daughter! What has her (daughter) life been? Her (daughter) surname even is not her (daughter) true one.'' (unknown)

``She (daughter) is Captain Vye's granddaughter, and her (daughter) father merely took her (daughter) mother's name. And she (daughter) is a lady by instinct.'' (unknown)

``They call him (father) `captain,' but anybody is captain.'' (unknown)

``He (captain) was in the Royal Navy!'' (unknown)

``No doubt he (captain) has been to sea in some tub or other. Why doesn't he (captain) look after her (daughter)? No lady would rove about the heath at all hours of the day and night as she (lady) does. But that's not all of it. There was something queer between her (lady) and Thomasin's husband at one time--I am as sure of it as that I stand here.'' (unknown)

``Eustacia has told me. He (husband) did pay her (lady) a little attention a year ago; but there's no harm in that. I like her (lady) all the better.'' (unknown)

``Clym,'' (mother)
said his (man) mother with firmness,
``I have no proofs against her (lady), unfortunately. But if she (lady) makes you a good wife, there has never been a bad one.'' (mother)

``Believe me, you are almost exasperating,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright vehemently.
``And this very day I had intended to arrange a meeting between you. But you give me no peace; you try to thwart my wishes in everything.'' (unknown)

``I hate the thought of any son of mine marrying badly! I wish I had never lived to see this; it is too much for me--it is more than I dreamt!'' (She)
She (mother) turned to the window. Her (mother) breath was coming quickly, and her (mother) lips were pale, parted, and trembling.

``Mother,'' (unknown)
said Clym,
``whatever you do, you will always be dear to me--that you know. But one thing I have a right to say, which is, that at my age I am old enough to know what is best for me.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright remained for some time silent and shaken, as if she (Yeobright) could say no more. Then she (Yeobright) replied,

``Best? Is it best for you to injure your prospects for such a voluptuous, idle woman as that? Don't you see that by the very fact of your choosing her (woman) you prove that you do not know what is best for you? You give up your whole thought--you set your whole soul--to please a woman.'' (she)

``I do. And that woman is you.'' (unknown)

``How can you treat me so flippantly!'' (mother)
said his (man) mother, turning again to him (man) with a tearful look.
``You are unnatural, Clym, and I did not expect it.'' (unknown)

``Very likely,'' (he)
said he (man) cheerlessly.
``You did not know the measure you were going to mete me, and therefore did not know the measure that would be returned to you again.'' (unknown)

``You answer me; you think only of her (woman). You stick to her (woman) in all things.'' (unknown)

``That proves her (woman) to be worthy. I have never yet supported what is bad. And I do not care only for her (woman). I care for you and for myself, and for anything that is good. When a woman once dislikes another she (woman) is merciless!'' (unknown)

``O Clym! please don't go setting down as my fault what is your obstinate wrongheadedness. If you wished to connect yourself with an unworthy person why did you come home here to do it? Why didn't you do it in Paris?--it is more the fashion there. You have come only to distress me, a lonely woman, and shorten my days! I wish that you would bestow your presence where you bestow your love!'' (unknown)

Clym said huskily,

``You are my mother. I will say no more--beyond this, that I beg your pardon for having thought this my home. I will no longer inflict myself upon you; I'll go.'' (he)
And he (man) went out with tears in his (man) eyes.

It was a sunny afternoon at the beginning of summer, and the moist hollows of the heath had passed from their brown to their green stage. Yeobright walked to the edge of the basin which extended down from Mistover and Rainbarrow.

By this time he (man) was calm, and he (man) looked over the landscape. In the minor valleys, between the hillocks which diversified the contour of the vale, the fresh young ferns were luxuriantly growing up, ultimately to reach a height of five or six feet. He (man) descended a little way, flung himself down in a spot where a path emerged from one of the small hollows, and waited. Hither it was that he (man) had promised Eustacia to bring his (man) mother this afternoon, that they might meet and be friends. His (man) attempt had utterly failed.

He (man) was in a nest of vivid green. The ferny vegetation round him (man), though so abundant, was quite uniform--it was a grove of machine-made foliage, a world of green triangles with saw-edges, and not a single flower. The air was warm with a vaporous warmth, and the stillness was unbroken. Lizards, grasshoppers, and ants were the only living things to be beheld. The scene seemed to belong to the ancient world of the carboniferous period, when the forms of plants were few, and of the fern kind; when there was neither bud nor blossom, nothing but a monotonous extent of leafage, amid which no bird sang.

When he (Lizards) had reclined for some considerable time, gloomily pondering, he (Lizards) discerned above the ferns a drawn bonnet of white silk approaching from the left, and Yeobright knew directly that it covered the head of her (it) he (Lizards) loved. His (Lizards) heart awoke from its apathy to a warm excitement, and, jumping to his (Lizards) feet, he (Lizards) said aloud,

``I knew she (mother) was sure to come.'' (he)

She (it) vanished in a hollow for a few moments, and then her (it) whole form unfolded itself from the brake.

``Only you here?'' (she)
she (it) exclaimed, with a disappointed air, whose hollowness was proved by her (it) rising redness and her (it) half-guilty low laugh.
``Where is Mrs. Yeobright?'' (unknown)

``She (Yeobright) has not come,'' (he)
he (Lizards) replied in a subdued tone.

``I wish I had known that you would be here alone,'' (she)
she (it) said seriously,
``and that we were going to have such an idle, pleasant time as this. Pleasure not known beforehand is half wasted; to anticipate it is to double it. I have not thought once today of having you all to myself this afternoon, and the actual moment of a thing is so soon gone.'' (she)

``It is indeed.'' (unknown)

``Poor Clym!'' (she)
she (it) continued, looking tenderly into his (Lizards) face.
``You are sad. Something has happened at your home. Never mind what is--let us only look at what seems.'' (unknown)

``But, darling, what shall we do?'' (he)
said he (Lizards).

``Still go on as we do now--just live on from meeting to meeting, never minding about another day. You, I know, are always thinking of that--I can see you are. But you must not--will you, dear Clym?'' (unknown)

``You are just like all women. They are ever content to build their lives on any incidental position that offers itself; whilst men would fain make a globe to suit them. Listen to this, Eustacia. There is a subject I have determined to put off no longer. Your sentiment on the wisdom of Carpe diem does not impress me today. Our present mode of life must shortly be brought to an end.'' (unknown)

``It is your mother!'' (unknown)

``It is. I love you none the less in telling you; it is only right you should know.'' (unknown)

``I have feared my bliss,'' (she)
she (it) said, with the merest motion of her (it) lips.
``It has been too intense and consuming.'' (unknown)

``There is hope yet. There are forty years of work in me yet, and why should you despair? I am only at an awkward turning. I wish people wouldn't be so ready to think that there is no progress without uniformity.'' (unknown)

``Ah--your mind runs off to the philosophical side of it. Well, these sad and hopeless obstacles are welcome in one sense, for they enable us to look with indifference upon the cruel satires that Fate loves to indulge in. I have heard of people, who, upon coming suddenly into happiness, have died from anxiety lest they should not live to enjoy it. I felt myself in that whimsical state of uneasiness lately; but I shall be spared it now. Let us walk on.'' (him)

Clym took the hand which was already bared for him (Lizards)--it was a favourite way with them to walk bare hand in bare hand--and led her (it) through the ferns. They formed a very comely picture of love at full flush, as they walked along the valley that late afternoon, the sun sloping down on their right, and throwing their thin spectral shadows, tall as poplar trees, far out across the furze and fern. Eustacia went with her (Eustacia) head thrown back fancifully, a certain glad and voluptuous air of triumph pervading her (Eustacia) eyes at having won by her (Eustacia) own unaided self a man who was her (Eustacia) perfect complement in attainment, appearance, and age. On the young man's part, the paleness of face which he (man) had brought with him (man) from Paris, and the incipient marks of time and thought, were less perceptible than when he (man) returned, the healthful and energetic sturdiness which was his (man) by nature having partially recovered its original proportions. They wandered onward till they reached the nether margin of the heath, where it became marshy and merged in moorland.

``I must part from you here, Clym,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.

They stood still and prepared to bid each other farewell. Everything before them was on a perfect level. The sun, resting on the horizon line, streamed across the ground from between copper-coloured and lilac clouds, stretched out in flats beneath a sky of pale soft green. All dark objects on the earth that lay towards the sun were overspread by a purple haze, against which groups of wailing gnats shone out, rising upwards and dancing about like sparks of fire.

``O! this leaving you is too hard to bear!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
exclaimed Eustacia in a sudden whisper of anguish.
``Your mother will influence you too much; I shall not be judged fairly, it will get afloat that I am not a good girl, and the witch story will be added to make me blacker!'' (unknown)

``They cannot. Nobody dares to speak disrespectfully of you or of me.'' (unknown)

``Oh how I wish I was sure of never losing you--that you could not be able to desert me anyhow!'' (unknown)

Clym stood silent a moment. His (groups) feelings were high, the moment was passionate, and he (groups) cut the knot.

``You shall be sure of me, darling,'' (he)
he (groups) said, folding her (Eustacia) in his (groups) arms.
``We will be married at once.'' (unknown)

``O Clym!'' (unknown)

``Do you agree to it?'' (unknown)

``If--if we can.'' (unknown)

``We certainly can, both being of full age. And I have not followed my occupation all these years without having accumulated money; and if you will agree to live in a tiny cottage somewhere on the heath, until I take a house in Budmouth for the school, we can do it at a very little expense.'' (unknown)

``How long shall we have to live in the tiny cottage, Clym?'' (unknown)

``About six months. At the end of that time I shall have finished my reading--yes, we will do it, and this heart-aching will be over. We shall, of course, live in absolute seclusion, and our married life will only begin to outward view when we take the house in Budmouth, where I have already addressed a letter on the matter. Would your grandfather allow you?'' (unknown)

``I think he (grandfather) would--on the understanding that it should not last longer than six months.'' (unknown)

``I will guarantee that, if no misfortune happens.'' (unknown)

``If no misfortune happens,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) repeated slowly.

``Which is not likely. Dearest, fix the exact day.'' (unknown)

And then they consulted on the question, and the day was chosen. It was to be a fortnight from that time.

This was the end of their talk, and Eustacia left him (groups). Clym watched her (Eustacia) as she (Eustacia) retired towards the sun. The luminous rays wrapped her (Eustacia) up with her (Eustacia) increasing distance, and the rustle of her (Eustacia) dress over the sprouting sedge and grass died away. As he (groups) watched, the dead flat of the scenery overpowered him (groups), though he (groups) was fully alive to the beauty of that untarnished early summer green which was worn for the nonce by the poorest blade. There was something in its oppressive horizontality which too much reminded him (groups) of the arena of life; it gave him (groups) a sense of bare equality with, and no superiority to, a single living thing under the sun.

Eustacia was now no longer the goddess but the woman to him (groups), a being to fight for, support, help, be maligned for. Now that he (groups) had reached a cooler moment he (groups) would have preferred a less hasty marriage; but the card was laid, and he (groups) determined to abide by the game. Whether Eustacia was to add one other to the list of those who love too hotly to love long and well, the forthcoming event was certainly a ready way of proving.

6--Yeobright Goes, and the Breach Is Complete

All that evening smart sounds denoting an active packing up came from Yeobright's room to the ears of his (groups) mother downstairs.

Next morning he (groups) departed from the house and again proceeded across the heath. A long day's march was before him (groups), his (groups) object being to secure a dwelling to which he (groups) might take Eustacia when she (Eustacia) became his (groups) wife. Such a house, small, secluded, and with its windows boarded up, he (groups) had casually observed a month earlier, about two miles beyond the village of East Egdon, and six miles distant altogether; and thither he (groups) directed his (groups) steps today.

The weather was far different from that of the evening before. The yellow and vapoury sunset which had wrapped up Eustacia from his (groups) parting gaze had presaged change. It was one of those not infrequent days of an English June which are as wet and boisterous as November. The cold clouds hastened on in a body, as if painted on a moving slide. Vapours from other continents arrived upon the wind, which curled and parted round him (groups) as he (groups) walked on.

At length Clym reached the margin of a fir and beech plantation that had been enclosed from heath land in the year of his (groups) birth. Here the trees, laden heavily with their new and humid leaves, were now suffering more damage than during the highest winds of winter, when the boughs are especially disencumbered to do battle with the storm. The wet young beeches were undergoing amputations, bruises, cripplings, and harsh lacerations, from which the wasting sap would bleed for many a day to come, and which would leave scars visible till the day of their burning. Each stem was wrenched at the root, where it moved like a bone in its socket, and at every onset of the gale convulsive sounds came from the branches, as if pain were felt. In a neighbouring brake a finch was trying to sing; but the wind blew under his (finch) feathers till they stood on end, twisted round his (finch) little tail, and made him (finch) give up his (finch) song.

Yet a few yards to Yeobright's left, on the open heath, how ineffectively gnashed the storm! Those gusts which tore the trees merely waved the furze and heather in a light caress. Egdon was made for such times as these.

Yeobright reached the empty house about midday. It was almost as lonely as that of Eustacia's grandfather, but the fact that it stood near a heath was disguised by a belt of firs which almost enclosed the premises. He (grandfather) journeyed on about a mile further to the village in which the owner lived, and, returning with him (owner) to the house, arrangements were completed, and the man undertook that one room at least should be ready for occupation the next day. Clym's intention was to live there alone until Eustacia should join him (man) on their wedding-day.

Then he (man) turned to pursue his (man) way homeward through the drizzle that had so greatly transformed the scene. The ferns, among which he (man) had lain in comfort yesterday, were dripping moisture from every frond, wetting his (man) legs through as he (man) brushed past; and the fur of the rabbits leaping before him (man) was clotted into dark locks by the same watery surrounding.

He (man) reached home damp and weary enough after his (man) ten-mile walk. It had hardly been a propitious beginning, but he (man) had chosen his (man) course, and would show no swerving. The evening and the following morning were spent in concluding arrangements for his (man) departure. To stay at home a minute longer than necessary after having once come to his (man) determination would be, he (man) felt, only to give new pain to his (man) mother by some word, look, or deed.

He (man) had hired a conveyance and sent off his (man) goods by two o’clock that day. The next step was to get some furniture, which, after serving for temporary use in the cottage, would be available for the house at Budmouth when increased by goods of a better description. A mart extensive enough for the purpose existed at Anglebury, some miles beyond the spot chosen for his (man) residence, and there he (man) resolved to pass the coming night.

It now only remained to wish his (man) mother good-bye. She (mother) was sitting by the window as usual when he (man) came downstairs.

``Mother, I am going to leave you,'' (he)
he (man) said, holding out his (man) hand.

``I thought you were, by your packing,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
replied Mrs. Yeobright in a voice from which every particle of emotion was painfully excluded.

``And you will part friends with me?'' (unknown)

``Certainly, Clym.'' (unknown)

``I am going to be married on the twenty-fifth.'' (unknown)

``I thought you were going to be married.'' (unknown)

``And then--and then you must come and see us. You will understand me better after that, and our situation will not be so wretched as it is now.'' (unknown)

``I do not think it likely I shall come to see you.'' (unknown)

``Then it will not be my fault or Eustacia's, Mother. Good-bye!'' (He)

He (man) kissed her (Yeobright) cheek, and departed in great misery, which was several hours in lessening itself to a controllable level. The position had been such that nothing more could be said without, in the first place, breaking down a barrier; and that was not to be done.

No sooner had Yeobright gone from his (man) mother's house than her (mother) face changed its rigid aspect for one of blank despair. After a while she (mother) wept, and her (mother) tears brought some relief. During the rest of the day she (mother) did nothing but walk up and down the garden path in a state bordering on stupefaction. Night came, and with it but little rest. The next day, with an instinct to do something which should reduce prostration to mournfulness, she (mother) went to her (mother) son's room, and with her (mother) own hands arranged it in order, for an imaginary time when he (son) should return again. She (mother) gave some attention to her (mother) flowers, but it was perfunctorily bestowed, for they no longer charmed her (mother).

It was a great relief when, early in the afternoon, Thomasin paid her (mother) an unexpected visit. This was not the first meeting between the relatives since Thomasin's marriage; and past blunders having been in a rough way rectified, they could always greet each other with pleasure and ease.

The oblique band of sunlight which followed her (mother) through the door became the young wife well. It illuminated her (wife) as her (wife) presence illuminated the heath. In her (wife) movements, in her (wife) gaze, she (wife) reminded the beholder of the feathered creatures who lived around her (wife) home. All similes and allegories concerning her (wife) began and ended with birds. There was as much variety in her (wife) motions as in their flight. When she (wife) was musing she (wife) was a kestrel, which hangs in the air by an invisible motion of its wings. When she (wife) was in a high wind her (wife) light body was blown against trees and banks like a heron's. When she (wife) was frightened she (wife) darted noiselessly like a kingfisher. When she (wife) was serene she (wife) skimmed like a swallow, and that is how she (wife) was moving now.

``You are looking very blithe, upon my word, Tamsie,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright, with a sad smile.
``How is Damon?'' (unknown)

``He (Damon) is very well.'' (unknown)

``Is he (Damon) kind to you, Thomasin?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
And Mrs. Yeobright observed her (Yeobright) narrowly.

``Pretty fairly.'' (unknown)

``Is that honestly said?'' (unknown)

``Yes, Aunt. I would tell you if he (Damon) were unkind.'' (She)
She (Yeobright) added, blushing, and with hesitation,
``He (Damon)--I don't know if I ought to complain to you about this, but I am not quite sure what to do. I want some money, you know, Aunt--some to buy little things for myself--and he (Damon) doesn't give me any. I don't like to ask him (Damon); and yet, perhaps, he (Damon) doesn't give it me because he (Damon) doesn't know. Ought I to mention it to him (Damon), Aunt?'' (She)

``Of course you ought. Have you never said a word on the matter?'' (unknown)

``You see, I had some of my own,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin evasively,
``and I have not wanted any of his (Damon) until lately. I did just say something about it last week; but he (Damon) seems--not to remember.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

``He (Damon) must be made to remember. You are aware that I have a little box full of spade-guineas, which your uncle put into my hands to divide between yourself and Clym whenever I chose. Perhaps the time has come when it should be done. They can be turned into sovereigns at any moment.'' (unknown)

``I think I should like to have my share--that is, if you don't mind.'' (unknown)

``You shall, if necessary. But it is only proper that you should first tell your husband distinctly that you are without any, and see what he (husband) will do.'' (unknown)

``Very well, I will... Aunt, I have heard about Clym. I know you are in trouble about him (husband), and that's why I have come.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright turned away, and her (Yeobright) features worked in her (Yeobright) attempt to conceal her (Yeobright) feelings. Then she (Yeobright) ceased to make any attempt, and said, weeping,

``O Thomasin, do you think he (husband) hates me? How can he (husband) bear to grieve me so, when I have lived only for him (husband) through all these years?'' (she)

``Hate you--no,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin soothingly.
``It is only that he (husband) loves her (Aunt) too well. Look at it quietly--do. It is not so very bad of him (husband). Do you know, I thought it not the worst match he (husband) could have made. Miss Vye's family is a good one on her (Aunt) mother's side; and her (Aunt) father was a romantic wanderer--a sort of Greek Ulysses.'' (unknown)

``It is no use, Thomasin; it is no use. Your intention is good; but I will not trouble you to argue. I have gone through the whole that can be said on either side times, and many times. Clym and I have not parted in anger; we have parted in a worse way. It is not a passionate quarrel that would have broken my heart; it is the steady opposition and persistence in going wrong that he (father) has shown. O Thomasin, he (father) was so good as a little boy--so tender and kind!'' (unknown)

``He (father) was, I know.'' (unknown)

``I did not think one whom I called mine would grow up to treat me like this. He (father) spoke to me as if I opposed him (father) to injure him (father). As though I could wish him (father) ill!'' (unknown)

``There are worse women in the world than Eustacia Vye.'' (unknown)

``There are too many better that's the agony of it. It was she (I), Thomasin, and she (I) only, who led your husband to act as he (husband) did--I would swear it!'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin eagerly.
``It was before he (husband) knew me that he (husband) thought of her (I), and it was nothing but a mere flirtation.'' (unknown)

``Very well; we will let it be so. There is little use in unravelling that now. Sons must be blind if they will. Why is it that a woman can see from a distance what a man cannot see close? Clym must do as he (man) will--he (man) is nothing more to me. And this is maternity--to give one's best years and best love to ensure the fate of being despised!'' (unknown)

``You are too unyielding. Think how many mothers there are whose sons have brought them to public shame by real crimes before you feel so deeply a case like this.'' (unknown)

``Thomasin, don't lecture me--I can't have it. It is the excess above what we expect that makes the force of the blow, and that may not be greater in their case than in mine--they may have foreseen the worst... I am wrongly made, Thomasin,'' (she)
she (Yeobright) added, with a mournful smile.
``Some widows can guard against the wounds their children give them by turning their hearts to another husband and beginning life again. But I always was a poor, weak, one-idea'd creature--I had not the compass of heart nor the enterprise for that. Just as forlorn and stupefied as I was when my husband's spirit flew away I have sat ever since--never attempting to mend matters at all. I was comparatively a young woman then, and I might have had another family by this time, and have been comforted by them for the failure of this one son.'' (unknown)

``It is more noble in you that you did not.'' (unknown)

``The more noble, the less wise.'' (unknown)

``Forget it, and be soothed, dear Aunt. And I shall not leave you alone for long. I shall come and see you every day.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

And for one week Thomasin literally fulfilled her (Yeobright) word. She (Yeobright) endeavoured to make light of the wedding; and brought news of the preparations, and that she (Yeobright) was invited to be present. The next week she (Yeobright) was rather unwell, and did not appear. Nothing had as yet been done about the guineas, for Thomasin feared to address her (Yeobright) husband again on the subject, and Mrs. Yeobright had insisted upon this.

One day just before this time Wildeve was standing at the door of the Quiet Woman. In addition to the upward path through the heath to Rainbarrow and Mistover, there was a road which branched from the highway a short distance below the inn, and ascended to Mistover by a circuitous and easy incline. This was the only route on that side for vehicles to the captain's retreat. A light cart from the nearest town descended the road, and the lad who was driving pulled up in front of the inn for something to drink.

``You come from Mistover?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

``Yes. They are taking in good things up there. Going to be a wedding.'' (the driver)
And the driver buried his (Wildeve) face in his (driver) mug.

Wildeve had not received an inkling of the fact before, and a sudden expression of pain overspread his (Wildeve) face. He (Wildeve) turned for a moment into the passage to hide it. Then he (Wildeve) came back again.

``Do you mean Miss Vye?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.
``How is it--that she (Aunt) can be married so soon?'' (unknown)

``By the will of God and a ready young man, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``You don't mean Mr. Yeobright?'' (unknown)

``Yes. He (Yeobright) has been creeping about with her (Aunt) all the spring.'' (unknown)

``I suppose--she (Aunt) was immensely taken with him (Yeobright)?'' (unknown)

``She (Aunt) is crazy about him (Yeobright), so their general servant of all work tells me. And that lad Charley that looks after the horse is all in a daze about it. The stun-poll has got fond-like of her (Aunt).'' (unknown)

``Is she (Aunt) lively--is she (Aunt) glad? Going to be married so soon--well!'' (unknown)

``It isn't so very soon.'' (unknown)

``No; not so very soon.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve went indoors to the empty room, a curious heartache within him (Wildeve). He (Wildeve) rested his (Wildeve) elbow upon the mantelpiece and his (Wildeve) face upon his (Wildeve) hand. When Thomasin entered the room he (Wildeve) did not tell her (Wildeve) of what he (Wildeve) had heard. The old longing for Eustacia had reappeared in his (Wildeve) soul--and it was mainly because he (Wildeve) had discovered that it was another man's intention to possess her (Eustacia).

To be yearning for the difficult, to be weary of that offered; to care for the remote, to dislike the near; it was Wildeve's nature always. This is the true mark of the man of sentiment. Though Wildeve's fevered feeling had not been elaborated to real poetical compass, it was of the standard sort. His (Wildeve) might have been called the Rousseau of Egdon.

7--The Morning and the Evening of a Day

The wedding morning came. Nobody would have imagined from appearances that Blooms-End had any interest in Mistover that day. A solemn stillness prevailed around the house of Clym's mother, and there was no more animation indoors. Mrs. Yeobright, who had declined to attend the ceremony, sat by the breakfast table in the old room which communicated immediately with the porch, her (Yeobright) eyes listlessly directed towards the open door. It was the room in which, six months earlier, the merry Christmas party had met, to which Eustacia came secretly and as a stranger. The only living thing that entered now was a sparrow; and seeing no movements to cause alarm, he (stranger) hopped boldly round the room, endeavoured to go out by the window, and fluttered among the pot-flowers. This roused the lonely sitter, who got up, released the bird, and went to the door. She (sitter) was expecting Thomasin, who had written the night before to state that the time had come when she (sitter) would wish to have the money and that she (sitter) would if possible call this day.

Yet Thomasin occupied Mrs. Yeobright's thoughts but slightly as she (Yeobright) looked up the valley of the heath, alive with butterflies, and with grasshoppers whose husky noises on every side formed a whispered chorus. A domestic drama, for which the preparations were now being made a mile or two off, was but little less vividly present to her (Yeobright) eyes than if enacted before her (Yeobright). She (Yeobright) tried to dismiss the vision, and walked about the garden plot; but her (Yeobright) eyes ever and anon sought out the direction of the parish church to which Mistover belonged, and her (Yeobright) excited fancy clove the hills which divided the building from her (Yeobright) eyes. The morning wore away. Eleven o’clock struck--could it be that the wedding was then in progress? It must be so. She (Yeobright) went on imagining the scene at the church, which he (Yeobright) had by this time approached with his (Yeobright) bride. She (bride) pictured the little group of children by the gate as the pony carriage drove up in which, as Thomasin had learnt, they were going to perform the short journey. Then she (bride) saw them enter and proceed to the chancel and kneel; and the service seemed to go on.

She (bride) covered her (bride) face with her (bride) hands.

``O, it is a mistake!'' (she)
she (bride) groaned.
``And he (Charley) will rue it some day, and think of me!'' (she)

While she (bride) remained thus, overcome by her (bride) forebodings, the old clock indoors whizzed forth twelve strokes. Soon after, faint sounds floated to her (bride) ear from afar over the hills. The breeze came from that quarter, and it had brought with it the notes of distant bells, gaily starting off in a peal: one, two, three, four, five. The ringers at East Egdon were announcing the nuptials of Eustacia and her (Eustacia) son.

``Then it is over,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) murmured. ``Well, well! and life too will be over soon. And why should I go on scalding my face like this? Cry about one thing in life, cry about all; one thread runs through the whole piece. And yet we say, `a time to laugh!'''

Towards evening Wildeve came. Since Thomasin's marriage Mrs. Yeobright had shown him (Wildeve) that grim friendliness which at last arises in all such cases of undesired affinity. The vision of what ought to have been is thrown aside in sheer weariness, and browbeaten human endeavour listlessly makes the best of the fact that is. Wildeve, to do him (Wildeve) justice, had behaved very courteously to his (Wildeve) wife's aunt; and it was with no surprise that she (aunt) saw him (Wildeve) enter now.

``Thomasin has not been able to come, as she (aunt) promised to do,'' (he)
he (son) replied to her (Eustacia) inquiry, which had been anxious, for she (Eustacia) knew that her (Eustacia) niece was badly in want of money.
``The captain came down last night and personally pressed her (aunt) to join them today. So, not to be unpleasant, she (aunt) determined to go. They fetched her (aunt) in the pony-chaise, and are going to bring her (aunt) back.'' (unknown)

``Then it is done,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright.
``Have they gone to their new home?'' (unknown)

``I don't know. I have had no news from Mistover since Thomasin left to go.'' (unknown)

``You did not go with her (aunt)?'' (she)
said she (Yeobright), as if there might be good reasons why.

``I could not,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve, reddening slightly.
``We could not both leave the house; it was rather a busy morning, on account of Anglebury Great Market. I believe you have something to give to Thomasin? If you like, I will take it.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright hesitated, and wondered if Wildeve knew what the something was.

``Did she (aunt) tell you of this?'' (she)
she (Yeobright) inquired.

``Not particularly. She (aunt) casually dropped a remark about having arranged to fetch some article or other.'' (unknown)

``It is hardly necessary to send it. She (aunt) can have it whenever she (aunt) chooses to come.'' (unknown)

``That won't be yet. In the present state of her (aunt) health she (aunt) must not go on walking so much as she (aunt) has done.'' (He)
He (Wildeve) added, with a faint twang of sarcasm,
``What wonderful thing is it that I cannot be trusted to take?'' (He)

``Nothing worth troubling you with.'' (unknown)

``One would think you doubted my honesty,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said, with a laugh, though his (Wildeve) colour rose in a quick resentfulness frequent with him (Wildeve).

``You need think no such thing,'' (she)
said she (Yeobright) drily.
``It is simply that I, in common with the rest of the world, feel that there are certain things which had better be done by certain people than by others.'' (unknown)

``As you like, as you like,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve laconically.
``It is not worth arguing about. Well, I think I must turn homeward again, as the inn must not be left long in charge of the lad and the maid only.'' (He)

He (Wildeve) went his (Wildeve) way, his (Wildeve) farewell being scarcely so courteous as his (Wildeve) greeting. But Mrs. Yeobright knew him (Wildeve) thoroughly by this time, and took little notice of his (Wildeve) manner, good or bad.

When Wildeve was gone Mrs. Yeobright stood and considered what would be the best course to adopt with regard to the guineas, which she (Yeobright) had not liked to entrust to Wildeve. It was hardly credible that Thomasin had told him (Wildeve) to ask for them, when the necessity for them had arisen from the difficulty of obtaining money at his (Wildeve) hands. At the same time Thomasin really wanted them, and might be unable to come to Blooms-End for another week at least. To take or send the money to her (Yeobright) at the inn would be impolite, since Wildeve would pretty surely be present, or would discover the transaction; and if, as her (Yeobright) aunt suspected, he (Wildeve) treated her (Yeobright) less kindly than she (Yeobright) deserved to be treated, he (Wildeve) might then get the whole sum out of her (Yeobright) gentle hands. But on this particular evening Thomasin was at Mistover, and anything might be conveyed to her (Yeobright) there without the knowledge of her (Yeobright) husband. Upon the whole the opportunity was worth taking advantage of.

Her (Yeobright) son, too, was there, and was now married. There could be no more proper moment to render him (son) his (son) share of the money than the present. And the chance that would be afforded her (Yeobright), by sending him (son) this gift, of showing how far she (Yeobright) was from bearing him (son) ill-will, cheered the sad mother's heart.

She (Yeobright) went upstairs and took from a locked drawer a little box, out of which she (Yeobright) poured a hoard of broad unworn guineas that had lain there many a year. There were a hundred in all, and she (Yeobright) divided them into two heaps, fifty in each. Tying up these in small canvas bags, she (Yeobright) went down to the garden and called to Christian Cantle, who was loitering about in hope of a supper which was not really owed him (Cantle). Mrs. Yeobright gave him (Cantle) the moneybags, charged him (Cantle) to go to Mistover, and on no account to deliver them into any one's hands save her (Yeobright) son's and Thomasin's. On further thought she (Yeobright) deemed it advisable to tell Christian precisely what the two bags contained, that he (Christian) might be fully impressed with their importance. Christian pocketed the moneybags, promised the greatest carefulness, and set out on his (Christian) way.

``You need not hurry,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright.
``It will be better not to get there till after dusk, and then nobody will notice you. Come back here to supper, if it is not too late.'' (he)
