It was nearly nine o’clock when he (Christian) began to ascend the vale towards Mistover; but the long days of summer being at their climax, the first obscurity of evening had only just begun to tan the landscape. At this point of his (Christian) journey Christian heard voices, and found that they proceeded from a company of men and women who were traversing a hollow ahead of him (Christian), the tops only of their heads being visible.

He (Christian) paused and thought of the money he (Christian) carried. It was almost too early even for Christian seriously to fear robbery; nevertheless he (Christian) took a precaution which ever since his (Christian) boyhood he (Christian) had adopted whenever he (Christian) carried more than two or three shillings upon his (Christian) person--a precaution somewhat like that of the owner of the Pitt Diamond when filled with similar misgivings. He (Diamond) took off his (Diamond) boots, untied the guineas, and emptied the contents of one little bag into the right boot, and of the other into the left, spreading them as flatly as possible over the bottom of each, which was really a spacious coffer by no means limited to the size of the foot. Pulling them on again and lacing them to the very top, he (Diamond) proceeded on his (Diamond) way, more easy in his (Diamond) head than under his (Diamond) soles.

His (Diamond) path converged towards that of the noisy company, and on coming nearer he (Diamond) found to his (Diamond) relief that they were several Egdon people whom he (Diamond) knew very well, while with them walked Fairway, of Blooms-End.

``What! Christian going too?'' (he)
said Fairway as soon as he (Diamond) recognized the newcomer.
``You've got no young woman nor wife to your name to gie a gown-piece to, I'm sure.'' (unknown)

``What d’ye mean?'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian.

``Why, the raffle. The one we go to every year. Going to the raffle as well as ourselves?'' (unknown)

``Never knew a word o't. Is it like cudgel playing or other sportful forms of bloodshed? I don't want to go, thank you, Mister Fairway, and no offence.'' (unknown)

``Christian don't know the fun o't, and `twould be a fine sight for him (Christian),'' (a woman)
said a buxom woman.
``There's no danger at all, Christian. Every man puts in a shilling apiece, and one wins a gown-piece for his (Christian) wife or sweetheart if he (Christian)'s got one.'' (unknown)

``Well, as that's not my fortune there's no meaning in it to me. But I should like to see the fun, if there's nothing of the black art in it, and if a man may look on without cost or getting into any dangerous wrangle?'' (unknown)

``There will be no uproar at all,'' (Timothy/Timothy Fairway)
said Timothy.
``Sure, Christian, if you'd like to come we'll see there's no harm done.'' (unknown)

``And no ba'dy gaieties, I suppose? You see, neighbours, if so, it would be setting father a bad example, as he (father) is so light moral'd. But a gown-piece for a shilling, and no black art--`tis worth looking in to see, and it wouldn't hinder me half an hour. Yes, I'll come, if you'll step a little way towards Mistover with me afterwards, supposing night should have closed in, and nobody else is going that way?'' (unknown)

One or two promised; and Christian, diverging from his (Christian) direct path, turned round to the right with his (Christian) companions towards the Quiet Woman.

When they entered the large common room of the inn they found assembled there about ten men from among the neighbouring population, and the group was increased by the new contingent to double that number. Most of them were sitting round the room in seats divided by wooden elbows like those of crude cathedral stalls, which were carved with the initials of many an illustrious drunkard of former times who had passed his (drunkard) days and his (drunkard) nights between them, and now lay as an alcoholic cinder in the nearest churchyard. Among the cups on the long table before the sitters lay an open parcel of light drapery--the gown-piece, as it was called--which was to be raffled for. Wildeve was standing with his (Wildeve) back to the fireplace smoking a cigar; and the promoter of the raffle, a packman from a distant town, was expatiating upon the value of the fabric as material for a summer dress.

``Now, gentlemen,'' (he)
he (promoter) continued, as the newcomers drew up to the table,
``there's five have entered, and we want four more to make up the number. I think, by the faces of those gentlemen who have just come in, that they are shrewd enough to take advantage of this rare opportunity of beautifying their ladies at a very trifling expense.'' (the newcomers)

Fairway, Sam, and another placed their shillings on the table, and the man turned to Christian.

``No, sir,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian, drawing back, with a quick gaze of misgiving.
``I am only a poor chap come to look on, an it please ye, sir. I don't so much as know how you do it. If so be I was sure of getting it I would put down the shilling; but I couldn't otherwise.'' (unknown)

``I think you might almost be sure,'' (the pedlar)
said the pedlar.
``In fact, now I look into your face, even if I can't say you are sure to win, I can say that I never saw anything look more like winning in my life.'' (unknown)

``You'll anyhow have the same chance as the rest of us,'' (Sam)
said Sam.

``And the extra luck of being the last comer,'' (unknown)
said another.

``And I was born wi' a caul, and perhaps can be no more ruined than drowned?'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
Christian added, beginning to give way.

Ultimately Christian laid down his (Christian) shilling, the raffle began, and the dice went round. When it came to Christian's turn he (Christian) took the box with a trembling hand, shook it fearfully, and threw a pair-royal. Three of the others had thrown common low pairs, and all the rest mere points.

``The gentleman looked like winning, as I said,'' (unknown)
observed the chapman blandly.
``Take it, sir; the article is yours.'' (unknown)

``Haw-haw-haw!'' (unknown)
said Fairway.
``I'm damned if this isn't the quarest start that ever I knowed!'' (unknown)

``Mine?'' (Christian)
asked Christian, with a vacant stare from his (Christian) target eyes.
``I--I haven't got neither maid, wife, nor widder belonging to me at all, and I'm afeard it will make me laughed at to ha’e it, Master Traveller. What with being curious to join in I never thought of that! What shall I do wi' a woman's clothes in MY bedroom, and not lose my decency!'' (unknown)

``Keep `em, to be sure,'' (unknown)
said Fairway,
``if it is only for luck. Perhaps `twill tempt some woman that thy poor carcase had no power over when standing empty-handed.'' (unknown)

``Keep it, certainly,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve, who had idly watched the scene from a distance.

The table was then cleared of the articles, and the men began to drink.

``Well, to be sure!'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian, half to himself.
``To think I should have been born so lucky as this, and not have found it out until now! What curious creatures these dice be--powerful rulers of us all, and yet at my command! I am sure I never need be afeared of anything after this.'' (He)
He (Christian) handled the dice fondly one by one.
``Why, sir,'' (he)
he (Christian) said in a confidential whisper to Wildeve, who was near his (Wildeve) left hand,
``if I could only use this power that's in me of multiplying money I might do some good to a near relation of yours, seeing what I've got about me of hers--eh?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
He (Wildeve) tapped one of his (Wildeve) money-laden boots upon the floor.

``What do you mean?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

``That's a secret. Well, I must be going now.'' (He)
He (Wildeve) looked anxiously towards Fairway.

``Where are you going?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
Wildeve asked.

``To Mistover Knap. I have to see Mrs. Thomasin there--that's all.'' (unknown)

``I am going there, too, to fetch Mrs. Wildeve. We can walk together.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve became lost in thought, and a look of inward illumination came into his (Wildeve) eyes. It was money for his (Wildeve) wife that Mrs. Yeobright could not trust him (Wildeve) with.

``Yet she (Wildeve) could trust this fellow,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said to himself.
``Why doesn't that which belongs to the wife belong to the husband too?'' (He)

He (Wildeve) called to the pot-boy to bring him (Wildeve) his (Wildeve) hat, and said,

``Now, Christian, I am ready.'' (him)

``Mr. Wildeve,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian timidly, as he (Christian) turned to leave the room,
``would you mind lending me them wonderful little things that carry my luck inside `em, that I might practise a bit by myself, you know?'' (he)
He (Christian) looked wistfully at the dice and box lying on the mantlepiece.

``Certainly,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve carelessly.
``They were only cut out by some lad with his (lad) knife, and are worth nothing.'' (Christian)
And Christian went back and privately pocketed them.

Wildeve opened the door and looked out. The night was warm and cloudy.

``By Gad! `tis dark,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) continued.
``But I suppose we shall find our way.'' (unknown)

``If we should lose the path it might be awkward,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian.
``A lantern is the only shield that will make it safe for us.'' (unknown)

``Let's have a lantern by all means.'' (unknown)
The stable lantern was fetched and lighted. Christian took up his (Christian) gownpiece, and the two set out to ascend the hill.

Within the room the men fell into chat till their attention was for a moment drawn to the chimney-corner. This was large, and, in addition to its proper recess, contained within its jambs, like many on Egdon, a receding seat, so that a person might sit there absolutely unobserved, provided there was no fire to light him (Egdon) up, as was the case now and throughout the summer. From the niche a single object protruded into the light from the candles on the table. It was a clay pipe, and its colour was reddish. The men had been attracted to this object by a voice behind the pipe asking for a light.

``Upon my life, it fairly startled me when the man spoke!'' (unknown)
said Fairway, handing a candle.
``Oh--`tis the reddleman! You've kept a quiet tongue, young man.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I had nothing to say,'' (unknown)
observed Venn. In a few minutes he (Egdon) arose and wished the company good night.

Meanwhile Wildeve and Christian had plunged into the heath.

It was a stagnant, warm, and misty night, full of all the heavy perfumes of new vegetation not yet dried by hot sun, and among these particularly the scent of the fern. The lantern, dangling from Christian's hand, brushed the feathery fronds in passing by, disturbing moths and other winged insects, which flew out and alighted upon its horny panes.

``So you have money to carry to Mrs. Wildeve?'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian's companion, after a silence.
``Don't you think it very odd that it shouldn't be given to me?'' (unknown)

``As man and wife be one flesh, `twould have been all the same, I should think,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian.
``But my strict documents was, to give the money into Mrs. Wildeve's hand--and `tis well to do things right.'' (unknown)

``No doubt,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve. Any person who had known the circumstances might have perceived that Wildeve was mortified by the discovery that the matter in transit was money, and not, as he (Wildeve) had supposed when at Blooms-End, some fancy nick-nack which only interested the two women themselves. Mrs. Yeobright's refusal implied that his (Wildeve) honour was not considered to be of sufficiently good quality to make him (Wildeve) a safer bearer of his (Wildeve) wife's property.

``How very warm it is tonight, Christian!'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said, panting, when they were nearly under Rainbarrow.
``Let us sit down for a few minutes, for Heaven's sake.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve flung himself down on the soft ferns; and Christian, placing the lantern and parcel on the ground, perched himself in a cramped position hard by, his (Christian) knees almost touching his (Christian) chin. He (Christian) presently thrust one hand into his (Christian) coat-pocket and began shaking it about.

``What are you rattling in there?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

``Only the dice, sir,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian, quickly withdrawing his (Christian) hand.
``What magical machines these little things be, Mr. Wildeve! `Tis a game I should never get tired of. Would you mind my taking `em out and looking at `em for a minute, to see how they are made? I didn't like to look close before the other men, for fear they should think it bad manners in me.'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
Christian took them out and examined them in the hollow of his (Christian) hand by the lantern light.
``That these little things should carry such luck, and such charm, and such a spell, and such power in `em, passes all I ever heard or zeed,'' (he)
he (Christian) went on, with a fascinated gaze at the dice, which, as is frequently the case in country places, were made of wood, the points being burnt upon each face with the end of a wire.

``They are a great deal in a small compass, You think?'' (unknown)

``Yes. Do ye suppose they really be the devil's playthings, Mr. Wildeve? If so, `tis no good sign that I be such a lucky man.'' (unknown)

``You ought to win some money, now that you've got them. Any woman would marry you then. Now is your time, Christian, and I would recommend you not to let it slip. Some men are born to luck, some are not. I belong to the latter class.'' (unknown)

``Did you ever know anybody who was born to it besides myself?'' (unknown)

``O yes. I once heard of an Italian, who sat down at a gaming table with only a louis, -LRB-that's a foreign sovereign-RRB-, in his (Christian) pocket. He (Christian) played on for twenty-four hours, and won ten thousand pounds, stripping the bank he (Christian) had played against. Then there was another man who had lost a thousand pounds, and went to the broker's next day to sell stock, that he (man) might pay the debt. The man to whom he (man) owed the money went with him (man) in a hackney-coach; and to pass the time they tossed who should pay the fare. The ruined man won, and the other was tempted to continue the game, and they played all the way. When the coachman stopped he (man) was told to drive home again: the whole thousand pounds had been won back by the man who was going to sell.'' (unknown)

``Ha--ha--splendid!'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
exclaimed Christian.
``Go on--go on!'' (unknown)

``Then there was a man of London, who was only a waiter at White's clubhouse. He (White) began playing first half-crown stakes, and then higher and higher, till he (White) became very rich, got an appointment in India, and rose to be Governor of Madras. His (Governor) daughter married a member of Parliament, and the Bishop of Carlisle stood godfather to one of the children.'' (unknown)

``Wonderful! wonderful!'' (unknown)

``And once there was a young man in America who gambled till he (man) had lost his (man) last dollar. He (man) staked his (man) watch and chain, and lost as before; staked his (man) umbrella, lost again; staked his (man) hat, lost again; staked his (man) coat and stood in his (man) shirt-sleeves, lost again. Began taking off his (man) breeches, and then a looker-on gave him (man) a trifle for his (man) pluck. With this he (man) won. Won back his (man) coat, won back his (man) hat, won back his (man) umbrella, his (man) watch, his (man) money, and went out of the door a rich man.'' (unknown)

``Oh, `tis too good--it takes away my breath! Mr. Wildeve, I think I will try another shilling with you, as I am one of that sort; no danger can come o't, and you can afford to lose.'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve, rising. Searching about with the lantern, he (Wildeve) found a large flat stone, which he (Wildeve) placed between himself and Christian, and sat down again. The lantern was opened to give more light, and it's rays directed upon the stone. Christian put down a shilling, Wildeve another, and each threw. Christian won. They played for two, Christian won again.

``Let us try four,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve. They played for four. This time the stakes were won by Wildeve.

``Ah, those little accidents will, of course, sometimes happen, to the luckiest man,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) observed.

``And now I have no more money!'' (unknown)
explained Christian excitedly.
``And yet, if I could go on, I should get it back again, and more. I wish this was mine.'' (He)
He (Wildeve) struck his (Wildeve) boot upon the ground, so that the guineas chinked within.

``What! you have not put Mrs. Wildeve's money there?'' (unknown)

``Yes. `Tis for safety. Is it any harm to raffle with a married lady's money when, if I win, I shall only keep my winnings, and give her (lady) her (lady) own all the same; and if t'other man wins, her (lady) money will go to the lawful owner?'' (unknown)

``None at all.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve had been brooding ever since they started on the mean estimation in which he (Wildeve) was held by his (Wildeve) wife's friends; and it cut his (Wildeve) heart severely. As the minutes passed he (Wildeve) had gradually drifted into a revengeful intention without knowing the precise moment of forming it. This was to teach Mrs. Yeobright a lesson, as he (Wildeve) considered it to be; in other words, to show her (Yeobright) if he (Wildeve) could that her (Yeobright) niece's husband was the proper guardian of her (Yeobright) niece's money.

``Well, here goes!'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian, beginning to unlace one boot.
``I shall dream of it nights and nights, I suppose; but I shall always swear my flesh don't crawl when I think o't!'' (He)

He (Christian) thrust his (Christian) hand into the boot and withdrew one of poor Thomasin's precious guineas, piping hot. Wildeve had already placed a sovereign on the stone. The game was then resumed. Wildeve won first, and Christian ventured another, winning himself this time. The game fluctuated, but the average was in Wildeve's favour. Both men became so absorbed in the game that they took no heed of anything but the pigmy objects immediately beneath their eyes, the flat stone, the open lantern, the dice, and the few illuminated fern-leaves which lay under the light, were the whole world to them.

At length Christian lost rapidly; and presently, to his (Christian) horror, the whole fifty guineas belonging to Thomasin had been handed over to his (Christian) adversary.

``I don't care--I don't care!'' (he)
he (Christian) moaned, and desperately set about untying his (Christian) left boot to get at the other fifty.
``The devil will toss me into the flames on his (devil) three-pronged fork for this night's work, I know! But perhaps I shall win yet, and then I'll get a wife to sit up with me o' nights and I won't be afeard, I won't! Here's another for'ee, my man!'' (He)
He (Christian) slapped another guinea down upon the stone, and the dice-box was rattled again.

Time passed on. Wildeve began to be as excited as Christian himself. When commencing the game his (Wildeve) intention had been nothing further than a bitter practical joke on Mrs. Yeobright. To win the money, fairly or otherwise, and to hand it contemptuously to Thomasin in her (Yeobright) aunt's presence, had been the dim outline of his (Wildeve) purpose. But men are drawn from their intentions even in the course of carrying them out, and it was extremely doubtful, by the time the twentieth guinea had been reached, whether Wildeve was conscious of any other intention than that of winning for his (Wildeve) own personal benefit. Moreover, he (Wildeve) was now no longer gambling for his (Wildeve) wife's money, but for Yeobright's; though of this fact Christian, in his (Christian) apprehensiveness, did not inform him (Christian) till afterwards.

It was nearly eleven o’clock, when, with almost a shriek, Christian placed Yeobright's last gleaming guinea upon the stone. In thirty seconds it had gone the way of its companions.

Christian turned and flung himself on the ferns in a convulsion of remorse,

``O, what shall I do with my wretched self?'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
he (Christian) groaned.
``What shall I do? Will any good Heaven hae mercy upon my wicked soul?'' (unknown)

``Do? Live on just the same.'' (unknown)

``I won't live on just the same! I'll die! I say you are a--a--'' (unknown)

``A man sharper than my neighbour.'' (unknown)

``Yes, a man sharper than my neighbour; a regular sharper!'' (unknown)

``Poor chips-in-porridge, you are very unmannerly.'' (unknown)

``I don't know about that! And I say you be unmannerly! You've got money that isn't your own. Half the guineas are poor Mr. Clym's.'' (unknown)

``How's that?'' (unknown)

``Because I had to gie fifty of `em to him (Mr.). Mrs. Yeobright said so.'' (unknown)

``Oh?... Well, `twould have been more graceful of her (Yeobright) to have given them to his (Mr.) wife Eustacia. But they are in my hands now.'' (Christian)

Christian pulled on his (Christian) boots, and with heavy breathings, which could be heard to some distance, dragged his (Christian) limbs together, arose, and tottered away out of sight. Wildeve set about shutting the lantern to return to the house, for he (Wildeve) deemed it too late to go to Mistover to meet his (Wildeve) wife, who was to be driven home in the captain's four-wheel. While he (Wildeve) was closing the little horn door a figure rose from behind a neighbouring bush and came forward into the lantern light. It was the reddleman approaching.

8--A New Force Disturbs the Current

Wildeve stared. Venn looked coolly towards Wildeve, and, without a word being spoken, he (bush) deliberately sat himself down where Christian had been seated, thrust his (Christian) hand into his (Christian) pocket, drew out a sovereign, and laid it on the stone.

``You have been watching us from behind that bush?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

The reddleman nodded.

``Down with your stake,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.
``Or haven't you pluck enough to go on?'' (unknown)

Now, gambling is a species of amusement which is much more easily begun with full pockets than left off with the same; and though Wildeve in a cooler temper might have prudently declined this invitation, the excitement of his (Wildeve) recent success carried him (Wildeve) completely away. He (Wildeve) placed one of the guineas on a slab beside the reddleman's sovereign.

``Mine is a guinea,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.

``A guinea that's not your own,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn sarcastically.

``It is my own,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
answered Wildeve haughtily.
``It is my wife's, and what is hers is mine.'' (unknown)

``Very well; let's make a beginning.'' (He)
He (Wildeve) shook the box, and threw eight, ten, and nine; the three casts amounted to twenty-seven.

This encouraged Wildeve. He (Wildeve) took the box; and his (Wildeve) three casts amounted to forty-five.

Down went another of the reddleman's sovereigns against his (Wildeve) first one which Wildeve laid. This time Wildeve threw fifty-one points, but no pair. The reddleman looked grim, threw a raffle of aces, and pocketed the stakes.

``Here you are again,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve contemptuously.
``Double the stakes.'' (He)
He (Wildeve) laid two of Thomasin's guineas, and the reddleman his (Wildeve) two pounds. Venn won again. New stakes were laid on the stone, and the gamblers proceeded as before.

Wildeve was a nervous and excitable man, and the game was beginning to tell upon his (Wildeve) temper. He (Wildeve) writhed, fumed, shifted his (Wildeve) seat, and the beating of his (Wildeve) heart was almost audible. Venn sat with lips impassively closed and eyes reduced to a pair of unimportant twinkles; he (Venn) scarcely appeared to breathe. He (Venn) might have been an Arab, or an automaton; he (Venn) would have been like a red sandstone statue but for the motion of his (Venn) arm with the dice-box.

The game fluctuated, now in favour of one, now in favour of the other, without any great advantage on the side of either. Nearly twenty minutes were passed thus. The light of the candle had by this time attracted heath-flies, moths, and other winged creatures of night, which floated round the lantern, flew into the flame, or beat about the faces of the two players.

But neither of the men paid much attention to these things, their eyes being concentrated upon the little flat stone, which to them was an arena vast and important as a battlefield. By this time a change had come over the game; the reddleman won continually. At length sixty guineas--Thomasin's fifty, and ten of Clym's--had passed into his (their) hands. Wildeve was reckless, frantic, exasperated.

```Won back his (Wildeve) coat,''' said Venn slily.

Another throw, and the money went the same way.

```Won back his (Wildeve) hat,''' continued Venn.

``Oh, oh!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

```Won back his (Wildeve) watch, won back his (Wildeve) money, and went out of the door a rich man,''' added Venn sentence by sentence, as stake after stake passed over to him (Wildeve).

``Five more!'' (unknown)
shouted Wildeve, dashing down the money.
``And three casts be hanged--one shall decide.'' (unknown)

The red automaton opposite lapsed into silence, nodded, and followed his (Wildeve) example. Wildeve rattled the box, and threw a pair of sixes and five points. He (Wildeve) clapped his (Wildeve) hands;

``I have done it this time--hurrah!'' (He)

``There are two playing, and only one has thrown,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman, quietly bringing down the box. The eyes of each were then so intently converged upon the stone that one could fancy their beams were visible, like rays in a fog.

Venn lifted the box, and behold a triplet of sixes was disclosed.

Wildeve was full of fury. While the reddleman was grasping the stakes Wildeve seized the dice and hurled them, box and all, into the darkness, uttering a fearful imprecation. Then he (Wildeve) arose and began stamping up and down like a madman.

``It is all over, then?'' (unknown)
said Venn.

``No, no!'' (unknown)
cried Wildeve.
``I mean to have another chance yet. I must!'' (unknown)

``But, my good man, what have you done with the dice?'' (unknown)

``I threw them away--it was a momentary irritation. What a fool I am! Here--come and help me to look for them--we must find them again.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve snatched up the lantern and began anxiously prowling among the furze and fern.

``You are not likely to find them there,'' (unknown)
said Venn, following.
``What did you do such a crazy thing as that for? Here's the box. The dice can't be far off.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve turned the light eagerly upon the spot where Venn had found the box, and mauled the herbage right and left. In the course of a few minutes one of the dice was found. They searched on for some time, but no other was to be seen.

``Never mind,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve;
``let's play with one.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

``Agreed,'' (unknown)
said Venn.

Down they sat again, and recommenced with single guinea stakes; and the play went on smartly. But Fortune had unmistakably fallen in love with the reddleman tonight. He (Wildeve) won steadily, till he (Wildeve) was the owner of fourteen more of the gold pieces. Seventy-nine of the hundred guineas were his (Wildeve), Wildeve possessing only twenty-one. The aspect of the two opponents was now singular. Apart from motions, a complete diorama of the fluctuations of the game went on in their eyes. A diminutive candle-flame was mirrored in each pupil, and it would have been possible to distinguish therein between the moods of hope and the moods of abandonment, even as regards the reddleman, though his (pupil) facial muscles betrayed nothing at all. Wildeve played on with the recklessness of despair.

``What's that?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) suddenly exclaimed, hearing a rustle; and they both looked up.

They were surrounded by dusky forms between four and five feet high, standing a few paces beyond the rays of the lantern. A moment's inspection revealed that the encircling figures were heath-croppers, their heads being all towards the players, at whom they gazed intently.

``Hoosh!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve, and the whole forty or fifty animals at once turned and galloped away. Play was again resumed.

Ten minutes passed away. Then a large death's head moth advanced from the obscure outer air, wheeled twice round the lantern, flew straight at the candle, and extinguished it by the force of the blow. Wildeve had just thrown, but had not lifted the box to see what he (Wildeve) had cast; and now it was impossible.

``What the infernal!'' (he)
he (Wildeve) shrieked.
``Now, what shall we do? Perhaps I have thrown six--have you any matches?'' (unknown)

``None,'' (unknown)
said Venn.

``Christian had some--I wonder where he (Christian) is. Christian!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

But there was no reply to Wildeve's shout, save a mournful whining from the herons which were nesting lower down the vale. Both men looked blankly round without rising. As their eyes grew accustomed to the darkness they perceived faint greenish points of light among the grass and fern. These lights dotted the hillside like stars of a low magnitude.

``Ah--glowworms,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.
``Wait a minute. We can continue the game.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn sat still, and his (Wildeve) companion went hither and thither till he (Wildeve) had gathered thirteen glowworms--as many as he (Wildeve) could find in a space of four or five minutes--upon a fox-glove leaf which he (Wildeve) pulled for the purpose. The reddleman vented a low humorous laugh when he (Wildeve) saw his (Wildeve) adversary return with these.

``Determined to go on, then?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said drily.

``I always am!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve angrily. And shaking the glowworms from the leaf he (Wildeve) ranged them with a trembling hand in a circle on the stone, leaving a space in the middle for the descent of the dice-box, over which the thirteen tiny lamps threw a pale phosphoric shine. The game was again renewed. It happened to be that season of the year at which glowworms put forth their greatest brilliancy, and the light they yielded was more than ample for the purpose, since it is possible on such nights to read the handwriting of a letter by the light of two or three.

The incongruity between the men's deeds and their environment was great. Amid the soft juicy vegetation of the hollow in which they sat, the motionless and the uninhabited solitude, intruded the chink of guineas, the rattle of dice, the exclamations of the reckless players.

Wildeve had lifted the box as soon as the lights were obtained, and the solitary die proclaimed that the game was still against him (Wildeve).

``I won't play any more--you've been tampering with the dice,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) shouted.

``How--when they were your own?'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman.

``We'll change the game: the lowest point shall win the stake--it may cut off my ill luck. Do you refuse?'' (unknown)

``No--go on,'' (unknown)
said Venn.

``O, there they are again--damn them!'' (unknown)
cried Wildeve, looking up. The heath-croppers had returned noiselessly, and were looking on with erect heads just as before, their timid eyes fixed upon the scene, as if they were wondering what mankind and candlelight could have to do in these haunts at this untoward hour.

``What a plague those creatures are--staring at me so!'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said, and flung a stone, which scattered them; when the game was continued as before.

Wildeve had now ten guineas left; and each laid five. Wildeve threw three points; Venn two, and raked in the coins. The other seized the die, and clenched his (Wildeve) teeth upon it in sheer rage, as if he (Wildeve) would bite it in pieces.

``Never give in--here are my last five!'' (he)
he (Wildeve) cried, throwing them down.
``Hang the glowworms--they are going out. Why don't you burn, you little fools? Stir them up with a thorn.'' (He)

He (Wildeve) probed the glowworms with a bit of stick, and rolled them over, till the bright side of their tails was upwards.

``There's light enough. Throw on,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Venn.

Wildeve brought down the box within the shining circle and looked eagerly. He (Wildeve) had thrown ace.

``Well done!--I said it would turn, and it has turned.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
Venn said nothing; but his (Venn) hand shook slightly.

He (Venn) threw ace also.

``O!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.
``Curse me!'' (unknown)

The die smacked the stone a second time. It was ace again. Venn looked gloomy, threw--the die was seen to be lying in two pieces, the cleft sides uppermost.

``I've thrown nothing at all,'' (he)
he (Venn) said.

``Serves me right--I split the die with my teeth. Here--take your money. Blank is less than one.'' (unknown)

``I don't wish it.'' (unknown)

``Take it, I say--you've won it!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
And Wildeve threw the stakes against the reddleman's chest. Venn gathered them up, arose, and withdrew from the hollow, Wildeve sitting stupefied.

When he (Wildeve) had come to himself he (Wildeve) also arose, and, with the extinguished lantern in his (Wildeve) hand, went towards the highroad. On reaching it he (Wildeve) stood still. The silence of night pervaded the whole heath except in one direction; and that was towards Mistover. There he (Wildeve) could hear the noise of light wheels, and presently saw two carriagelamps descending the hill. Wildeve screened himself under a bush and waited.

The vehicle came on and passed before him (Wildeve). It was a hired carriage, and behind the coachman were two persons whom he (Wildeve) knew well. There sat Eustacia and Yeobright, the arm of the latter being round her (Eustacia) waist. They turned the sharp corner at the bottom towards the temporary home which Clym had hired and furnished, about five miles to the eastward.

Wildeve forgot the loss of the money at the sight of his (Wildeve) lost love, whose preciousness in his (Wildeve) eyes was increasing in geometrical progression with each new incident that reminded him (Wildeve) of their hopeless division. Brimming with the subtilized misery that he (Wildeve) was capable of feeling, he (Wildeve) followed the opposite way towards the inn.

About the same moment that Wildeve stepped into the highway Venn also had reached it at a point a hundred yards further on; and he (Wildeve), hearing the same wheels, likewise waited till the carriage should come up. When he (Wildeve) saw who sat therein he (Wildeve) seemed to be disappointed. Reflecting a minute or two, during which interval the carriage rolled on, he (Wildeve) crossed the road, and took a short cut through the furze and heath to a point where the turnpike road bent round in ascending a hill. He (Wildeve) was now again in front of the carriage, which presently came up at a walking pace. Venn stepped forward and showed himself.

Eustacia started when the lamp shone upon him (Venn), and Clym's arm was involuntarily withdrawn from her (Eustacia) waist. He (Venn) said,

``What, Diggory? You are having a lonely walk.'' (He)

``Yes--I beg your pardon for stopping you,'' (unknown)
said Venn.
``But I am waiting about for Mrs. Wildeve: I have something to give her (I) from Mrs. Yeobright. Can you tell me if she (I)'s gone home from the party yet?'' (unknown)

``No. But she (I) will be leaving soon. You may possibly meet her (I) at the corner.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn made a farewell obeisance, and walked back to his (Venn) former position, where the byroad from Mistover joined the highway. Here he (Venn) remained fixed for nearly half an hour, and then another pair of lights came down the hill. It was the old-fashioned wheeled nondescript belonging to the captain, and Thomasin sat in it alone, driven by Charley.

The reddleman came up as they slowly turned the corner.

``I beg pardon for stopping you, Mrs. Wildeve,'' (he)
he (Charley) said.
``But I have something to give you privately from Mrs. Yeobright.'' (He)
He (Charley) handed a small parcel; it consisted of the hundred guineas he (Charley) had just won, roughly twisted up in a piece of paper.

Thomasin recovered from her (Charley) surprise, and took the packet.

``That's all, ma’am--I wish you good night,'' (he)
he (Charley) said, and vanished from her (Charley) view.

Thus Venn, in his (Charley) anxiety to rectify matters, had placed in Thomasin's hands not only the fifty guineas which rightly belonged to her (Charley), but also the fifty intended for her (Charley) cousin Clym. His (cousin) mistake had been based upon Wildeve's words at the opening of the game, when he (Wildeve) indignantly denied that the guinea was not his (Wildeve) own. It had not been comprehended by the reddleman that at halfway through the performance the game was continued with the money of another person; and it was an error which afterwards helped to cause more misfortune than treble the loss in money value could have done.

The night was now somewhat advanced; and Venn plunged deeper into the heath, till he (Venn) came to a ravine where his (Venn) van was standing--a spot not more than two hundred yards from the site of the gambling bout. He (Venn) entered this movable home of his (Venn), lit his (Venn) lantern, and, before closing his (Venn) door for the night, stood reflecting on the circumstances of the preceding hours. While he (Venn) stood the dawn grew visible in the northeast quarter of the heavens, which, the clouds having cleared off, was bright with a soft sheen at this midsummer time, though it was only between one and two o’clock. Venn, thoroughly weary, then shut his (Venn) door and flung himself down to sleep.

BOOK FOUR -- THE CLOSED DOOR

1--The Rencounter by the Pool

The July sun shone over Egdon and fired its crimson heather to scarlet. It was the one season of the year, and the one weather of the season, in which the heath was gorgeous. This flowering period represented the second or noontide division in the cycle of those superficial changes which alone were possible here; it followed the green or young-fern period, representing the morn, and preceded the brown period, when the heathbells and ferns would wear the russet tinges of evening; to be in turn displaced by the dark hue of the winter period, representing night.

Clym and Eustacia, in their little house at Alderworth, beyond East Egdon, were living on with a monotony which was delightful to them. The heath and changes of weather were quite blotted out from their eyes for the present. They were enclosed in a sort of luminous mist, which hid from them surroundings of any inharmonious colour, and gave to all things the character of light. When it rained they were charmed, because they could remain indoors together all day with such a show of reason; when it was fine they were charmed, because they could sit together on the hills. They were like those double stars which revolve round and round each other, and from a distance appear to be one. The absolute solitude in which they lived intensified their reciprocal thoughts; yet some might have said that it had the disadvantage of consuming their mutual affections at a fearfully prodigal rate. Yeobright did not fear for his (it) own part; but recollection of Eustacia's old speech about the evanescence of love, now apparently forgotten by her (Eustacia), sometimes caused him (it) to ask himself a question; and he (it) recoiled at the thought that the quality of finiteness was not foreign to Eden.

When three or four weeks had been passed thus, Yeobright resumed his (it) reading in earnest. To make up for lost time he (it) studied indefatigably, for he (it) wished to enter his (it) new profession with the least possible delay.

Now, Eustacia's dream had always been that, once married to Clym, she (Eustacia) would have the power of inducing him (it) to return to Paris. He (it) had carefully withheld all promise to do so; but would he (it) be proof against her (Eustacia) coaxing and argument? She (Eustacia) had calculated to such a degree on the probability of success that she (Eustacia) had represented Paris, and not Budmouth, to her (Eustacia) grandfather as in all likelihood their future home. Her (Eustacia) hopes were bound up in this dream. In the quiet days since their marriage, when Yeobright had been poring over her (Eustacia) lips, her (Eustacia) eyes, and the lines of her (Eustacia) face, she (Eustacia) had mused and mused on the subject, even while in the act of returning his (grandfather) gaze; and now the sight of the books, indicating a future which was antagonistic to her (Eustacia) dream, struck her (Eustacia) with a positively painful jar. She (Eustacia) was hoping for the time when, as the mistress of some pretty establishment, however small, near a Parisian Boulevard, she (Eustacia) would be passing her (Eustacia) days on the skirts at least of the gay world, and catching stray wafts from those town pleasures she (Eustacia) was so well fitted to enjoy. Yet Yeobright was as firm in the contrary intention as if the tendency of marriage were rather to develop the fantasies of young philanthropy than to sweep them away.

Her (Eustacia) anxiety reached a high pitch; but there was something in Clym's undeviating manner which made her (Eustacia) hesitate before sounding him (mistress) on the subject. At this point in their experience, however, an incident helped her (Eustacia). It occurred one evening about six weeks after their union, and arose entirely out of the unconscious misapplication of Venn of the fifty guineas intended for Yeobright.

A day or two after the receipt of the money Thomasin had sent a note to her (Eustacia) aunt to thank her (Eustacia). She (Eustacia) had been surprised at the largeness of the amount; but as no sum had ever been mentioned she (Eustacia) set that down to her (Eustacia) late uncle's generosity. She (Eustacia) had been strictly charged by her (Eustacia) aunt to say nothing to her (Eustacia) husband of this gift; and Wildeve, as was natural enough, had not brought himself to mention to his (Wildeve) wife a single particular of the midnight scene in the heath. Christian's terror, in like manner, had tied his (Christian) tongue on the share he (Christian) took in that proceeding; and hoping that by some means or other the money had gone to its proper destination, he (Christian) simply asserted as much, without giving details.

Therefore, when a week or two had passed away, Mrs. Yeobright began to wonder why she (Yeobright) never heard from her (Yeobright) son of the receipt of the present; and to add gloom to her (Yeobright) perplexity came the possibility that resentment might be the cause of his (son) silence. She (Yeobright) could hardly believe as much, but why did he (son) not write? She (Yeobright) questioned Christian, and the confusion in his (Christian) answers would at once have led her (Yeobright) to believe that something was wrong, had not one-half of his (Christian) story been corroborated by Thomasin's note.

Mrs. Yeobright was in this state of uncertainty when she (Yeobright) was informed one morning that her (Yeobright) son's wife was visiting her (Yeobright) grandfather at Mistover. She (Yeobright) determined to walk up the hill, see Eustacia, and ascertain from her (Eustacia) daughter-in-law's lips whether the family guineas, which were to Mrs. Yeobright what family jewels are to wealthier dowagers, had miscarried or not.

When Christian learnt where she (Yeobright) was going his (Christian) concern reached its height. At the moment of her (Yeobright) departure he (Christian) could prevaricate no longer, and, confessing to the gambling, told her (Yeobright) the truth as far as he (Christian) knew it--that the guineas had been won by Wildeve.

``What, is he (I) going to keep them?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
Mrs. Yeobright cried.

``I hope and trust not!'' (Christian)
moaned Christian.
``He (I)'s a good man, and perhaps will do right things. He (I) said you ought to have gied Mr. Clym's share to Eustacia, and that's perhaps what he (Mr.)'ll do himself.'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

To Mrs. Yeobright, as soon as she (Yeobright) could calmly reflect, there was much likelihood in this, for she (Yeobright) could hardly believe that Wildeve would really appropriate money belonging to her (Yeobright) son. The intermediate course of giving it to Eustacia was the sort of thing to please Wildeve's fancy. But it filled the mother with anger none the less. That Wildeve should have got command of the guineas after all, and should rearrange the disposal of them, placing Clym's share in Clym's wife's hands, because she (wife) had been his (Wildeve) own sweetheart, and might be so still, was as irritating a pain as any that Mrs. Yeobright had ever borne.

She (Yeobright) instantly dismissed the wretched Christian from her (Yeobright) employ for his (Christian) conduct in the affair; but, feeling quite helpless and unable to do without him (Christian), told him (Christian) afterwards that he (Christian) might stay a little longer if he (Christian) chose. Then she (Yeobright) hastened off to Eustacia, moved by a much less promising emotion towards her (Eustacia) daughter-in-law than she (Eustacia) had felt half an hour earlier, when planning her (Eustacia) journey. At that time it was to inquire in a friendly spirit if there had been any accidental loss; now it was to ask plainly if Wildeve had privately given her (Eustacia) money which had been intended as a sacred gift to Clym.

She (Eustacia) started at two o’clock, and her (Eustacia) meeting with Eustacia was hastened by the appearance of the young lady beside the pool and bank which bordered her (Eustacia) grandfather's premises, where she (Eustacia) stood surveying the scene, and perhaps thinking of the romantic enactments it had witnessed in past days. When Mrs. Yeobright approached, Eustacia surveyed her (Eustacia) with the calm stare of a stranger.

The mother-in-law was the first to speak.

``I was coming to see you,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.

``Indeed!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia with surprise, for Mrs. Yeobright, much to the girl's mortification, had refused to be present at the wedding.
``I did not at all expect you.'' (unknown)

``I was coming on business only,'' (the visitor)
said the visitor, more coldly than at first.
``Will you excuse my asking this--Have you received a gift from Thomasin's husband?'' (unknown)

``A gift?'' (unknown)

``I mean money!'' (unknown)

``What--I myself?'' (unknown)

``Well, I meant yourself, privately--though I was not going to put it in that way.'' (unknown)

``Money from Mr. Wildeve? No--never! Madam, what do you mean by that?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
Eustacia fired up all too quickly, for her (Eustacia) own consciousness of the old attachment between herself and Wildeve led her (Eustacia) to jump to the conclusion that Mrs. Yeobright also knew of it, and might have come to accuse her (Yeobright) of receiving dishonourable presents from him (Wildeve) now.

``I simply ask the question,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright.
``I have been--'' (unknown)

``You ought to have better opinions of me--I feared you were against me from the first!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
exclaimed Eustacia.

``No. I was simply for Clym,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
replied Mrs. Yeobright, with too much emphasis in her (Yeobright) earnestness.
``It is the instinct of everyone to look after their own.'' (unknown)

``How can you imply that he (Wildeve) required guarding against me?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
cried Eustacia, passionate tears in her (Eustacia) eyes.
``I have not injured him (Wildeve) by marrying him (Wildeve)! What sin have I done that you should think so ill of me? You had no right to speak against me to him (Wildeve) when I have never wronged you.'' (unknown)

``I only did what was fair under the circumstances,'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright more softly.
``I would rather not have gone into this question at present, but you compel me. I am not ashamed to tell you the honest truth. I was firmly convinced that he (Wildeve) ought not to marry you--therefore I tried to dissuade him (Wildeve) by all the means in my power. But it is done now, and I have no idea of complaining any more. I am ready to welcome you.'' (unknown)

``Ah, yes, it is very well to see things in that business point of view,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
murmured Eustacia with a smothered fire of feeling.
``But why should you think there is anything between me and Mr. Wildeve? I have a spirit as well as you. I am indignant; and so would any woman be. It was a condescension in me to be Clym's wife, and not a manoeuvre, let me remind you; and therefore I will not be treated as a schemer whom it becomes necessary to bear with because she (wife) has crept into the family.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)
said Mrs. Yeobright, vainly endeavouring to control her (Yeobright) anger.
``I have never heard anything to show that my son's lineage is not as good as the Vyes'--perhaps better. It is amusing to hear you talk of condescension.'' (unknown)

``It was condescension, nevertheless,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia vehemently.
``And if I had known then what I know now, that I should be living in this wild heath a month after my marriage, I--I should have thought twice before agreeing.'' (unknown)

``It would be better not to say that; it might not sound truthful. I am not aware that any deception was used on his (son) part--I know there was not--whatever might have been the case on the other side.'' (unknown)

``This is too exasperating!'' (the woman)
answered the younger woman huskily, her (Eustacia) face crimsoning, and her (Eustacia) eyes darting light.
``How can you dare to speak to me like that? I insist upon repeating to you that had I known that my life would from my marriage up to this time have been as it is, I should have said NO. I don't complain. I have never uttered a sound of such a thing to him (son); but it is true. I hope therefore that in the future you will be silent on my eagerness. If you injure me now you injure yourself.'' (unknown)

``Injure you? Do you think I am an evil-disposed person?'' (unknown)

``You injured me before my marriage, and you have now suspected me of secretly favouring another man for money!'' (unknown)

``I could not help what I thought. But I have never spoken of you outside my house.'' (unknown)

``You spoke of me within it, to Clym, and you could not do worse.'' (unknown)

``I did my duty.'' (unknown)

``And I'll do mine.'' (unknown)

``A part of which will possibly be to set him (man) against his (man) mother. It is always so. But why should I not bear it as others have borne it before me!'' (unknown)

``I understand you,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia, breathless with emotion.
``You think me capable of every bad thing. Who can be worse than a wife who encourages a lover, and poisons her (wife) husband's mind against his (husband) relative? Yet that is now the character given to me. Will you not come and drag him (husband) out of my hands?'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

Mrs. Yeobright gave back heat for heat.

``Don't rage at me, madam! It ill becomes your beauty, and I am not worth the injury you may do it on my account, I assure you. I am only a poor old woman who has lost a son.'' (unknown)

``If you had treated me honourably you would have had him (son) still.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
Eustacia said, while scalding tears trickled from her (Eustacia) eyes.
``You have brought yourself to folly; you have caused a division which can never be healed!'' (unknown)

``I have done nothing. This audacity from a young woman is more than I can bear.'' (unknown)

``It was asked for; you have suspected me, and you have made me speak of my husband in a way I would not have done. You will let him (husband) know that I have spoken thus, and it will cause misery between us. Will you go away from me? You are no friend!'' (unknown)

``I will go when I have spoken a word. If anyone says I have come here to question you without good grounds for it, that person speaks untruly. If anyone says that I attempted to stop your marriage by any but honest means, that person, too, does not speak the truth. I have fallen on an evil time; God has been unjust to me in letting you insult me! Probably my son's happiness does not lie on this side of the grave, for he (son) is a foolish man who neglects the advice of his (son) parent. You, Eustacia, stand on the edge of a precipice without knowing it. Only show my son one-half the temper you have shown me today--and you may before long--and you will find that though he (son) is as gentle as a child with you now, he (son) can be as hard as steel!'' (The mother)

The excited mother then withdrew, and Eustacia, panting, stood looking into the pool.

2--He (Yeobright) Is Set upon by Adversities but He (Yeobright) Sings a Song

The result of that unpropitious interview was that Eustacia, instead of passing the afternoon with her (Eustacia) grandfather, hastily returned home to Clym, where she (Eustacia) arrived three hours earlier than she (Eustacia) had been expected.

She (Eustacia) came indoors with her (Eustacia) face flushed, and her (Eustacia) eyes still showing traces of her (Eustacia) recent excitement. Yeobright looked up astonished; he (grandfather) had never seen her (Eustacia) in any way approaching to that state before. She (Eustacia) passed him (grandfather) by, and would have gone upstairs unnoticed, but Clym was so concerned that he (grandfather) immediately followed her (Eustacia).

``What is the matter, Eustacia?'' (he)
he (grandfather) said. She (Eustacia) was standing on the hearthrug in the bedroom, looking upon the floor, her (Eustacia) hands clasped in front of her (Eustacia), her (Eustacia) bonnet yet unremoved. For a moment she (Eustacia) did not answer; and then she (Eustacia) replied in a low voice--

``I have seen your mother; and I will never see her (Eustacia) again!'' (she)

A weight fell like a stone upon Clym. That same morning, when Eustacia had arranged to go and see her (Eustacia) grandfather, Clym had expressed a wish that she (Eustacia) would drive down to Blooms-End and inquire for her (Eustacia) mother-in- law, or adopt any other means she (Eustacia) might think fit to bring about a reconciliation. She (Eustacia) had set out gaily; and he (grandfather) had hoped for much.

``Why is this?'' (he)
he (grandfather) asked.

``I cannot tell--I cannot remember. I met your mother. And I will never meet her (mother) again.'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (unknown)

``What do I know about Mr. Wildeve now? I won't have wicked opinions passed on me by anybody. O! it was too humiliating to be asked if I had received any money from him (Wildeve), or encouraged him (Wildeve), or something of the sort--I don't exactly know what!'' (unknown)

``How could she (mother) have asked you that?'' (unknown)

``She (mother) did.'' (unknown)

``Then there must have been some meaning in it. What did my mother say besides?'' (unknown)

``I don't know what she (mother) said, except in so far as this, that we both said words which can never be forgiven!'' (unknown)

``Oh, there must be some misapprehension. Whose fault was it that her (mother) meaning was not made clear?'' (unknown)

``I would rather not say. It may have been the fault of the circumstances, which were awkward at the very least. O Clym--I cannot help expressing it--this is an unpleasant position that you have placed me in. But you must improve it--yes, say you will--for I hate it all now! Yes, take me to Paris, and go on with your old occupation, Clym! I don't mind how humbly we live there at first, if it can only be Paris, and not Egdon Heath.'' (unknown)

``But I have quite given up that idea,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright, with surprise.
``Surely I never led you to expect such a thing?'' (unknown)

``I own it. Yet there are thoughts which cannot be kept out of mind, and that one was mine. Must I not have a voice in the matter, now I am your wife and the sharer of your doom?'' (unknown)

``Well, there are things which are placed beyond the pale of discussion; and I thought this was specially so, and by mutual agreement.'' (unknown)

``Clym, I am unhappy at what I hear,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said in a low voice; and her (Eustacia) eyes drooped, and she (Eustacia) turned away.

This indication of an unexpected mine of hope in Eustacia's bosom disconcerted her (Eustacia) husband. It was the first time that he (husband) had confronted the fact of the indirectness of a woman's movement towards her (woman) desire. But his (husband) intention was unshaken, though he (husband) loved Eustacia well. All the effect that her (Eustacia) remark had upon him (husband) was a resolve to chain himself more closely than ever to his (husband) books, so as to be the sooner enabled to appeal to substantial results from another course in arguing against her (Eustacia) whim.

Next day the mystery of the guineas was explained. Thomasin paid them a hurried visit, and Clym's share was delivered up to him (husband) by her (Eustacia) own hands. Eustacia was not present at the time.

``Then this is what my mother meant,'' (unknown)
exclaimed Clym.
``Thomasin, do you know that they have had a bitter quarrel?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

There was a little more reticence now than formerly in Thomasin's manner towards her (Eustacia) cousin. It is the effect of marriage to engender in several directions some of the reserve it annihilates in one.

``Your mother told me,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said quietly.
``She (mother) came back to my house after seeing Eustacia.'' (unknown)

``The worst thing I dreaded has come to pass. Was Mother much disturbed when she (Mother) came to you, Thomasin?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Very much indeed?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

Clym leant his (cousin) elbow upon the post of the garden gate, and covered his (cousin) eyes with his (cousin) hand.

``Don't trouble about it, Clym. They may get to be friends.'' (He)

He (cousin) shook his (cousin) head.

``Not two people with inflammable natures like theirs. Well, what must be will be.'' (unknown)

``One thing is cheerful in it--the guineas are not lost.'' (unknown)

``I would rather have lost them twice over than have had this happen.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Amid these jarring events Yeobright felt one thing to be indispensable--that he (cousin) should speedily make some show of progress in his (cousin) scholastic plans. With this view he (cousin) read far into the small hours during many nights.

One morning, after a severer strain than usual, he (cousin) awoke with a strange sensation in his (cousin) eyes. The sun was shining directly upon the window-blind, and at his (cousin) first glance thitherward a sharp pain obliged him (cousin) to close his (cousin) eyelids quickly. At every new attempt to look about him (cousin) the same morbid sensibility to light was manifested, and excoriating tears ran down his (cousin) cheeks. He (cousin) was obliged to tie a bandage over his (cousin) brow while dressing; and during the day it could not be abandoned. Eustacia was thoroughly alarmed. On finding that the case was no better the next morning they decided to send to Anglebury for a surgeon.

Towards evening he (surgeon) arrived, and pronounced the disease to be acute inflammation induced by Clym's night studies, continued in spite of a cold previously caught, which had weakened his (surgeon) eyes for the time.

Fretting with impatience at this interruption to a task he (surgeon) was so anxious to hasten, Clym was transformed into an invalid. He (surgeon) was shut up in a room from which all light was excluded, and his (surgeon) condition would have been one of absolute misery had not Eustacia read to him (surgeon) by the glimmer of a shaded lamp. He (surgeon) hoped that the worst would soon be over; but at the surgeon's third visit he (surgeon) learnt to his (surgeon) dismay that although he (surgeon) might venture out of doors with shaded eyes in the course of a month, all thought of pursuing his (surgeon) work, or of reading print of any description, would have to be given up for a long time to come.

One week and another week wore on, and nothing seemed to lighten the gloom of the young couple. Dreadful imaginings occurred to Eustacia, but she (Eustacia) carefully refrained from uttering them to her (Eustacia) husband. Suppose he (husband) should become blind, or, at all events, never recover sufficient strength of sight to engage in an occupation which would be congenial to her (Eustacia) feelings, and conduce to her (Eustacia) removal from this lonely dwelling among the hills? That dream of beautiful Paris was not likely to cohere into substance in the presence of this misfortune. As day after day passed by, and he (husband) got no better, her (Eustacia) mind ran more and more in this mournful groove, and she (Eustacia) would go away from him (husband) into the garden and weep despairing tears.

Yeobright thought he (husband) would send for his (husband) mother; and then he (husband) thought he (husband) would not. Knowledge of his (husband) state could only make her (mother) the more unhappy; and the seclusion of their life was such that she (mother) would hardly be likely to learn the news except through a special messenger. Endeavouring to take the trouble as philosophically as possible, he (husband) waited on till the third week had arrived, when he (husband) went into the open air for the first time since the attack. The surgeon visited him (surgeon) again at this stage, and Clym urged him (surgeon) to express a distinct opinion. The young man learnt with added surprise that the date at which he (man) might expect to resume his (man) labours was as uncertain as ever, his (man) eyes being in that peculiar state which, though affording him (man) sight enough for walking about, would not admit of their being strained upon any definite object without incurring the risk of reproducing ophthalmia in its acute form.

Clym was very grave at the intelligence, but not despairing. A quiet firmness, and even cheerfulness, took possession of him (man). He (man) was not to be blind; that was enough. To be doomed to behold the world through smoked glass for an indefinite period was bad enough, and fatal to any kind of advance; but Yeobright was an absolute stoic in the face of mishaps which only affected his (man) social standing; and, apart from Eustacia, the humblest walk of life would satisfy him (man) if it could be made to work in with some form of his (man) culture scheme. To keep a cottage night-school was one such form; and his (man) affliction did not master his (man) spirit as it might otherwise have done.

He (man) walked through the warm sun westward into those tracts of Egdon with which he (man) was best acquainted, being those lying nearer to his (man) old home. He (man) saw before him (man) in one of the valleys the gleaming of whetted iron, and advancing, dimly perceived that the shine came from the tool of a man who was cutting furze. The worker recognized Clym, and Yeobright learnt from the voice that the speaker was Humphrey.

Humphrey expressed his (Humphrey) sorrow at Clym's condition, and added,

``Now, if yours was low-class work like mine, you could go on with it just the same.'' (Humphrey)

``Yes, I could,'' (Yeobright)
said Yeobright musingly.
``How much do you get for cutting these faggots?'' (unknown)

``Half-a-crown a hundred, and in these long days I can live very well on the wages.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

During the whole of Yeobright's walk home to Alderworth he (Humphrey) was lost in reflections which were not of an unpleasant kind. On his (Humphrey) coming up to the house Eustacia spoke to him (Humphrey) from the open window, and he (Humphrey) went across to her (Eustacia).

``Darling,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said,
``I am much happier. And if my mother were reconciled to me and to you I should, I think, be happy quite.'' (he)

``I fear that will never be,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, looking afar with her (Eustacia) beautiful stormy eyes.
``How CAN you say `I am happier,' and nothing changed?'' (unknown)

``It arises from my having at last discovered something I can do, and get a living at, in this time of misfortune.'' (unknown)

``Yes?'' (unknown)

``I am going to be a furze- and turf-cutter.'' (unknown)

``No, Clym!'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, the slight hopefulness previously apparent in her (Eustacia) face going off again, and leaving her (Eustacia) worse than before.

``Surely I shall. Is it not very unwise in us to go on spending the little money we've got when I can keep down expenditures by an honest occupation? The outdoor exercise will do me good, and who knows but that in a few months I shall be able to go on with my reading again?'' (unknown)

``But my grandfather offers to assist us, if we require assistance.'' (unknown)

``We don't require it. If I go furze-cutting we shall be fairly well off.'' (unknown)

``In comparison with slaves, and the Israelites in Egypt, and such people!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
A bitter tear rolled down Eustacia's face, which he (Humphrey) did not see. There had been nonchalance in his (Humphrey) tone, showing her (Eustacia) that he (Humphrey) felt no absolute grief at a consummation which to her (Eustacia) was a positive horror.

The very next day Yeobright went to Humphrey's cottage, and borrowed of him (Humphrey) leggings, gloves, a whetstone, and a hook, to use till he (Humphrey) should be able to purchase some for himself. Then he (Humphrey) sallied forth with his (Humphrey) new fellow-labourer and old acquaintance, and selecting a spot where the furze grew thickest he (Humphrey) struck the first blow in his (Humphrey) adopted calling. His (Humphrey) sight, like the wings in Rasselas, though useless to him (Humphrey) for his (Humphrey) grand purpose, sufficed for this strait, and he (Humphrey) found that when a little practice should have hardened his (Humphrey) palms against blistering he (Humphrey) would be able to work with ease.

Day after day he (Humphrey) rose with the sun, buckled on his (Humphrey) leggings, and went off to the rendezvous with Humphrey. His (Humphrey) custom was to work from four o’clock in the morning till noon; then, when the heat of the day was at its highest, to go home and sleep for an hour or two; afterwards coming out again and working till dusk at nine.

This man from Paris was now so disguised by his (man) leather accoutrements, and by the goggles he (man) was obliged to wear over his (man) eyes, that his (man) closest friend might have passed by without recognizing him (man). He (man) was a brown spot in the midst of an expanse of olive-green gorse, and nothing more. Though frequently depressed in spirit when not actually at work, owing to thoughts of Eustacia's position and his (man) mother's estrangement, when in the full swing of labour he (man) was cheerfully disposed and calm.

His (man) daily life was of a curious microscopic sort, his (man) whole world being limited to a circuit of a few feet from his (man) person. His (man) familiars were creeping and winged things, and they seemed to enroll him (man) in their band. Bees hummed around his (man) ears with an intimate air, and tugged at the heath and furze-flowers at his (man) side in such numbers as to weigh them down to the sod. The strange amber-coloured butterflies which Egdon produced, and which were never seen elsewhere, quivered in the breath of his (Egdon) lips, alighted upon his (Egdon) bowed back, and sported with the glittering point of his (Egdon) hook as he (Egdon) flourished it up and down. Tribes of emerald-green grasshoppers leaped over his (Egdon) feet, falling awkwardly on their backs, heads, or hips, like unskilful acrobats, as chance might rule; or engaged themselves in noisy flirtations under the fern-fronds with silent ones of homely hue. Huge flies, ignorant of larders and wire-netting, and quite in a savage state, buzzed about him (Egdon) without knowing that he (Egdon) was a man. In and out of the fern-dells snakes glided in their most brilliant blue and yellow guise, it being the season immediately following the shedding of their old skins, when their colours are brightest. Litters of young rabbits came out from their forms to sun themselves upon hillocks, the hot beams blazing through the delicate tissue of each thin-fleshed ear, and firing it to a blood-red transparency in which the veins could be seen. None of them feared him (Egdon).

The monotony of his (Egdon) occupation soothed him (Egdon), and was in itself a pleasure. A forced limitation of effort offered a justification of homely courses to an unambitious man, whose conscience would hardly have allowed him (man) to remain in such obscurity while his (man) powers were unimpeded. Hence Yeobright sometimes sang to himself, and when obliged to accompany Humphrey in search of brambles for faggot-bonds he (Humphrey) would amuse his (Humphrey) companion with sketches of Parisian life and character, and so while away the time.

On one of these warm afternoons Eustacia walked out alone in the direction of Yeobright's place of work. He (Humphrey) was busily chopping away at the furze, a long row of faggots which stretched downward from his (Humphrey) position representing the labour of the day. He (Humphrey) did not observe her (Eustacia) approach, and she (Eustacia) stood close to him (Humphrey), and heard his (Humphrey) undercurrent of song. It shocked her (Eustacia). To see him (Humphrey) there, a poor afflicted man, earning money by the sweat of his (man) brow, had at first moved her (Eustacia) to tears; but to hear him (man) sing and not at all rebel against an occupation which, however satisfactory to himself, was degrading to her (Eustacia), as an educated lady- wife, wounded her (wife) through. Unconscious of her (wife) presence, he (man) still went on singing:--

``Le point du jour A nos bosquets rend toute leur parure; Flore est plus belle a son retour; L’oiseau reprend doux chant d’amour; Tout celebre dans la nature Le point du jour.

``Le point du jour Cause parfois, cause douleur extreme; Que l’espace des nuits est court Pour le berger brulant d’amour, Force de quitter ce qu’il aime Au point du jour!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

It was bitterly plain to Eustacia that he (man) did not care much about social failure; and the proud fair woman bowed her (woman) head and wept in sick despair at thought of the blasting effect upon her (woman) own life of that mood and condition in him (man). Then she (woman) came forward.

``I would starve rather than do it!'' (she)
she (woman) exclaimed vehemently.
``And you can sing! I will go and live with my grandfather again!'' (unknown)

``Eustacia! I did not see you, though I noticed something moving,'' (he)
he (man) said gently. He (man) came forward, pulled off his (man) huge leather glove, and took her (woman) hand.
``Why do you speak in such a strange way? It is only a little old song which struck my fancy when I was in Paris, and now just applies to my life with you. Has your love for me all died, then, because my appearance is no longer that of a fine gentleman?'' (unknown)

``Dearest, you must not question me unpleasantly, or it may make me not love you.'' (unknown)

``Do you believe it possible that I would run the risk of doing that?'' (unknown)

``Well, you follow out your own ideas, and won't give in to mine when I wish you to leave off this shameful labour. Is there anything you dislike in me that you act so contrarily to my wishes? I am your wife, and why will you not listen? Yes, I am your wife indeed!'' (unknown)

``I know what that tone means.'' (unknown)

``What tone?'' (unknown)

``The tone in which you said, `Your wife indeed.' It meant, `Your wife, worse luck.'''

``It is hard in you to probe me with that remark. A woman may have reason, though she (woman) is not without heart, and if I felt `worse luck,' it was no ignoble feeling--it was only too natural. There, you see that at any rate I do not attempt untruths. Do you remember how, before we were married, I warned you that I had not good wifely qualities?'' (unknown)

``You mock me to say that now. On that point at least the only noble course would be to hold your tongue, for you are still queen of me, Eustacia, though I may no longer be king of you.'' (unknown)

``You are my husband. Does not that content you?'' (unknown)

``Not unless you are my wife without regret.'' (unknown)

``I cannot answer you. I remember saying that I should be a serious matter on your hands.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I saw that.'' (unknown)

``Then you were too quick to see! No true lover would have seen any such thing; you are too severe upon me, Clym--I won't like your speaking so at all.'' (unknown)

``Well, I married you in spite of it, and don't regret doing so. How cold you seem this afternoon! and yet I used to think there never was a warmer heart than yours.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I fear we are cooling--I see it as well as you,'' (she)
she (woman) sighed mournfully.
``And how madly we loved two months ago! You were never tired of contemplating me, nor I of contemplating you. Who could have thought then that by this time my eyes would not seem so very bright to yours, nor your lips so very sweet to mine? Two months--is it possible? Yes, `tis too true!'' (unknown)

``You sigh, dear, as if you were sorry for it; and that's a hopeful sign.'' (unknown)

``No. I don't sigh for that. There are other things for me to sigh for, or any other woman in my place.'' (unknown)

``That your chances in life are ruined by marrying in haste an unfortunate man?'' (unknown)

``Why will you force me, Clym, to say bitter things? I deserve pity as much as you. As much?--I think I deserve it more. For you can sing! It would be a strange hour which should catch me singing under such a cloud as this! Believe me, sweet, I could weep to a degree that would astonish and confound such an elastic mind as yours. Even had you felt careless about your own affliction, you might have refrained from singing out of sheer pity for mine. God! if I were a man in such a position I would curse rather than sing.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright placed his (man) hand upon her (woman) arm.

``Now, don't you suppose, my inexperienced girl, that I cannot rebel, in high Promethean fashion, against the gods and fate as well as you. I have felt more steam and smoke of that sort than you have ever heard of. But the more I see of life the more do I perceive that there is nothing particularly great in its greatest walks, and therefore nothing particularly small in mine of furze-cutting. If I feel that the greatest blessings vouchsafed to us are not very valuable, how can I feel it to be any great hardship when they are taken away? So I sing to pass the time. Have you indeed lost all tenderness for me, that you begrudge me a few cheerful moments?'' (unknown)

``I have still some tenderness left for you.'' (unknown)

``Your words have no longer their old flavour. And so love dies with good fortune!'' (unknown)

``I cannot listen to this, Clym--it will end bitterly,'' (she)
she (woman) said in a broken voice.
``I will go home.'' (She)

3--She (woman) Goes Out to Battle against Depression

A few days later, before the month of August has expired, Eustacia and Yeobright sat together at their early dinner.

Eustacia's manner had become of late almost apathetic. There was a forlorn look about her (Eustacia) beautiful eyes which, whether she (Eustacia) deserved it or not, would have excited pity in the breast of anyone who had known her (Eustacia) during the full flush of her (Eustacia) love for Clym. The feelings of husband and wife varied, in some measure, inversely with their positions. Clym, the afflicted man, was cheerful; and he (man) even tried to comfort her (Eustacia), who had never felt a moment of physical suffering in her (Eustacia) whole life.

``Come, brighten up, dearest; we shall be all right again. Some day perhaps I shall see as well as ever. And I solemnly promise that I'll leave off cutting furze as soon as I have the power to do anything better. You cannot seriously wish me to stay idling at home all day?'' (unknown)

``But it is so dreadful--a furze-cutter! and you a man who have lived about the world, and speak French, and German, and who are fit for what is so much better than this.'' (unknown)

``I suppose when you first saw me and heard about me I was wrapped in a sort of golden halo to your eyes--a man who knew glorious things, and had mixed in brilliant scenes--in short, an adorable, delightful, distracting hero?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, sobbing.

``And now I am a poor fellow in brown leather.'' (unknown)

``Don't taunt me. But enough of this. I will not be depressed any more. I am going from home this afternoon, unless you greatly object. There is to be a village picnic--a gipsying, they call it--at East Egdon, and I shall go.'' (unknown)

``To dance?'' (unknown)

``Why not? You can sing.'' (unknown)

``Well, well, as you will. Must I come to fetch you?'' (unknown)

``If you return soon enough from your work. But do not inconvenience yourself about it. I know the way home, and the heath has no terror for me.'' (unknown)

``And can you cling to gaiety so eagerly as to walk all the way to a village festival in search of it?'' (unknown)

``Now, you don't like my going alone! Clym, you are not jealous?'' (unknown)

``No. But I would come with you if it could give you any pleasure; though, as things stand, perhaps you have too much of me already. Still, I somehow wish that you did not want to go. Yes, perhaps I am jealous; and who could be jealous with more reason than I, a half-blind man, over such a woman as you?'' (unknown)

``Don't think like it. Let me go, and don't take all my spirits away!'' (unknown)

``I would rather lose all my own, my sweet wife. Go and do whatever you like. Who can forbid your indulgence in any whim? You have all my heart yet, I believe; and because you bear with me, who am in truth a drag upon you, I owe you thanks. Yes, go alone and shine. As for me, I will stick to my doom. At that kind of meeting people would shun me. My hook and gloves are like the St. Lazarus rattle of the leper, warning the world to get out of the way of a sight that would sadden them.'' (He)
He (man) kissed her (Eustacia), put on his (man) leggings, and went out.
