In almost every one of the isolated and stunted thorns which grew here and there a nighthawk revealed his (husband) presence by whirring like the clack of a mill as long as he (husband) could hold his (husband) breath, then stopping, flapping his (husband) wings, wheeling round the bush, alighting, and after a silent interval of listening beginning to whirr again. At each brushing of Clym's feet white millermoths flew into the air just high enough to catch upon their dusty wings the mellowed light from the west, which now shone across the depressions and levels of the ground without falling thereon to light them up.

Yeobright walked on amid this quiet scene with a hope that all would soon be well. Three miles on he (husband) came to a spot where a soft perfume was wafted across his (husband) path, and he (husband) stood still for a moment to inhale the familiar scent. It was the place at which, four hours earlier, his (husband) mother had sat down exhausted on the knoll covered with shepherd's-thyme. While he (husband) stood a sound between a breathing and a moan suddenly reached his (husband) ears.

He (husband) looked to where the sound came from; but nothing appeared there save the verge of the hillock stretching against the sky in an unbroken line. He (husband) moved a few steps in that direction, and now he (husband) perceived a recumbent figure almost close to his (husband) feet.

Among the different possibilities as to the person's individuality there did not for a moment occur to Yeobright that it might be one of his (husband) own family. Sometimes furze-cutters had been known to sleep out of doors at these times, to save a long journey homeward and back again; but Clym remembered the moan and looked closer, and saw that the form was feminine; and a distress came over him (husband) like cold air from a cave. But he (husband) was not absolutely certain that the woman was his (husband) mother till he (husband) stooped and beheld her (woman) face, pallid, and with closed eyes.

His (husband) breath went, as it were, out of his (husband) body and the cry of anguish which would have escaped him (husband) died upon his (husband) lips. During the momentary interval that elapsed before he (husband) became conscious that something must be done all sense of time and place left him (husband), and it seemed as if he (husband) and his (husband) mother were as when he (husband) was a child with her (mother) many years ago on this heath at hours similar to the present. Then he (husband) awoke to activity; and bending yet lower he (husband) found that she (mother) still breathed, and that her (mother) breath though feeble was regular, except when disturbed by an occasional gasp.

``O, what is it! Mother, are you very ill--you are not dying?'' (he)
he (husband) cried, pressing his (husband) lips to her (mother) face.
``I am your Clym. How did you come here? What does it all mean?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

At that moment the chasm in their lives which his (husband) love for Eustacia had caused was not remembered by Yeobright, and to him (husband) the present joined continuously with that friendly past that had been their experience before the division.

She (Eustacia) moved her (Eustacia) lips, appeared to know him (husband), but could not speak; and then Clym strove to consider how best to move her (Eustacia), as it would be necessary to get her (Eustacia) away from the spot before the dews were intense. He (husband) was able-bodied, and his (husband) mother was thin. He (husband) clasped his (husband) arms round her (mother), lifted her (mother) a little, and said,

``Does that hurt you?'' (her)

She (mother) shook her (mother) head, and he (husband) lifted her (mother) up; then, at a slow pace, went onward with his (husband) load. The air was now completely cool; but whenever he (husband) passed over a sandy patch of ground uncarpeted with vegetation there was reflected from its surface into his (husband) face the heat which it had imbibed during the day. At the beginning of his (husband) undertaking he (husband) had thought but little of the distance which yet would have to be traversed before Blooms-End could be reached; but though he (husband) had slept that afternoon he (husband) soon began to feel the weight of his (husband) burden. Thus he (husband) proceeded, like Aeneas with his (husband) father; the bats circling round his (husband) head, nightjars flapping their wings within a yard of his (husband) face, and not a human being within call.

While he (husband) was yet nearly a mile from the house his (husband) mother exhibited signs of restlessness under the constraint of being borne along, as if his (husband) arms were irksome to her (mother). He (husband) lowered her (mother) upon his (husband) knees and looked around. The point they had now reached, though far from any road, was not more than a mile from the Blooms-End cottages occupied by Fairway, Sam, Humphrey, and the Cantles. Moreover, fifty yards off stood a hut, built of clods and covered with thin turves, but now entirely disused. The simple outline of the lonely shed was visible, and thither he (Humphrey) determined to direct his (Humphrey) steps. As soon as he (Humphrey) arrived he (Humphrey) laid her (mother) down carefully by the entrance, and then ran and cut with his (Humphrey) pocketknife an armful of the dryest fern. Spreading this within the shed, which was entirely open on one side, he (Humphrey) placed his (Humphrey) mother thereon; then he (Humphrey) ran with all his (Humphrey) might towards the dwelling of Fairway.

Nearly a quarter of an hour had passed, disturbed only by the broken breathing of the sufferer, when moving figures began to animate the line between heath and sky. In a few moments Clym arrived with Fairway, Humphrey, and Susan Nunsuch; Olly Dowden, who had chanced to be at Fairway's, Christian and Grandfer Cantle following helter-skelter behind. They had brought a lantern and matches, water, a pillow, and a few other articles which had occurred to their minds in the hurry of the moment. Sam had been despatched back again for brandy, and a boy brought Fairway's pony, upon which he (boy) rode off to the nearest medical man, with directions to call at Wildeve's on his (Wildeve) way, and inform Thomasin that her (Nunsuch) aunt was unwell.

Sam and the brandy soon arrived, and it was administered by the light of the lantern; after which she (Nunsuch) became sufficiently conscious to signify by signs that something was wrong with her (Nunsuch) foot. Olly Dowden at length understood her (Nunsuch) meaning, and examined the foot indicated. It was swollen and red. Even as they watched the red began to assume a more livid colour, in the midst of which appeared a scarlet speck, smaller than a pea, and it was found to consist of a drop of blood, which rose above the smooth flesh of her (Nunsuch) ankle in a hemisphere.

``I know what it is,'' (Sam)
cried Sam.
``She (Mother) has been stung by an adder!'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (unknown)
said Clym instantly.
``I remember when I was a child seeing just such a bite. O, my poor mother!'' (unknown)

``It was my father who was bit,'' (Sam)
said Sam.
``And there's only one way to cure it. You must rub the place with the fat of other adders, and the only way to get that is by frying them. That's what they did for him (father).'' (unknown)

```Tis an old remedy,'' said Clym distrustfully,

``and I have doubts about it. But we can do nothing else till the doctor comes.'' (unknown)

```Tis a sure cure,'' said Olly Dowden, with emphasis.

``I've used it when I used to go out nursing.'' (unknown)

``Then we must pray for daylight, to catch them,'' (unknown)
said Clym gloomily.

``I will see what I can do,'' (Sam)
said Sam.

He (Sam) took a green hazel which he (Sam) had used as a walking stick, split it at the end, inserted a small pebble, and with the lantern in his (Sam) hand went out into the heath. Clym had by this time lit a small fire, and despatched Susan Nunsuch for a frying pan. Before she (Nunsuch) had returned Sam came in with three adders, one briskly coiling and uncoiling in the cleft of the stick, and the other two hanging dead across it.

``I have only been able to get one alive and fresh as he (doctor) ought to be,'' (Sam)
said Sam.
``These limp ones are two I killed today at work; but as they don't die till the sun goes down they can't be very stale meat.'' (unknown)

The live adder regarded the assembled group with a sinister look in its small black eye, and the beautiful brown and jet pattern on its back seemed to intensify with indignation. Mrs. Yeobright saw the creature, and the creature saw her (Yeobright)--she (Yeobright) quivered throughout, and averted her (Yeobright) eyes.

``Look at that,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
murmured Christian Cantle.
``Neighbours, how do we know but that something of the old serpent in God's garden, that gied the apple to the young woman with no clothes, lives on in adders and snakes still? Look at his (God) eye--for all the world like a villainous sort of black currant. `Tis to be hoped he (God) can't ill-wish us! There's folks in heath who've been overlooked already. I will never kill another adder as long as I live.'' (unknown)

``Well, `tis right to be afeard of things, if folks can't help it,'' (Grandfer Cantle/Grandfer)
said Grandfer Cantle. ```Twould have saved me many a brave danger in my time.''

``I fancy I heard something outside the shed,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian.
``I wish troubles would come in the daytime, for then a man could show his (man) courage, and hardly beg for mercy of the most broomstick old woman he (man) should see, if he (man) was a brave man, and able to run out of her (woman) sight!'' (unknown)

``Even such an ignorant fellow as I should know better than do that,'' (Sam)
said Sam.

``Well, there's calamities where we least expect it, whether or no. Neighbours, if Mrs. Yeobright were to die, d’ye think we should be took up and tried for the manslaughter of a woman?'' (unknown)

``No, they couldn't bring it in as that,'' (Sam)
said Sam,
``unless they could prove we had been poachers at some time of our lives. But she (woman)'ll fetch round.'' (Sam)

``Now, if I had been stung by ten adders I should hardly have lost a day's work for't,'' (Grandfer Cantle/Grandfer)
said Grandfer Cantle.
``Such is my spirit when I am on my mettle. But perhaps `tis natural in a man trained for war. Yes, I've gone through a good deal; but nothing ever came amiss to me after I joined the Locals in four.'' (He)
He (Sam) shook his (Sam) head and smiled at a mental picture of himself in uniform.
``I was always first in the most galliantest scrapes in my younger days!'' (unknown)

``I suppose that was because they always used to put the biggest fool afore,'' (he)
said Fairway from the fire, beside which he (Sam) knelt, blowing it with his (Sam) breath.

``D’ye think so, Timothy?'' (Grandfer Cantle/Grandfer)
said Grandfer Cantle, coming forward to Fairway's side with sudden depression in his (Sam) face.
``Then a man may feel for years that he (man) is good solid company, and be wrong about himself after all?'' (unknown)

``Never mind that question, Grandfer. Stir your stumps and get some more sticks. `Tis very nonsense of an old man to prattle so when life and death's in mangling.'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes,'' (Grandfer Cantle/Grandfer)
said Grandfer Cantle, with melancholy conviction.
``Well, this is a bad night altogether for them that have done well in their time; and if I were ever such a dab at the hautboy or tenor viol, I shouldn't have the heart to play tunes upon `em now.'' (Susan/Susan Nunsuch)

Susan now arrived with the frying pan, when the live adder was killed and the heads of the three taken off. The remainders, being cut into lengths and split open, were tossed into the pan, which began hissing and crackling over the fire. Soon a rill of clear oil trickled from the carcases, whereupon Clym dipped the corner of his (Sam) handkerchief into the liquid and anointed the wound.

8--Eustacia Hears of Good Fortune, and Beholds Evil

In the meantime Eustacia, left alone in her (Eustacia) cottage at Alderworth, had become considerably depressed by the posture of affairs. The consequences which might result from Clym's discovery that his (Sam) mother had been turned from his (Sam) door that day were likely to be disagreeable, and this was a quality in events which she (mother) hated as much as the dreadful.

To be left to pass the evening by herself was irksome to her (mother) at any time, and this evening it was more irksome than usual by reason of the excitements of the past hours. The two visits had stirred her (mother) into restlessness. She (mother) was not wrought to any great pitch of uneasiness by the probability of appearing in an ill light in the discussion between Clym and his (Sam) mother, but she (mother) was wrought to vexation, and her (mother) slumbering activities were quickened to the extent of wishing that she (mother) had opened the door. She (mother) had certainly believed that Clym was awake, and the excuse would be an honest one as far as it went; but nothing could save her (mother) from censure in refusing to answer at the first knock. Yet, instead of blaming herself for the issue she (mother) laid the fault upon the shoulders of some indistinct, colossal Prince of the World, who had framed her (mother) situation and ruled her (mother) lot.

At this time of the year it was pleasanter to walk by night than by day, and when Clym had been absent about an hour she (mother) suddenly resolved to go out in the direction of Blooms-End, on the chance of meeting him (Prince) on his (Prince) return. When she (mother) reached the garden gate she (mother) heard wheels approaching, and looking round beheld her (mother) grandfather coming up in his (grandfather) car.

``I can't stay a minute, thank ye,'' (he)
he (grandfather) answered to her (mother) greeting.
``I am driving to East Egdon; but I came round here just to tell you the news. Perhaps you have heard--about Mr. Wildeve's fortune?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia blankly.

``Well, he (Wildeve) has come into a fortune of eleven thousand pounds--uncle died in Canada, just after hearing that all his (uncle) family, whom he (uncle) was sending home, had gone to the bottom in the Cassiopeia; so Wildeve has come into everything, without in the least expecting it.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia stood motionless awhile.

``How long has he (Wildeve) known of this?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) asked.

``Well, it was known to him (Wildeve) this morning early, for I knew it at ten o’clock, when Charley came back. Now, he (Charley) is what I call a lucky man. What a fool you were, Eustacia!'' (unknown)

``In what way?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, lifting her (Eustacia) eyes in apparent calmness.

``Why, in not sticking to him (Charley) when you had him (Charley).'' (unknown)

``Had him (Charley), indeed!'' (unknown)

``I did not know there had ever been anything between you till lately; and, faith, I should have been hot and strong against it if I had known; but since it seems that there was some sniffing between ye, why the deuce didn't you stick to him (Charley)?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia made no reply, but she (Eustacia) looked as if she (Eustacia) could say as much upon that subject as he (grandfather) if she (Eustacia) chose.

``And how is your poor purblind husband?'' (the man)
continued the old man.
``Not a bad fellow either, as far as he (fellow) goes.'' (unknown)

``He (fellow) is quite well.'' (unknown)

``It is a good thing for his (fellow) cousin what-d’ye-call-her? By George, you ought to have been in that galley, my girl! Now I must drive on. Do you want any assistance? What's mine is yours, you know.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, Grandfather, we are not in want at present,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said coldly.
``Clym cuts furze, but he (Grandfather) does it mostly as a useful pastime, because he (Grandfather) can do nothing else.'' (unknown)

``He (Grandfather) is paid for his (Grandfather) pastime, isn't he (Grandfather)? Three shillings a hundred, I heard.'' (unknown)

``Clym has money,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, colouring,
``but he (Grandfather) likes to earn a little.'' (she)

``Very well; good night.'' (the captain)
And the captain drove on.

When her (Eustacia) grandfather was gone Eustacia went on her (Eustacia) way mechanically; but her (Eustacia) thoughts were no longer concerning her (Eustacia) mother-in-law and Clym. Wildeve, notwithstanding his (Wildeve) complaints against his (Wildeve) fate, had been seized upon by destiny and placed in the sunshine once more. Eleven thousand pounds! From every Egdon point of view he (Egdon) was a rich man. In Eustacia's eyes, too, it was an ample sum--one sufficient to supply those wants of hers which had been stigmatized by Clym in his (Egdon) more austere moods as vain and luxurious. Though she (Eustacia) was no lover of money she (Eustacia) loved what money could bring; and the new accessories she (Eustacia) imagined around him (lover) clothed Wildeve with a great deal of interest. She (Eustacia) recollected now how quietly well-dressed he (lover) had been that morning--he (lover) had probably put on his (lover) newest suit, regardless of damage by briars and thorns. And then she (Eustacia) thought of his (lover) manner towards herself.

``O I see it, I see it,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.
``How much he (Grandfather) wishes he (Grandfather) had me now, that he (Grandfather) might give me all I desire!'' (unknown)

In recalling the details of his (lover) glances and words--at the time scarcely regarded--it became plain to her (Eustacia) how greatly they had been dictated by his (lover) knowledge of this new event.

``Had he (Grandfather) been a man to bear a jilt ill-will he (Grandfather) would have told me of his (Grandfather) good fortune in crowing tones; instead of doing that he (Grandfather) mentioned not a word, in deference to my misfortunes, and merely implied that he (Grandfather) loved me still, as one superior to him (Grandfather).'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve's silence that day on what had happened to him (Wildeve) was just the kind of behaviour calculated to make an impression on such a woman. Those delicate touches of good taste were, in fact, one of the strong points in his (Wildeve) demeanour towards the other sex. The peculiarity of Wildeve was that, while at one time passionate, upbraiding, and resentful towards a woman, at another he (Wildeve) would treat her (woman) with such unparalleled grace as to make previous neglect appear as no discourtesy, injury as no insult, interference as a delicate attention, and the ruin of her (woman) honour as excess of chivalry. This man, whose admiration today Eustacia had disregarded, whose good wishes she (Eustacia) had scarcely taken the trouble to accept, whom she (Eustacia) had shown out of the house by the back door, was the possessor of eleven thousand pounds--a man of fair professional education, and one who had served his (man) articles with a civil engineer.

So intent was Eustacia upon Wildeve's fortunes that she (Eustacia) forgot how much closer to her (Eustacia) own course were those of Clym; and instead of walking on to meet him (Wildeve) at once she (Eustacia) sat down upon a stone. She (Eustacia) was disturbed in her (Eustacia) reverie by a voice behind, and turning her (Eustacia) head beheld the old lover and fortunate inheritor of wealth immediately beside her (Eustacia).

She (Eustacia) remained sitting, though the fluctuation in her (Eustacia) look might have told any man who knew her (Eustacia) so well as Wildeve that she (Eustacia) was thinking of him (Wildeve).

``How did you come here?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said in her (Eustacia) clear low tone.
``I thought you were at home.'' (unknown)

``I went on to the village after leaving your garden; and now I have come back again--that's all. Which way are you walking, may I ask?'' (She)

She (Eustacia) waved her (Eustacia) hand in the direction of Blooms-End.

``I am going to meet my husband. I think I may possibly have got into trouble whilst you were with me today.'' (unknown)

``How could that be?'' (unknown)

``By not letting in Mrs. Yeobright.'' (unknown)

``I hope that visit of mine did you no harm.'' (unknown)

``None. It was not your fault,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said quietly.

By this time she (Eustacia) had risen; and they involuntarily sauntered on together, without speaking, for two or three minutes; when Eustacia broke silence by saying,

``I assume I must congratulate you.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

``On what? O yes; on my eleven thousand pounds, you mean. Well, since I didn't get something else, I must be content with getting that.'' (unknown)

``You seem very indifferent about it. Why didn't you tell me today when you came?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said in the tone of a neglected person.
``I heard of it quite by accident.'' (unknown)

``I did mean to tell you,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.
``But I--well, I will speak frankly--I did not like to mention it when I saw, Eustacia, that your star was not high. The sight of a man lying wearied out with hard work, as your husband lay, made me feel that to brag of my own fortune to you would be greatly out of place. Yet, as you stood there beside him (husband), I could not help feeling too that in many respects he (husband) was a richer man than I.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

At this Eustacia said, with slumbering mischievousness,

``What, would you exchange with him (husband)--your fortune for me?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

``I certainly would,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

``As we are imagining what is impossible and absurd, suppose we change the subject?'' (unknown)

``Very well; and I will tell you of my plans for the future, if you care to hear them. I shall permanently invest nine thousand pounds, keep one thousand as ready money, and with the remaining thousand travel for a year or so.'' (unknown)

``Travel? What a bright idea! Where will you go to?'' (unknown)

``From here to Paris, where I shall pass the winter and spring. Then I shall go to Italy, Greece, Egypt, and Palestine, before the hot weather comes on. In the summer I shall go to America; and then, by a plan not yet settled, I shall go to Australia and round to India. By that time I shall have begun to have had enough of it. Then I shall probably come back to Paris again, and there I shall stay as long as I can afford to.'' (unknown)

``Back to Paris again,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) murmured in a voice that was nearly a sigh. She (Eustacia) had never once told Wildeve of the Parisian desires which Clym's description had sown in her (Eustacia); yet here was he (Wildeve) involuntarily in a position to gratify them.
``You think a good deal of Paris?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) added.

``Yes. In my opinion it is the central beauty-spot of the world.'' (unknown)

``And in mine! And Thomasin will go with you?'' (unknown)

``Yes, if she (I) cares to. She (I) may prefer to stay at home.'' (unknown)

``So you will be going about, and I shall be staying here!'' (unknown)

``I suppose you will. But we know whose fault that is.'' (unknown)

``I am not blaming you,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said quickly.

``Oh, I thought you were. If ever you SHOULD be inclined to blame me, think of a certain evening by Rainbarrow, when you promised to meet me and did not. You sent me a letter; and my heart ached to read that as I hope yours never will. That was one point of divergence. I then did something in haste... But she (me) is a good woman, and I will say no more.'' (unknown)

``I know that the blame was on my side that time,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.
``But it had not always been so. However, it is my misfortune to be too sudden in feeling. O, Damon, don't reproach me any more--I can't bear that.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

They went on silently for a distance of two or three miles, when Eustacia said suddenly,

``Haven't you come out of your way, Mr. Wildeve?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

``My way is anywhere tonight. I will go with you as far as the hill on which we can see Blooms-End, as it is getting late for you to be alone.'' (unknown)

``Don't trouble. I am not obliged to be out at all. I think I would rather you did not accompany me further. This sort of thing would have an odd look if known.'' (unknown)

``Very well, I will leave you.'' (He)
He (Wildeve) took her (Eustacia) hand unexpectedly, and kissed it--for the first time since her (Eustacia) marriage.
``What light is that on the hill?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) added, as it were to hide the caress.

She (Eustacia) looked, and saw a flickering firelight proceeding from the open side of a hovel a little way before them. The hovel, which she (Eustacia) had hitherto always found empty, seemed to be inhabited now.

``Since you have come so far,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia,
``will you see me safely past that hut? I thought I should have met Clym somewhere about here, but as he (you) doesn't appear I will hasten on and get to Blooms-End before he (you) leaves.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

They advanced to the turf-shed, and when they got near it the firelight and the lantern inside showed distinctly enough the form of a woman reclining on a bed of fern, a group of heath men and women standing around her (woman). Eustacia did not recognize Mrs. Yeobright in the reclining figure, nor Clym as one of the standers-by till she (Eustacia) came close. Then she (Eustacia) quickly pressed her (Eustacia) hand up on Wildeve's arm and signified to him (Wildeve) to come back from the open side of the shed into the shadow.

``It is my husband and his (you) mother,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) whispered in an agitated voice.
``What can it mean? Will you step forward and tell me?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve left her (Eustacia) side and went to the back wall of the hut. Presently Eustacia perceived that he (Wildeve) was beckoning to her (Eustacia), and she (Eustacia) advanced and joined him (Wildeve).

``It is a serious case,'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

From their position they could hear what was proceeding inside.

``I cannot think where she (mother) could have been going,'' (someone)
said Clym to someone.
``She (mother) had evidently walked a long way, but even when she (mother) was able to speak just now she (mother) would not tell me where. What do you really think of her (mother)?'' (unknown)

``There is a great deal to fear,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
was gravely answered, in a voice which Eustacia recognized as that of the only surgeon in the district.
``She (mother) has suffered somewhat from the bite of the adder; but it is exhaustion which has overpowered her (mother). My impression is that her (mother) walk must have been exceptionally long.'' (unknown)

``I used to tell her (mother) not to overwalk herself this weather,'' (unknown)
said Clym, with distress.
``Do you think we did well in using the adder's fat?'' (unknown)

``Well, it is a very ancient remedy--the old remedy of the viper-catchers, I believe,'' (the doctor)
replied the doctor.
``It is mentioned as an infallible ointment by Hoffman, Mead, and I think the Abbe Fontana. Undoubtedly it was as good a thing as you could do; though I question if some other oils would not have been equally efficacious.'' (unknown)

``Come here, come here!'' (the doctor)
was then rapidly said in anxious female tones, and Clym and the doctor could be heard rushing forward from the back part of the shed to where Mrs. Yeobright lay.

``Oh, what is it?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
whispered Eustacia.

```Twas Thomasin who spoke,'' said Wildeve.

``Then they have fetched her (it). I wonder if I had better go in--yet it might do harm.'' (unknown)

For a long time there was utter silence among the group within; and it was broken at last by Clym saying, in an agonized voice,

``O Doctor, what does it mean?'' (The doctor)

The doctor did not reply at once; ultimately he (doctor) said,

``She (it) is sinking fast. Her (it) heart was previously affected, and physical exhaustion has dealt the finishing blow.'' (he)

Then there was a weeping of women, then waiting, then hushed exclamations, then a strange gasping sound, then a painful stillness.

``It is all over,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor.

Further back in the hut the cotters whispered,

``Mrs. Yeobright is dead.'' (the watchers)

Almost at the same moment the two watchers observed the form of a small old-fashioned child entering at the open side of the shed. Susan Nunsuch, whose boy it was, went forward to the opening and silently beckoned to him (boy) to go back.

``I've got something to tell `ee, Mother,'' (he)
he (boy) cried in a shrill tone.
``That woman asleep there walked along with me today; and she (woman) said I was to say that I had seed her (woman), and she (woman) was a broken-hearted woman and cast off by her (woman) son, and then I came on home.'' (a man)

A confused sob as from a man was heard within, upon which Eustacia gasped faintly,

``That's Clym--I must go to him (son)--yet dare I do it? No--come away!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

When they had withdrawn from the neighbourhood of the shed she (Eustacia) said huskily,

``I am to blame for this. There is evil in store for me.'' (she)

``Was she (woman) not admitted to your house after all?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
Wildeve inquired.

``No, and that's where it all lies! Oh, what shall I do! I shall not intrude upon them--I shall go straight home. Damon, good-bye! I cannot speak to you any more now.'' (unknown)

They parted company; and when Eustacia had reached the next hill she (Eustacia) looked back. A melancholy procession was wending its way by the light of the lantern from the hut towards Blooms-End. Wildeve was nowhere to be seen.

BOOK FIVE -- THE DISCOVERY

1--

``Wherefore Is Light Given to Him (Damon) That Is in Misery'' (Mrs. Yeobright/Yeobright)

One evening, about three weeks after the funeral of Mrs. Yeobright, when the silver face of the moon sent a bundle of beams directly upon the floor of Clym's house at Alderworth, a woman came forth from within. She (woman) reclined over the garden gate as if to refresh herself awhile. The pale lunar touches which make beauties of hags lent divinity to this face, already beautiful.

She (woman) had not long been there when a man came up the road and with some hesitation said to her (woman),

``How is he (Damon) tonight, ma’am, if you please?'' (her)

``He (Damon) is better, though still very unwell, Humphrey,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
replied Eustacia.

``Is he (Humphrey) light-headed, ma’am?'' (unknown)

``No. He (Humphrey) is quite sensible now.'' (unknown)

``Do he (Humphrey) rave about his (Humphrey) mother just the same, poor fellow?'' (Humphrey)
continued Humphrey.

``Just as much, though not quite so wildly,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said in a low voice.

``It was very unfortunate, ma’am, that the boy Johnny should ever ha' told him (Johnny) his (Johnny) mother's dying words, about her (mother) being broken-hearted and cast off by her (mother) son. `Twas enough to upset any man alive.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia made no reply beyond that of a slight catch in her (Eustacia) breath, as of one who fain would speak but could not; and Humphrey, declining her (Eustacia) invitation to come in, went away.

Eustacia turned, entered the house, and ascended to the front bedroom, where a shaded light was burning. In the bed lay Clym, pale, haggard, wide awake, tossing to one side and to the other, his (Humphrey) eyes lit by a hot light, as if the fire in their pupils were burning up their substance.

``Is it you, Eustacia?'' (he)
he (Humphrey) said as she (Eustacia) sat down.

``Yes, Clym. I have been down to the gate. The moon is shining beautifully, and there is not a leaf stirring.'' (unknown)

``Shining, is it? What's the moon to a man like me? Let it shine--let anything be, so that I never see another day!... Eustacia, I don't know where to look--my thoughts go through me like swords. O, if any man wants to make himself immortal by painting a picture of wretchedness, let him (man) come here!'' (unknown)

``Why do you say so?'' (unknown)

``I cannot help feeling that I did my best to kill her (me).'' (unknown)

``No, Clym.'' (unknown)

``Yes, it was so; it is useless to excuse me! My conduct to her (me) was too hideous--I made no advances; and she (me) could not bring herself to forgive me. Now she (me) is dead! If I had only shown myself willing to make it up with her (me) sooner, and we had been friends, and then she (me) had died, it wouldn't be so hard to bear. But I never went near her (me) house, so she (me) never came near mine, and didn't know how welcome she (me) would have been--that's what troubles me. She (me) did not know I was going to her (me) house that very night, for she (me) was too insensible to understand me. If she (me) had only come to see me! I longed that she (me) would. But it was not to be.'' (unknown)

There escaped from Eustacia one of those shivering sighs which used to shake her (Eustacia) like a pestilent blast. She (Eustacia) had not yet told.

But Yeobright was too deeply absorbed in the ramblings incidental to his (Humphrey) remorseful state to notice her (Eustacia). During his (Humphrey) illness he (Humphrey) had been continually talking thus. Despair had been added to his (Humphrey) original grief by the unfortunate disclosure of the boy who had received the last words of Mrs. Yeobright--words too bitterly uttered in an hour of misapprehension. Then his (Humphrey) distress had overwhelmed him (Humphrey), and he (Humphrey) longed for death as a field labourer longs for the shade. It was the pitiful sight of a man standing in the very focus of sorrow. He (man) continually bewailed his (man) tardy journey to his (man) mother's house, because it was an error which could never be rectified, and insisted that he (man) must have been horribly perverted by some fiend not to have thought before that it was his (man) duty to go to her (mother), since she (mother) did not come to him (man). He (man) would ask Eustacia to agree with him (man) in his (man) self-condemnation; and when she (Eustacia), seared inwardly by a secret she (Eustacia) dared not tell, declared that she (Eustacia) could not give an opinion, he (man) would say,

``That's because you didn't know my mother's nature. She (mother) was always ready to forgive if asked to do so; but I seemed to her (mother) to be as an obstinate child, and that made her (mother) unyielding. Yet not unyielding--she (mother) was proud and reserved, no more... Yes, I can understand why she (mother) held out against me so long. She (mother) was waiting for me. I dare say she (mother) said a hundred times in her (mother) sorrow, `What a return he (mother) makes for all the sacrifices I have made for him (mother)!' I never went to her (mother)! When I set out to visit her (mother) it was too late. To think of that is nearly intolerable!'' (he)

Sometimes his (man) condition had been one of utter remorse, unsoftened by a single tear of pure sorrow: and then he (man) writhed as he (man) lay, fevered far more by thought than by physical ills.

``If I could only get one assurance that she (mother) did not die in a belief that I was resentful,'' (he)
he (man) said one day when in this mood,
``it would be better to think of than a hope of heaven. But that I cannot do.'' (he)

``You give yourself up too much to this wearying despair,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.
``Other men's mothers have died.'' (unknown)

``That doesn't make the loss of mine less. Yet it is less the loss than the circumstances of the loss. I sinned against her (mother), and on that account there is no light for me.'' (unknown)

``She (mother) sinned against you, I think.'' (unknown)

``No, she (mother) did not. I committed the guilt; and may the whole burden be upon my head!'' (unknown)

``I think you might consider twice before you say that,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
Eustacia replied.
``Single men have, no doubt, a right to curse themselves as much as they please; but men with wives involve two in the doom they pray down.'' (unknown)

``I am in too sorry a state to understand what you are refining on,'' (the man)
said the wretched man.
``Day and night shout at me, `You have helped to kill her (mother).' But in loathing myself I may, I own, be unjust to you, my poor wife. Forgive me for it, Eustacia, for I scarcely know what I do.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

Eustacia was always anxious to avoid the sight of her (Eustacia) husband in such a state as this, which had become as dreadful to her (Eustacia) as the trial scene was to Judas Iscariot. It brought before her (Eustacia) eyes the spectre of a worn-out woman knocking at a door which she (Eustacia) would not open; and she (Eustacia) shrank from contemplating it. Yet it was better for Yeobright himself when he (Judas) spoke openly of his (Judas) sharp regret, for in silence he (Judas) endured infinitely more, and would sometimes remain so long in a tense, brooding mood, consuming himself by the gnawing of his (Judas) thought, that it was imperatively necessary to make him (Judas) talk aloud, that his (Judas) grief might in some degree expend itself in the effort.

Eustacia had not been long indoors after her (Eustacia) look at the moonlight when a soft footstep came up to the house, and Thomasin was announced by the woman downstairs.

``Ah, Thomasin! Thank you for coming tonight,'' (she)
said Clym when she (woman) entered the room.
``Here am I, you see. Such a wretched spectacle am I, that I shrink from being seen by a single friend, and almost from you.'' (unknown)

``You must not shrink from me, dear Clym,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin earnestly, in that sweet voice of hers which came to a sufferer like fresh air into a Black Hole.
``Nothing in you can ever shock me or drive me away. I have been here before, but you don't remember it.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I do; I am not delirious, Thomasin, nor have I been so at all. Don't you believe that if they say so. I am only in great misery at what I have done, and that, with the weakness, makes me seem mad. But it has not upset my reason. Do you think I should remember all about my mother's death if I were out of my mind? No such good luck. Two months and a half, Thomasin, the last of her (mother) life, did my poor mother live alone, distracted and mourning because of me; yet she (mother) was unvisited by me, though I was living only six miles off. Two months and a half--seventy-five days did the sun rise and set upon her (mother) in that deserted state which a dog didn't deserve! Poor people who had nothing in common with her (mother) would have cared for her (mother), and visited her (mother) had they known her (mother) sickness and loneliness; but I, who should have been all to her (mother), stayed away like a cur. If there is any justice in God let Him (God) kill me now. He (God) has nearly blinded me, but that is not enough. If He (God) would only strike me with more pain I would believe in Him (God) forever!'' (unknown)

``Hush, hush! O, pray, Clym, don't, don't say it!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
implored Thomasin, affrighted into sobs and tears; while Eustacia, at the other side of the room, though her (Eustacia) pale face remained calm, writhed in her (Eustacia) chair. Clym went on without heeding his (sufferer) cousin.

``But I am not worth receiving further proof even of Heaven's reprobation. Do you think, Thomasin, that she (mother) knew me--that she (mother) did not die in that horrid mistaken notion about my not forgiving her (mother), which I can't tell you how she (mother) acquired? If you could only assure me of that! Do you think so, Eustacia? Do speak to me.'' (unknown)

``I think I can assure you that she (Eustacia) knew better at last,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin. The pallid Eustacia said nothing.

``Why didn't she (Eustacia) come to my house? I would have taken her (Eustacia) in and showed her (Eustacia) how I loved her (Eustacia) in spite of all. But she (Eustacia) never came; and I didn't go to her (Eustacia), and she (Eustacia) died on the heath like an animal kicked out, nobody to help her (Eustacia) till it was too late. If you could have seen her (Eustacia), Thomasin, as I saw her (Eustacia)--a poor dying woman, lying in the dark upon the bare ground, moaning, nobody near, believing she (Eustacia) was utterly deserted by all the world, it would have moved you to anguish, it would have moved a brute. And this poor woman my mother! No wonder she (mother) said to the child, `You have seen a broken-hearted woman.' What a state she (woman) must have been brought to, to say that! and who can have done it but I? It is too dreadful to think of, and I wish I could be punished more heavily than I am. How long was I what they called out of my senses?'' (unknown)

``A week, I think.'' (unknown)

``And then I became calm.'' (unknown)

``Yes, for four days.'' (unknown)

``And now I have left off being calm.'' (unknown)

``But try to be quiet--please do, and you will soon be strong. If you could remove that impression from your mind--'' (he)

``Yes, yes,'' (he)
he (sufferer) said impatiently.
``But I don't want to get strong. What's the use of my getting well? It would be better for me if I die, and it would certainly be better for Eustacia. Is Eustacia there?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``It would be better for you, Eustacia, if I were to die?'' (unknown)

``Don't press such a question, dear Clym.'' (unknown)

``Well, it really is but a shadowy supposition; for unfortunately I am going to live. I feel myself getting better. Thomasin, how long are you going to stay at the inn, now that all this money has come to your husband?'' (unknown)

``Another month or two, probably; until my illness is over. We cannot get off till then. I think it will be a month or more.'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes. Of course. Ah, Cousin Tamsie, you will get over your trouble--one little month will take you through it, and bring something to console you; but I shall never get over mine, and no consolation will come!'' (unknown)

``Clym, you are unjust to yourself. Depend upon it, Aunt thought kindly of you. I know that, if she (Aunt) had lived, you would have been reconciled with her (Aunt).'' (unknown)

``But she (Aunt) didn't come to see me, though I asked her (Aunt), before I married, if she (Aunt) would come. Had she (Aunt) come, or had I gone there, she (Aunt) would never have died saying, `I am a broken-hearted woman, cast off by my son.' My door has always been open to her (woman)--a welcome here has always awaited her (woman). But that she (woman) never came to see.'' (unknown)

``You had better not talk any more now, Clym,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia faintly from the other part of the room, for the scene was growing intolerable to her (Eustacia).

``Let me talk to you instead for the little time I shall be here,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
Thomasin said soothingly.
``Consider what a one-sided way you have of looking at the matter, Clym. When she (woman) said that to the little boy you had not found her (woman) and taken her (woman) into your arms; and it might have been uttered in a moment of bitterness. It was rather like Aunt to say things in haste. She (Aunt) sometimes used to speak so to me. Though she (Aunt) did not come I am convinced that she (Aunt) thought of coming to see you. Do you suppose a man's mother could live two or three months without one forgiving thought? She (mother) forgave me; and why should she (mother) not have forgiven you?'' (unknown)

``You laboured to win her (mother) round; I did nothing. I, who was going to teach people the higher secrets of happiness, did not know how to keep out of that gross misery which the most untaught are wise enough to avoid.'' (unknown)

``How did you get here tonight, Thomasin?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.

``Damon set me down at the end of the lane. He (Damon) has driven into East Egdon on business, and he (Damon) will come and pick me up by-and-by.'' (unknown)

Accordingly they soon after heard the noise of wheels. Wildeve had come, and was waiting outside with his (Wildeve) horse and gig.

``Send out and tell him (Damon) I will be down in two minutes,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin.

``I will run down myself,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.

She (Eustacia) went down. Wildeve had alighted, and was standing before the horse's head when Eustacia opened the door. He (Wildeve) did not turn for a moment, thinking the comer Thomasin. Then he (Wildeve) looked, startled ever so little, and said one word:

``Well?'' (he)

``I have not yet told him (Damon),'' (she)
she (Eustacia) replied in a whisper.

``Then don't do so till he (Damon) is well--it will be fatal. You are ill yourself.'' (unknown)

``I am wretched... O Damon,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, bursting into tears,
``I--I can't tell you how unhappy I am! I can hardly bear this. I can tell nobody of my trouble--nobody knows of it but you.'' (she)

``Poor girl!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve, visibly affected at her (Eustacia) distress, and at last led on so far as to take her (Eustacia) hand.
``It is hard, when you have done nothing to deserve it, that you should have got involved in such a web as this. You were not made for these sad scenes. I am to blame most. If I could only have saved you from it all!'' (unknown)

``But, Damon, please pray tell me what I must do? To sit by him (Damon) hour after hour, and hear him (Damon) reproach himself as being the cause of her (girl) death, and to know that I am the sinner, if any human being is at all, drives me into cold despair. I don't know what to do. Should I tell him (sinner) or should I not tell him (sinner)? I always am asking myself that. O, I want to tell him (sinner); and yet I am afraid. If he (sinner) finds it out he (sinner) must surely kill me, for nothing else will be in proportion to his (sinner) feelings now. `Beware the fury of a patient man' sounds day by day in my ears as I watch him (sinner).'' (unknown)

``Well, wait till he (sinner) is better, and trust to chance. And when you tell, you must only tell part--for his (sinner) own sake.'' (unknown)

``Which part should I keep back?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve paused.

``That I was in the house at the time,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said in a low tone.

``Yes; it must be concealed, seeing what has been whispered. How much easier are hasty actions than speeches that will excuse them!'' (unknown)

``If he (sinner) were only to die--'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
Wildeve murmured.

``Do not think of it! I would not buy hope of immunity by so cowardly a desire even if I hated him (sinner). Now I am going up to him (sinner) again. Thomasin bade me tell you she (sinner) would be down in a few minutes. Good-bye.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) returned, and Thomasin soon appeared. When she (Eustacia) was seated in the gig with her (Eustacia) husband, and the horse was turning to go off, Wildeve lifted his (Wildeve) eyes to the bedroom windows. Looking from one of them he (Wildeve) could discern a pale, tragic face watching him (Wildeve) drive away. It was Eustacia's.

2--A Lurid Light Breaks in upon a Darkened Understanding

Clym's grief became mitigated by wearing itself out. His (Wildeve) strength returned, and a month after the visit of Thomasin he (Wildeve) might have been seen walking about the garden. Endurance and despair, equanimity and gloom, the tints of health and the pallor of death, mingled weirdly in his (Wildeve) face. He (Wildeve) was now unnaturally silent upon all of the past that related to his (Wildeve) mother; and though Eustacia knew that he (Wildeve) was thinking of it none the less, she (Eustacia) was only too glad to escape the topic ever to bring it up anew. When his (Wildeve) mind had been weaker his (Wildeve) heart had led him (Wildeve) to speak out; but reason having now somewhat recovered itself he (Wildeve) sank into taciturnity.

One evening when he (Wildeve) was thus standing in the garden, abstractedly spudding up a weed with his (Wildeve) stick, a bony figure turned the corner of the house and came up to him (Wildeve).

``Christian, isn't it?'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``I am glad you have found me out. I shall soon want you to go to Blooms-End and assist me in putting the house in order. I suppose it is all locked up as I left it?'' (unknown)

``Yes, Mister Clym.'' (unknown)

``Have you dug up the potatoes and other roots?'' (unknown)

``Yes, without a drop o' rain, thank God. But I was coming to tell `ee of something else which is quite different from what we have lately had in the family. I am sent by the rich gentleman at the Woman, that we used to call the landlord, to tell `ee that Mrs. Wildeve is doing well of a girl, which was born punctually at one o’clock at noon, or a few minutes more or less; and `tis said that expecting of this increase is what have kept `em there since they came into their money.'' (unknown)

``And she (Wildeve) is getting on well, you say?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir. Only Mr. Wildeve is twanky because `tisn't a boy--that's what they say in the kitchen, but I was not supposed to notice that.'' (unknown)

``Christian, now listen to me.'' (unknown)

``Yes, sure, Mr. Yeobright.'' (unknown)

``Did you see my mother the day before she (mother) died?'' (unknown)

``No, I did not.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright's face expressed disappointment.

``But I zeed her (mother) the morning of the same day she (mother) died.'' (unknown)

Clym's look lighted up.

``That's nearer still to my meaning,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.

``Yes, I know `twas the same day; for she (mother) said, `I be going to see him (Yeobright), Christian; so I shall not want any vegetables brought in for dinner.'''

``See whom?'' (unknown)

``See you. She (mother) was going to your house, you understand.'' (unknown)

Yeobright regarded Christian with intense surprise.

``Why did you never mention this?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.
``Are you sure it was my house she (mother) was coming to?'' (unknown)

``O yes. I didn't mention it because I've never zeed you lately. And as she (mother) didn't get there it was all nought, and nothing to tell.'' (unknown)

``And I have been wondering why she (mother) should have walked in the heath on that hot day! Well, did she (mother) say what she (mother) was coming for? It is a thing, Christian, I am very anxious to know.'' (unknown)

``Yes, Mister Clym. She (mother) didn't say it to me, though I think she (mother) did to one here and there.'' (unknown)

``Do you know one person to whom she (mother) spoke of it?'' (unknown)

``There is one man, please, sir, but I hope you won't mention my name to him (man), as I have seen him (man) in strange places, particular in dreams. One night last summer he (man) glared at me like Famine and Sword, and it made me feel so low that I didn't comb out my few hairs for two days. He (man) was standing, as it might be, Mister Yeobright, in the middle of the path to Mistover, and your mother came up, looking as pale--'' (unknown)

``Yes, when was that?'' (unknown)

``Last summer, in my dream.'' (unknown)

``Pooh! Who's the man?'' (unknown)

``Diggory, the reddleman. He (Diggory) called upon her (mother) and sat with her (mother) the evening before she (mother) set out to see you. I hadn't gone home from work when he (Diggory) came up to the gate.'' (unknown)

``I must see Venn--I wish I had known it before,'' (unknown)
said Clym anxiously.
``I wonder why he (Diggory) has not come to tell me?'' (unknown)

``He (Diggory) went out of Egdon Heath the next day, so would not be likely to know you wanted him (Heath).'' (unknown)

``Christian,'' (unknown)
said Clym,
``you must go and find Venn. I am otherwise engaged, or I would go myself. Find him (Christian) at once, and tell him (Christian) I want to speak to him (Christian).'' (unknown)

``I am a good hand at hunting up folk by day,'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian, looking dubiously round at the declining light;
``but as to night-time, never is such a bad hand as I, Mister Yeobright.'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)

``Search the heath when you will, so that you bring him (Yeobright) soon. Bring him (Yeobright) tomorrow, if you can.'' (unknown)

Christian then departed. The morrow came, but no Venn. In the evening Christian arrived, looking very weary. He (Christian) had been searching all day, and had heard nothing of the reddleman.

``Inquire as much as you can tomorrow without neglecting your work,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.
``Don't come again till you have found him (Yeobright).'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

The next day Yeobright set out for the old house at Blooms-End, which, with the garden, was now his (Christian) own. His (Christian) severe illness had hindered all preparations for his (Christian) removal thither; but it had become necessary that he (Christian) should go and overlook its contents, as administrator to his (Christian) mother's little property; for which purpose he (Christian) decided to pass the next night on the premises.

He (Christian) journeyed onward, not quickly or decisively, but in the slow walk of one who has been awakened from a stupefying sleep. It was early afternoon when he (Christian) reached the valley. The expression of the place, the tone of the hour, were precisely those of many such occasions in days gone by; and these antecedent similarities fostered the illusion that she (mother), who was there no longer, would come out to welcome him (Christian). The garden gate was locked and the shutters were closed, just as he (Christian) himself had left them on the evening after the funeral. He (Christian) unlocked the gate, and found that a spider had already constructed a large web, tying the door to the lintel, on the supposition that it was never to be opened again. When he (Christian) had entered the house and flung back the shutters he (Christian) set about his (Christian) task of overhauling the cupboards and closets, burning papers, and considering how best to arrange the place for Eustacia's reception, until such time as he (Christian) might be in a position to carry out his (Christian) long-delayed scheme, should that time ever arrive.

As he (Christian) surveyed the rooms he (Christian) felt strongly disinclined for the alterations which would have to be made in the time-honoured furnishing of his (Christian) parents and grandparents, to suit Eustacia's modern ideas. The gaunt oak-cased clock, with the picture of the Ascension on the door panel and the Miraculous Draught of Fishes on the base; his (Christian) grandmother's corner cupboard with the glass door, through which the spotted china was visible; the dumb-waiter; the wooden tea trays; the hanging fountain with the brass tap--whither would these venerable articles have to be banished?

He (Christian) noticed that the flowers in the window had died for want of water, and he (Christian) placed them out upon the ledge, that they might be taken away. While thus engaged he (Christian) heard footsteps on the gravel without, and somebody knocked at the door.

Yeobright opened it, and Venn was standing before him (Venn).

``Good morning,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman.
``Is Mrs. Yeobright at home?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright looked upon the ground.

``Then you have not seen Christian or any of the Egdon folks?'' (he)
he (Venn) said.

``No. I have only just returned after a long stay away. I called here the day before I left.'' (unknown)

``And you have heard nothing?'' (unknown)

``Nothing.'' (unknown)

``My mother is--dead.'' (unknown)

``Dead!'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn mechanically.

``Her (mother) home now is where I shouldn't mind having mine.'' (him)

Venn regarded him (Venn), and then said,

``If I didn't see your face I could never believe your words. Have you been ill?'' (him)

``I had an illness.'' (unknown)

``Well, the change! When I parted from her (mother) a month ago everything seemed to say that she (mother) was going to begin a new life.'' (unknown)

``And what seemed came true.'' (unknown)

``You say right, no doubt. Trouble has taught you a deeper vein of talk than mine. All I meant was regarding her (mother) life here. She (mother) has died too soon.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps through my living too long. I have had a bitter experience on that score this last month, Diggory. But come in; I have been wanting to see you.'' (He)

He (Venn) conducted the reddleman into the large room where the dancing had taken place the previous Christmas, and they sat down in the settle together.

``There's the cold fireplace, you see,'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``When that half-burnt log and those cinders were alight she (mother) was alive! Little has been changed here yet. I can do nothing. My life creeps like a snail.'' (unknown)

``How came she (mother) to die?'' (unknown)
said Venn.

Yeobright gave him (Venn) some particulars of her (they) illness and death, and continued:

``After this no kind of pain will ever seem more than an indisposition to me. I began saying that I wanted to ask you something, but I stray from subjects like a drunken man. I am anxious to know what my mother said to you when she (mother) last saw you. You talked with her (mother) a long time, I think?'' (him)

``I talked with her (mother) more than half an hour.'' (unknown)

``About me?'' (unknown)

``Yes. And it must have been on account of what we said that she (mother) was on the heath. Without question she (mother) was coming to see you.'' (unknown)

``But why should she (mother) come to see me if she (mother) felt so bitterly against me? There's the mystery.'' (unknown)

``Yet I know she (mother) quite forgave `ee.'' (unknown)

``But, Diggory--would a woman, who had quite forgiven her (woman) son, say, when she (woman) felt herself ill on the way to his (son) house, that she (woman) was broken-hearted because of his (son) ill-usage? Never!'' (unknown)

``What I know is that she (woman) didn't blame you at all. She (woman) blamed herself for what had happened, and only herself. I had it from her (woman) own lips.'' (unknown)

``You had it from her (woman) lips that I had NOT ill-treated her (woman); and at the same time another had it from her (woman) lips that I HAD ill-treated her (woman)? My mother was no impulsive woman who changed her (woman) opinion every hour without reason. How can it be, Venn, that she (woman) should have told such different stories in close succession?'' (unknown)

``I cannot say. It is certainly odd, when she (woman) had forgiven you, and had forgiven your wife, and was going to see ye on purpose to make friends.'' (unknown)

``If there was one thing wanting to bewilder me it was this incomprehensible thing!... Diggory, if we, who remain alive, were only allowed to hold conversation with the dead--just once, a bare minute, even through a screen of iron bars, as with persons in prison--what we might learn! How many who now ride smiling would hide their heads! And this mystery--I should then be at the bottom of it at once. But the grave has forever shut her (friends) in; and how shall it be found out now?'' (companion)

No reply was returned by his (Venn) companion, since none could be given; and when Venn left, a few minutes later, Clym had passed from the dullness of sorrow to the fluctuation of carking incertitude.

He (Venn) continued in the same state all the afternoon. A bed was made up for him (Venn) in the same house by a neighbour, that he (Venn) might not have to return again the next day; and when he (Venn) retired to rest in the deserted place it was only to remain awake hour after hour thinking the same thoughts. How to discover a solution to this riddle of death seemed a query of more importance than highest problems of the living. There was housed in his (Venn) memory a vivid picture of the face of a little boy as he (Venn) entered the hovel where Clym's mother lay. The round eyes, eager gaze, the piping voice which enunciated the words, had operated like stilettos on his (Venn) brain.

A visit to the boy suggested itself as a means of gleaning new particulars; though it might be quite unproductive. To probe a child's mind after the lapse of six weeks, not for facts which the child had seen and understood, but to get at those which were in their nature beyond him (Venn), did not promise much; yet when every obvious channel is blocked we grope towards the small and obscure. There was nothing else left to do; after that he (Venn) would allow the enigma to drop into the abyss of undiscoverable things.

It was about daybreak when he (Venn) had reached this decision, and he (Venn) at once arose. He (Venn) locked up the house and went out into the green patch which merged in heather further on. In front of the white garden-palings the path branched into three like a broad arrow. The road to the right led to the Quiet Woman and its neighbourhood; the middle track led to Mistover Knap; the left-hand track led over the hill to another part of Mistover, where the child lived. On inclining into the latter path Yeobright felt a creeping chilliness, familiar enough to most people, and probably caused by the unsunned morning air. In after days he (Woman) thought of it as a thing of singular significance.

When Yeobright reached the cottage of Susan Nunsuch, the mother of the boy he (boy) sought, he (boy) found that the inmates were not yet astir. But in upland hamlets the transition from a-bed to abroad is surprisingly swift and easy. There no dense partition of yawns and toilets divides humanity by night from humanity by day. Yeobright tapped at the upper windowsill, which he (boy) could reach with his (boy) walking stick; and in three or four minutes the woman came down.

It was not till this moment that Clym recollected her (woman) to be the person who had behaved so barbarously to Eustacia. It partly explained the insuavity with which the woman greeted him (boy). Moreover, the boy had been ailing again; and Susan now, as ever since the night when he (boy) had been pressed into Eustacia's service at the bonfire, attributed his (boy) indispositions to Eustacia's influence as a witch. It was one of those sentiments which lurk like moles underneath the visible surface of manners, and may have been kept alive by Eustacia's entreaty to the captain, at the time that he (captain) had intended to prosecute Susan for the pricking in church, to let the matter drop; which he (captain) accordingly had done.

Yeobright overcame his (captain) repugnance, for Susan had at least borne his (captain) mother no ill-will. He (captain) asked kindly for the boy; but her (mother) manner did not improve.

``I wish to see him (Diggory),'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
continued Yeobright, with some hesitation,
``to ask him (Diggory) if he (Diggory) remembers anything more of his (Diggory) walk with my mother than what he (Diggory) has previously told.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

She (mother) regarded him (captain) in a peculiar and criticizing manner. To anybody but a half-blind man it would have said,

``You want another of the knocks which have already laid you so low.'' (a man)

She (mother) called the boy downstairs, asked Clym to sit down on a stool, and continued,

``Now, Johnny, tell Mr. Yeobright anything you can call to mind.'' (boy)

``You have not forgotten how you walked with the poor lady on that hot day?'' (unknown)
said Clym.

``No,'' (the boy)
said the boy.

``And what she (lady) said to you?'' (The boy)

The boy repeated the exact words he (boy) had used on entering the hut. Yeobright rested his (boy) elbow on the table and shaded his (boy) face with his (boy) hand; and the mother looked as if she (mother) wondered how a man could want more of what had stung him (man) so deeply.

``She (lady) was going to Alderworth when you first met her (lady)?'' (unknown)

``No; she (lady) was coming away.'' (unknown)

``That can't be.'' (unknown)

``Yes; she (lady) walked along with me. I was coming away, too.'' (unknown)

``Then where did you first see her (lady)?'' (unknown)

``At your house.'' (unknown)

``Attend, and speak the truth!'' (unknown)
said Clym sternly.

``Yes, sir; at your house was where I seed her (lady) first.'' (Susan/Susan Nunsuch)

Clym started up, and Susan smiled in an expectant way which did not embellish her (Susan) face; it seemed to mean,

``Something sinister is coming!'' (Susan/Susan Nunsuch)

``What did she (lady) do at my house?'' (unknown)

``She (lady) went and sat under the trees at the Devil's Bellows.'' (unknown)

``Good God! this is all news to me!'' (unknown)

``You never told me this before?'' (Susan/Susan Nunsuch)
said Susan.

``No, Mother; because I didn't like to tell `ee I had been so far. I was picking blackhearts, and went further than I meant.'' (unknown)

``What did she (Mother) do then?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.

``Looked at a man who came up and went into your house.'' (unknown)

``That was myself--a furze-cutter, with brambles in his (man) hand.'' (unknown)

``No; `twas not you. `Twas a gentleman. You had gone in afore.'' (unknown)

``Who was he (man)?'' (unknown)

``I don't know.'' (unknown)

``Now tell me what happened next.'' (unknown)

``The poor lady went and knocked at your door, and the lady with black hair looked out of the side window at her (lady).'' (The boy)

The boy's mother turned to Clym and said,

``This is something you didn't expect?'' (boy mother)

Yeobright took no more notice of her (Susan) than if he (boy) had been of stone.

``Go on, go on,'' (he)
he (boy) said hoarsely to the boy.

``And when she (lady) saw the young lady look out of the window the old lady knocked again; and when nobody came she (lady) took up the furze-hook and looked at it, and put it down again, and then she (lady) looked at the faggot-bonds; and then she (lady) went away, and walked across to me, and blowed her (lady) breath very hard, like this. We walked on together, she (lady) and I, and I talked to her (lady) and she (lady) talked to me a bit, but not much, because she (lady) couldn't blow her (lady) breath.'' (unknown)

``O!'' (unknown)
murmured Clym, in a low tone, and bowed his (boy) head.
``Let's have more,'' (he)
he (boy) said.

``She (lady) couldn't talk much, and she (lady) couldn't walk; and her (lady) face was, O so queer!'' (unknown)

``How was her (lady) face?'' (unknown)

``Like yours is now.'' (The woman)

The woman looked at Yeobright, and beheld him (boy) colourless, in a cold sweat.

``Isn't there meaning in it?'' (she)
she (woman) said stealthily.
``What do you think of her (lady) now?'' (unknown)

``Silence!'' (unknown)
said Clym fiercely. And, turning to the boy,
``And then you left her (lady) to die?'' (the boy)

``No,'' (the woman)
said the woman, quickly and angrily.
``He (lady) did not leave her (lady) to die! She (lady) sent him (lady) away. Whoever says he (lady) forsook her (lady) says what's not true.'' (unknown)

``Trouble no more about that,'' (unknown)
answered Clym, with a quivering mouth.
``What he (lady) did is a trifle in comparison with what he (lady) saw. Door kept shut, did you say? Kept shut, she (lady) looking out of window? Good heart of God!--what does it mean?'' (The child)

The child shrank away from the gaze of his (boy) questioner.

``He (God) said so,'' (the mother)
answered the mother,
``and Johnny's a God-fearing boy and tells no lies.'' (the mother)

```Cast off by my son!' No, by my best life, dear mother, it is not so! But by your son's, your son's--May all murderesses get the torment they deserve!''

With these words Yeobright went forth from the little dwelling. The pupils of his (son) eyes, fixed steadfastly on blankness, were vaguely lit with an icy shine; his (son) mouth had passed into the phase more or less imaginatively rendered in studies of Oedipus. The strangest deeds were possible to his (Oedipus) mood. But they were not possible to his (Oedipus) situation. Instead of there being before him (Oedipus) the pale face of Eustacia, and a masculine shape unknown, there was only the imperturbable countenance of the heath, which, having defied the cataclysmal onsets of centuries, reduced to insignificance by its seamed and antique features the wildest turmoil of a single man.

3--Eustacia Dresses Herself on a Black Morning

A consciousness of a vast impassivity in all which lay around him (man) took possession even of Yeobright in his (man) wild walk towards Alderworth. He (man) had once before felt in his (man) own person this overpowering of the fervid by the inanimate; but then it had tended to enervate a passion far sweeter than that which at present pervaded him (man). It was once when he (man) stood parting from Eustacia in the moist still levels beyond the hills.

But dismissing all this he (man) went onward home, and came to the front of his (man) house. The blinds of Eustacia's bedroom were still closely drawn, for she (Eustacia) was no early riser. All the life visible was in the shape of a solitary thrush cracking a small snail upon the door-stone for his (man) breakfast, and his (man) tapping seemed a loud noise in the general silence which prevailed; but on going to the door Clym found it unfastened, the young girl who attended upon Eustacia being astir in the back part of the premises. Yeobright entered and went straight to his (man) wife's room.

The noise of his (man) arrival must have aroused her (Eustacia), for when he (man) opened the door she (Eustacia) was standing before the looking glass in her (Eustacia) nightdress, the ends of her (Eustacia) hair gathered into one hand, with which she (Eustacia) was coiling the whole mass round her (Eustacia) head, previous to beginning toilette operations. She (Eustacia) was not a woman given to speaking first at a meeting, and she (Eustacia) allowed Clym to walk across in silence, without turning her (Eustacia) head. He (man) came behind her (Eustacia), and she (Eustacia) saw his (man) face in the glass. It was ashy, haggard, and terrible. Instead of starting towards him (man) in sorrowful surprise, as even Eustacia, undemonstrative wife as she (Eustacia) was, would have done in days before she (Eustacia) burdened herself with a secret, she (Eustacia) remained motionless, looking at him (man) in the glass. And while she (Eustacia) looked the carmine flush with which warmth and sound sleep had suffused her (Eustacia) cheeks and neck dissolved from view, and the deathlike pallor in his (man) face flew across into hers. He (man) was close enough to see this, and the sight instigated his (man) tongue.

``You know what is the matter,'' (he)
he (man) said huskily.
``I see it in your face.'' (unknown)

Her (Eustacia) hand relinquished the rope of hair and dropped to her (Eustacia) side, and the pile of tresses, no longer supported, fell from the crown of her (Eustacia) head about her (Eustacia) shoulders and over the white nightgown. She (Eustacia) made no reply.

``Speak to me,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright peremptorily.

The blanching process did not cease in her (Eustacia), and her (Eustacia) lips now became as white as her (Eustacia) face. She (Eustacia) turned to him (man) and said,

``Yes, Clym, I'll speak to you. Why do you return so early? Can I do anything for you?'' (him)

``Yes, you can listen to me. It seems that my wife is not very well?'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (unknown)

``Your face, my dear; your face. Or perhaps it is the pale morning light which takes your colour away? Now I am going to reveal a secret to you. Ha-ha!'' (unknown)

``O, that is ghastly!'' (unknown)

``What?'' (unknown)

``Your laugh.'' (unknown)

``There's reason for ghastliness. Eustacia, you have held my happiness in the hollow of your hand, and like a devil you have dashed it down!'' (She)

She (Eustacia) started back from the dressing-table, retreated a few steps from him (man), and looked him (man) in the face.

``Ah! you think to frighten me,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said, with a slight laugh.
``Is it worth while? I am undefended, and alone.'' (unknown)

``How extraordinary!'' (unknown)

``What do you mean?'' (unknown)

``As there is ample time I will tell you, though you know well enough. I mean that it is extraordinary that you should be alone in my absence. Tell me, now, where is he (devil) who was with you on the afternoon of the thirty-first of August? Under the bed? Up the chimney?'' (her)

A shudder overcame her (Eustacia) and shook the light fabric of her (Eustacia) nightdress throughout.

``I do not remember dates so exactly,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.
``I cannot recollect that anybody was with me besides yourself.'' (unknown)

``The day I mean,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright, his (man) voice growing louder and harsher,
``was the day you shut the door against my mother and killed her (mother). O, it is too much--too bad!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
He (man) leant over the footpiece of the bedstead for a few moments, with his (man) back towards her (Eustacia); then rising again--
``Tell me, tell me! tell me--do you hear?'' (He)
he (man) cried, rushing up to her (Eustacia) and seizing her (Eustacia) by the loose folds of her (Eustacia) sleeve.

The superstratum of timidity which often overlies those who are daring and defiant at heart had been passed through, and the mettlesome substance of the woman was reached. The red blood inundated her (woman) face, previously so pale.

``What are you going to do?'' (she)
she (woman) said in a low voice, regarding him (man) with a proud smile.
``You will not alarm me by holding on so; but it would be a pity to tear my sleeve.'' (he)

Instead of letting go he (man) drew her (woman) closer to him (man).

``Tell me the particulars of--my mother's death,'' (he)
he (man) said in a hard, panting whisper;
``or--I'll--I'll--'' (he)

``Clym,'' (he)
she (woman) answered slowly,
``do you think you dare do anything to me that I dare not bear? But before you strike me listen. You will get nothing from me by a blow, even though it should kill me, as it probably will. But perhaps you do not wish me to speak--killing may be all you mean?'' (she)

``Kill you! Do you expect it?'' (unknown)

``I do.'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (unknown)

``No less degree of rage against me will match your previous grief for her (you).'' (unknown)

``Phew--I shall not kill you,'' (he)
he (man) said contemptuously, as if under a sudden change of purpose.
``I did think of it; but--I shall not. That would be making a martyr of you, and sending you to where she (you) is; and I would keep you away from her (you) till the universe come to an end, if I could.'' (unknown)

``I almost wish you would kill me,'' (she)
said she (woman) with gloomy bitterness.
``It is with no strong desire, I assure you, that I play the part I have lately played on earth. You are no blessing, my husband.'' (unknown)

``You shut the door--you looked out of the window upon her (you)--you had a man in the house with you--you sent her (you) away to die. The inhumanity--the treachery--I will not touch you--stand away from me--and confess every word!'' (unknown)

``Never! I'll hold my tongue like the very death that I don't mind meeting, even though I can clear myself of half you believe by speaking. Yes. I will! Who of any dignity would take the trouble to clear cobwebs from a wild man's mind after such language as this? No; let him (man) go on, and think his (man) narrow thoughts, and run his (man) head into the mire. I have other cares.'' (I)

```Tis too much--but I must spare you.''

``Poor charity.'' (unknown)

``By my wretched soul you sting me, Eustacia! I can keep it up, and hotly too. Now, then, madam, tell me his (man) name!'' (unknown)

``Never, I am resolved.'' (unknown)

``How often does he (man) write to you? Where does he (man) put his (man) letters--when does he (man) meet you? Ah, his (man) letters! Do you tell me his (man) name?'' (unknown)

``I do not.'' (unknown)

``Then I'll find it myself.'' (she)
His (man) eyes had fallen upon a small desk that stood near, on which she (woman) was accustomed to write her (woman) letters. He (man) went to it. It was locked.

``Unlock this!'' (unknown)

``You have no right to say it. That's mine.'' (he)

Without another word he (man) seized the desk and dashed it to the floor. The hinge burst open, and a number of letters tumbled out.

``Stay!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia, stepping before him (man) with more excitement than she (Eustacia) had hitherto shown.

``Come, come! stand away! I must see them.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) looked at the letters as they lay, checked her (Eustacia) feeling and moved indifferently aside; when he (man) gathered them up, and examined them.

By no stretch of meaning could any but a harmless construction be placed upon a single one of the letters themselves. The solitary exception was an empty envelope directed to her (Eustacia), and the handwriting was Wildeve's. Yeobright held it up. Eustacia was doggedly silent.

``Can you read, madam? Look at this envelope. Doubtless we shall find more soon, and what was inside them. I shall no doubt be gratified by learning in good time what a well-finished and full-blown adept in a certain trade my lady is.'' (unknown)

``Do you say it to me--do you?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) gasped.

He (man) searched further, but found nothing more.

``What was in this letter?'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Ask the writer. Am I your hound that you should talk to me in this way?'' (unknown)

``Do you brave me? do you stand me out, mistress? Answer. Don't look at me with those eyes if you would bewitch me again! Sooner than that I die. You refuse to answer?'' (unknown)

``I wouldn't tell you after this, if I were as innocent as the sweetest babe in heaven!'' (unknown)

``Which you are not.'' (unknown)

``Certainly I am not absolutely,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) replied.
``I have not done what you suppose; but if to have done no harm at all is the only innocence recognized, I am beyond forgiveness. But I require no help from your conscience.'' (unknown)

``You can resist, and resist again! Instead of hating you I could, I think, mourn for and pity you, if you were contrite, and would confess all. Forgive you I never can. I don't speak of your lover--I will give you the benefit of the doubt in that matter, for it only affects me personally. But the other--had you half-killed me, had it been that you wilfully took the sight away from these feeble eyes of mine, I could have forgiven you. But THAT'S too much for nature!'' (unknown)

``Say no more. I will do without your pity. But I would have saved you from uttering what you will regret.'' (unknown)

``I am going away now. I shall leave you.'' (unknown)

``You need not go, as I am going myself. You will keep just as far away from me by staying here.'' (unknown)

``Call her (me) to mind--think of her (me)--what goodness there was in her (me)--it showed in every line of her (me) face!
