Most women, even when but slightly annoyed, show a flicker of evil in some curl of the mouth or some corner of the cheek; but as for her (me), never in her (me) angriest moments was there anything malicious in her (me) look. She (me) was angered quickly, but she (me) forgave just as readily, and underneath her (me) pride there was the meekness of a child. What came of it?--what cared you? You hated her (me) just as she (me) was learning to love you. O! couldn't you see what was best for you, but must bring a curse upon me, and agony and death upon her (me), by doing that cruel deed! What was the fellow's name who was keeping you company and causing you to add cruelty to her (me) to your wrong to me? Was it Wildeve? Was it poor Thomasin's husband? Heaven, what wickedness! Lost your voice, have you? It is natural after detection of that most noble trick... Eustacia, didn't any tender thought of your own mother lead you to think of being gentle to mine at such a time of weariness? Did not one grain of pity enter your heart as she (mother) turned away? Think what a vast opportunity was then lost of beginning a forgiving and honest course. Why did not you kick him (husband) out, and let her (mother) in, and say I'll be an honest wife and a noble woman from this hour? Had I told you to go and quench eternally our last flickering chance of happiness here you could have done no worse. Well, she (woman)'s asleep now; and have you a hundred gallants, neither they nor you can insult her (woman) any more.'' (unknown)

``You exaggerate fearfully,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said in a faint, weary voice;
``but I cannot enter into my defence--it is not worth doing. You are nothing to me in future, and the past side of the story may as well remain untold. I have lost all through you, but I have not complained. Your blunders and misfortunes may have been a sorrow to you, but they have been a wrong to me. All persons of refinement have been scared away from me since I sank into the mire of marriage. Is this your cherishing--to put me into a hut like this, and keep me like the wife of a hind? You deceived me--not by words, but by appearances, which are less seen through than words. But the place will serve as well as any other--as somewhere to pass from--into my grave.'' (she)
Her (Eustacia) words were smothered in her (Eustacia) throat, and her (Eustacia) head drooped down.

``I don't know what you mean by that. Am I the cause of your sin?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
-LRB-Eustacia made a trembling motion towards him (man).-RRB-
``What, you can begin to shed tears and offer me your hand? Good God! can you? No, not I. I'll not commit the fault of taking that.'' (she)
-LRB-The hand she (Eustacia) had offered dropped nervelessly, but the tears continued flowing.-RRB-
``Well, yes, I'll take it, if only for the sake of my own foolish kisses that were wasted there before I knew what I cherished. How bewitched I was! How could there be any good in a woman that everybody spoke ill of?'' (unknown)

``O, O, O!'' (she)
she (Eustacia) cried, breaking down at last; and, shaking with sobs which choked her (Eustacia), she (Eustacia) sank upon her (Eustacia) knees.
``O, will you have done! O, you are too relentless--there's a limit to the cruelty of savages! I have held out long--but you crush me down. I beg for mercy--I cannot bear this any longer--it is inhuman to go further with this! If I had--killed your--mother with my own hand--I should not deserve such a scourging to the bone as this. O, O! God have mercy upon a miserable woman!... You have beaten me in this game--I beg you to stay your hand in pity!... I confess that I--wilfully did not undo the door the first time she (woman) knocked--but--I should have unfastened it the second--if I had not thought you had gone to do it yourself. When I found you had not I opened it, but she (woman) was gone. That's the extent of my crime--towards HER. Best natures commit bad faults sometimes, don't they?--I think they do. Now I will leave you--for ever and ever!'' (unknown)

``Tell all, and I WILL pity you. Was the man in the house with you Wildeve?'' (unknown)

``I cannot tell,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said desperately through her (Eustacia) sobbing.
``Don't insist further--I cannot tell. I am going from this house. We cannot both stay here.'' (unknown)

``You need not go--I will go. You can stay here.'' (unknown)

``No, I will dress, and then I will go.'' (unknown)

``Where?'' (unknown)

``Where I came from, or ELSEWHERE.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) hastily dressed herself, Yeobright moodily walking up and down the room the whole of the time. At last all her (Eustacia) things were on. Her (Eustacia) little hands quivered so violently as she (Eustacia) held them to her (Eustacia) chin to fasten her (Eustacia) bonnet that she (Eustacia) could not tie the strings, and after a few moments she (Eustacia) relinquished the attempt. Seeing this he (Eustacia) moved forward and said,

``Let me tie them.'' (he)

She (Eustacia) assented in silence, and lifted her (Eustacia) chin. For once at least in her (Eustacia) life she (Eustacia) was totally oblivious of the charm of her (Eustacia) attitude. But he (Eustacia) was not, and he (Eustacia) turned his (Eustacia) eyes aside, that he (Eustacia) might not be tempted to softness.

The strings were tied; she (Eustacia) turned from him (Eustacia).

``Do you still prefer going away yourself to my leaving you?'' (he)
he (Eustacia) inquired again.

``I do.'' (unknown)

``Very well--let it be. And when you will confess to the man I may pity you.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) flung her (Eustacia) shawl about her (Eustacia) and went downstairs, leaving him (Eustacia) standing in the room.

Eustacia had not long been gone when there came a knock at the door of the bedroom; and Yeobright said,

``Well?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

It was the servant; and she (Eustacia) replied,

``Somebody from Mrs. Wildeve's have called to tell `ee that the mis'ess and the baby are getting on wonderful well, and the baby's name is to be Eustacia Clementine.'' (she)
And the girl retired.

``What a mockery!'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``This unhappy marriage of mine to be perpetuated in that child's name!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

4--The Ministrations of a Half-forgotten One

Eustacia's journey was at first as vague in direction as that of thistledown on the wind. She (Eustacia) did not know what to do. She (Eustacia) wished it had been night instead of morning, that she (Eustacia) might at least have borne her (Eustacia) misery without the possibility of being seen. Tracing mile after mile along between the dying ferns and the wet white spiders' webs, she (Eustacia) at length turned her (Eustacia) steps towards her (Eustacia) grandfather's house. She (Eustacia) found the front door closed and locked. Mechanically she (Eustacia) went round to the end where the stable was, and on looking in at the stable door she (Eustacia) saw Charley standing within.

``Captain Vye is not at home?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.

``No, ma’am,'' (the lad)
said the lad in a flutter of feeling;
``he (Captain)'s gone to Weatherbury, and won't be home till night. And the servant is gone home for a holiday. So the house is locked up.'' (the lad)

Eustacia's face was not visible to Charley as she (Eustacia) stood at the doorway, her (Eustacia) back being to the sky, and the stable but indifferently lighted; but the wildness of her (Eustacia) manner arrested his (Charley) attention. She (Eustacia) turned and walked away across the enclosure to the gate, and was hidden by the bank.

When she (Eustacia) had disappeared Charley, with misgiving in his (Charley) eyes, slowly came from the stable door, and going to another point in the bank he (Charley) looked over. Eustacia was leaning against it on the outside, her (Eustacia) face covered with her (Eustacia) hands, and her (Eustacia) head pressing the dewy heather which bearded the bank's outer side. She (Eustacia) appeared to be utterly indifferent to the circumstance that her (Eustacia) bonnet, hair, and garments were becoming wet and disarranged by the moisture of her (Eustacia) cold, harsh pillow. Clearly something was wrong.

Charley had always regarded Eustacia as Eustacia had regarded Clym when she (Eustacia) first beheld him (Charley)--as a romantic and sweet vision, scarcely incarnate. He (Charley) had been so shut off from her (Eustacia) by the dignity of her (Eustacia) look and the pride of her (Eustacia) speech, except at that one blissful interval when he (Charley) was allowed to hold her (Eustacia) hand, that he (Charley) had hardly deemed her (Eustacia) a woman, wingless and earthly, subject to household conditions and domestic jars. The inner details of her (Eustacia) life he (Charley) had only conjectured. She (Eustacia) had been a lovely wonder, predestined to an orbit in which the whole of his (Charley) own was but a point; and this sight of her (Eustacia) leaning like a helpless, despairing creature against a wild wet bank filled him (Charley) with an amazed horror. He (Charley) could no longer remain where he (Charley) was. Leaping over, he (Charley) came up, touched her (Eustacia) with his (Charley) finger, and said tenderly,

``You are poorly, ma’am. What can I do?'' (her)

Eustacia started up, and said,

``Ah, Charley--you have followed me. You did not think when I left home in the summer that I should come back like this!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

``I did not, dear ma’am. Can I help you now?'' (unknown)

``I am afraid not. I wish I could get into the house. I feel giddy--that's all.'' (unknown)

``Lean on my arm, ma’am, till we get to the porch, and I will try to open the door.'' (He)

He (Charley) supported her (Eustacia) to the porch, and there depositing her (Eustacia) on a seat hastened to the back, climbed to a window by the help of a ladder, and descending inside opened the door. Next he (Charley) assisted her (Eustacia) into the room, where there was an old-fashioned horsehair settee as large as a donkey wagon. She (Eustacia) lay down here, and Charley covered her (Eustacia) with a cloak he (Charley) found in the hall.

``Shall I get you something to eat and drink?'' (he)
he (Charley) said.

``If you please, Charley. But I suppose there is no fire?'' (unknown)

``I can light it, ma’am.'' (He)

He (Charley) vanished, and she (Eustacia) heard a splitting of wood and a blowing of bellows; and presently he (Charley) returned, saying,

``I have lighted a fire in the kitchen, and now I'll light one here.'' (he)

He (Charley) lit the fire, Eustacia dreamily observing him (Charley) from her (Eustacia) couch. When it was blazing up he (Charley) said,

``Shall I wheel you round in front of it, ma’am, as the morning is chilly?'' (he)

``Yes, if you like.'' (unknown)

``Shall I go and bring the victuals now?'' (unknown)

``Yes, do,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) murmured languidly.

When he (Charley) had gone, and the dull sounds occasionally reached her (Eustacia) ears of his (Charley) movements in the kitchen, she (Eustacia) forgot where she (Eustacia) was, and had for a moment to consider by an effort what the sounds meant. After an interval which seemed short to her (Eustacia) whose thoughts were elsewhere, he (Charley) came in with a tray on which steamed tea and toast, though it was nearly lunch-time.

``Place it on the table,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.
``I shall be ready soon.'' (He)

He (Charley) did so, and retired to the door; when, however, he (Charley) perceived that she (Eustacia) did not move he (Charley) came back a few steps.

``Let me hold it to you, if you don't wish to get up,'' (Charley)
said Charley. He (Charley) brought the tray to the front of the couch, where he (Charley) knelt down, adding,
``I will hold it for you.'' (he)

Eustacia sat up and poured out a cup of tea.

``You are very kind to me, Charley,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) murmured as she (Eustacia) sipped.

``Well, I ought to be,'' (he)
said he (Charley) diffidently, taking great trouble not to rest his (Charley) eyes upon her (Eustacia), though this was their only natural position, Eustacia being immediately before him (Charley).
``You have been kind to me.'' (unknown)

``How have I?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.

``You let me hold your hand when you were a maiden at home.'' (unknown)

``Ah, so I did. Why did I do that? My mind is lost--it had to do with the mumming, had it not?'' (unknown)

``Yes, you wanted to go in my place.'' (unknown)

``I remember. I do indeed remember--too well!'' (She)

She (Eustacia) again became utterly downcast; and Charley, seeing that she (Eustacia) was not going to eat or drink any more, took away the tray.

Afterwards he (Charley) occasionally came in to see if the fire was burning, to ask her (Eustacia) if she (Eustacia) wanted anything, to tell her (Eustacia) that the wind had shifted from south to west, to ask her (Eustacia) if she (Eustacia) would like him (Charley) to gather her (Eustacia) some blackberries; to all which inquiries she (Eustacia) replied in the negative or with indifference.

She (Eustacia) remained on the settee some time longer, when she (Eustacia) aroused herself and went upstairs. The room in which she (Eustacia) had formerly slept still remained much as she (Eustacia) had left it, and the recollection that this forced upon her (Eustacia) of her (Eustacia) own greatly changed and infinitely worsened situation again set on her (Eustacia) face the undetermined and formless misery which it had worn on her (Eustacia) first arrival. She (Eustacia) peeped into her (Eustacia) grandfather's room, through which the fresh autumn air was blowing from the open window. Her (Eustacia) eye was arrested by what was a familiar sight enough, though it broke upon her (Eustacia) now with a new significance.

It was a brace of pistols, hanging near the head of her (Eustacia) grandfather's bed, which he (grandfather) always kept there loaded, as a precaution against possible burglars, the house being very lonely. Eustacia regarded them long, as if they were the page of a book in which she (Eustacia) read a new and a strange matter. Quickly, like one afraid of herself, she (Eustacia) returned downstairs and stood in deep thought.

``If I could only do it!'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.
``It would be doing much good to myself and all connected with me, and no harm to a single one.'' (her)

The idea seemed to gather force within her (Eustacia), and she (Eustacia) remained in a fixed attitude nearly ten minutes, when a certain finality was expressed in her (Eustacia) gaze, and no longer the blankness of indecision.

She (Eustacia) turned and went up the second time--softly and stealthily now--and entered her (Eustacia) grandfather's room, her (Eustacia) eyes at once seeking the head of the bed. The pistols were gone.

The instant quashing of her (Eustacia) purpose by their absence affected her (Eustacia) brain as a sudden vacuum affects the body--she (Eustacia) nearly fainted. Who had done this? There was only one person on the premises besides herself. Eustacia involuntarily turned to the open window which overlooked the garden as far as the bank that bounded it. On the summit of the latter stood Charley, sufficiently elevated by its height to see into the room. His (Charley) gaze was directed eagerly and solicitously upon her (Eustacia).

She (Eustacia) went downstairs to the door and beckoned to him (Charley).

``You have taken them away?'' (unknown)

``Yes, ma’am.'' (unknown)

``Why did you do it?'' (unknown)

``I saw you looking at them too long.'' (unknown)

``What has that to do with it?'' (unknown)

``You have been heart-broken all the morning, as if you did not want to live.'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (unknown)

``And I could not bear to leave them in your way. There was meaning in your look at them.'' (unknown)

``Where are they now?'' (unknown)

``Locked up.'' (unknown)

``Where?'' (unknown)

``In the stable.'' (unknown)

``Give them to me.'' (unknown)

``No, ma’am.'' (unknown)

``You refuse?'' (unknown)

``I do. I care too much for you to give `em up.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) turned aside, her (Eustacia) face for the first time softening from the stony immobility of the earlier day, and the corners of her (Eustacia) mouth resuming something of that delicacy of cut which was always lost in her (Eustacia) moments of despair. At last she (Eustacia) confronted him (Charley) again.

``Why should I not die if I wish?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said tremulously.
``I have made a bad bargain with life, and I am weary of it--weary. And now you have hindered my escape. O, why did you, Charley! What makes death painful except the thought of others' grief?--and that is absent in my case, for not a sigh would follow me!'' (unknown)

``Ah, it is trouble that has done this! I wish in my very soul that he (Charley) who brought it about might die and rot, even if `tis transportation to say it!'' (unknown)

``Charley, no more of that. What do you mean to do about this you have seen?'' (unknown)

``Keep it close as night, if you promise not to think of it again.'' (unknown)

``You need not fear. The moment has passed. I promise.'' (She)
She (Eustacia) then went away, entered the house, and lay down.

Later in the afternoon her (Eustacia) grandfather returned. He (grandfather) was about to question her (Eustacia) categorically, but on looking at her (Eustacia) he (grandfather) withheld his (grandfather) words.

``Yes, it is too bad to talk of,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) slowly returned in answer to his (grandfather) glance.
``Can my old room be got ready for me tonight, Grandfather? I shall want to occupy it again.'' (He)

He (grandfather) did not ask what it all meant, or why she (Eustacia) had left her (Eustacia) husband, but ordered the room to be prepared.

5--An Old Move Inadvertently Repeated

Charley's attentions to his (Charley) former mistress were unbounded. The only solace to his (Charley) own trouble lay in his (Charley) attempts to relieve hers. Hour after hour he (Charley) considered her (mistress) wants; he (Charley) thought of her (mistress) presence there with a sort of gratitude, and, while uttering imprecations on the cause of her (mistress) unhappiness, in some measure blessed the result. Perhaps she (mistress) would always remain there, he (Charley) thought, and then he (Charley) would be as happy as he (Charley) had been before. His (Charley) dread was lest she (mistress) should think fit to return to Alderworth, and in that dread his (Charley) eyes, with all the inquisitiveness of affection, frequently sought her (mistress) face when she (mistress) was not observing him (Charley), as he (Charley) would have watched the head of a stockdove to learn if it contemplated flight. Having once really succoured her (mistress), and possibly preserved her (mistress) from the rashest of acts, he (Charley) mentally assumed in addition a guardian's responsibility for her (mistress) welfare.

For this reason he (Charley) busily endeavoured to provide her (mistress) with pleasant distractions, bringing home curious objects which he (Charley) found in the heath, such as white trumpet-shaped mosses, redheaded lichens, stone arrowheads used by the old tribes on Egdon, and faceted crystals from the hollows of flints. These he (Egdon) deposited on the premises in such positions that she (mistress) should see them as if by accident.

A week passed, Eustacia never going out of the house. Then she (Eustacia) walked into the enclosed plot and looked through her (Eustacia) grandfather's spyglass, as she (Eustacia) had been in the habit of doing before her (Eustacia) marriage. One day she (Eustacia) saw, at a place where the highroad crossed the distant valley, a heavily laden wagon passing along. It was piled with household furniture. She (Eustacia) looked again and again, and recognized it to be her (Eustacia) own. In the evening her (Eustacia) grandfather came indoors with a rumour that Yeobright had removed that day from Alderworth to the old house at Blooms-End.

On another occasion when reconnoitring thus she (Eustacia) beheld two female figures walking in the vale. The day was fine and clear; and the persons not being more than half a mile off she (Eustacia) could see their every detail with the telescope. The woman walking in front carried a white bundle in her (woman) arms, from one end of which hung a long appendage of drapery; and when the walkers turned, so that the sun fell more directly upon them, Eustacia could see that the object was a baby. She (Eustacia) called Charley, and asked him (Charley) if he (Charley) knew who they were, though she (Eustacia) well guessed.

``Mrs. Wildeve and the nurse-girl,'' (Charley)
said Charley.

``The nurse is carrying the baby?'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia.

``No, `tis Mrs. Wildeve carrying that,'' (he)
he (Charley) answered,
``and the nurse walks behind carrying nothing.'' (he)

The lad was in good spirits that day, for the Fifth of November had again come round, and he (Charley) was planning yet another scheme to divert her (Eustacia) from her (Eustacia) too absorbing thoughts. For two successive years his (Charley) mistress had seemed to take pleasure in lighting a bonfire on the bank overlooking the valley; but this year she (mistress) had apparently quite forgotten the day and the customary deed. He (Charley) was careful not to remind her (mistress), and went on with his (Charley) secret preparations for a cheerful surprise, the more zealously that he (Charley) had been absent last time and unable to assist. At every vacant minute he (Charley) hastened to gather furze-stumps, thorn-tree roots, and other solid materials from the adjacent slopes, hiding them from cursory view.

The evening came, and Eustacia was still seemingly unconscious of the anniversary. She (Eustacia) had gone indoors after her (Eustacia) survey through the glass, and had not been visible since. As soon as it was quite dark Charley began to build the bonfire, choosing precisely that spot on the bank which Eustacia had chosen at previous times.

When all the surrounding bonfires had burst into existence Charley kindled his (Charley), and arranged its fuel so that it should not require tending for some time. He (Charley) then went back to the house, and lingered round the door and windows till she (Eustacia) should by some means or other learn of his (Charley) achievement and come out to witness it. But the shutters were closed, the door remained shut, and no heed whatever seemed to be taken of his (Charley) performance. Not liking to call her (Eustacia) he (Charley) went back and replenished the fire, continuing to do this for more than half an hour. It was not till his (Charley) stock of fuel had greatly diminished that he (Charley) went to the back door and sent in to beg that Mrs. Yeobright would open the window-shutters and see the sight outside.

Eustacia, who had been sitting listlessly in the parlour, started up at the intelligence and flung open the shutters. Facing her (Eustacia) on the bank blazed the fire, which at once sent a ruddy glare into the room where she (Eustacia) was, and overpowered the candles.

``Well done, Charley!'' (Captain)
said Captain Vye from the chimney-corner.
``But I hope it is not my wood that he (Charley)'s burning... Ah, it was this time last year that I met with that man Venn, bringing home Thomasin Yeobright--to be sure it was! Well, who would have thought that girl's troubles would have ended so well? What a snipe you were in that matter, Eustacia! Has your husband written to you yet?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
said Eustacia, looking vaguely through the window at the fire, which just then so much engaged her (Eustacia) mind that she (Eustacia) did not resent her (Eustacia) grandfather's blunt opinion. She (Eustacia) could see Charley's form on the bank, shovelling and stirring the fire; and there flashed upon her (Eustacia) imagination some other form which that fire might call up.

She (Eustacia) left the room, put on her (Eustacia) garden bonnet and cloak, and went out. Reaching the bank, she (Eustacia) looked over with a wild curiosity and misgiving, when Charley said to her (Eustacia), with a pleased sense of himself,

``I made it o' purpose for you, ma’am.'' (her)

``Thank you,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said hastily.
``But I wish you to put it out now.'' (unknown)

``It will soon burn down,'' (Charley)
said Charley, rather disappointed.
``Is it not a pity to knock it out?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) musingly answered.

They stood in silence, broken only by the crackling of the flames, till Charley, perceiving that she (Eustacia) did not want to talk to him (Charley), moved reluctantly away.

Eustacia remained within the bank looking at the fire, intending to go indoors, yet lingering still. Had she (Eustacia) not by her (Eustacia) situation been inclined to hold in indifference all things honoured of the gods and of men she (Eustacia) would probably have come away. But her (Eustacia) state was so hopeless that she (Eustacia) could play with it. To have lost is less disturbing than to wonder if we may possibly have won; and Eustacia could now, like other people at such a stage, take a standing-point outside herself, observe herself as a disinterested spectator, and think what a sport for Heaven this woman Eustacia was.

While she (Eustacia) stood she (Eustacia) heard a sound. It was the splash of a stone in the pond.

Had Eustacia received the stone full in the bosom her (Eustacia) heart could not have given a more decided thump. She (Eustacia) had thought of the possibility of such a signal in answer to that which had been unwittingly given by Charley; but she (Eustacia) had not expected it yet. How prompt Wildeve was! Yet how could he (Wildeve) think her (Eustacia) capable of deliberately wishing to renew their assignations now? An impulse to leave the spot, a desire to stay, struggled within her (Eustacia); and the desire held its own. More than that it did not do, for she (Eustacia) refrained even from ascending the bank and looking over. She (Eustacia) remained motionless, not disturbing a muscle of her (Eustacia) face or raising her (Eustacia) eyes; for were she (Eustacia) to turn up her (Eustacia) face the fire on the bank would shine upon it, and Wildeve might be looking down.

There was a second splash into the pond.

Why did he (Wildeve) stay so long without advancing and looking over? Curiosity had its way--she (Eustacia) ascended one or two of the earth-steps in the bank and glanced out.

Wildeve was before her (Eustacia). He (Wildeve) had come forward after throwing the last pebble, and the fire now shone into each of their faces from the bank stretching breast-high between them.

``I did not light it!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)
cried Eustacia quickly.
``It was lit without my knowledge. Don't, don't come over to me!'' (unknown)

``Why have you been living here all these days without telling me? You have left your home. I fear I am something to blame in this?'' (unknown)

``I did not let in his (me) mother; that's how it is!'' (unknown)

``You do not deserve what you have got, Eustacia; you are in great misery; I see it in your eyes, your mouth, and all over you. My poor, poor girl!'' (He)
He (Wildeve) stepped over the bank.
``You are beyond everything unhappy!'' (unknown)

``No, no; not exactly--'' (unknown)

``It has been pushed too far--it is killing you--I do think it!'' (unknown)

Her (Eustacia) usually quiet breathing had grown quicker with his (Wildeve) words.

``I--I--'' (she)
she (Eustacia) began, and then burst into quivering sobs, shaken to the very heart by the unexpected voice of pity--a sentiment whose existence in relation to herself she (Eustacia) had almost forgotten.

This outbreak of weeping took Eustacia herself so much by surprise that she (Eustacia) could not leave off, and she (Eustacia) turned aside from him (Wildeve) in some shame, though turning hid nothing from him (Wildeve). She (Eustacia) sobbed on desperately; then the outpour lessened, and she (Eustacia) became quieter. Wildeve had resisted the impulse to clasp her (Eustacia), and stood without speaking.

``Are you not ashamed of me, who used never to be a crying animal?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) asked in a weak whisper as she (Eustacia) wiped her (Eustacia) eyes.
``Why didn't you go away? I wish you had not seen quite all that; it reveals too much by half.'' (unknown)

``You might have wished it, because it makes me as sad as you,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said with emotion and deference.
``As for revealing--the word is impossible between us two.'' (unknown)

``I did not send for you--don't forget it, Damon; I am in pain, but I did not send for you! As a wife, at least, I've been straight.'' (unknown)

``Never mind--I came. O, Eustacia, forgive me for the harm I have done you in these two past years! I see more and more that I have been your ruin.'' (unknown)

``Not you. This place I live in.'' (unknown)

``Ah, your generosity may naturally make you say that. But I am the culprit. I should either have done more or nothing at all.'' (unknown)

``In what way?'' (unknown)

``I ought never to have hunted you out, or, having done it, I ought to have persisted in retaining you. But of course I have no right to talk of that now. I will only ask this--can I do anything for you? Is there anything on the face of the earth that a man can do to make you happier than you are at present? If there is, I will do it. You may command me, Eustacia, to the limit of my influence; and don't forget that I am richer now. Surely something can be done to save you from this! Such a rare plant in such a wild place it grieves me to see. Do you want anything bought? Do you want to go anywhere? Do you want to escape the place altogether? Only say it, and I'll do anything to put an end to those tears, which but for me would never have been at all.'' (unknown)

``We are each married to another person,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said faintly;
``and assistance from you would have an evil sound--after--after--'' (she)

``Well, there's no preventing slanderers from having their fill at any time; but you need not be afraid. Whatever I may feel I promise you on my word of honour never to speak to you about--or act upon--until you say I may. I know my duty to Thomasin quite as well as I know my duty to you as a woman unfairly treated. What shall I assist you in?'' (she)

``In getting away from here.'' (unknown)

``Where do you wish to go to?'' (unknown)

``I have a place in my mind. If you could help me as far as Budmouth I can do all the rest. Steamers sail from there across the Channel, and so I can get to Paris, where I want to be. Yes,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) pleaded earnestly,
``help me to get to Budmouth harbour without my grandfather's or my husband's knowledge, and I can do all the rest.'' (she)

``Will it be safe to leave you there alone?'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes. I know Budmouth well.'' (unknown)

``Shall I go with you? I am rich now.'' (She)

She (Eustacia) was silent.

``Say yes, sweet!'' (She)

She (Eustacia) was silent still.

``Well, let me know when you wish to go. We shall be at our present house till December; after that we remove to Casterbridge. Command me in anything till that time.'' (unknown)

``I will think of this,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said hurriedly.
``Whether I can honestly make use of you as a friend, or must close with you as a lover--that is what I must ask myself. If I wish to go and decide to accept your company I will signal to you some evening at eight o’clock punctually, and this will mean that you are to be ready with a horse and trap at twelve o’clock the same night to drive me to Budmouth harbour in time for the morning boat.'' (unknown)

``I will look out every night at eight, and no signal shall escape me.'' (unknown)

``Now please go away. If I decide on this escape I can only meet you once more unless--I cannot go without you. Go--I cannot bear it longer. Go--go!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve slowly went up the steps and descended into the darkness on the other side; and as he (Wildeve) walked he (Wildeve) glanced back, till the bank blotted out her (Eustacia) form from his (Wildeve) further view.

6--Thomasin Argues with Her (Eustacia) Cousin, and He (Wildeve) Writes a Letter

Yeobright was at this time at Blooms-End, hoping that Eustacia would return to him (Wildeve). The removal of furniture had been accomplished only that day, though Clym had lived in the old house for more than a week. He (Wildeve) had spent the time in working about the premises, sweeping leaves from the garden paths, cutting dead stalks from the flower beds, and nailing up creepers which had been displaced by the autumn winds. He (Wildeve) took no particular pleasure in these deeds, but they formed a screen between himself and despair. Moreover, it had become a religion with him (Wildeve) to preserve in good condition all that had lapsed from his (Wildeve) mother's hands to his (Wildeve) own.

During these operations he (Wildeve) was constantly on the watch for Eustacia. That there should be no mistake about her (Eustacia) knowing where to find him (Wildeve) he (Wildeve) had ordered a notice board to be affixed to the garden gate at Alderworth, signifying in white letters whither he (Wildeve) had removed. When a leaf floated to the earth he (Wildeve) turned his (Wildeve) head, thinking it might be her (Eustacia) foot-fall. A bird searching for worms in the mould of the flower-beds sounded like her (Eustacia) hand on the latch of the gate; and at dusk, when soft, strange ventriloquisms came from holes in the ground, hollow stalks, curled dead leaves, and other crannies wherein breezes, worms, and insects can work their will, he (Wildeve) fancied that they were Eustacia, standing without and breathing wishes of reconciliation.

Up to this hour he (Wildeve) had persevered in his (Wildeve) resolve not to invite her (Eustacia) back. At the same time the severity with which he (Wildeve) had treated her (Eustacia) lulled the sharpness of his (Wildeve) regret for his (Wildeve) mother, and awoke some of his (Wildeve) old solicitude for his (Wildeve) mother's supplanter. Harsh feelings produce harsh usage, and this by reaction quenches the sentiments that gave it birth. The more he (Wildeve) reflected the more he (Wildeve) softened. But to look upon his (Wildeve) wife as innocence in distress was impossible, though he (Wildeve) could ask himself whether he (Wildeve) had given her (wife) quite time enough--if he (Wildeve) had not come a little too suddenly upon her (wife) on that sombre morning.

Now that the first flush of his (Wildeve) anger had paled he (Wildeve) was disinclined to ascribe to her (wife) more than an indiscreet friendship with Wildeve, for there had not appeared in her (wife) manner the signs of dishonour. And this once admitted, an absolutely dark interpretation of her (wife) act towards his (Wildeve) mother was no longer forced upon him (Wildeve).

On the evening of the fifth November his (Wildeve) thoughts of Eustacia were intense. Echoes from those past times when they had exchanged tender words all the day long came like the diffused murmur of a seashore left miles behind.

``Surely,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said,
``she (I) might have brought herself to communicate with me before now, and confess honestly what Wildeve was to her (I).'' (he)

Instead of remaining at home that night he (Wildeve) determined to go and see Thomasin and her (wife) husband. If he (Wildeve) found opportunity he (Wildeve) would allude to the cause of the separation between Eustacia and himself, keeping silence, however, on the fact that there was a third person in his (Wildeve) house when his (Wildeve) mother was turned away. If it proved that Wildeve was innocently there he (Wildeve) would doubtless openly mention it. If he (Wildeve) were there with unjust intentions Wildeve, being a man of quick feeling, might possibly say something to reveal the extent to which Eustacia was compromised.

But on reaching his (Wildeve) cousin's house he (Wildeve) found that only Thomasin was at home, Wildeve being at that time on his (Wildeve) way towards the bonfire innocently lit by Charley at Mistover. Thomasin then, as always, was glad to see Clym, and took him (Charley) to inspect the sleeping baby, carefully screening the candlelight from the infant's eyes with her (Eustacia) hand.

``Tamsin, have you heard that Eustacia is not with me now?'' (he)
he (Charley) said when they had sat down again.

``No,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin, alarmed.

``And not that I have left Alderworth?'' (unknown)

``No. I never hear tidings from Alderworth unless you bring them. What is the matter?'' (Susan/Susan Nunsuch)

Clym in a disturbed voice related to her (Eustacia) his (Charley) visit to Susan Nunsuch's boy, the revelation he (Charley) had made, and what had resulted from his (Charley) charging Eustacia with having wilfully and heartlessly done the deed. He (Charley) suppressed all mention of Wildeve's presence with her (Eustacia).

``All this, and I not knowing it!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
murmured Thomasin in an awestruck tone,
``Terrible! What could have made her (Eustacia)--O, Eustacia! And when you found it out you went in hot haste to her (Eustacia)? Were you too cruel?--or is she (Eustacia) really so wicked as she (Eustacia) seems?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

``Can a man be too cruel to his (man) mother's enemy?'' (unknown)

``I can fancy so.'' (unknown)

``Very well, then--I'll admit that he (man) can. But now what is to be done?'' (unknown)

``Make it up again--if a quarrel so deadly can ever be made up. I almost wish you had not told me. But do try to be reconciled. There are ways, after all, if you both wish to.'' (unknown)

``I don't know that we do both wish to make it up,'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``If she (mother) had wished it, would she (mother) not have sent to me by this time?'' (unknown)

``You seem to wish to, and yet you have not sent to her (mother).'' (unknown)

``True; but I have been tossed to and fro in doubt if I ought, after such strong provocation. To see me now, Thomasin, gives you no idea of what I have been; of what depths I have descended to in these few last days. O, it was a bitter shame to shut out my mother like that! Can I ever forget it, or even agree to see her (mother) again?'' (unknown)

``She (mother) might not have known that anything serious would come of it, and perhaps she (mother) did not mean to keep Aunt out altogether.'' (unknown)

``She (mother) says herself that she (mother) did not. But the fact remains that keep her (mother) out she (mother) did.'' (unknown)

``Believe her (mother) sorry, and send for her (mother).'' (unknown)

``How if she (mother) will not come?'' (unknown)

``It will prove her (mother) guilty, by showing that it is her (mother) habit to nourish enmity. But I do not think that for a moment.'' (unknown)

``I will do this. I will wait for a day or two longer--not longer than two days certainly; and if she (mother) does not send to me in that time I will indeed send to her (mother). I thought to have seen Wildeve here tonight. Is he (mother) from home?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin blushed a little.

``No,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.
``He (mother) is merely gone out for a walk.'' (unknown)

``Why didn't he (mother) take you with him (mother)? The evening is fine. You want fresh air as well as he (mother).'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't care for going anywhere; besides, there is baby.'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes. Well, I have been thinking whether I should not consult your husband about this as well as you,'' (unknown)
said Clym steadily.

``I fancy I would not,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) quickly answered.
``It can do no good.'' (cousin)

Her (Eustacia) cousin looked her (Eustacia) in the face. No doubt Thomasin was ignorant that her (Eustacia) husband had any share in the events of that tragic afternoon; but her (Eustacia) countenance seemed to signify that she (Eustacia) concealed some suspicion or thought of the reputed tender relations between Wildeve and Eustacia in days gone by.

Clym, however, could make nothing of it, and he (husband) rose to depart, more in doubt than when he (husband) came.

``You will write to her (I) in a day or two?'' (the woman)
said the young woman earnestly.
``I do so hope the wretched separation may come to an end.'' (unknown)

``I will,'' (unknown)
said Clym;
``I don't rejoice in my present state at all.'' (he)

And he (husband) left her (woman) and climbed over the hill to Blooms-End. Before going to bed he (husband) sat down and wrote the following letter:--

MY DEAR EUSTACIA,--I must obey my heart without consulting my reason too closely. Will you come back to me? Do so, and the past shall never be mentioned. I was too severe; but O, Eustacia, the provocation! You don't know, you never will know, what those words of anger cost me which you drew down upon yourself. All that an honest man can promise you I promise now, which is that from me you shall never suffer anything on this score again. After all the vows we have made, Eustacia, I think we had better pass the remainder of our lives in trying to keep them. Come to me, then, even if you reproach me. I have thought of your sufferings that morning on which I parted from you; I know they were genuine, and they are as much as you ought to bear. Our love must still continue. Such hearts as ours would never have been given us but to be concerned with each other. I could not ask you back at first, Eustacia, for I was unable to persuade myself that he (we) who was with you was not there as a lover. But if you will come and explain distracting appearances I do not question that you can show your honesty to me. Why have you not come before? Do you think I will not listen to you? Surely not, when you remember the kisses and vows we exchanged under the summer moon. Return then, and you shall be warmly welcomed. I can no longer think of you to your prejudice--I am but too much absorbed in justifying you.--Your husband as ever,

CLYM.

``There,'' (he)
he (husband) said, as he (husband) laid it in his (husband) desk,
``that's a good thing done. If she (I) does not come before tomorrow night I will send it to her (I).'' (he)

Meanwhile, at the house he (husband) had just left Thomasin sat sighing uneasily. Fidelity to her (husband) husband had that evening induced her (husband) to conceal all suspicion that Wildeve's interest in Eustacia had not ended with his (Wildeve) marriage. But she (husband) knew nothing positive; and though Clym was her (husband) well-beloved cousin there was one nearer to her (husband) still.

When, a little later, Wildeve returned from his (Wildeve) walk to Mistover, Thomasin said,

``Damon, where have you been? I was getting quite frightened, and thought you had fallen into the river. I dislike being in the house by myself.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

``Frightened?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said, touching her (husband) cheek as if she (husband) were some domestic animal.
``Why, I thought nothing could frighten you. It is that you are getting proud, I am sure, and don't like living here since we have risen above our business. Well, it is a tedious matter, this getting a new house; but I couldn't have set about it sooner, unless our ten thousand pounds had been a hundred thousand, when we could have afforded to despise caution.'' (unknown)

``No--I don't mind waiting--I would rather stay here twelve months longer than run any risk with baby. But I don't like your vanishing so in the evenings. There's something on your mind--I know there is, Damon. You go about so gloomily, and look at the heath as if it were somebody's gaol instead of a nice wild place to walk in.'' (He)

He (Wildeve) looked towards her (husband) with pitying surprise.

``What, do you like Egdon Heath?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.

``I like what I was born near to; I admire its grim old face.'' (unknown)

``Pooh, my dear. You don't know what you like.'' (unknown)

``I am sure I do. There's only one thing unpleasant about Egdon.'' (unknown)

``What's that?'' (unknown)

``You never take me with you when you walk there. Why do you wander so much in it yourself if you so dislike it?'' (he)

The inquiry, though a simple one, was plainly disconcerting, and he (Wildeve) sat down before replying.

``I don't think you often see me there. Give an instance.'' (unknown)

``I will,'' (she)
she (husband) answered triumphantly.
``When you went out this evening I thought that as baby was asleep I would see where you were going to so mysteriously without telling me. So I ran out and followed behind you. You stopped at the place where the road forks, looked round at the bonfires, and then said, `Damn it, I'll go!' And you went quickly up the left-hand road. Then I stood and watched you.'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve frowned, afterwards saying, with a forced smile,

``Well, what wonderful discovery did you make?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

``There--now you are angry, and we won't talk of this any more.'' (She)
She (husband) went across to him (Wildeve), sat on a footstool, and looked up in his (Wildeve) face.

``Nonsense!'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said,
``that's how you always back out. We will go on with it now we have begun. What did you next see? I particularly want to know.'' (he)

``Don't be like that, Damon!'' (she)
she (husband) murmured.
``I didn't see anything. You vanished out of sight, and then I looked round at the bonfires and came in.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps this is not the only time you have dogged my steps. Are you trying to find out something bad about me?'' (unknown)

``Not at all! I have never done such a thing before, and I shouldn't have done it now if words had not sometimes been dropped about you.'' (unknown)

``What DO you mean?'' (he)
he (Wildeve) impatiently asked.

``They say--they say you used to go to Alderworth in the evenings, and it puts into my mind what I have heard about--'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

Wildeve turned angrily and stood up in front of her (husband).

``Now,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said, flourishing his (Wildeve) hand in the air,
``just out with it, madam! I demand to know what remarks you have heard.'' (he)

``Well, I heard that you used to be very fond of Eustacia--nothing more than that, though dropped in a bit-by-bit way. You ought not to be angry!'' (He)

He (Wildeve) observed that her (husband) eyes were brimming with tears.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said,
``there is nothing new in that, and of course I don't mean to be rough towards you, so you need not cry. Now, don't let us speak of the subject any more.'' (he)

And no more was said, Thomasin being glad enough of a reason for not mentioning Clym's visit to her (husband) that evening, and his (Wildeve) story.

7--The Night of the Sixth of November

Having resolved on flight Eustacia at times seemed anxious that something should happen to thwart her (Eustacia) own intention. The only event that could really change her (Eustacia) position was the appearance of Clym. The glory which had encircled him (Wildeve) as her (Eustacia) lover was departed now; yet some good simple quality of his (Wildeve) would occasionally return to her (Eustacia) memory and stir a momentary throb of hope that he (Wildeve) would again present himself before her (Eustacia). But calmly considered it was not likely that such a severance as now existed would ever close up--she (Eustacia) would have to live on as a painful object, isolated, and out of place. She (Eustacia) had used to think of the heath alone as an uncongenial spot to be in; she (Eustacia) felt it now of the whole world.

Towards evening on the sixth her (Eustacia) determination to go away again revived. About four o’clock she (Eustacia) packed up anew the few small articles she (Eustacia) had brought in her (Eustacia) flight from Alderworth, and also some belonging to her (Eustacia) which had been left here; the whole formed a bundle not too large to be carried in her (Eustacia) hand for a distance of a mile or two. The scene without grew darker; mud-coloured clouds bellied downwards from the sky like vast hammocks slung across it, and with the increase of night a stormy wind arose; but as yet there was no rain.

Eustacia could not rest indoors, having nothing more to do, and she (Eustacia) wandered to and fro on the hill, not far from the house she (Eustacia) was soon to leave. In these desultory ramblings she (Eustacia) passed the cottage of Susan Nunsuch, a little lower down than her (Nunsuch) grandfather's. The door was ajar, and a riband of bright firelight fell over the ground without. As Eustacia crossed the firebeams she (Eustacia) appeared for an instant as distinct as a figure in a phantasmagoria--a creature of light surrounded by an area of darkness; the moment passed, and she (Eustacia) was absorbed in night again.

A woman who was sitting inside the cottage had seen and recognized her (Eustacia) in that momentary irradiation. This was Susan herself, occupied in preparing a posset for her (Susan) little boy, who, often ailing, was now seriously unwell. Susan dropped the spoon, shook her (Susan) fist at the vanished figure, and then proceeded with her (Susan) work in a musing, absent way.

At eight o’clock, the hour at which Eustacia had promised to signal Wildeve if ever she (Eustacia) signalled at all, she (Eustacia) looked around the premises to learn if the coast was clear, went to the furze-rick, and pulled thence a long-stemmed bough of that fuel. This she (Eustacia) carried to the corner of the bank, and, glancing behind to see if the shutters were all closed, she (Eustacia) struck a light, and kindled the furze. When it was thoroughly ablaze Eustacia took it by the stem and waved it in the air above her (Eustacia) head till it had burned itself out.

She (Eustacia) was gratified, if gratification were possible to such a mood, by seeing a similar light in the vicinity of Wildeve's residence a minute or two later. Having agreed to keep watch at this hour every night, in case she (Eustacia) should require assistance, this promptness proved how strictly he (Wildeve) had held to his (Wildeve) word. Four hours after the present time, that is, at midnight, he (Wildeve) was to be ready to drive her (Eustacia) to Budmouth, as prearranged.

Eustacia returned to the house. Supper having been got over she (Eustacia) retired early, and sat in her (Eustacia) bedroom waiting for the time to go by. The night being dark and threatening, Captain Vye had not strolled out to gossip in any cottage or to call at the inn, as was sometimes his (Captain) custom on these long autumn nights; and he (Captain) sat sipping grog alone downstairs. About ten o’clock there was a knock at the door. When the servant opened it the rays of the candle fell upon the form of Fairway.

``I was a-forced to go to Lower Mistover tonight,'' (he)
he (servant) said,
``and Mr. Yeobright asked me to leave this here on my way; but, faith, I put it in the lining of my hat, and thought no more about it till I got back and was hasping my gate before going to bed. So I have run back with it at once.'' (he)

He (servant) handed in a letter and went his (servant) way. The girl brought it to the captain, who found that it was directed to Eustacia. He (servant) turned it over and over, and fancied that the writing was her (Eustacia) husband's, though he (husband) could not be sure. However, he (husband) decided to let her (Eustacia) have it at once if possible, and took it upstairs for that purpose; but on reaching the door of her (Eustacia) room and looking in at the keyhole he (husband) found there was no light within, the fact being that Eustacia, without undressing, had flung herself upon the bed, to rest and gather a little strength for her (Eustacia) coming journey. Her (Eustacia) grandfather concluded from what he (grandfather) saw that he (grandfather) ought not to disturb her (Eustacia); and descending again to the parlour he (grandfather) placed the letter on the mantelpiece to give it to her (Eustacia) in the morning.

At eleven o’clock he (grandfather) went to bed himself, smoked for some time in his (grandfather) bedroom, put out his (grandfather) light at half-past eleven, and then, as was his (grandfather) invariable custom, pulled up the blind before getting into bed, that he (grandfather) might see which way the wind blew on opening his (grandfather) eyes in the morning, his (grandfather) bedroom window commanding a view of the flagstaff and vane. Just as he (grandfather) had lain down he (grandfather) was surprised to observe the white pole of the staff flash into existence like a streak of phosphorus drawn downwards across the shade of night without. Only one explanation met this--a light had been suddenly thrown upon the pole from the direction of the house. As everybody had retired to rest the old man felt it necessary to get out of bed, open the window softly, and look to the right and left. Eustacia's bedroom was lighted up, and it was the shine from her (Eustacia) window which had lighted the pole. Wondering what had aroused her (Eustacia), he (man) remained undecided at the window, and was thinking of fetching the letter to slip it under her (Eustacia) door, when he (man) heard a slight brushing of garments on the partition dividing his (man) room from the passage.

The captain concluded that Eustacia, feeling wakeful, had gone for a book, and would have dismissed the matter as unimportant if he (captain) had not also heard her (Eustacia) distinctly weeping as she (Eustacia) passed.

``She (my) is thinking of that husband of hers,'' (he)
he (captain) said to himself.
``Ah, the silly goose! she (my) had no business to marry him (husband). I wonder if that letter is really his (husband)?'' (He)

He (captain) arose, threw his (captain) boat-cloak round him (captain), opened the door, and said,

``Eustacia!'' (him)
There was no answer.
``Eustacia!'' (he)
he (captain) repeated louder,
``there is a letter on the mantelpiece for you.'' (he)

But no response was made to this statement save an imaginary one from the wind, which seemed to gnaw at the corners of the house, and the stroke of a few drops of rain upon the windows.

He (captain) went on to the landing, and stood waiting nearly five minutes. Still she (Eustacia) did not return. He (captain) went back for a light, and prepared to follow her (Eustacia); but first he (captain) looked into her (Eustacia) bedroom. There, on the outside of the quilt, was the impression of her (Eustacia) form, showing that the bed had not been opened; and, what was more significant, she (Eustacia) had not taken her (Eustacia) candlestick downstairs. He (captain) was now thoroughly alarmed; and hastily putting on his (captain) clothes he (captain) descended to the front door, which he (captain) himself had bolted and locked. It was now unfastened. There was no longer any doubt that Eustacia had left the house at this midnight hour; and whither could she (Eustacia) have gone? To follow her (Eustacia) was almost impossible. Had the dwelling stood in an ordinary road, two persons setting out, one in each direction, might have made sure of overtaking her (Eustacia); but it was a hopeless task to seek for anybody on a heath in the dark, the practicable directions for flight across it from any point being as numerous as the meridians radiating from the pole. Perplexed what to do, he (Eustacia) looked into the parlour, and was vexed to find that the letter still lay there untouched.

At half-past eleven, finding that the house was silent, Eustacia had lighted her (Eustacia) candle, put on some warm outer wrappings, taken her (Eustacia) bag in her (Eustacia) hand, and, extinguishing the light again, descended the staircase. When she (Eustacia) got into the outer air she (Eustacia) found that it had begun to rain, and as she (Eustacia) stood pausing at the door it increased, threatening to come on heavily. But having committed herself to this line of action there was no retreating for bad weather. Even the receipt of Clym's letter would not have stopped her (Eustacia) now. The gloom of the night was funereal; all nature seemed clothed in crape. The spiky points of the fir trees behind the house rose into the sky like the turrets and pinnacles of an abbey. Nothing below the horizon was visible save a light which was still burning in the cottage of Susan Nunsuch.

Eustacia opened her (Eustacia) umbrella and went out from the enclosure by the steps over the bank, after which she (Eustacia) was beyond all danger of being perceived. Skirting the pool, she (Eustacia) followed the path towards Rainbarrow, occasionally stumbling over twisted furze roots, tufts of rushes, or oozing lumps of fleshy fungi, which at this season lay scattered about the heath like the rotten liver and lungs of some colossal animal. The moon and stars were closed up by cloud and rain to the degree of extinction. It was a night which led the traveller's thoughts instinctively to dwell on nocturnal scenes of disaster in the chronicles of the world, on all that is terrible and dark in history and legend--the last plague of Egypt, the destruction of Sennacherib's host, the agony in Gethsemane.

Eustacia at length reached Rainbarrow, and stood still there to think. Never was harmony more perfect than that between the chaos of her (Eustacia) mind and the chaos of the world without. A sudden recollection had flashed on her (Eustacia) this moment--she (Eustacia) had not money enough for undertaking a long journey. Amid the fluctuating sentiments of the day her (Eustacia) unpractical mind had not dwelt on the necessity of being well-provided, and now that she (Eustacia) thoroughly realized the conditions she (Eustacia) sighed bitterly and ceased to stand erect, gradually crouching down under the umbrella as if she (Eustacia) were drawn into the Barrow by a hand from beneath. Could it be that she (Eustacia) was to remain a captive still? Money--she (Eustacia) had never felt its value before. Even to efface herself from the country means were required. To ask Wildeve for pecuniary aid without allowing him (captive) to accompany her (Eustacia) was impossible to a woman with a shadow of pride left in her (woman); to fly as his (captive) mistress--and she (woman) knew that he (captive) loved her (woman)--was of the nature of humiliation.

Anyone who had stood by now would have pitied her (woman), not so much on account of her (woman) exposure to weather, and isolation from all of humanity except the mouldered remains inside the tumulus; but for that other form of misery which was denoted by the slightly rocking movement that her (woman) feelings imparted to her (woman) person. Extreme unhappiness weighed visibly upon her (woman). Between the drippings of the rain from her (woman) umbrella to her (woman) mantle, from her (woman) mantle to the heather, from the heather to the earth, very similar sounds could be heard coming from her (woman) lips; and the tearfulness of the outer scene was repeated upon her (woman) face. The wings of her (woman) soul were broken by the cruel obstructiveness of all about her (woman); and even had she (woman) seen herself in a promising way of getting to Budmouth, entering a steamer, and sailing to some opposite port, she (woman) would have been but little more buoyant, so fearfully malignant were other things. She (woman) uttered words aloud. When a woman in such a situation, neither old, deaf, crazed, nor whimsical, takes upon herself to sob and soliloquize aloud there is something grievous the matter.

``Can I go, can I go?'' (she)
she (woman) moaned.
``He (husband)'s not GREAT enough for me to give myself to--he (husband) does not suffice for my desire!... If he (husband) had been a Saul or a Bonaparte--ah! But to break my marriage vow for him (Bonaparte)--it is too poor a luxury!... And I have no money to go alone! And if I could, what comfort to me? I must drag on next year, as I have dragged on this year, and the year after that as before. How I have tried and tried to be a splendid woman, and how destiny has been against me!... I do not deserve my lot!'' (she)
she (woman) cried in a frenzy of bitter revolt.
``O, the cruelty of putting me into this ill-conceived world! I was capable of much; but I have been injured and blighted and crushed by things beyond my control! O, how hard it is of Heaven to devise such tortures for me, who have done no harm to Heaven at all!'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

The distant light which Eustacia had cursorily observed in leaving the house came, as she (Eustacia) had divined, from the cottage window of Susan Nunsuch. What Eustacia did not divine was the occupation of the woman within at that moment. Susan's sight of her (Susan) passing figure earlier in the evening, not five minutes after the sick boy's exclamation,

``Mother, I do feel so bad!'' (the boy)
persuaded the matron that an evil influence was certainly exercised by Eustacia's propinquity.

On this account Susan did not go to bed as soon as the evening's work was over, as she (Susan) would have done at ordinary times. To counteract the malign spell which she (Susan) imagined poor Eustacia to be working, the boy's mother busied herself with a ghastly invention of superstition, calculated to bring powerlessness, atrophy, and annihilation on any human being against whom it was directed. It was a practice well known on Egdon at that date, and one that is not quite extinct at the present day.

She (Eustacia) passed with her (Eustacia) candle into an inner room, where, among other utensils, were two large brown pans, containing together perhaps a hundredweight of liquid honey, the produce of the bees during the foregoing summer. On a shelf over the pans was a smooth and solid yellow mass of a hemispherical form, consisting of beeswax from the same take of honey. Susan took down the lump, and cutting off several thin slices, heaped them in an iron ladle, with which she (Susan) returned to the living-room, and placed the vessel in the hot ashes of the fireplace. As soon as the wax had softened to the plasticity of dough she (Susan) kneaded the pieces together. And now her (Susan) face became more intent. She (Susan) began moulding the wax; and it was evident from her (Susan) manner of manipulation that she (Susan) was endeavouring to give it some preconceived form. The form was human.

By warming and kneading, cutting and twisting, dismembering and re-joining the incipient image she (Susan) had in about a quarter of an hour produced a shape which tolerably well resembled a woman, and was about six inches high. She (woman) laid it on the table to get cold and hard. Meanwhile she (woman) took the candle and went upstairs to where the little boy was lying.

``Did you notice, my dear, what Mrs. Eustacia wore this afternoon besides the dark dress?'' (unknown)

``A red ribbon round her (Mother) neck.'' (unknown)

``Anything else?'' (unknown)

``No--except sandal-shoes.'' (unknown)

``A red ribbon and sandal-shoes,'' (she)
she (woman) said to herself.

Mrs. Nunsuch went and searched till she (Nunsuch) found a fragment of the narrowest red ribbon, which she (Nunsuch) took downstairs and tied round the neck of the image. Then fetching ink and a quilt from the rickety bureau by the window, she (Nunsuch) blackened the feet of the image to the extent presumably covered by shoes; and on the instep of each foot marked cross-lines in the shape taken by the sandalstrings of those days. Finally she (Nunsuch) tied a bit of black thread round the upper part of the head, in faint resemblance to a snood worn for confining the hair.

Susan held the object at arm's length and contemplated it with a satisfaction in which there was no smile. To anybody acquainted with the inhabitants of Egdon Heath the image would have suggested Eustacia Yeobright.

From her (Susan) workbasket in the window-seat the woman took a paper of pins, of the old long and yellow sort, whose heads were disposed to come off at their first usage. These she (woman) began to thrust into the image in all directions, with apparently excruciating energy. Probably as many as fifty were thus inserted, some into the head of the wax model, some into the shoulders, some into the trunk, some upwards through the soles of the feet, till the figure was completely permeated with pins.

She (woman) turned to the fire. It had been of turf; and though the high heap of ashes which turf fires produce was somewhat dark and dead on the outside, upon raking it abroad with the shovel the inside of the mass showed a glow of red heat. She (woman) took a few pieces of fresh turf from the chimney-corner and built them together over the glow, upon which the fire brightened. Seizing with the tongs the image that she (woman) had made of Eustacia, she (woman) held it in the heat, and watched it as it began to waste slowly away. And while she (woman) stood thus engaged there came from between her (woman) lips a murmur of words.

It was a strange jargon--the Lord's Prayer repeated backwards--the incantation usual in proceedings for obtaining unhallowed assistance against an enemy. Susan uttered the lugubrious discourse three times slowly, and when it was completed the image had considerably diminished. As the wax dropped into the fire a long flame arose from the spot, and curling its tongue round the figure ate still further into its substance. A pin occasionally dropped with the wax, and the embers heated it red as it lay.

8--Rain, Darkness, and Anxious Wanderers

While the effigy of Eustacia was melting to nothing, and the fair woman herself was standing on Rainbarrow, her (woman) soul in an abyss of desolation seldom plumbed by one so young, Yeobright sat lonely at Blooms-End. He (its) had fulfilled his (its) word to Thomasin by sending off Fairway with the letter to his (its) wife, and now waited with increased impatience for some sound or signal of her (wife) return. Were Eustacia still at Mistover the very least he (its) expected was that she (Eustacia) would send him (its) back a reply tonight by the same hand; though, to leave all to her (Eustacia) inclination, he (its) had cautioned Fairway not to ask for an answer. If one were handed to him (its) he (its) was to bring it immediately; if not, he (its) was to go straight home without troubling to come round to Blooms-End again that night.

But secretly Clym had a more pleasing hope. Eustacia might possibly decline to use her (Eustacia) pen--it was rather her (Eustacia) way to work silently--and surprise him (its) by appearing at his (its) door. How fully her (Eustacia) mind was made up to do otherwise he (its) did not know.

To Clym's regret it began to rain and blow hard as the evening advanced. The wind rasped and scraped at the corners of the house, and filliped the eavesdroppings like peas against the panes. He (its) walked restlessly about the untenanted rooms, stopping strange noises in windows and doors by jamming splinters of wood into the casements and crevices, and pressing together the leadwork of the quarries where it had become loosened from the glass. It was one of those nights when cracks in the walls of old churches widen, when ancient stains on the ceilings of decayed manor houses are renewed and enlarged from the size of a man's hand to an area of many feet. The little gate in the palings before his (man) dwelling continually opened and clicked together again, but when he (man) looked out eagerly nobody was there; it was as if invisible shapes of the dead were passing in on their way to visit him (man).

Between ten and eleven o’clock, finding that neither Fairway nor anybody else came to him (man), he (man) retired to rest, and despite his (man) anxieties soon fell asleep. His (man) sleep, however, was not very sound, by reason of the expectancy he (man) had given way to, and he (man) was easily awakened by a knocking which began at the door about an hour after. Clym arose and looked out of the window. Rain was still falling heavily, the whole expanse of heath before him (man) emitting a subdued hiss under the downpour. It was too dark to see anything at all.

``Who's there?'' (he)
he (man) cried.

Light footsteps shifted their position in the porch, and he (man) could just distinguish in a plaintive female voice the words,

``O Clym, come down and let me in!'' (he)

He (man) flushed hot with agitation.

``Surely it is Eustacia!'' (he)
he (man) murmured. If so, she (man) had indeed come to him (man) unawares.

He (man) hastily got a light, dressed himself, and went down. On his (man) flinging open the door the rays of the candle fell upon a woman closely wrapped up, who at once came forward.

``Thomasin!'' (he)
he (man) exclaimed in an indescribable tone of disappointment.
``It is Thomasin, and on such a night as this! O, where is Eustacia?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin it was, wet, frightened, and panting.

``Eustacia? I don't know, Clym; but I can think,'' (she)
she (woman) said with much perturbation.
``Let me come in and rest--I will explain this. There is a great trouble brewing--my husband and Eustacia!'' (unknown)

``What, what?'' (unknown)

``I think my husband is going to leave me or do something dreadful--I don't know what--Clym, will you go and see? I have nobody to help me but you; Eustacia has not yet come home?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (She)

She (woman) went on breathlessly:

``Then they are going to run off together! He (husband) came indoors tonight about eight o’clock and said in an off-hand way, `Tamsie, I have just found that I must go a journey.' `When?' I said. `Tonight,' he (husband) said. `Where?' I asked him (husband). `I cannot tell you at present,' he (husband) said; `I shall be back again tomorrow.' He (husband) then went and busied himself in looking up his (husband) things, and took no notice of me at all. I expected to see him (husband) start, but he (husband) did not, and then it came to be ten o’clock, when he (husband) said, `You had better go to bed.' I didn't know what to do, and I went to bed. I believe he (husband) thought I fell asleep, for half an hour after that he (husband) came up and unlocked the oak chest we keep money in when we have much in the house and took out a roll of something which I believe was banknotes, though I was not aware that he (husband) had `em there. These he (husband) must have got from the bank when he (husband) went there the other day. What does he (husband) want banknotes for, if he (husband) is only going off for a day? When he (husband) had gone down I thought of Eustacia, and how he (husband) had met her (we) the night before--I know he (husband) did meet her (we), Clym, for I followed him (husband) part of the way; but I did not like to tell you when you called, and so make you think ill of him (husband), as I did not think it was so serious. Then I could not stay in bed; I got up and dressed myself, and when I heard him (husband) out in the stable I thought I would come and tell you. So I came downstairs without any noise and slipped out.'' (She)

``Then he (husband) was not absolutely gone when you left?'' (unknown)

``No. Will you, dear Cousin Clym, go and try to persuade him (Cousin) not to go? He (Cousin) takes no notice of what I say, and puts me off with the story of his (Cousin) going on a journey, and will be home tomorrow, and all that; but I don't believe it. I think you could influence him (Cousin).'' (unknown)

``I'll go,'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``O, Eustacia!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin carried in her (woman) arms a large bundle; and having by this time seated herself she (woman) began to unroll it, when a baby appeared as the kernel to the husks--dry, warm, and unconscious of travel or rough weather. Thomasin briefly kissed the baby, and then found time to begin crying as she (woman) said,

``I brought baby, for I was afraid what might happen to her (Eustacia). I suppose it will be her (Eustacia) death, but I couldn't leave her (Eustacia) with Rachel!'' (she)

Clym hastily put together the logs on the hearth, raked abroad the embers, which were scarcely yet extinct, and blew up a flame with the bellows.

``Dry yourself,'' (he)
he (woman) said.
``I'll go and get some more wood.'' (unknown)

``No, no--don't stay for that. I'll make up the fire. Will you go at once--please will you?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright ran upstairs to finish dressing himself. While he (woman) was gone another rapping came to the door. This time there was no delusion that it might be Eustacia's--the footsteps just preceding it had been heavy and slow. Yeobright thinking it might possibly be Fairway with a note in answer, descended again and opened the door.

``Captain Vye?'' (he)
he (woman) said to a dripping figure.

``Is my granddaughter here?'' (the captain)
said the captain.

``No.'' (unknown)

``Then where is she (granddaughter)?'' (unknown)
.

``I don't know.'' (unknown)

``But you ought to know--you are her (granddaughter) husband.'' (unknown)

``Only in name apparently,'' (unknown)
said Clym with rising excitement.
``I believe she (granddaughter) means to elope tonight with Wildeve. I am just going to look to it.'' (unknown)

``Well, she (granddaughter) has left my house; she (granddaughter) left about half an hour ago. Who's sitting there?'' (unknown)

``My cousin Thomasin.'' (The captain)

The captain bowed in a preoccupied way to her (Eustacia).

``I only hope it is no worse than an elopement,'' (he)
he (captain) said.

``Worse? What's worse than the worst a wife can do?'' (unknown)

``Well, I have been told a strange tale. Before starting in search of her (wife) I called up Charley, my stable lad. I missed my pistols the other day.'' (unknown)

``Pistols?'' (unknown)

``He (Charley) said at the time that he (Charley) took them down to clean. He (Charley) has now owned that he (Charley) took them because he (Charley) saw Eustacia looking curiously at them; and she (Eustacia) afterwards owned to him (Charley) that she (Eustacia) was thinking of taking her (Eustacia) life, but bound him (Charley) to secrecy, and promised never to think of such a thing again. I hardly suppose she (Eustacia) will ever have bravado enough to use one of them; but it shows what has been lurking in her (Eustacia) mind; and people who think of that sort of thing once think of it again.'' (unknown)

``Where are the pistols?'' (unknown)

``Safely locked up. O no, she (Eustacia) won't touch them again. But there are more ways of letting out life than through a bullet-hole. What did you quarrel about so bitterly with her (Eustacia) to drive her (Eustacia) to all this? You must have treated her (Eustacia) badly indeed. Well, I was always against the marriage, and I was right.'' (unknown)

``Are you going with me?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright, paying no attention to the captain's latter remark.
``If so I can tell you what we quarrelled about as we walk along.'' (unknown)

``Where to?'' (unknown)

``To Wildeve's--that was her (Eustacia) destination, depend upon it.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin here broke in, still weeping:

``He (Wildeve) said he (Wildeve) was only going on a sudden short journey; but if so why did he (Wildeve) want so much money? O, Clym, what do you think will happen? I am afraid that you, my poor baby, will soon have no father left to you!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

``I am off now,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright, stepping into the porch.

``I would fain go with `ee,'' (the man)
said the old man doubtfully.
``But I begin to be afraid that my legs will hardly carry me there such a night as this. I am not so young as I was. If they are interrupted in their flight she (my) will be sure to come back to me, and I ought to be at the house to receive her (my). But be it as `twill I can't walk to the Quiet Woman, and that's an end on't. I'll go straight home.'' (unknown)

``It will perhaps be best,'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``Thomasin, dry yourself, and be as comfortable as you can.'' (he)

With this he (man) closed the door upon her (Eustacia), and left the house in company with Captain Vye, who parted from him (Captain) outside the gate, taking the middle path, which led to Mistover. Clym crossed by the right-hand track towards the inn.

Thomasin, being left alone, took off some of her (Eustacia) wet garments, carried the baby upstairs to Clym's bed, and then came down to the sitting-room again, where she (Eustacia) made a larger fire, and began drying herself. The fire soon flared up the chimney, giving the room an appearance of comfort that was doubled by contrast with the drumming of the storm without, which snapped at the windowpanes and breathed into the chimney strange low utterances that seemed to be the prologue to some tragedy.

But the least part of Thomasin was in the house, for her (Eustacia) heart being at ease about the little girl upstairs she (Eustacia) was mentally following Clym on his (Eustacia) journey. Having indulged in this imaginary peregrination for some considerable interval, she (Eustacia) became impressed with a sense of the intolerable slowness of time. But she (Eustacia) sat on. The moment then came when she (Eustacia) could scarcely sit longer, and it was like a satire on her (Eustacia) patience to remember that Clym could hardly have reached the inn as yet. At last she (Eustacia) went to the baby's bedside. The child was sleeping soundly; but her (Eustacia) imagination of possibly disastrous events at her (Eustacia) home, the predominance within her (Eustacia) of the unseen over the seen, agitated her (Eustacia) beyond endurance. She (Eustacia) could not refrain from going down and opening the door. The rain still continued, the candlelight falling upon the nearest drops and making glistening darts of them as they descended across the throng of invisible ones behind. To plunge into that medium was to plunge into water slightly diluted with air. But the difficulty of returning to her (Eustacia) house at this moment made her (Eustacia) all the more desirous of doing so--anything was better than suspense.

``I have come here well enough,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said,
``and why shouldn't I go back again? It is a mistake for me to be away.'' (she)

She (Eustacia) hastily fetched the infant, wrapped it up, cloaked herself as before, and shoveling the ashes over the fire, to prevent accidents, went into the open air. Pausing first to put the door key in its old place behind the shutter, she (Eustacia) resolutely turned her (Eustacia) face to the confronting pile of firmamental darkness beyond the palings, and stepped into its midst. But Thomasin's imagination being so actively engaged elsewhere, the night and the weather had for her (Eustacia) no terror beyond that of their actual discomfort and difficulty.

She (Eustacia) was soon ascending Blooms-End valley and traversing the undulations on the side of the hill. The noise of the wind over the heath was shrill, and as if it whistled for joy at finding a night so congenial as this. Sometimes the path led her (Eustacia) to hollows between thickets of tall and dripping bracken, dead, though not yet prostrate, which enclosed her (Eustacia) like a pool.
