When they were more than usually tall she (Eustacia) lifted the baby to the top of her (Eustacia) head, that it might be out of the reach of their drenching fronds. On higher ground, where the wind was brisk and sustained, the rain flew in a level flight without sensible descent, so that it was beyond all power to imagine the remoteness of the point at which it left the bosoms of the clouds. Here self-defence was impossible, and individual drops stuck into her (Eustacia) like the arrows into Saint Sebastian. She (Eustacia) was enabled to avoid puddles by the nebulous paleness which signified their presence, though beside anything less dark than the heath they themselves would have appeared as blackness.

Yet in spite of all this Thomasin was not sorry that she (Eustacia) had started. To her (Eustacia) there were not, as to Eustacia, demons in the air, and malice in every bush and bough. The drops which lashed her (Eustacia) face were not scorpions, but prosy rain; Egdon in the mass was no monster whatever, but impersonal open ground. Her (Eustacia) fears of the place were rational, her (Eustacia) dislikes of its worst moods reasonable. At this time it was in her (Eustacia) view a windy, wet place, in which a person might experience much discomfort, lose the path without care, and possibly catch cold.

If the path is well known the difficulty at such times of keeping therein is not altogether great, from its familiar feel to the feet; but once lost it is irrecoverable. Owing to her (Eustacia) baby, who somewhat impeded Thomasin's view forward and distracted her (Eustacia) mind, she (Eustacia) did at last lose the track. This mishap occurred when she (Eustacia) was descending an open slope about two-thirds home. Instead of attempting, by wandering hither and thither, the hopeless task of finding such a mere thread, she (Eustacia) went straight on, trusting for guidance to her (Eustacia) general knowledge of the contours, which was scarcely surpassed by Clym's or by that of the heath-croppers themselves.

At length Thomasin reached a hollow and began to discern through the rain a faint blotted radiance, which presently assumed the oblong form of an open door. She (Eustacia) knew that no house stood hereabouts, and was soon aware of the nature of the door by its height above the ground.

``Why, it is Diggory Venn's van, surely!'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said.

A certain secluded spot near Rainbarrow was, she (Eustacia) knew, often Venn's chosen centre when staying in this neighbourhood; and she (Eustacia) guessed at once that she (Eustacia) had stumbled upon this mysterious retreat. The question arose in her (Eustacia) mind whether or not she (Eustacia) should ask him (Venn) to guide her (Eustacia) into the path. In her (Eustacia) anxiety to reach home she (Eustacia) decided that she (Eustacia) would appeal to him (Venn), notwithstanding the strangeness of appearing before his (Venn) eyes at this place and season. But when, in pursuance of this resolve, Thomasin reached the van and looked in she (Eustacia) found it to be untenanted; though there was no doubt that it was the reddleman's. The fire was burning in the stove, the lantern hung from the nail. Round the doorway the floor was merely sprinkled with rain, and not saturated, which told her (Eustacia) that the door had not long been opened.

While she (Eustacia) stood uncertainly looking in Thomasin heard a footstep advancing from the darkness behind her (Eustacia), and turning, beheld the well-known form in corduroy, lurid from head to foot, the lantern beams falling upon him (nail) through an intervening gauze of raindrops.

``I thought you went down the slope,'' (he)
he (nail) said, without noticing her (Eustacia) face.
``How do you come back here again?'' (unknown)

``Diggory?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin faintly.

``Who are you?'' (unknown)
said Venn, still unperceiving.
``And why were you crying so just now?'' (unknown)

``O, Diggory! don't you know me?'' (she)
said she (Eustacia).
``But of course you don't, wrapped up like this. What do you mean? I have not been crying here, and I have not been here before.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn then came nearer till he (Venn) could see the illuminated side of her (Eustacia) form.

``Mrs. Wildeve!'' (he)
he (Venn) exclaimed, starting.
``What a time for us to meet! And the baby too! What dreadful thing can have brought you out on such a night as this?'' (She)

She (Eustacia) could not immediately answer; and without asking her (Eustacia) permission he (Venn) hopped into his (Venn) van, took her (Eustacia) by the arm, and drew her (Eustacia) up after him (Venn).

``What is it?'' (he)
he (Venn) continued when they stood within.

``I have lost my way coming from Blooms-End, and I am in a great hurry to get home. Please show me as quickly as you can! It is so silly of me not to know Egdon better, and I cannot think how I came to lose the path. Show me quickly, Diggory, please.'' (unknown)

``Yes, of course. I will go with `ee. But you came to me before this, Mrs. Wildeve?'' (unknown)

``I only came this minute.'' (unknown)

``That's strange. I was lying down here asleep about five minutes ago, with the door shut to keep out the weather, when the brushing of a woman's clothes over the heath-bushes just outside woke me up, for I don't sleep heavy, and at the same time I heard a sobbing or crying from the same woman. I opened my door and held out my lantern, and just as far as the light would reach I saw a woman; she (woman) turned her (woman) head when the light sheened on her (woman), and then hurried on downhill. I hung up the lantern, and was curious enough to pull on my things and dog her (woman) a few steps, but I could see nothing of her (woman) any more. That was where I had been when you came up; and when I saw you I thought you were the same one.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps it was one of the heathfolk going home?'' (unknown)

``No, it couldn't be. `Tis too late. The noise of her (woman) gown over the he (dog)'th was of a whistling sort that nothing but silk will make.'' (unknown)

``It wasn't I, then. My dress is not silk, you see... Are we anywhere in a line between Mistover and the inn?'' (unknown)

``Well, yes; not far out.'' (unknown)

``Ah, I wonder if it was she (woman)! Diggory, I must go at once!'' (She)

She (Eustacia) jumped down from the van before he (Venn) was aware, when Venn unhooked the lantern and leaped down after her (Eustacia).

``I'll take the baby, ma’am,'' (he)
he (Venn) said.
``You must be tired out by the weight.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin hesitated a moment, and then delivered the baby into Venn's hands.

``Don't squeeze her (woman), Diggory,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said,
``or hurt her (woman) little arm; and keep the cloak close over her (woman) like this, so that the rain may not drop in her (woman) face.'' (she)

``I will,'' (unknown)
said Venn earnestly.
``As if I could hurt anything belonging to you!'' (unknown)

``I only meant accidentally,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin.

``The baby is dry enough, but you are pretty wet,'' (the reddleman)
said the reddleman when, in closing the door of his (Venn) cart to padlock it, he (Venn) noticed on the floor a ring of water drops where her (Eustacia) cloak had hung from her (Eustacia).

Thomasin followed him (Venn) as he (Venn) wound right and left to avoid the larger bushes, stopping occasionally and covering the lantern, while he (Venn) looked over his (Venn) shoulder to gain some idea of the position of Rainbarrow above them, which it was necessary to keep directly behind their backs to preserve a proper course.

``You are sure the rain does not fall upon baby?'' (unknown)

``Quite sure. May I ask how old he (Diggory) is, ma’am?'' (unknown)

``He (Diggory)!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin reproachfully.
``Anybody can see better than that in a moment. She (woman) is nearly two months old. How far is it now to the inn?'' (unknown)

``A little over a quarter of a mile.'' (unknown)

``Will you walk a little faster?'' (unknown)

``I was afraid you could not keep up.'' (unknown)

``I am very anxious to get there. Ah, there is a light from the window!'' (unknown)

```Tis not from the window. That's a gig-lamp, to the best of my belief.''

``O!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin in despair.
``I wish I had been there sooner--give me the baby, Diggory--you can go back now.'' (unknown)

``I must go all the way,'' (unknown)
said Venn.
``There is a quag between us and that light, and you will walk into it up to your neck unless I take you round.'' (unknown)

``But the light is at the inn, and there is no quag in front of that.'' (unknown)

``No, the light is below the inn some two or three hundred yards.'' (unknown)

``Never mind,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin hurriedly.
``Go towards the light, and not towards the inn.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (unknown)
answered Venn, swerving round in obedience; and, after a pause,
``I wish you would tell me what this great trouble is. I think you have proved that I can be trusted.'' (unknown)

``There are some things that cannot be--cannot be told to--'' (she)
And then her (it) heart rose into her (it) throat, and she (it) could say no more.

9--Sights and Sounds Draw the Wanderers Together

Having seen Eustacia's signal from the hill at eight o’clock, Wildeve immediately prepared to assist her (Eustacia) in her (Eustacia) flight, and, as he (Wildeve) hoped, accompany her (Eustacia). He (Wildeve) was somewhat perturbed, and his (Wildeve) manner of informing Thomasin that he (Wildeve) was going on a journey was in itself sufficient to rouse her (Eustacia) suspicions. When she (Eustacia) had gone to bed he (Wildeve) collected the few articles he (Wildeve) would require, and went upstairs to the money-chest, whence he (Wildeve) took a tolerably bountiful sum in notes, which had been advanced to him (Wildeve) on the property he (Wildeve) was so soon to have in possession, to defray expenses incidental to the removal.

He (Wildeve) then went to the stable and coach-house to assure himself that the horse, gig, and harness were in a fit condition for a long drive. Nearly half an hour was spent thus, and on returning to the house Wildeve had no thought of Thomasin being anywhere but in bed. He (Wildeve) had told the stable lad not to stay up, leading the boy to understand that his (Wildeve) departure would be at three or four in the morning; for this, though an exceptional hour, was less strange than midnight, the time actually agreed on, the packet from Budmouth sailing between one and two.

At last all was quiet, and he (Wildeve) had nothing to do but to wait. By no effort could he (Wildeve) shake off the oppression of spirits which he (Wildeve) had experienced ever since his (Wildeve) last meeting with Eustacia, but he (Wildeve) hoped there was that in his (Wildeve) situation which money could cure. He (Wildeve) had persuaded himself that to act not ungenerously towards his (Wildeve) gentle wife by settling on her (wife) the half of his (Wildeve) property, and with chivalrous devotion towards another and greater woman by sharing her (woman) fate, was possible. And though he (Wildeve) meant to adhere to Eustacia's instructions to the letter, to deposit her (Eustacia) where she (Eustacia) wished and to leave her (Eustacia), should that be her (Eustacia) will, the spell that she (Eustacia) had cast over him (Wildeve) intensified, and his (Wildeve) heart was beating fast in the anticipated futility of such commands in the face of a mutual wish that they should throw in their lot together.

He (Wildeve) would not allow himself to dwell long upon these conjectures, maxims, and hopes, and at twenty minutes to twelve he (Wildeve) again went softly to the stable, harnessed the horse, and lit the lamps; whence, taking the horse by the head, he (Wildeve) led him (Wildeve) with the covered car out of the yard to a spot by the roadside some quarter of a mile below the inn.

Here Wildeve waited, slightly sheltered from the driving rain by a high bank that had been cast up at this place. Along the surface of the road where lit by the lamps the loosened gravel and small stones scudded and clicked together before the wind, which, leaving them in heaps, plunged into the heath and boomed across the bushes into darkness. Only one sound rose above this din of weather, and that was the roaring of a ten-hatch weir to the southward, from a river in the meads which formed the boundary of the heath in this direction.

He (them) lingered on in perfect stillness till he (them) began to fancy that the midnight hour must have struck. A very strong doubt had arisen in his (them) mind if Eustacia would venture down the hill in such weather; yet knowing her (Eustacia) nature he (them) felt that she (Eustacia) might.

``Poor thing! `tis like her (I) ill-luck,'' (he)
he (them) murmured.

At length he (them) turned to the lamp and looked at his (them) watch. To his (them) surprise it was nearly a quarter past midnight. He (them) now wished that he (them) had driven up the circuitous road to Mistover, a plan not adopted because of the enormous length of the route in proportion to that of the pedestrian's path down the open hillside, and the consequent increase of labour for the horse.

At this moment a footstep approached; but the light of the lamps being in a different direction the comer was not visible. The step paused, then came on again.

``Eustacia?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve.

The person came forward, and the light fell upon the form of Clym, glistening with wet, whom Wildeve immediately recognized; but Wildeve, who stood behind the lamp, was not at once recognized by Yeobright.

He (Wildeve) stopped as if in doubt whether this waiting vehicle could have anything to do with the flight of his (Wildeve) wife or not. The sight of Yeobright at once banished Wildeve's sober feelings, who saw him (Wildeve) again as the deadly rival from whom Eustacia was to be kept at all hazards. Hence Wildeve did not speak, in the hope that Clym would pass by without particular inquiry.

While they both hung thus in hesitation a dull sound became audible above the storm and wind. Its origin was unmistakable--it was the fall of a body into the stream in the adjoining mead, apparently at a point near the weir.

Both started.

``Good God! can it be she (I)?'' (unknown)
said Clym.

``Why should it be she (I)?'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
said Wildeve, in his (Wildeve) alarm forgetting that he (Wildeve) had hitherto screened himself.

``Ah!--that's you, you traitor, is it?'' (Yeobright)
cried Yeobright.
``Why should it be she (I)? Because last week she (I) would have put an end to her (I) life if she (I) had been able. She (I) ought to have been watched! Take one of the lamps and come with me.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright seized the one on his (Wildeve) side and hastened on; Wildeve did not wait to unfasten the other, but followed at once along the meadow track to the weir, a little in the rear of Clym.

Shadwater Weir had at its foot a large circular pool, fifty feet in diameter, into which the water flowed through ten huge hatches, raised and lowered by a winch and cogs in the ordinary manner. The sides of the pool were of masonry, to prevent the water from washing away the bank; but the force of the stream in winter was sometimes such as to undermine the retaining wall and precipitate it into the hole. Clym reached the hatches, the framework of which was shaken to its foundations by the velocity of the current. Nothing but the froth of the waves could be discerned in the pool below. He (its) got upon the plank bridge over the race, and holding to the rail, that the wind might not blow him (its) off, crossed to the other side of the river. There he (its) leant over the wall and lowered the lamp, only to behold the vortex formed at the curl of the returning current.

Wildeve meanwhile had arrived on the former side, and the light from Yeobright's lamp shed a flecked and agitated radiance across the weir pool, revealing to the ex-engineer the tumbling courses of the currents from the hatches above. Across this gashed and puckered mirror a dark body was slowly borne by one of the backward currents.

``O, my darling!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)
exclaimed Wildeve in an agonized voice; and, without showing sufficient presence of mind even to throw off his (Wildeve) greatcoat, he (Wildeve) leaped into the boiling caldron.

Yeobright could now also discern the floating body, though but indistinctly; and imagining from Wildeve's plunge that there was life to be saved he (Wildeve) was about to leap after. Bethinking himself of a wiser plan, he (Wildeve) placed the lamp against a post to make it stand upright, and running round to the lower part of the pool, where there was no wall, he (Wildeve) sprang in and boldly waded upwards towards the deeper portion. Here he (Wildeve) was taken off his (Wildeve) legs, and in swimming was carried round into the centre of the basin, where he (Wildeve) perceived Wildeve struggling.

While these hasty actions were in progress here, Venn and Thomasin had been toiling through the lower corner of the heath in the direction of the light. They had not been near enough to the river to hear the plunge, but they saw the removal of the carriage lamp, and watched its motion into the mead. As soon as they reached the car and horse Venn guessed that something new was amiss, and hastened to follow in the course of the moving light. Venn walked faster than Thomasin, and came to the weir alone.

The lamp placed against the post by Clym still shone across the water, and the reddleman observed something floating motionless. Being encumbered with the infant, he (Venn) ran back to meet Thomasin.

``Take the baby, please, Mrs. Wildeve,'' (he)
he (Venn) said hastily.
``Run home with her (Wildeve), call the stable lad, and make him (lad) send down to me any men who may be living near. Somebody has fallen into the weir.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin took the child and ran. When she (they) came to the covered car the horse, though fresh from the stable, was standing perfectly still, as if conscious of misfortune. She (they) saw for the first time whose it was. She (they) nearly fainted, and would have been unable to proceed another step but that the necessity of preserving the little girl from harm nerved her (girl) to an amazing self-control. In this agony of suspense she (girl) entered the house, put the baby in a place of safety, woke the lad and the female domestic, and ran out to give the alarm at the nearest cottage.

Diggory, having returned to the brink of the pool, observed that the small upper hatches or floats were withdrawn. He (Diggory) found one of these lying upon the grass, and taking it under one arm, and with his (Diggory) lantern in his (Diggory) hand, entered at the bottom of the pool as Clym had done. As soon as he (Diggory) began to be in deep water he (Diggory) flung himself across the hatch; thus supported he (Diggory) was able to keep afloat as long as he (Diggory) chose, holding the lantern aloft with his (Diggory) disengaged hand. Propelled by his (Diggory) feet, he (Diggory) steered round and round the pool, ascending each time by one of the back streams and descending in the middle of the current.

At first he (Diggory) could see nothing. Then amidst the glistening of the whirlpools and the white clots of foam he (Diggory) distinguished a woman's bonnet floating alone. His (Diggory) search was now under the left wall, when something came to the surface almost close beside him (Diggory). It was not, as he (Diggory) had expected, a woman, but a man. The reddleman put the ring of the lantern between his (Diggory) teeth, seized the floating man by the collar, and, holding on to the hatch with his (Diggory) remaining arm, struck out into the strongest race, by which the unconscious man, the hatch, and himself were carried down the stream. As soon as Venn found his (Venn) feet dragging over the pebbles of the shallower part below he (Venn) secured his (Venn) footing and waded towards the brink. There, where the water stood at about the height of his (Venn) waist, he (Venn) flung away the hatch, and attempted to drag forth the man. This was a matter of great difficulty, and he (man) found as the reason that the legs of the unfortunate stranger were tightly embraced by the arms of another man, who had hitherto been entirely beneath the surface.

At this moment his (man) heart bounded to hear footsteps running towards him (man), and two men, roused by Thomasin, appeared at the brink above. They ran to where Venn was, and helped him (Venn) in lifting out the apparently drowned persons, separating them, and laying them out upon the grass. Venn turned the light upon their faces. The one who had been uppermost was Yeobright; he (Venn) who had been completely submerged was Wildeve.

``Now we must search the hole again,'' (unknown)
said Venn.
``A woman is in there somewhere. Get a pole.'' (the men)

One of the men went to the footbridge and tore off the handrail. The reddleman and the two others then entered the water together from below as before, and with their united force probed the pool forwards to where it sloped down to its central depth. Venn was not mistaken in supposing that any person who had sunk for the last time would be washed down to this point, for when they had examined to about halfway across something impeded their thrust.

``Pull it forward,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn, and they raked it in with the pole till it was close to their feet.

Venn vanished under the stream, and came up with an armful of wet drapery enclosing a woman's cold form, which was all that remained of the desperate Eustacia.

When they reached the bank there stood Thomasin, in a stress of grief, bending over the two unconscious ones who already lay there. The horse and cart were brought to the nearest point in the road, and it was the work of a few minutes only to place the three in the vehicle. Venn led on the horse, supporting Thomasin upon his (Venn) arm, and the two men followed, till they reached the inn.

The woman who had been shaken out of her (woman) sleep by Thomasin had hastily dressed herself and lighted a fire, the other servant being left to snore on in peace at the back of the house. The insensible forms of Eustacia, Clym, and Wildeve were then brought in and laid on the carpet, with their feet to the fire, when such restorative processes as could be thought of were adopted at once, the stableman being in the meantime sent for a doctor. But there seemed to be not a whiff of life in either of the bodies. Then Thomasin, whose stupor of grief had been thrust off awhile by frantic action, applied a bottle of hartshorn to Clym's nostrils, having tried it in vain upon the other two. He (doctor) sighed.

``Clym's alive!'' (she)
she (it) exclaimed.

He (doctor) soon breathed distinctly, and again and again did she (it) attempt to revive her (it) husband by the same means; but Wildeve gave no sign. There was too much reason to think that he (Wildeve) and Eustacia both were for ever beyond the reach of stimulating perfumes. Their exertions did not relax till the doctor arrived, when one by one, the senseless three were taken upstairs and put into warm beds.

Venn soon felt himself relieved from further attendance, and went to the door, scarcely able yet to realize the strange catastrophe that had befallen the family in which he (Venn) took so great an interest. Thomasin surely would be broken down by the sudden and overwhelming nature of this event. No firm and sensible Mrs. Yeobright lived now to support the gentle girl through the ordeal; and, whatever an unimpassioned spectator might think of her (Yeobright) loss of such a husband as Wildeve, there could be no doubt that for the moment she (Yeobright) was distracted and horrified by the blow. As for himself, not being privileged to go to her (Yeobright) and comfort her (Yeobright), he (husband) saw no reason for waiting longer in a house where he (husband) remained only as a stranger.

He (husband) returned across the heath to his (husband) van. The fire was not yet out, and everything remained as he (husband) had left it. Venn now bethought himself of his (Venn) clothes, which were saturated with water to the weight of lead. He (Venn) changed them, spread them before the fire, and lay down to sleep. But it was more than he (Venn) could do to rest here while excited by a vivid imagination of the turmoil they were in at the house he (Venn) had quitted, and, blaming himself for coming away, he (Venn) dressed in another suit, locked up the door, and again hastened across to the inn. Rain was still falling heavily when he (Venn) entered the kitchen. A bright fire was shining from the hearth, and two women were bustling about, one of whom was Olly Dowden.

``Well, how is it going on now?'' (unknown)
said Venn in a whisper.

``Mr. Yeobright is better; but Mrs. Yeobright and Mr. Wildeve are dead and cold. The doctor says they were quite gone before they were out of the water.'' (unknown)

``Ah! I thought as much when I hauled `em up. And Mrs. Wildeve?'' (unknown)

``She (Wildeve) is as well as can be expected. The doctor had her (Wildeve) put between blankets, for she (Wildeve) was almost as wet as they that had been in the river, poor young thing. You don't seem very dry, reddleman.'' (unknown)

``Oh, `tis not much. I have changed my things. This is only a little dampness I've got coming through the rain again.'' (unknown)

``Stand by the fire. Mis'ess says you be to have whatever you want, and she (Wildeve) was sorry when she (Wildeve) was told that you'd gone away.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn drew near to the fireplace, and looked into the flames in an absent mood. The steam came from his (Venn) leggings and ascended the chimney with the smoke, while he (Venn) thought of those who were upstairs. Two were corpses, one had barely escaped the jaws of death, another was sick and a widow. The last occasion on which he (Venn) had lingered by that fireplace was when the raffle was in progress; when Wildeve was alive and well; Thomasin active and smiling in the next room; Yeobright and Eustacia just made husband and wife, and Mrs. Yeobright living at Blooms-End. It had seemed at that time that the then position of affairs was good for at least twenty years to come. Yet, of all the circle, he (husband) himself was the only one whose situation had not materially changed.

While he (husband) ruminated a footstep descended the stairs. It was the nurse, who brought in her (nurse) hand a rolled mass of wet paper. The woman was so engrossed with her (woman) occupation that she (woman) hardly saw Venn. She (woman) took from a cupboard some pieces of twine, which she (woman) strained across the fireplace, tying the end of each piece to the firedog, previously pulled forward for the purpose, and, unrolling the wet papers, she (woman) began pinning them one by one to the strings in a manner of clothes on a line.

``What be they?'' (unknown)
said Venn.

``Poor master's banknotes,'' (she)
she (woman) answered.
``They were found in his (master) pocket when they undressed him (master).'' (unknown)

``Then he (master) was not coming back again for some time?'' (unknown)
said Venn.

``That we shall never know,'' (she)
said she (woman).

Venn was loth to depart, for all on earth that interested him (Venn) lay under this roof. As nobody in the house had any more sleep that night, except the two who slept for ever, there was no reason why he (Venn) should not remain. So he (Venn) retired into the niche of the fireplace where he (Venn) had used to sit, and there he (Venn) continued, watching the steam from the double row of banknotes as they waved backwards and forwards in the draught of the chimney till their flaccidity was changed to dry crispness throughout. Then the woman came and unpinned them, and, folding them together, carried the handful upstairs. Presently the doctor appeared from above with the look of a man who could do no more, and, pulling on his (man) gloves, went out of the house, the trotting of his (man) horse soon dying away upon the road.

At four o’clock there was a gentle knock at the door. It was from Charley, who had been sent by Captain Vye to inquire if anything had been heard of Eustacia. The girl who admitted him (Captain) looked in his (Captain) face as if she (Eustacia) did not know what answer to return, and showed him (Captain) in to where Venn was seated, saying to the reddleman,

``Will you tell him (master), please?'' (the reddleman)

Venn told. Charley's only utterance was a feeble, indistinct sound. He (Venn) stood quite still; then he (Venn) burst out spasmodically,

``I shall see her (Wildeve) once more?'' (he)

``I dare say you may see her (Wildeve),'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Diggory gravely.
``But hadn't you better run and tell Captain Vye?'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes. Only I do hope I shall see her (Wildeve) just once again.'' (unknown)

``You shall,'' (Lazarus)
said a low voice behind; and starting round they beheld by the dim light, a thin, pallid, almost spectral form, wrapped in a blanket, and looking like Lazarus coming from the tomb.

It was Yeobright. Neither Venn nor Charley spoke, and Clym continued,

``You shall see her (Wildeve). There will be time enough to tell the captain when it gets daylight. You would like to see her (Wildeve) too--would you not, Diggory? She (Wildeve) looks very beautiful now.'' (Charley)

Venn assented by rising to his (Venn) feet, and with Charley he (Venn) followed Clym to the foot of the staircase, where he (Venn) took off his (Venn) boots; Charley did the same. They followed Yeobright upstairs to the landing, where there was a candle burning, which Yeobright took in his (Charley) hand, and with it led the way into an adjoining room. Here he (Charley) went to the bedside and folded back the sheet.

They stood silently looking upon Eustacia, who, as she (Eustacia) lay there still in death, eclipsed all her (Eustacia) living phases. Pallor did not include all the quality of her (Eustacia) complexion, which seemed more than whiteness; it was almost light. The expression of her (Eustacia) finely carved mouth was pleasant, as if a sense of dignity had just compelled her (Eustacia) to leave off speaking. Eternal rigidity had seized upon it in a momentary transition between fervour and resignation. Her (Eustacia) black hair was looser now than either of them had ever seen it before, and surrounded her (Eustacia) brow like a forest. The stateliness of look which had been almost too marked for a dweller in a country domicile had at last found an artistically happy background.

Nobody spoke, till at length Clym covered her (Eustacia) and turned aside.

``Now come here,'' (he)
he (Eustacia) said.

They went to a recess in the same room, and there, on a smaller bed, lay another figure--Wildeve. Less repose was visible in his (Wildeve) face than in Eustacia's, but the same luminous youthfulness overspread it, and the least sympathetic observer would have felt at sight of him (Wildeve) now that he (Wildeve) was born for a higher destiny than this. The only sign upon him (Wildeve) of his (Wildeve) recent struggle for life was in his (Wildeve) fingertips, which were worn and sacrificed in his (Wildeve) dying endeavours to obtain a hold on the face of the weir-wall.

Yeobright's manner had been so quiet, he (Wildeve) had uttered so few syllables since his (Wildeve) reappearance, that Venn imagined him (Venn) resigned. It was only when they had left the room and stood upon the landing that the true state of his (Venn) mind was apparent. Here he (Venn) said, with a wild smile, inclining his (Venn) head towards the chamber in which Eustacia lay,

``She (Wildeve) is the second woman I have killed this year. I was a great cause of my mother's death, and I am the chief cause of hers.'' (Eustacia/Miss Eustacia/EUSTACIA)

``How?'' (unknown)
said Venn.

``I spoke cruel words to her (mother), and she (mother) left my house. I did not invite her (mother) back till it was too late. It is I who ought to have drowned myself. It would have been a charity to the living had the river overwhelmed me and borne her (mother) up. But I cannot die. Those who ought to have lived lie dead; and here am I alive!'' (unknown)

``But you can't charge yourself with crimes in that way,'' (unknown)
said Venn.
``You may as well say that the parents be the cause of a murder by the child, for without the parents the child would never have been begot.'' (unknown)

``Yes, Venn, that is very true; but you don't know all the circumstances. If it had pleased God to put an end to me it would have been a good thing for all. But I am getting used to the horror of my existence. They say that a time comes when men laugh at misery through long acquaintance with it. Surely that time will soon come to me!'' (unknown)

``Your aim has always been good,'' (unknown)
said Venn.
``Why should you say such desperate things?'' (unknown)

``No, they are not desperate. They are only hopeless; and my great regret is that for what I have done no man or law can punish me!'' (Wildeve/Mr. Wildeve/MR. WILDEVE)

BOOK SIX -- AFTERCOURSES

1--The Inevitable Movement Onward

The story of the deaths of Eustacia and Wildeve was told throughout Egdon, and far beyond, for many weeks and months. All the known incidents of their love were enlarged, distorted, touched up, and modified, till the original reality bore but a slight resemblance to the counterfeit presentation by surrounding tongues. Yet, upon the whole, neither the man nor the woman lost dignity by sudden death. Misfortune had struck them gracefully, cutting off their erratic histories with a catastrophic dash, instead of, as with many, attenuating each life to an uninteresting meagreness, through long years of wrinkles, neglect, and decay.

On those most nearly concerned the effect was somewhat different. Strangers who had heard of many such cases now merely heard of one more; but immediately where a blow falls no previous imaginings amount to appreciable preparation for it. The very suddenness of her (woman) bereavement dulled, to some extent, Thomasin's feelings; yet irrationally enough, a consciousness that the husband she (woman) had lost ought to have been a better man did not lessen her (woman) mourning at all. On the contrary, this fact seemed at first to set off the dead husband in his (husband) young wife's eyes, and to be the necessary cloud to the rainbow.

But the horrors of the unknown had passed. Vague misgivings about her (wife) future as a deserted wife were at an end. The worst had once been matter of trembling conjecture; it was now matter of reason only, a limited badness. Her (wife) chief interest, the little Eustacia, still remained. There was humility in her (wife) grief, no defiance in her (wife) attitude; and when this is the case a shaken spirit is apt to be stilled.

Could Thomasin's mournfulness now and Eustacia's serenity during life have been reduced to common measure, they would have touched the same mark nearly. But Thomasin's former brightness made shadow of that which in a sombre atmosphere was light itself.

The spring came and calmed her (Eustacia); the summer came and soothed her (Eustacia); the autumn arrived, and she (Eustacia) began to be comforted, for her (Eustacia) little girl was strong and happy, growing in size and knowledge every day. Outward events flattered Thomasin not a little. Wildeve had died intestate, and she (Eustacia) and the child were his (Wildeve) only relatives. When administration had been granted, all the debts paid, and the residue of her (Eustacia) husband's uncle's property had come into her (Eustacia) hands, it was found that the sum waiting to be invested for her (Eustacia) own and the child's benefit was little less than ten thousand pounds.

Where should she (Eustacia) live? The obvious place was Blooms-End. The old rooms, it is true, were not much higher than the between-decks of a frigate, necessitating a sinking in the floor under the new clock-case she (Eustacia) brought from the inn, and the removal of the handsome brass knobs on its head, before there was height for it to stand; but, such as the rooms were, there were plenty of them, and the place was endeared to her (Eustacia) by every early recollection. Clym very gladly admitted her (Eustacia) as a tenant, confining his (them) own existence to two rooms at the top of the back staircase, where he (them) lived on quietly, shut off from Thomasin and the three servants she (Eustacia) had thought fit to indulge in now that she (Eustacia) was a mistress of money, going his (them) own ways, and thinking his (them) own thoughts.

His (them) sorrows had made some change in his (them) outward appearance; and yet the alteration was chiefly within. It might have been said that he (them) had a wrinkled mind. He (them) had no enemies, and he (them) could get nobody to reproach him (them), which was why he (them) so bitterly reproached himself.

He (them) did sometimes think he (them) had been ill-used by fortune, so far as to say that to be born is a palpable dilemma, and that instead of men aiming to advance in life with glory they should calculate how to retreat out of it without shame. But that he (them) and his (them) had been sarcastically and pitilessly handled in having such irons thrust into their souls he (them) did not maintain long. It is usually so, except with the sternest of men. Human beings, in their generous endeavour to construct a hypothesis that shall not degrade a First Cause, have always hesitated to conceive a dominant power of lower moral quality than their own; and, even while they sit down and weep by the waters of Babylon, invent excuses for the oppression which prompts their tears.

Thus, though words of solace were vainly uttered in his (them) presence, he (them) found relief in a direction of his (them) own choosing when left to himself. For a man of his (them) habits the house and the hundred and twenty pounds a year which he (them) had inherited from his (them) mother were enough to supply all worldly needs. Resources do not depend upon gross amounts, but upon the proportion of spendings to takings.

He (them) frequently walked the heath alone, when the past seized upon him (them) with its shadowy hand, and held him (them) there to listen to its tale. His (them) imagination would then people the spot with its ancient inhabitants--forgotten Celtic tribes trod their tracks about him (them), and he (them) could almost live among them, look in their faces, and see them standing beside the barrows which swelled around, untouched and perfect as at the time of their erection. Those of the dyed barbarians who had chosen the cultivable tracts were, in comparison with those who had left their marks here, as writers on paper beside writers on parchment. Their records had perished long ago by the plough, while the works of these remained. Yet they all had lived and died unconscious of the different fates awaiting their relics. It reminded him (them) that unforeseen factors operate in the evolution of immortality.

Winter again came round, with its winds, frosts, tame robins, and sparkling starlight. The year previous Thomasin had hardly been conscious of the season's advance; this year she (their) laid her (their) heart open to external influences of every kind. The life of this sweet cousin, her (their) baby, and her (their) servants, came to Clym's senses only in the form of sounds through a wood partition as he (cousin) sat over books of exceptionally large type; but his (cousin) ear became at last so accustomed to these slight noises from the other part of the house that he (cousin) almost could witness the scenes they signified. A faint beat of half-seconds conjured up Thomasin rocking the cradle, a wavering hum meant that she (their) was singing the baby to sleep, a crunching of sand as between millstones raised the picture of Humphrey's, Fairway's, or Sam's heavy feet crossing the stone floor of the kitchen; a light boyish step, and a gay tune in a high key, betokened a visit from Grandfer Cantle; a sudden break-off in the Grandfer's utterances implied the application to his (Sam) lips of a mug of small beer, a bustling and slamming of doors meant starting to go to market; for Thomasin, in spite of her (their) added scope of gentility, led a ludicrously narrow life, to the end that she (their) might save every possible pound for her (their) little daughter.

One summer day Clym was in the garden, immediately outside the parlour window, which was as usual open. He (Sam) was looking at the pot-flowers on the sill; they had been revived and restored by Thomasin to the state in which his (Sam) mother had left them. He (Sam) heard a slight scream from Thomasin, who was sitting inside the room.

``O, how you frightened me!'' (she)
she (mother) said to someone who had entered.
``I thought you were the ghost of yourself.'' (unknown)

Clym was curious enough to advance a little further and look in at the window. To his (Sam) astonishment there stood within the room Diggory Venn, no longer a reddleman, but exhibiting the strangely altered hues of an ordinary Christian countenance, white shirt-front, light flowered waistcoat, blue-spotted neckerchief, and bottle-green coat. Nothing in this appearance was at all singular but the fact of its great difference from what he (Venn) had formerly been. Red, and all approach to red, was carefully excluded from every article of clothes upon him (Venn); for what is there that persons just out of harness dread so much as reminders of the trade which has enriched them?

Yeobright went round to the door and entered.

``I was so alarmed!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin, smiling from one to the other.
``I couldn't believe that he (man) had got white of his (man) own accord! It seemed supernatural.'' (unknown)

``I gave up dealing in reddle last Christmas,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn.
``It was a profitable trade, and I found that by that time I had made enough to take the dairy of fifty cows that my father had in his (father) lifetime. I always thought of getting to that place again if I changed at all, and now I am there.'' (unknown)

``How did you manage to become white, Diggory?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
Thomasin asked.

``I turned so by degrees, ma’am.'' (unknown)

``You look much better than ever you did before.'' (unknown)

Venn appeared confused; and Thomasin, seeing how inadvertently she (Venn) had spoken to a man who might possibly have tender feelings for her (Venn) still, blushed a little. Clym saw nothing of this, and added good-humouredly--

``What shall we have to frighten Thomasin's baby with, now you have become a human being again?'' (unknown)

``Sit down, Diggory,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin,
``and stay to tea.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Venn moved as if he (Venn) would retire to the kitchen, when Thomasin said with pleasant pertness as she (Venn) went on with some sewing,

``Of course you must sit down here. And where does your fifty-cow dairy lie, Mr. Venn?'' (she)

``At Stickleford--about two miles to the right of Alderworth, ma’am, where the meads begin. I have thought that if Mr. Yeobright would like to pay me a visit sometimes he (Yeobright) shouldn't stay away for want of asking. I'll not bide to tea this afternoon, thank'ee, for I've got something on hand that must be settled. `Tis Maypole-day tomorrow, and the Shadwater folk have clubbed with a few of your neighbours here to have a pole just outside your palings in the heath, as it is a nice green place.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
Venn waved his (Venn) elbow towards the patch in front of the house.
``I have been talking to Fairway about it,'' (he)
he (Venn) continued,
``and I said to him (Yeobright) that before we put up the pole it would be as well to ask Mrs. Wildeve.'' (he)

``I can say nothing against it,'' (she)
she (Venn) answered.
``Our property does not reach an inch further than the white palings.'' (unknown)

``But you might not like to see a lot of folk going crazy round a stick, under your very nose?'' (unknown)

``I shall have no objection at all.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Venn soon after went away, and in the evening Yeobright strolled as far as Fairway's cottage. It was a lovely May sunset, and the birch trees which grew on this margin of the vast Egdon wilderness had put on their new leaves, delicate as butterflies' wings, and diaphanous as amber. Beside Fairway's dwelling was an open space recessed from the road, and here were now collected all the young people from within a radius of a couple of miles. The pole lay with one end supported on a trestle, and women were engaged in wreathing it from the top downwards with wild-flowers. The instincts of merry England lingered on here with exceptional vitality, and the symbolic customs which tradition has attached to each season of the year were yet a reality on Egdon. Indeed, the impulses of all such outlandish hamlets are pagan still--in these spots homage to nature, self-adoration, frantic gaieties, fragments of Teutonic rites to divinities whose names are forgotten, seem in some way or other to have survived mediaeval doctrine.

Yeobright did not interrupt the preparations, and went home again. The next morning, when Thomasin withdrew the curtains of her (Egdon) bedroom window, there stood the Maypole in the middle of the green, its top cutting into the sky. It had sprung up in the night, or rather early morning, like Jack's bean-stalk. She (Egdon) opened the casement to get a better view of the garlands and posies that adorned it. The sweet perfume of the flowers had already spread into the surrounding air, which, being free from every taint, conducted to her (Egdon) lips a full measure of the fragrance received from the spire of blossom in its midst. At the top of the pole were crossed hoops decked with small flowers; beneath these came a milk-white zone of Maybloom; then a zone of bluebells, then of cowslips, then of lilacs, then of ragged-robins, daffodils, and so on, till the lowest stage was reached. Thomasin noticed all these, and was delighted that the May revel was to be so near.

When afternoon came people began to gather on the green, and Yeobright was interested enough to look out upon them from the open window of his (Thomasin) room. Soon after this Thomasin walked out from the door immediately below and turned her (Thomasin) eyes up to her (Thomasin) cousin's face. She (Thomasin) was dressed more gaily than Yeobright had ever seen her (Thomasin) dressed since the time of Wildeve's death, eighteen months before; since the day of her (Thomasin) marriage even she (Thomasin) had not exhibited herself to such advantage.

``How pretty you look today, Thomasin!'' (he)
he (Wildeve) said.
``Is it because of the Maypole?'' (unknown)

``Not altogether.'' (she)
And then she (Thomasin) blushed and dropped her (Thomasin) eyes, which he (Wildeve) did not specially observe, though her (Thomasin) manner seemed to him (Wildeve) to be rather peculiar, considering that she (Thomasin) was only addressing himself. Could it be possible that she (Thomasin) had put on her (Thomasin) summer clothes to please him (Wildeve)?

He (Wildeve) recalled her (Thomasin) conduct towards him (Wildeve) throughout the last few weeks, when they had often been working together in the garden, just as they had formerly done when they were boy and girl under his (boy) mother's eye. What if her (mother) interest in him (boy) were not so entirely that of a relative as it had formerly been? To Yeobright any possibility of this sort was a serious matter; and he (boy) almost felt troubled at the thought of it. Every pulse of loverlike feeling which had not been stilled during Eustacia's lifetime had gone into the grave with her (Eustacia). His (boy) passion for her (Eustacia) had occurred too far on in his (boy) manhood to leave fuel enough on hand for another fire of that sort, as may happen with more boyish loves. Even supposing him (boy) capable of loving again, that love would be a plant of slow and laboured growth, and in the end only small and sickly, like an autumn-hatched bird.

He (boy) was so distressed by this new complexity that when the enthusiastic brass band arrived and struck up, which it did about five o’clock, with apparently wind enough among its members to blow down his (boy) house, he (boy) withdrew from his (boy) rooms by the back door, went down the garden, through the gate in the hedge, and away out of sight. He (boy) could not bear to remain in the presence of enjoyment today, though he (boy) had tried hard.

Nothing was seen of him (boy) for four hours. When he (boy) came back by the same path it was dusk, and the dews were coating every green thing. The boisterous music had ceased; but, entering the premises as he (boy) did from behind, he (boy) could not see if the May party had all gone till he (boy) had passed through Thomasin's division of the house to the front door. Thomasin was standing within the porch alone.

She (boy) looked at him (boy) reproachfully.

``You went away just when it began, Clym,'' (she)
she (boy) said.

``Yes. I felt I could not join in. You went out with them, of course?'' (unknown)

``No, I did not.'' (unknown)

``You appeared to be dressed on purpose.'' (unknown)

``Yes, but I could not go out alone; so many people were there. One is there now.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright strained his (boy) eyes across the dark-green patch beyond the paling, and near the black form of the Maypole he (boy) discerned a shadowy figure, sauntering idly up and down.

``Who is it?'' (he)
he (boy) said.

``Mr. Venn,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin.

``You might have asked him (Venn) to come in, I think, Tamsie. He (Venn) has been very kind to you first and last.'' (unknown)

``I will now,'' (she)
she (boy) said; and, acting on the impulse, went through the wicket to where Venn stood under the Maypole.

``It is Mr. Venn, I think?'' (she)
she (boy) inquired.

Venn started as if he (Venn) had not seen her (boy)--artful man that he (Venn) was--and said,

``Yes.'' (he)

``Will you come in?'' (unknown)

``I am afraid that I--'' (unknown)

``I have seen you dancing this evening, and you had the very best of the girls for your partners. Is it that you won't come in because you wish to stand here, and think over the past hours of enjoyment?'' (unknown)

``Well, that's partly it,'' (Mr. Venn)
said Mr. Venn, with ostentatious sentiment.
``But the main reason why I am biding here like this is that I want to wait till the moon rises.'' (unknown)

``To see how pretty the Maypole looks in the moonlight?'' (unknown)

``No. To look for a glove that was dropped by one of the maidens.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin was speechless with surprise. That a man who had to walk some four or five miles to his (man) home should wait here for such a reason pointed to only one conclusion--the man must be amazingly interested in that glove's owner.

``Were you dancing with her (it), Diggory?'' (she)
she (boy) asked, in a voice which revealed that he (owner) had made himself considerably more interesting to her (boy) by this disclosure.

``No,'' (he)
he (owner) sighed.

``And you will not come in, then?'' (unknown)

``Not tonight, thank you, ma’am.'' (unknown)

``Shall I lend you a lantern to look for the young person's glove, Mr. Venn?'' (unknown)

``O no; it is not necessary, Mrs. Wildeve, thank you. The moon will rise in a few minutes.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin went back to the porch.

``Is he (Venn) coming in?'' (she)
said Clym, who had been waiting where she (boy) had left him (owner).

``He (Venn) would rather not tonight,'' (she)
she (boy) said, and then passed by him (owner) into the house; whereupon Clym too retired to his (owner) own rooms.

When Clym was gone Thomasin crept upstairs in the dark, and, just listening by the cot, to assure herself that the child was asleep, she (boy) went to the window, gently lifted the corner of the white curtain, and looked out. Venn was still there. She (boy) watched the growth of the faint radiance appearing in the sky by the eastern hill, till presently the edge of the moon burst upwards and flooded the valley with light. Diggory's form was now distinct on the green; he (Diggory) was moving about in a bowed attitude, evidently scanning the grass for the precious missing article, walking in zigzags right and left till he (Diggory) should have passed over every foot of the ground.

``How very ridiculous!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
Thomasin murmured to herself, in a tone which was intended to be satirical.
``To think that a man should be so silly as to go mooning about like that for a girl's glove! A respectable dairyman, too, and a man of money as he (man) is now. What a pity!'' (unknown)

At last Venn appeared to find it; whereupon he (Diggory) stood up and raised it to his (Diggory) lips. Then placing it in his (Diggory) breastpocket--the nearest receptacle to a man's heart permitted by modern raiment--he (Diggory) ascended the valley in a mathematically direct line towards his (Diggory) distant home in the meadows.

2--Thomasin Walks in a Green Place by the Roman Road

Clym saw little of Thomasin for several days after this; and when they met she (it) was more silent than usual. At length he (Roman) asked her (it) what she (it) was thinking of so intently.

``I am thoroughly perplexed,'' (she)
she (it) said candidly.
``I cannot for my life think who it is that Diggory Venn is so much in love with. None of the girls at the Maypole were good enough for him (Venn), and yet she (girl) must have been there.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Clym tried to imagine Venn's choice for a moment; but ceasing to be interested in the question he (Venn) went on again with his (Venn) gardening.

No clearing up of the mystery was granted her (it) for some time. But one afternoon Thomasin was upstairs getting ready for a walk, when she (it) had occasion to come to the landing and call

``Rachel.'' (she)
Rachel was a girl about thirteen, who carried the baby out for airings; and she (Rachel) came upstairs at the call.

``Have you seen one of my last new gloves about the house, Rachel?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
inquired Thomasin.
``It is the fellow to this one.'' (Rachel)

Rachel did not reply.

``Why don't you answer?'' (mistress)
said her (Rachel) mistress.

``I think it is lost, ma’am.'' (unknown)

``Lost? Who lost it? I have never worn them but once.'' (Rachel)

Rachel appeared as one dreadfully troubled, and at last began to cry.

``Please, ma’am, on the day of the Maypole I had none to wear, and I seed yours on the table, and I thought I would borrow `em. I did not mean to hurt `em at all, but one of them got lost. Somebody gave me some money to buy another pair for you, but I have not been able to go anywhere to get `em.'' (unknown)

``Who's somebody?'' (unknown)

``Mr. Venn.'' (unknown)

``Did he (Venn) know it was my glove?'' (unknown)

``Yes. I told him (Venn).'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Thomasin was so surprised by the explanation that she (Rachel) quite forgot to lecture the girl, who glided silently away. Thomasin did not move further than to turn her (Rachel) eyes upon the grass-plat where the Maypole had stood. She (Rachel) remained thinking, then said to herself that she (Rachel) would not go out that afternoon, but would work hard at the baby's unfinished lovely plaid frock, cut on the cross in the newest fashion. How she (Rachel) managed to work hard, and yet do no more than she (Rachel) had done at the end of two hours, would have been a mystery to anyone not aware that the recent incident was of a kind likely to divert her (Rachel) industry from a manual to a mental channel.

Next day she (Rachel) went her (Rachel) ways as usual, and continued her (Rachel) custom of walking in the heath with no other companion than little Eustacia, now of the age when it is a matter of doubt with such characters whether they are intended to walk through the world on their hands or on their feet; so that they get into painful complications by trying both. It was very pleasant to Thomasin, when she (Eustacia) had carried the child to some lonely place, to give her (Eustacia) a little private practice on the green turf and shepherd's-thyme, which formed a soft mat to fall headlong upon them when equilibrium was lost.

Once, when engaged in this system of training, and stooping to remove bits of stick, fern-stalks, and other such fragments from the child's path, that the journey might not be brought to an untimely end by some insuperable barrier a quarter of an inch high, she (Eustacia) was alarmed by discovering that a man on horseback was almost close beside her (Eustacia), the soft natural carpet having muffled the horse's tread. The rider, who was Venn, waved his (rider) hat in the air and bowed gallantly.

``Diggory, give me my glove,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin, whose manner it was under any circumstances to plunge into the midst of a subject which engrossed her (Eustacia).

Venn immediately dismounted, put his (Venn) hand in his (Venn) breastpocket, and handed the glove.

``Thank you. It was very good of you to take care of it.'' (unknown)

``It is very good of you to say so.'' (unknown)

``O no. I was quite glad to find you had it. Everybody gets so indifferent that I was surprised to know you thought of me.'' (unknown)

``If you had remembered what I was once you wouldn't have been surprised.'' (unknown)

``Ah, no,'' (she)
she (Eustacia) said quickly.
``But men of your character are mostly so independent.'' (unknown)

``What is my character?'' (he)
he (Venn) asked.

``I don't exactly know,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin simply,
``except it is to cover up your feelings under a practical manner, and only to show them when you are alone.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

``Ah, how do you know that?'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn strategically.

``Because,'' (she)
said she (Eustacia), stopping to put the little girl, who had managed to get herself upside down, right end up again,
``because I do.'' (the girl)

``You mustn't judge by folks in general,'' (unknown)
said Venn.
``Still I don't know much what feelings are nowadays. I have got so mixed up with business of one sort and t'other that my soft sentiments are gone off in vapour like. Yes, I am given up body and soul to the making of money. Money is all my dream.'' (unknown)

``O Diggory, how wicked!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin reproachfully, and looking at him (Venn) in exact balance between taking his (Venn) words seriously and judging them as said to tease her (Eustacia).

``Yes, `tis rather a rum course,'' (he)
said Venn, in the bland tone of one comfortably resigned to sins he (Venn) could no longer overcome.

``You, who used to be so nice!'' (unknown)

``Well, that's an argument I rather like, because what a man has once been he (man) may be again.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
Thomasin blushed.
``Except that it is rather harder now,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
Venn continued.

``Why?'' (she)
she (Eustacia) asked.

``Because you be richer than you were at that time.'' (unknown)

``O no--not much. I have made it nearly all over to the baby, as it was my duty to do, except just enough to live on.'' (unknown)

``I am rather glad of that,'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)
said Venn softly, and regarding her (Eustacia) from the corner of his (Venn) eye,
``for it makes it easier for us to be friendly.'' (Venn/Diggory/Diggory Venn)

Thomasin blushed again, and, when a few more words had been said of a not unpleasing kind, Venn mounted his (Venn) horse and rode on.

This conversation had passed in a hollow of the heath near the old Roman road, a place much frequented by Thomasin. And it might have been observed that she (Eustacia) did not in future walk that way less often from having met Venn there now. Whether or not Venn abstained from riding thither because he (Venn) had met Thomasin in the same place might easily have been guessed from her (Eustacia) proceedings about two months later in the same year.

3--The Serious Discourse of Clym with His (Venn) Cousin

Throughout this period Yeobright had more or less pondered on his (Venn) duty to his (Venn) cousin Thomasin. He (Venn) could not help feeling that it would be a pitiful waste of sweet material if the tender-natured thing should be doomed from this early stage of her (Eustacia) life onwards to dribble away her (Eustacia) winsome qualities on lonely gorse and fern. But he (Venn) felt this as an economist merely, and not as a lover. His (Venn) passion for Eustacia had been a sort of conserve of his (Venn) whole life, and he (Venn) had nothing more of that supreme quality left to bestow. So far the obvious thing was not to entertain any idea of marriage with Thomasin, even to oblige her (Eustacia).

But this was not all. Years ago there had been in his (Venn) mother's mind a great fancy about Thomasin and himself. It had not positively amounted to a desire, but it had always been a favourite dream. That they should be man and wife in good time, if the happiness of neither were endangered thereby, was the fancy in question. So that what course save one was there now left for any son who reverenced his (son) mother's memory as Yeobright did? It is an unfortunate fact that any particular whim of parents, which might have been dispersed by half an hour's conversation during their lives, becomes sublimated by their deaths into a fiat the most absolute, with such results to conscientious children as those parents, had they lived, would have been the first to decry.

Had only Yeobright's own future been involved he (son) would have proposed to Thomasin with a ready heart. He (son) had nothing to lose by carrying out a dead mother's hope. But he (son) dreaded to contemplate Thomasin wedded to the mere corpse of a lover that he (lover) now felt himself to be. He (lover) had but three activities alive in him (lover). One was his (lover) almost daily walk to the little graveyard wherein his (lover) mother lay, another, his (lover) just as frequent visits by night to the more distant enclosure which numbered his (lover) Eustacia among its dead; the third was self-preparation for a vocation which alone seemed likely to satisfy his (lover) cravings--that of an itinerant preacher of the eleventh commandment. It was difficult to believe that Thomasin would be cheered by a husband with such tendencies as these.

Yet he (husband) resolved to ask her (mother), and let her (mother) decide for herself. It was even with a pleasant sense of doing his (husband) duty that he (husband) went downstairs to her (mother) one evening for this purpose, when the sun was printing on the valley the same long shadow of the housetop that he (husband) had seen lying there times out of number while his (husband) mother lived.

Thomasin was not in her (mother) room, and he (husband) found her (mother) in the front garden.

``I have long been wanting, Thomasin,'' (he)
he (husband) began,
``to say something about a matter that concerns both our futures.'' (he)

``And you are going to say it now?'' (she)
she (mother) remarked quickly, colouring as she (mother) met his (husband) gaze.
``Do stop a minute, Clym, and let me speak first, for oddly enough, I have been wanting to say something to you.'' (unknown)

``By all means say on, Tamsie.'' (unknown)

``I suppose nobody can overhear us?'' (she)
she (mother) went on, casting her (mother) eyes around and lowering her (mother) voice.
``Well, first you will promise me this--that you won't be angry and call me anything harsh if you disagree with what I propose?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

Yeobright promised, and she (mother) continued:

``What I want is your advice, for you are my relation--I mean, a sort of guardian to me--aren't you, Clym?'' (she)

``Well, yes, I suppose I am; a sort of guardian. In fact, I am, of course,'' (he)
he (husband) said, altogether perplexed as to her (mother) drift.

``I am thinking of marrying,'' (she)
she (mother) then observed blandly.
``But I shall not marry unless you assure me that you approve of such a step. Why don't you speak?'' (unknown)

``I was taken rather by surprise. But, nevertheless, I am very glad to hear such news. I shall approve, of course, dear Tamsie. Who can it be? I am quite at a loss to guess. No I am not--`tis the old doctor!--not that I mean to call him (doctor) old, for he (doctor) is not very old after all. Ah--I noticed when he (doctor) attended you last time!'' (unknown)

``No, no,'' (she)
she (mother) said hastily. ```Tis Mr. Venn.''

Clym's face suddenly became grave.

``There, now, you don't like him (doctor), and I wish I hadn't mentioned him (doctor)!'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed almost petulantly.
``And I shouldn't have done it, either, only he (doctor) keeps on bothering me so till I don't know what to do!'' (unknown)

Clym looked at the heath.

``I like Venn well enough,'' (he)
he (Venn) answered at last.
``He (Venn) is a very honest and at the same time astute man. He (Venn) is clever too, as is proved by his (Venn) having got you to favour him (Venn). But really, Thomasin, he (Venn) is not quite--'' (unknown)

``Gentleman enough for me? That is just what I feel. I am sorry now that I asked you, and I won't think any more of him (Venn). At the same time I must marry him (Venn) if I marry anybody--that I WILL say!'' (unknown)

``I don't see that,'' (she)
said Clym, carefully concealing every clue to his (Venn) own interrupted intention, which she (mother) plainly had not guessed.
``You might marry a professional man, or somebody of that sort, by going into the town to live and forming acquaintances there.'' (unknown)

``I am not fit for town life--so very rural and silly as I always have been. Do not you yourself notice my countrified ways?'' (unknown)

``Well, when I came home from Paris I did, a little; but I don't now.'' (unknown)

``That's because you have got countrified too. O, I couldn't live in a street for the world! Egdon is a ridiculous old place; but I have got used to it, and I couldn't be happy anywhere else at all.'' (unknown)

``Neither could I,'' (unknown)
said Clym.

``Then how could you say that I should marry some town man? I am sure, say what you will, that I must marry Diggory, if I marry at all. He (Diggory) has been kinder to me than anybody else, and has helped me in many ways that I don't know of!'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
Thomasin almost pouted now.

``Yes, he (Diggory) has,'' (unknown)
said Clym in a neutral tone.
``Well, I wish with all my heart that I could say, marry him (Diggory). But I cannot forget what my mother thought on that matter, and it goes rather against me not to respect her (mother) opinion. There is too much reason why we should do the little we can to respect it now.'' (unknown)

``Very well, then,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
sighed Thomasin.
``I will say no more.'' (unknown)

``But you are not bound to obey my wishes. I merely say what I think.'' (unknown)

``O no--I don't want to be rebellious in that way,'' (she)
she (mother) said sadly.
``I had no business to think of him (you)--I ought to have thought of my family. What dreadfully bad impulses there are in me!'' (she)
Her (mother) lips trembled, and she (mother) turned away to hide a tear.

Clym, though vexed at what seemed her (mother) unaccountable taste, was in a measure relieved to find that at any rate the marriage question in relation to himself was shelved. Through several succeeding days he (Venn) saw her (mother) at different times from the window of his (Venn) room moping disconsolately about the garden. He (Venn) was half angry with her (mother) for choosing Venn; then he (Venn) was grieved at having put himself in the way of Venn's happiness, who was, after all, as honest and persevering a young fellow as any on Egdon, since he (Egdon) had turned over a new leaf. In short, Clym did not know what to do.

When next they met she (mother) said abruptly,

``He (you) is much more respectable now than he (you) was then!'' (she)

``Who? O yes--Diggory Venn.'' (unknown)

``Aunt only objected because he (Venn) was a reddleman.'' (unknown)

``Well, Thomasin, perhaps I don't know all the particulars of my mother's wish. So you had better use your own discretion.'' (unknown)

``You will always feel that I slighted your mother's memory.'' (unknown)

``No, I will not. I shall think you are convinced that, had she (mother) seen Diggory in his (Diggory) present position, she (mother) would have considered him (Diggory) a fitting husband for you. Now, that's my real feeling. Don't consult me any more, but do as you like, Thomasin. I shall be content.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

It is to be supposed that Thomasin was convinced; for a few days after this, when Clym strayed into a part of the heath that he (Egdon) had not lately visited, Humphrey, who was at work there, said to him (Humphrey),

``I am glad to see that Mrs. Wildeve and Venn have made it up again, seemingly.'' (him)

``Have they?'' (unknown)
said Clym abstractedly.

``Yes; and he (Venn) do contrive to stumble upon her (Wildeve) whenever she (Wildeve) walks out on fine days with the chiel. But, Mr. Yeobright, I can't help feeling that your cousin ought to have married you. `Tis a pity to make two chimleycorners where there need be only one. You could get her (Wildeve) away from him (cousin) now, `tis my belief, if you were only to set about it.'' (unknown)

``How can I have the conscience to marry after having driven two women to their deaths? Don't think such a thing, Humphrey. After my experience I should consider it too much of a burlesque to go to church and take a wife. In the words of Job, `I have made a covenant with mine eyes; when then should I think upon a maid?'''

``No, Mr. Clym, don't fancy that about driving two women to their deaths. You shouldn't say it.'' (unknown)

``Well, we'll leave that out,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.
``But anyhow God has set a mark upon me which wouldn't look well in a love-making scene. I have two ideas in my head, and no others. I am going to keep a night-school; and I am going to turn preacher. What have you got to say to that, Humphrey?'' (unknown)

``I'll come and hear `ee with all my heart.'' (unknown)

``Thanks. `Tis all I wish.'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)

As Clym descended into the valley Thomasin came down by the other path, and met him (Humphrey) at the gate.

``What do you think I have to tell you, Clym?'' (she)
she (mother) said, looking archly over her (mother) shoulder at him (Humphrey).

``I can guess,'' (he)
he (Humphrey) replied.

She (mother) scrutinized his (Humphrey) face.

``Yes, you guess right. It is going to be after all. He (Humphrey) thinks I may as well make up my mind, and I have got to think so too. It is to be on the twenty-fifth of next month, if you don't object.'' (unknown)

``Do what you think right, dear. I am only too glad that you see your way clear to happiness again. My sex owes you every amends for the treatment you received in days gone by.'' (The writer)
*

* The writer may state here that the original conception of the story did not design a marriage between Thomasin and Venn. He (Venn) was to have retained his (Venn) isolated and weird character to the last, and to have disappeared mysteriously from the heath, nobody knowing whither--Thomasin remaining a widow. But certain circumstances of serial publication led to a change of intent.

Readers can therefore choose between the endings, and those with an austere artistic code can assume the more consistent conclusion to be the true one.

4--Cheerfulness Again Asserts Itself at Blooms-End, and Clym Finds His (Venn) Vocation

Anybody who had passed through Blooms-End about eleven o’clock on the morning fixed for the wedding would have found that, while Yeobright's house was comparatively quiet, sounds denoting great activity came from the dwelling of his (Venn) nearest neighbour, Timothy Fairway. It was chiefly a noise of feet, briskly crunching hither and thither over the sanded floor within. One man only was visible outside, and he (man) seemed to be later at an appointment than he (man) had intended to be, for he (man) hastened up to the door, lifted the latch, and walked in without ceremony.

The scene within was not quite the customary one. Standing about the room was the little knot of men who formed the chief part of the Egdon coterie, there being present Fairway himself, Grandfer Cantle, Humphrey, Christian, and one or two turf-cutters. It was a warm day, and the men were as a matter of course in their shirtsleeves, except Christian, who had always a nervous fear of parting with a scrap of his (Christian) clothing when in anybody's house but his (Christian) own. Across the stout oak table in the middle of the room was thrown a mass of striped linen, which Grandfer Cantle held down on one side, and Humphrey on the other, while Fairway rubbed its surface with a yellow lump, his (Humphrey) face being damp and creased with the effort of the labour.

``Waxing a bed-tick, souls?'' (the newcomer)
said the newcomer.

``Yes, Sam,'' (Grandfer Cantle/Grandfer)
said Grandfer Cantle, as a man too busy to waste words.
``Shall I stretch this corner a shade tighter, Timothy?'' (unknown)

Fairway replied, and the waxing went on with unabated vigour. ```Tis going to be a good bed, by the look o't,'' continued Sam, after an interval of silence.

``Who may it be for?'' (the folks)

```Tis a present for the new folks that's going to set up housekeeping,'' said Christian, who stood helpless and overcome by the majesty of the proceedings.

``Ah, to be sure; and a valuable one, `a b'lieve.'' (unknown)

``Beds be dear to fokes that don't keep geese, bain't they, Mister Fairway?'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)
said Christian, as to an omniscient being.

``Yes,'' (Humphrey)
said the furze-dealer, standing up, giving his (Christian) forehead a thorough mopping, and handing the beeswax to Humphrey, who succeeded at the rubbing forthwith.
``Not that this couple be in want of one, but `twas well to show `em a bit of friendliness at this great racketing vagary of their lives. I set up both my own daughters in one when they was married, and there have been feathers enough for another in the house the last twelve months. Now then, neighbours, I think we have laid on enough wax. Grandfer Cantle, you turn the tick the right way outwards, and then I'll begin to shake in the feathers.'' (Christian/Christian Cantle)

When the bed was in proper trim Fairway and Christian brought forward vast paper bags, stuffed to the full, but light as balloons, and began to turn the contents of each into the receptacle just prepared. As bag after bag was emptied, airy tufts of down and feathers floated about the room in increasing quantity till, through a mishap of Christian's, who shook the contents of one bag outside the tick, the atmosphere of the room became dense with gigantic flakes, which descended upon the workers like a windless snowstorm.

``I never saw such a clumsy chap as you, Christian,'' (Grandfer Cantle/Grandfer)
said Grandfer Cantle severely.
``You might have been the son of a man that's never been outside Blooms-End in his (man) life for all the wit you have. Really all the soldiering and smartness in the world in the father seems to count for nothing in forming the nater of the son. As far as that chief Christian is concerned I might as well have stayed at home and seed nothing, like all the rest of ye here. Though, as far as myself is concerned, a dashing spirit has counted for sommat, to be sure!'' (unknown)

``Don't ye let me down so, Father; I feel no bigger than a ninepin after it. I've made but a bruckle hit, I'm afeard.'' (unknown)

``Come, come. Never pitch yerself in such a low key as that, Christian; you should try more,'' (unknown)
said Fairway.

``Yes, you should try more,'' (he)
echoed the Grandfer with insistence, as if he (Christian) had been the first to make the suggestion.
``In common conscience every man ought either to marry or go for a soldier. `Tis a scandal to the nation to do neither one nor t'other. I did both, thank God! Neither to raise men nor to lay `em low--that shows a poor do-nothing spirit indeed.'' (unknown)

``I never had the nerve to stand fire,'' (Christian)
faltered Christian.
``But as to marrying, I own I've asked here and there, though without much fruit from it. Yes, there's some house or other that might have had a man for a master--such as he (master) is--that's now ruled by a woman alone. Still it might have been awkward if I had found her (woman); for, d’ye see, neighbours, there'd have been nobody left at home to keep down Father's spirits to the decent pitch that becomes a old man.'' (unknown)

``And you've your work cut out to do that, my son,'' (Grandfer Cantle/Grandfer)
said Grandfer Cantle smartly.
``I wish that the dread of infirmities was not so strong in me!--I'd start the very first thing tomorrow to see the world over again! But seventy-one, though nothing at home, is a high figure for a rover... Ay, seventy-one, last Candlemasday. Gad, I'd sooner have it in guineas than in years!'' (the man)
And the old man sighed.

``Don't you be mournful, Grandfer,'' (unknown)
said Fairway.
``Empt some more feathers into the bed-tick, and keep up yer heart. Though rather lean in the stalks you be a green-leaved old man still. There's time enough left to ye yet to fill whole chronicles.'' (unknown)

``Begad, I'll go to `em, Timothy--to the married pair!'' (unknown)
said Granfer Cantle in an encouraged voice, and starting round briskly.
``I'll go to `em tonight and sing a wedding song, hey? `Tis like me to do so, you know; and they'd see it as such. My `Down in Cupid's Gardens' was well liked in four; still, I've got others as good, and even better. What do you say to my

She (you) cal'-led to' her (you) love' From the lat'-tice a-bove, `O come in' from the fog-gy fog'-gy dew'.'

`Twould please `em well at such a time! Really, now I come to think of it, I haven't turned my tongue in my head to the shape of a real good song since Old Midsummer night, when we had the `Barley Mow' at the Woman; and `tis a pity to neglect your strong point where there's few that have the compass for such things!'' (unknown)

``So `tis, so `tis,'' (unknown)
said Fairway.
``Now gie the bed a shake down. We've put in seventy pounds of best feathers, and I think that's as many as the tick will fairly hold. A bit and a drap wouldn't be amiss now, I reckon. Christian, maul down the victuals from corner-cupboard if canst reach, man, and I'll draw a drap o' sommat to wet it with.'' (the midst)

They sat down to a lunch in the midst of their work, feathers around, above, and below them; the original owners of which occasionally came to the open door and cackled begrudgingly at sight of such a quantity of their old clothes.

``Upon my soul I shall be chokt,'' (he)
