said Fairway when, having extracted a feather from his (Christian) mouth, he (Christian) found several others floating on the mug as it was handed round.

``I've swallered several; and one had a tolerable quill,'' (Sam)
said Sam placidly from the corner.

``Hullo--what's that--wheels I hear coming?'' (unknown)
Grandfer Cantle exclaimed, jumping up and hastening to the door.
``Why, `tis they back again--I didn't expect `em yet this half-hour. To be sure, how quick marrying can be done when you are in the mind for't!'' (unknown)

``O yes, it can soon be DONE,'' (He)
said Fairway, as if something should be added to make the statement complete.

He (Sam) arose and followed the Grandfer, and the rest also went to the door. In a moment an open fly was driven past, in which sat Venn and Mrs. Venn, Yeobright, and a grand relative of Venn's who had come from Budmouth for the occasion. The fly had been hired at the nearest town, regardless of distance and cost, there being nothing on Egdon Heath, in Venn's opinion, dignified enough for such an event when such a woman as Thomasin was the bride; and the church was too remote for a walking bridal-party.

As the fly passed the group which had run out from the homestead they shouted

``Hurrah!'' (unknown)
and waved their hands; feathers and down floating from their hair, their sleeves, and the folds of their garments at every motion, and Grandfer Cantle's seals dancing merrily in the sunlight as he (Heath) twirled himself about. The driver of the fly turned a supercilious gaze upon them; he (driver) even treated the wedded pair themselves with something like condescension; for in what other state than heathen could people, rich or poor, exist who were doomed to abide in such a world's end as Egdon? Thomasin showed no such superiority to the group at the door, fluttering her (Cantle) hand as quickly as a bird's wing towards them, and asking Diggory, with tears in her (Cantle) eyes, if they ought not to alight and speak to these kind neighbours. Venn, however, suggested that, as they were all coming to the house in the evening, this was hardly necessary.

After this excitement the saluting party returned to their occupation, and the stuffing and sewing were soon afterwards finished, when Fairway harnessed a horse, wrapped up the cumbrous present, and drove off with it in the cart to Venn's house at Stickleford.

Yeobright, having filled the office at the wedding service which naturally fell to his (Venn) hands, and afterwards returned to the house with the husband and wife, was indisposed to take part in the feasting and dancing that wound up the evening. Thomasin was disappointed.

``I wish I could be there without dashing your spirits,'' (he)
he (Venn) said.
``But I might be too much like the skull at the banquet.'' (unknown)

``No, no.'' (unknown)

``Well, dear, apart from that, if you would excuse me, I should be glad. I know it seems unkind; but, dear Thomasin, I fear I should not be happy in the company--there, that's the truth of it. I shall always be coming to see you at your new home, you know, so that my absence now will not matter.'' (unknown)

``Then I give in. Do whatever will be most comfortable to yourself.'' (he)

Clym retired to his (Venn) lodging at the housetop much relieved, and occupied himself during the afternoon in noting down the heads of a sermon, with which he (Venn) intended to initiate all that really seemed practicable of the scheme that had originally brought him (Venn) hither, and that he (Venn) had so long kept in view under various modifications, and through evil and good report. He (Venn) had tested and weighed his (Venn) convictions again and again, and saw no reason to alter them, though he (Venn) had considerably lessened his (Venn) plan. His (Venn) eyesight, by long humouring in his (Venn) native air, had grown stronger, but not sufficiently strong to warrant his (Venn) attempting his (Venn) extensive educational project. Yet he (Venn) did not repine--there was still more than enough of an unambitious sort to tax all his (Venn) energies and occupy all his (Venn) hours.

Evening drew on, and sounds of life and movement in the lower part of the domicile became more pronounced, the gate in the palings clicking incessantly. The party was to be an early one, and all the guests were assembled long before it was dark. Yeobright went down the back staircase and into the heath by another path than that in front, intending to walk in the open air till the party was over, when he (Venn) would return to wish Thomasin and her (Venn) husband good-bye as they departed. His (Venn) steps were insensibly bent towards Mistover by the path that he (Venn) had followed on that terrible morning when he (Venn) learnt the strange news from Susan's boy.

He (Venn) did not turn aside to the cottage, but pushed on to an eminence, whence he (Venn) could see over the whole quarter that had once been Eustacia's home. While he (Venn) stood observing the darkening scene somebody came up. Clym, seeing him (Venn) but dimly, would have let him (Venn) pass silently, had not the pedestrian, who was Charley, recognized the young man and spoken to him (Charley).

``Charley, I have not seen you for a length of time,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Yeobright.
``Do you often walk this way?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (the lad)
the lad replied.
``I don't often come outside the bank.'' (unknown)

``You were not at the Maypole.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Charley)
said Charley, in the same listless tone.
``I don't care for that sort of thing now.'' (unknown)

``You rather liked Miss Eustacia, didn't you?'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
Yeobright gently asked. Eustacia had frequently told him (Charley) of Charley's romantic attachment.

``Yes, very much. Ah, I wish--'' (unknown)

``Yes?'' (unknown)

``I wish, Mr. Yeobright, you could give me something to keep that once belonged to her (Eustacia)--if you don't mind.'' (unknown)

``I shall be very happy to. It will give me very great pleasure, Charley. Let me think what I have of hers that you would like. But come with me to the house, and I'll see.'' (unknown)

They walked towards Blooms-End together. When they reached the front it was dark, and the shutters were closed, so that nothing of the interior could be seen.

``Come round this way,'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``My entrance is at the back for the present.'' (he)

The two went round and ascended the crooked stair in darkness till Clym's sitting-room on the upper floor was reached, where he (Charley) lit a candle, Charley entering gently behind. Yeobright searched his (Charley) desk, and taking out a sheet of tissue-paper unfolded from it two or three undulating locks of raven hair, which fell over the paper like black streams. From these he (Charley) selected one, wrapped it up, and gave it to the lad, whose eyes had filled with tears. He (lad) kissed the packet, put it in his (lad) pocket, and said in a voice of emotion,

``O, Mr. Clym, how good you are to me!'' (He)

``I will go a little way with you,'' (unknown)
said Clym. And amid the noise of merriment from below they descended. Their path to the front led them close to a little side window, whence the rays of candles streamed across the shrubs. The window, being screened from general observation by the bushes, had been left unblinded, so that a person in this private nook could see all that was going on within the room which contained the wedding guests, except in so far as vision was hindered by the green antiquity of the panes.

``Charley, what are they doing?'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``My sight is weaker again tonight, and the glass of this window is not good.'' (Charley)

Charley wiped his (Charley) own eyes, which were rather blurred with moisture, and stepped closer to the casement.

``Mr. Venn is asking Christian Cantle to sing,'' (he)
he (Charley) replied,
``and Christian is moving about in his (Christian) chair as if he (Christian) were much frightened at the question, and his (Christian) father has struck up a stave instead of him (Christian).'' (he)

``Yes, I can hear the old man's voice,'' (unknown)
said Clym.
``So there's to be no dancing, I suppose. And is Thomasin in the room? I see something moving in front of the candles that resembles her (Christian) shape, I think.'' (unknown)

``Yes. She (Christian) do seem happy. She (Christian) is red in the face, and laughing at something Fairway has said to her (Christian). O my!'' (unknown)

``What noise was that?'' (unknown)
said Clym.

``Mr. Venn is so tall that he (Venn) knocked his (Venn) head against the beam in gieing a skip as he (Venn) passed under. Mrs. Venn has run up quite frightened and now she (Venn)'s put her (Venn) hand to his (Venn) head to feel if there's a lump. And now they be all laughing again as if nothing had happened.'' (unknown)

``Do any of them seem to care about my not being there?'' (unknown)
Clym asked.

``No, not a bit in the world. Now they are all holding up their glasses and drinking somebody's health.'' (unknown)

``I wonder if it is mine?'' (unknown)

``No, `tis Mr. and Mrs. Venn's, because he (Mr.) is making a hearty sort of speech. There--now Mrs. Venn has got up, and is going away to put on her (Venn) things, I think.'' (unknown)

``Well, they haven't concerned themselves about me, and it is quite right they should not. It is all as it should be, and Thomasin at least is happy. We will not stay any longer now, as they will soon be coming out to go home.'' (He)

He (Charley) accompanied the lad into the heath on his (Charley) way home, and, returning alone to the house a quarter of an hour later, found Venn and Thomasin ready to start, all the guests having departed in his (Venn) absence. The wedded pair took their seats in the four-wheeled dogcart which Venn's head milker and handy man had driven from Stickleford to fetch them in; little Eustacia and the nurse were packed securely upon the open flap behind; and the milker, on an ancient overstepping pony, whose shoes clashed like cymbals at every tread, rode in the rear, in the manner of a body-servant of the last century.

``Now we leave you in absolute possession of your own house again,'' (Thomasin/Yeobright/Thomasin Yeobright)
said Thomasin as she (nurse) bent down to wish her (nurse) cousin good night.
``It will be rather lonely for you, Clym, after the hubbub we have been making.'' (unknown)

``O, that's no inconvenience,'' (unknown)
said Clym, smiling rather sadly. And then the party drove off and vanished in the night shades, and Yeobright entered the house. The ticking of the clock was the only sound that greeted him (cousin), for not a soul remained; Christian, who acted as cook, valet, and gardener to Clym, sleeping at his (gardener) father's house. Yeobright sat down in one of the vacant chairs, and remained in thought a long time. His (gardener) mother's old chair was opposite; it had been sat in that evening by those who had scarcely remembered that it ever was hers. But to Clym she (mother) was almost a presence there, now as always. Whatever she (mother) was in other people's memories, in his (gardener) she (mother) was the sublime saint whose radiance even his (gardener) tenderness for Eustacia could not obscure. But his (gardener) heart was heavy, that Mother had NOT crowned him (gardener) in the day of his (gardener) espousals and in the day of the gladness of his (gardener) heart. And events had borne out the accuracy of her (Mother) judgment, and proved the devotedness of her (Mother) care. He (gardener) should have heeded her (Mother) for Eustacia's sake even more than for his (gardener) own.
``It was all my fault,'' (he)
he (gardener) whispered.
``O, my mother, my mother! would to God that I could live my life again, and endure for you what you endured for me!'' (unknown)

On the Sunday after this wedding an unusual sight was to be seen on Rainbarrow. From a distance there simply appeared to be a motionless figure standing on the top of the tumulus, just as Eustacia had stood on that lonely summit some two years and a half before. But now it was fine warm weather, with only a summer breeze blowing, and early afternoon instead of dull twilight. Those who ascended to the immediate neighbourhood of the Barrow perceived that the erect form in the centre, piercing the sky, was not really alone. Round him (Eustacia) upon the slopes of the Barrow a number of heathmen and women were reclining or sitting at their ease. They listened to the words of the man in their midst, who was preaching, while they abstractedly pulled heather, stripped ferns, or tossed pebbles down the slope. This was the first of a series of moral lectures or Sermons on the Mount, which were to be delivered from the same place every Sunday afternoon as long as the fine weather lasted.

The commanding elevation of Rainbarrow had been chosen for two reasons: first, that it occupied a central position among the remote cottages around; secondly, that the preacher thereon could be seen from all adjacent points as soon as he (preacher) arrived at his (preacher) post, the view of him (preacher) being thus a convenient signal to those stragglers who wished to draw near. The speaker was bareheaded, and the breeze at each waft gently lifted and lowered his (speaker) hair, somewhat too thin for a man of his (speaker) years, these still numbering less than thirty-three. He (speaker) wore a shade over his (speaker) eyes, and his (speaker) face was pensive and lined; but, though these bodily features were marked with decay there was no defect in the tones of his (speaker) voice, which were rich, musical, and stirring. He (speaker) stated that his (speaker) discourses to people were to be sometimes secular, and sometimes religious, but never dogmatic; and that his (speaker) texts would be taken from all kinds of books. This afternoon the words were as follows:--

```And the king rose up to meet her (speaker), and bowed himself unto her (speaker), and sat down on his (king) throne, and caused a seat to be set for the king's mother; and she (mother) sat on his (king) right hand. Then she (mother) said, I desire one small petition of thee; I pray thee say me not nay. And the king said unto her (mother), Ask, on, my mother: for I will not say thee nay.'''

Yeobright had, in fact, found his (king) vocation in the career of an itinerant open-air preacher and lecturer on morally unimpeachable subjects; and from this day he (king) laboured incessantly in that office, speaking not only in simple language on Rainbarrow and in the hamlets round, but in a more cultivated strain elsewhere--from the steps and porticoes of town halls, from market-crosses, from conduits, on esplanades and on wharves, from the parapets of bridges, in barns and outhouses, and all other such places in the neighbouring Wessex towns and villages. He (king) left alone creeds and systems of philosophy, finding enough and more than enough to occupy his (king) tongue in the opinions and actions common to all good men. Some believed him (king), and some believed not; some said that his (king) words were commonplace, others complained of his (king) want of theological doctrine; while others again remarked that it was well enough for a man to take to preaching who could not see to do anything else. But everywhere he (man) was kindly received, for the story of his (man) life had become generally known.
